“Look at the family in the management of the group. It’s only male members. It is not that we (women) do not have expertise in running a company. Just that we have not been given a chance in the affairs of the business of the group,” she said.

She is a nuclear scientist, and her sister Vellachi has been working with tech companies for the past 10 years.

“At this stage, we are one of the largest shareholder blocks and we have no visibility nor have a fair representation.”

Murugappa Group did not wish to comment as it was a matter in the affairs of a privately held holding company and not the business ventures.

While Arunachalam said that she will wait to hear from the family, she also warned, “we do have to look at other options” as the family has “parked their responsibility”.

She said for any settlement, there has to be an intent.

“We have an intent to settle this. The other side must also have the intent and call for a focused discussion on the subject. There are many innovative ways to do a settlement. All we want is intent,” she said.

Murugappa Group runs 28 businesses across financial services ( Cholamandalam ), engineering ( Tube Investments ), fertilisers (Coromandel) and sugar (EID Parry), among others, and earns nearly Rs 37,000 crore in annual revenues with more than 50,000 employees.

Title: Truck rentals: Truck rentals firm up due to fuel price fears
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

File photo

CHENNAI: The US-Iran conflict and its resultant impact on oil prices is also casting a shadow on India’s auto and transportation sector.

As crude firms up, truck rentals , which were down more than 20% all through calendar 2019, have suddenly started firming up, says Indian Foundation for Transport Research & Training (IFTRT).

Auto bosses however say that oil price hikes in the past have not had a very significant impact on car and SUV sales.

“High fuel prices do affect sales but the bigger impact is on usage as people drive their vehicle less. Oil has in the past been as high as $100 per barrel and even then vehicle sales have been good,” said RC Bhargava, chairman, Maruti Suzuki .

Adding that, “Marginal customers may wonder whether they can afford to run the car but the bulk of vehicle buyers are not in that category”.

The bigger impact has been on transportation. “Truck rentals are already up in the January 1-6 period. Rental trends are up 3%-4% on trunk routes after being low 2%- 2.5% during December ‘19,” he added.

The rise would have been sharper, had the economy been in top gear.

The combination of rising fuel prices and rupee depreciation “could further impact consumer spending,” said SP Singh, senior fellow & coordinator, IFTRT.

Since November-December 2018, fleet utilisation for the full calendar year 2019 had dropped by over 30% on a national average.

“Key trunk routes like Delhi-Mumbai-Delhi were down -20%,” said Singh.The current firming up of rentals is entire driven by fuel prices, he added.

Title: Bihar: Fearing for lives, many JNU students head home
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Students stage a protest at main Gate of JNU over Sunday's violence, in New Delhi (File photo)

PATNA: Following the violent attack at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi, many students, who hail from Bihar , are reportedly leaving the campus with packed bags and heading home. Their parents, they say, have called them back immediately, fearing recurrence of similar incidents in future.

Some students, who are still in a state of shock, talked to this newspaper over phone from Delhi on Monday and recounted their experiences at the university. Gopalganj resident Atique Quasmi, who is pursuing MPhil at JNU, was on the campus when students and faculty members were assaulted by a group of masked men on Sunday.

Atique said, “I was not hurt, but many of my friends were brutally beaten up. My parents have been calling me up and asking me to go back home because they are concerned about my safety.”

Another JNUite, Ravi Pandey from Nawada, who is studying international relations, claimed, “I am scared because this is for the first time that I have witnessed so much violence. My parents are equally terrified and want me to return home.”

Many, who could not return home, shifted to safer places on Monday. JNU student Yash Sharma, also a native of Bihar, was so frightened that he left the campus and went to Noida. He said, “My parents, who live in Patna, told me to move to my uncle’s house this morning.”

Ex-students also shared their views on the violent attack at JNU. Chandrakanta Khan, a Patna-based social activist and alumna of JNU (1988 batch), rued, “Whatever happened at JNU was extremely unfortunate. Being a former student of the institution, I am absolutely devastated. It is unacceptable.”

Another alumnus, Sandeep Kumar (2014 batch) from Madhubani, condemned the violence. “I have many friends, who are still studying at JNU. I am worried for them. This should not have happened,” he said.

Title: Civic body to renovate Phalke memorial on its own
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to renovate the Dadasaheb Phalke Memorial Park on its own and outsource its maintenance to a private agency, following poor response to the tender it had floated for renovation.

The civic body has roped in a consultancy firm to chalk out a detailed plan for the renovation project, the cost of which was estimated at around Rs 5 crore, which was to be borne by the private agency concerned.

The tender had been floated to develop the memorial on design, build, finance, operate and transfer (DBFOT) basis under public private partnership (PPP).

“A higher investment cost was the major hurdle behind the poor response to the tender we had floated. Hence, the decision to develop the park on its own. The NMC will spend all the necessary amount. The maintenance work will be outsourced,” said civic officials on Monday.

Meanwhile, the contract for maintaining the park has already ended with the private agency, following which it was extended by a month to January 31.

Spread across 29 acres of land, the memorial park displays the works of the late Dadasaheb Phalke and has a beautiful garden in its courtyard.

It is in the surroundings of the majestic Pandava caves (Pandavleni Caves). The area houses lawns, musical fountains and museums that display the Phalke’s works. It is also adjacent to Buddha Memorial Park, which is spread on 11 acres.

The NMC intends to develop the entire complex spread on 40 acres of the park to its full potential and thereby convert it to a tourism hub in Nashik.

The civic body wants to introduce leisure and entertainment facilities, green zone, garden and bird park for tourists at the site through on PPP basis.

Title: Retail investors should avoid kneejerk reaction: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Mumbai: Small and retail investors should not panic and take a hasty decision with their money and other investments in the current volatile market, brokers and investment advisers have said. They add that it’s the geopolitical situation in the Middle East which is leading to jitters in global markets. While it is also impacting India, the domestic market is likely to be less affected than those that are more closely linked to the stand-off between the US and Iran.

“For retail investors, the safest thing now is not to do anything in this volatile situation,” said KR Choksey Investment Managers MD Deven Choksey. “Allow some clarity to emerge...it’s always better to operate when there’s clarity about the investment environment,” he added. Choksey believes that since Iran is already under economic and trade sanctions imposed by the US, not much of its oil is coming into the global market.

However, what could change this situation is if Iran blocks the Strait of Hormuz — one of the world’s most important sea passages through which about a fourth of global crude is shipped, said another broker.

Investment advisers too believe that it’s difficult to pinpoint for how long the current geopolitical tensions could continue and how it could end.

“The main factor that is currently pulling the Indian market down has its origin outside the country. So it’s difficult to predict when it could end and how,” said Arun Kejriwal, director of investment advisory firm KRIS. Kejriwal also believes that once the current volatility subsides, small and midcap stocks, which witnessed lacklustre trades during the past several months, could be the sectors to watch out for.

Brokers also believe that foreign portfolio investors (FPIs), who pumped over $14 billion into Indian stocks in 2019 and nearly $20 billion across all assets classes — including debt and hybrid instruments — may not be in a hurry to take money out of the country. However, among the various types of foreign investors, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are expected to be the first to sell in a major way in case the slide continues for some more time. On Monday, the sensex and Nifty both lost nearly 2% each.

Investment advisers also said that in case an investor has extra cash to invest, he should put the same either in savings bank account, short-term FDs or liquid funds. They also said that if an investor already has a financial plan in place and has been investing according to that to reach life’s financial goals, investments under such plans should not be stopped or changed just because the market has turned volatile.

Title: Now fish water to be used to draw leopards near cages
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Surat: In an unconventional approach to keep a leopard away, the forest department has been advising villagers to sing loudly while crossing fields alone. Now in yet another strange method, the forest officials are trying to draw leopards close to the cages by sprinkling water used to wash fish near the cages. After leopards killed two children and injured one in Surat and Bharuch, attempts are being made to trap it at the earliest before it can target any other human.

“We are sprinkling water in which fish, especially bumla or Bombay duck, was kept and cleaned. The water with strong smell of fish is being sprinkled around the cage and the track of leopard to bring the wild cat close to the cage and trap it,” said Puneet Nayyar, deputy conservator of forest, Surat.

The forest department normally keeps bait of chicken or goat in cages to attract the leopards. However, for a stronger smell in current situation, the forest officials are now using the water in which fish is kept for better results.

The forest department has placed 13 cages in Mandvi around Patal village and nearby locations to trap the leopard that killed the four-year-old daughter of a sugarcane harvesting labourer on January 2. They have installed 12 night vision cameras as well at strategic locations to capture the leopard’s movements.

Meanwhile, the forest department has started an awareness campaign and trained 25 leopard ambassadors in rural areas of Surat to prevent human-animal conflict. As part of the drive, villagers are being educated to avoid going alone in fields, and if they are going, they are asked to sing loudly to keep the big cats away. The villagers are also advised against going in open to answer nature’s call and keep precautions while harvesting sugarcane.

“Along with efforts to cage the leopards, we are also trying that the sugarcane harvesting labourers are shifted to safer locations. We held a meeting in the leadership of the district collector with the officials of sugar factories on Monday in which the workers were instructed to ensure that the labourers were provided shelter near village and not in farms,” Nayyar told TOI.

NO TOP HONCHOS OF SUGAR FACTORIES ATTEND MEETING

Despite the deaths of two children of sugarcane harvesting labourers and injury to one, no top officials of sugar factories attended the meeting with district collector Dhaval Patel on Monday. The officials of sugar factories from Madhi, Sayan, Mahuva, Kantha Vibhag, Kamrej and Chalthan remained present. However, no chairman or managing director of these sugar factories attended the meeting. Yet, the forest officials claimed that the factories had sent their officers from the operations department and they were likely to take some steps.

Title: Shivalik first co-op to get small bank licence
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Mumbai: Shivalik Mercantile Co-operative Bank has become the first in the sector to get permission from the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) to convert into a small finance bank (SFB). The Saharanpur-headquartered Shivalik MCB is a multi-state co-operative lender with presence in Uttar Pradesh, Delhi, Madhya Pradesh and Uttarakhand. The bank had deposits of Rs 1,051 crore and advances of Rs 715 crore as of end-March 2019.

Meanwhile, the RBI also decided to rationalise the supervisory action framework (SAF) to make it more effective in bringing about the desired improvement in urban co-operative banks (UCBs) as also expeditious resolution of UCBs experiencing financial stress. The RBI will continue to monitor asset quality, profitability and capital/net worth of UCBs under the revised SAF.

Co-operatives are governed under state laws as well as by RBI norms. They are owned by the customers and have restrictions on their activities. SFBs are like corporate entities limited by shares. They have much more flexibility in raising finances from the banking system. They are a new category of commercial banks that have been created to cater to small borrowers. Initially, only microfinance companies could convert into SFBs. However, in December 2019, the RBI came out with guidelines allowing co-operatives also to convert.

In a statement issued here, the RBI said that the permission has been granted under the ‘Scheme on voluntary transition of urban co-operative bank into a small finance bank’ issued on September 27, 2018. “The ‘in-principle’ approval granted will be valid for 18 months to enable the applicant to comply with the requirements under the scheme and fulfil other conditions as stipulated by the RBI. On being satisfied that the applicant has complied with the requisite conditions laid down by it as part of ‘in-principle’ approval, the RBI would consider granting it a licence for commencement of banking business under Section 22 (1) of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 as an SFB,” the RBI said.

The RBI had decided to allow co-operatives to convert into SFBs in pursuance of the recommendations of a high-powered committee on UCBs chaired by R Gandhi in 2015. Until now, DCB Bank (erstwhile Development Credit Co-operative Bank) was the only co-operative lender to convert into a commercial bank and receive a new private bank licence in 1995.

Other lenders like Saraswat Co-operative Bank had shown an interest into transitioning into commercial banks. However, the RBI has decided to allow conversions only into SFBs, which cannot give loans to corporates.

Title: JNU attack: Diaspora raises protest pitch
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The gathering on the steps of SOAS on Monday

KOLKATA: Soon after the images of the masked mob attack in JNU on Sunday evening went viral, students from SOAS University of London’s India Society decided to raise their voice in protest. A decision was taken to call all students and academics to the SOAS Steps on Monday morning to protest against the “brutality and violence” — a gathering that was attended by 50-60 people.

Social media was quick to spread the word. Adrija, a post- doctoral research fellow at SOAS, and a part of SOAS India Society, told TOI that for two-and-a-half years now, the group has been organizing protests “against the current regime”. “Our aim has been to build a platform of critique of what is happening in India now,” she said.

A few weeks ago, the society had organized a protest march outside the India House after CAB was passed. The aim of Monday’s protest, however, was not only to condemn the attack in JNU.

“Of course, we strongly stand against that. But the JNU incident didn’t happen in isolation. It is a product of years of hate that has been propagated by this current regime. We stand against this right-wing fascism, culture of hate and CAA-NRC,” Adrija added.

Kalpana Wilson, who teaches at Birkbeck, University of London and is a member of South Asia Solidarity Group, has signed a letter expressing solidarity with JNU students. She felt it was crucial that academics and students all over the world make their voices heard against what she called a “horrific premeditated attack by far-right thugs who had the backing of the administration and police”.

“After the brutal police violence against students in Jamia Millia Islamia and Aligarh Muslim University, this is another attempt to silence students exercising basic democratic rights to dissent by the Modi-Shah fascist regime. But we can see from the wave of solidarity protests against CAA-NRC, and now against these attacks, that Modi is getting completely exposed internationally and in the diaspora,” added Wilson, whose research pertains to India.

Even Bangladeshis based in London joined the protests. London-based architect and artist Sofia Karim rescheduled a meeting to be at the SOAS steps on Monday.

Speaking to TOI, Karim said that as a British-Bangladeshi Muslim, she is alarmed by the nightmare unfolding in India, the country of her parents’ birth. “This is not just an India issue. This affects the whole of South Asia, in particular my motherland, Bangladesh, and indeed the world. The world’s largest secular democracy has steadily turned into a fascist, Hindu fundamentalist state, with relative ease. That is ominous and should be a lesson for the world,” she said.

Title: Bodh Gaya: Dalai Lama’s five-day-long teaching schedule ends
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Dalai Lama

GAYA: The five-day-long teaching schedule of Buddhist spiritual leader His holiness the Dalai Lama ended on Monday. The programme began on January 2 with his teachings to his followers on how to develop virtues of compassion and renunciation of worldly pleasures and exchange of own happiness with other people’s pain among others.

Several thousand followers of the Dalai Lama from different countries of the world, including USA, UK, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Japan, Korea and Taiwan among others participated in the programme. Hollywood actor Richard Gere, a prominent follower of the Buddhist spiritual leader, especially flew in to participate on all the five days of the special teaching programme.

Besides giving tips on acquisition of wisdom and futility of worldly possessions, the Dalai Lama also introduced the initiation protocol and completed the wheel of teachings of Manjushri , the gentle glory associated with the path of wisdom. On the final day of the programme, longevity pills- a sacred eatable was distributed among the participants. Monks holding the longevity pill in bamboo baskets moved among the participants distributing the pill believed to give more years to the recipient’s life. The devotees also prayed for the spiritual leader’s long life and good health. A few years ago, the spiritual leader had to abandon the Kalchakra Puja mid way on account of health issues.

Earlier, on November 10 last year, the 84-year-old Dalai Lama had said that he had a dream about his life extending to 113 years.

Besides the followers from across the world, several high-ranking Tibetan monks and senior officials of the Tibetan administration in exile participated in the programme, which was broadcast live on FM in different languages including Hindi and Tibetan. Each teaching session lasted about 90 minutes.

According to sources, chief minister Nitish Kumar may shortly visit Bodh Gaya to meet the Dalai Lama. For the last many years, the CM makes it a point to meet the Dalai Lama whenever the spiritual leader is in Bodh Gaya. On his part, Dalai Lama has been profusely praising the CM and lauding the prohibition policy of his government.

Before his proposed departure on January 17, Dalai Lama is scheduled to visit IIM Bodh Gaya on January 14.

Title: Tata-Mistry case: NCLAT rejects plea by RoC-Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Cyrus Mistry (File photo)

MUMBAI: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) on Monday dismissed the application of the Registrar of Companies (RoC)-Mumbai that had sought the removal of certain observations from the December 18, 2019 judgment in the Cyrus Mistry vs Ratan Tata matter.

It also refused to amend its judgment because of the “absence of any factual or legal error apparent on the body of it”. The NCLAT said the RoC-Mumbai had a wrong perception as no observation was made against it. The judgment “does not cast any aspersions on RoC-Mumbai,” the NCLAT said in its 20-page order on Monday.

RoC-Mumbai had filed the application as it found certain strictures passed by the NCLAT in the December 18 judgment, against its statutory actions, were unwarranted and against the principles of natural justice, which require that the concerned party be given an opportunity of being heard before a judgment is passed against it. The December 18 judgment stated that the conversion of Tata Sons from a deemed public limited to a private company was done in a hurried manner with the help of RoC-Mumbai and that the action of RoC-Mumbai was illegal. RoC-Mumbai wanted “with the help of RoC-Mumbai” and “illegal” to be deleted from the 172-page judgment.

The NCLAT, however, clarified that hurry in the judgment was referred to be on the part of Tata Sons and its board of directors to change its status and “nothing has been alleged against RoC-Mumbai”. It added that it is its finding in the judgment that the action taken by the RoC-Mumbai was “prejudicial“ and “oppressive” to the minority shareholders of Tata Sons, specifically to Cyrus Mistry and his family; and “no specific malafide action has been alleged against RoC-Mumbai”.

Monday’s order was pronounced by Justice S J Mukhopadhyay and Justice Bansi Lal Bhat.

Title: Mukhtar Ansari’s recommendation got criminal an arms licence
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Mukhtar Ansari

VARANASI: A criminal gunned down by Ghazipur police in an encounter over a decade ago had procured arms licence in 2001 on the recommendation of jailed mafia-turned-politician and legislator Mukhtar Ansari .

The matter came to light during arms licence verification across Mau district ahead of Ghosi assembly by-poll in October 2019 after which Mau SP Anurag Arya ordered a probe under an additional superintendent of police.

After investigation revealed that four persons, including the criminal killed in encounter, procured arms licences in 2001 on the recommendation of Ansari, an FIR was lodged against six persons on Sunday night.

Besides Ansari, the other accused named in the FIR include then station officer, Dakshintola, JK Singh, then lekhpal Israel Ansari, Anwar, Shahzad and Salim. They were booked under sections 419 (cheating by impersonation), 420 (cheating and dishonesty), 467, 468 (forgery), 471 (using as genuine a forged document), 120B (criminal conspiracy) of IPC and the Arms Act.

Talking to TOI, SP Anurag Arya said: “Arms licence verification was initiated across Mau district ahead of Ghosi assembly by-poll in October 2019 in which four licence-holders, identified as Anwar, Salim, Shahzad and Mohd Shah Alam, were found missing.”

They had applied for arms licences for double-barrel guns in 2001 for which Mukhtar Ansari, in capacity of Mau MLA, wrote to then district magistrate on his letter pad asking him to issue licences to applicants.

The investigation also exposed the role of then station officer and lekhpal, JK Singh and Israel, who showed fake addresses of four applicants as verified.

While tracing the whereabouts of licence-holders, the investigator found that one of them, Mohd Shah Alam, was killed in a police encounter in Ghazipur between 2005 and 2010.

“Specific details of Alam’s killing in police encounter has been sought from Ghazipur police. The other three, who did not turn up to surrender their arms despite DM’s order, are untraceable. Efforts are on to trace them,” the SP said.

Mukhtar is in jail since 2006. His son Abbas Ansari was also booked in a case of cheating and contravention of gun licence at Lucknow’s Mahanagar police station on October 13, 2019. On October 17, police had seized six weapons and 4,431 cartridges from Abbas’s residence in Delhi.

Title: ‘Roko Toko’ campaign across Bihar to tame criminals: DGP
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Gupteshwar Pandey

PATNA: Jubilant over its success in Bhagalpur district, the state police headquarters has decided to implement the ‘ Roko Toko ’ (stop and find out) campaign across the state.

Under the campaign, police personnel on the night patrolling intercept the passersby and those travelling either in cars or riding motorbikes in the localities considered vulnerable from security point of view and carry out searches accordingly. Each team is headed by a senior police officer, who is assigned to send the report of the operation on WhatApp group of the district police.

DGP Gupteshwar Pandey said the ‘Roko Toko’ campaign would be implemented in other districts as well. “Such deterrent action is necessary to check the incidents of crime in the state during night hours,” he said, adding, “it would send a message to the people that police are alert round the clock.”

The campaign was launched in Bhagalpur on an experimental basis and turned out to be a success story with the arrest of over 300 antisocials, including a few notorious criminals, and seizure of one dozen illegal weapons in the last two weeks alone. Besides, several major incidents of crime were foiled by the police.

Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti said on Monday that the campaign, which was launched on December 25 last, yielded desired results. “The presence of police not only works as a deterrent to crime but also instils a sense of security among the law-abiding people,” he said. The SSP said a notorious gangster, Suraj Tanti, was nabbed during the campaign. He was evading arrest in several cases of murder, loot, extortion and dacoity in different parts of the district. “The list of the wanted criminals arrested during the night vigil as part of the ‘Roko Toko’ campaign is long,” he added.

According to the SSP, the district headquarters town recorded only three major incidents of crime in December. The crime graph, which usually increases during winter as most people prefer to remain indoors during night, has maintained a downward trend in the district, Bharti said.

Among the arrested were also those who were found violating the Prohibition and Excise Act 2016. “The team is equipped with breathalysers to conduct medical test of the alcoholics on the spot,” the SSP said.

The Bhagalpur police, in fact, had started the exercise in November 2018 when SM Khopde, now ADG (operation), was zonal IG of Bhagalpur. However, the campaign did not have tangible results in Bhagalpur town.

Under the campaign, the city SPs or the DSPs are assigned to monitor the campaign on rotational basis. “The follow-up action is more helpful in reining in the lawbreakers. Simultaneous raids are conducted to arrest those who managed either to give the police a slip or evaded arrest for long in criminal cases,” a senior police officer said.

Title: Kolkata: Steep-fine rule sees biker shelling out Rs 6,700
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The traffic police have decided to slap compound fines or tow away vehicles belonging to all those caught flouting traffic rules during office hours. The focus will be on bikes and buses in an effort to cut down on accidents between 8am and 11am and between 6pm and 9pm. Lalbazar has prepared an exhaustive list of the enhanced fines and the specific sections under which they can be implemented.The sergeants are usually held up in ensuring smooth traffic flow during office hours and can’t keep a close watch on rule-breakers. Compounding of cases will not only increase the fine amount but also make sure that the violations get logged on to the master sheet maintained by the cops.“The traffic police have been instructed to pump up the fines through compound challans. On Sunday evening, for example, a biker at Jadavpur was issued a challan Rs 6,700 for violating several laws at the same time — not carrying licence, damaged number plate and riding with a pillion rider very dangerously. Another biker, in the Jorabagan-Shyampukur area, was fined Rs 5,200. Vehicles are being seized as part of a special drive to ensure there is a total stop to reckless riding and driving. The aim now is to bring down accidents during office hours when cops usually refrain from campaigns. Special teams have been formed, which are carrying out checks without holding up traffic,” said an officer.“There was a tendency to break speed limits due to the comparatively lower number of vehicles on the roads on Sunday. By 2pm, each traffic guard recorded at least two compounded prosecutions — slapping of more than one Motor Vehicles (MV) Act sections and increasing the fine amount. The focus is on high-speed corridors, like EM Bypass, the Bypass connectors and Harish Mukherjee Road,” said another officer.“Each traffic guard has been asked to identify stretches which witness maximum rule violations,” said an officer.The task, claimed cops, will be to discipline bikers and bus drivers in the first two weeks.The police also said they are using social media platforms, like Twitter and Facebook, to make people aware that they are under watch on the roads via sergeant cameras and CCTV cameras.

Title: Muslims in Bihar lead peaceful life: Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sushil Kumar Modi

GAYA: Deputy chief minister Sushil Kumar Modi said on Monday that Muslims in the state need not worry as they are living in absolute peace.

Addressing about 500 BJP activists on the IMA premises in Gaya , SuMo said that no incidence of victimisation of Muslims has taken place in the state. “Congress and the Leftists are creating an atmosphere of fear among minorities for their own political gains,” he said.

The deputy CM was in Gaya to spread awareness among BJP functionaries and workers on issues like Citizenship (Amendment) Act, National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). The party workers and functionaries, in turn, have been asked to launch a campaign for creating awareness on the issue and remove the doubts of the people, particularly minorities.

Reiterating the party line that CAA was about giving and not taking away citizenship, SuMo said that persecuted minorities from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan , most of them belonging to the underprivileged sections, would benefit from the provisions of the CAA, which, in any case would not put any additional economic burden on the country.

“These people are already living in the country and citizen status would make them entitled to welfare schemes of the government, including education and poverty alleviation measures,” SuMo said.

He regretted that despite PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah making it clear many a time that CAA and NRC were altogether different and no discussion on NRC has taken place at any level in the government and yet canards were being spread to keep a section of the population in perpetual fear. “It is time such elements are exposed,” he said.

About NPR, the deputy CM said it is purely an economic exercise introduced by former PM Manmohan Singh with the object of creating a comprehensive and credible database for the purpose of economic planning in the country and it has nothing to do with politics.

“The NPR proforma was developed in the Congress regime and the previous proforma has only been updated to include items like use of internet among others. The last proforma did not seek information about the use of internet. Moreover, no documentary proof would be needed and information provided by the people would be accepted at face value with no questions asked,” he said.

Later talking to mediapersons in Gaya circuit house, SuMo said that UP CM Yogi Adityanath would be visiting Gaya on January 14 to explain the party’s stand on issues like CAA, NPR and NRC. “The UP CM would be addressing a public meeting in Gandhi Maidan in Gaya to clear doubts and misinformation on the issue,” he said.

Title: Pro-CAA campaign in Bettiah turns unruly
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BJP’s ‘Jan Jagran’ campaign in support of the CAA pushed Bettiah to the edge on Sunday

BETTIAH: BJP’s ‘Jan Jagran’ campaign in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) pushed Bettiah to the edge on Sunday as hordes of youth ran amok with provocative sloganeering in fast moving motorcycle rallies and foot marches through the town square in Lal Bazar and alleys crisscrossing the heart of town.

The bikers and foot soldiers were also seen carrying abusive placards and banners as the national tricolour was dwarfed in the swathe of saffron flags. A skirmish was contained from conflagrating within moments near the Jangi Masjid with the DM Nilesh Ramchandra Deore and SP Nitasha Gudiya rushing to the spot.

At the modest Maharaja Library ground, BJP state president Sanjay Jaiswal, who is also the local MP, led a chain of party leaders including state health minister Mangal Pandey with speeches supporting the CAA. The health minister diagnosed ‘stomach-ache’ in the Congress over the CAA. He said earlier Congress governments too had granted citizenship to persecuted refugees from neighbouring countries but now when the Modi government has brought in the Act, the Congress has been afflicted with ‘paet me dard’.

Meanwhile, a different ache was palpable in town as the foul-mouthing bikers and foot marchers, carrying flags and sticks spread fear among the section of society they trained their exuberant tongue-lashing on.

“Their slogans were abusive...some youths protested...they pushed an old man into the drain...a skirmish resulted. Fortunately the DM and SP came here within minutes,” Maulana Nazimuddin Ahmad Khan, Imam of the Jangi Masjid, said.

At the Madarsa Islamia adjoining the Badi Masjid, about a dozen women were seen getting their names verified in the voters list even as small boys chanted their readings in unison. “No, this has nothing to do with NPR or CAA...That we will not agree to,” Nessar Ahmed Quasmi, Qazi Shariat with the Imarat-e-Sharia, said.

Away from the Qazi’s apprehensions, BJP state chief Jaiswal was trying to allay fears at the Library ground: “We need to dispel the rumour mongering. The minorities are being misled,” he said, asserting, “Nobody’s citizenship will be taken away. But we will not allow citizenship to ‘ghoospaithiya’ (intruders) at any cost.”

An unruly mob that included boys as young as eight to ten years brandished sticks and struck at closed shop hoardings around Meena Bazar despite the heavy police bandobast. The cops responded with a mild lathi charge in the Raj Deorhi.

Title: KVB MD and CEO PR Seshadri resigns
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Chennai: Karur Vysya Bank’s managing director (MD) and chief executive officer (CEO) PR Seshadri resigns citing personal reasons. He will be relieved on March 31, 2020 as per his request.

Seshadri cut short his tenure with the Karur-based bank by five months said, “My contract with the bank expires on September 3, 2020. My resignation is a thought through decision and there is nothing to be read other than the reason cited on the bank’s statement.”

On help with choosing his successor he said, “The turn of events (my exit) is very recent, so the board will start the process of finding my replacement. My role in finding a replacement is going to be very limited.”

In August, 2017, the bank’s board co-opted Seshadri as additional director and appointed him as managing director and chief executive officer for a period of 3 years.

On his next plans after his departure with the bank, “I intend to finish my term and take a short break to think and decide my next steps.,” he added.

Seshadri started his banking career with Citigroup in 1992, before taking over charge as MD and CEO of Karur Vysya Bank in 2017.

Title: Rajiv case: HC grants 15 days leave to convict Ravichandran
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Ravichandran, a life convict in the former Prime Minister (PM) Rajiv Gandhi assassination case, has been granted 15 days ordinary leave by the Madras high court from January 10. P Rajeswari of Aruppukottai taluk in Virudhunagar district, mother of Ravinchandran in her petition had stated that her son, who was awarded life sentence in the case had completed nearly 28 years of imprisonment.

Though she had submitted several representations and moved the high court seeking leave for her son, it was not granted. Recently, she moved the high court, which on October 15, directed the state to consider her representation within three weeks. Subsequently, the superintendent of Madurai Central Prison passed an order on November 13 rejecting her claim on the ground that Virudhunagar superintendent of police had submitted a report stating that there was a possibility of life threat to her son and it would not be possible for the police to provide escort as police selection process and local body elections were to be announced. Hence, Rajeswari moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to grant one-month ordinary leave to Ravichandran to enable him settle the family after his release.

When the petition was taken up for hearing on Monday, the petitioner’s counsel submitted that recently ordinary leave was also granted to few other convicts in the case including Nalini Sriharan, Perarivalan and the same could also be extended to Ravichandran.

The additional advocate general K Chellapandian submitted that since more than 20 police officials are required for the convict’s escort and the same would not be possible due to the intervening local body elections, the representation seeking ordinary leave was rejected. He further submitted that the state would consider the ordinary leave plea after Pongal festival.

Taking note of the submissions, a division bench of justice T Raja and justice B Pugalendhi observed that the convict had been earlier granted ordinary leave five times since 2001 - four times based on the order of the high court and once based on the order of the prison authorities to attend the final rites of his father.

The judges observed that on all five occasions when ordinary leave was granted, the life convict had surrendered before prison authorities without causing any inconvenience. They further observed that the state in its counter had mentioned that his leave application had been rejected due to local body elections and it would not be able to provide sufficient protection for the convict.

The judges observed that even though the local body elections were completed, the government’s contention that it would consider the ordinary leave plea after Pongal festival is not acceptable. Hence, the judges granted 15 days leave to Ravichandran and observed, “Let him spend time with his family on this Pongal.” The judges directed him to surrender before the prison authorities after the completion of 15 days ordinary leave. The matter has been posted to January 28 for reporting compliance.

Title: Dairy firm employee robbed of Rs 2.5 lakh in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a daring act, two motorbike-borne youths looted Rs2.5 lakh from an agent of Barauni dairy on the busy Annie Besant Road under Pirbahore police station area in the state capital on Monday. It was the fourth case of loot in Patna district in the last 48 hours.

Police said two youths riding a motorbike intercepted one Abhishek Kumar on the Annie Besant Road around 1.30pm and looted a bag containing the cash from him at pistol point. The robbers, who had covered their faces with mufflers, also fired a shot in the air to terrorize the local businessmen and the passersby.

The criminals, who were in the age group of 20-25 years, however, fled the spot, leaving the victim in a state of shock. Police said Abhishek had collected the money from different counters of milk parlours and was on way to Bhootnath Road in Patna City subdivision to deposit the money in the bank account of the dairy.

Pirbahore police station SHO Rizwan Ahmad Khan said efforts were on to ascertain the identity of the robbers with the help of the CCTV footages in the area. Nobody was injured in the firing incident, he added.

DSP (Town) Suresh Prasad, however, claimed that police have collected some clues about the robbers. “We will crack the case at the earliest,” he said, adding that raids were on to nab the criminals involved in the crime. A case was lodged with the Pirbahore police station on the victim’s statement.

Locals told the police that the robbery came to light only when the victim raised an alarm. “The robbers dashed against the victim’s motorbike from behind on the road. As a result, he fell on the ground. We thought that the victim was hit from behind in an accident,” a police officer quoted a local shopkeeper as saying.

Earlier on Sunday, armed criminals looted Rs. 6.05 lakh in three separate incidents from areas falling under Kadamkuan, Digha and Naubatpur police stations in Patna district.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma, who assumed charge on Thursday, had categorically told the police officers to pull up their socks failing which stern disciplinary action would be taken against them.

Sharma held a meeting with the SHOs and gave tips on how to control crime. Sharma, who had earlier served as City SP in Patna, visited different police stations soon after he assumed charge as SSP. He has replaced Garima Malik, who has been promoted to the rank of DIG and posted in the CID at the headquarters.

Title: Drunk man beats mother of three puppies to death, held
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

One of the puppies whose mother was killed on Monday

HYDERABAD: In yet another heart-wrenching incident, a lactating dog was beaten to death by a drunk man at Gangaputra colony in Hasmathpet on Sunday night.

A passerby was in for a shock when the man, Pothula Sai Kumar (45), who was drunk and armed with an iron rod, beat up the dog in its stomach until it lost consciousness and succumbed to injuries.

“I was passing by the area when I saw this man pick up an iron rod and beat the dog mercilessly in its stomach. The man did not stop hitting the dog even though it was crying in pain. The dog was lactating and died in front of its three puppies,” said Kota Nandini, a resident of Hasmathpet.

Nandini, who lodged a complaint with the police, added that the man is not just a threat to the dogs but to the entire locality.

Meanwhile, an animal activist who was informed about the incident rushed to the spot and took custody of the three puppies. “The puppies were shivering and looked very scared when I found them. After rescuing them from the spot where this man brutally attacked their mother, I brought one puppy home, asked Nandini to take the second one and the third puppy is with one my colleagues. We will be taking care of them until we find someone who can adopt these puppies,” said Aanchal Khanna, an animal welfare activist.

The police took the accused into custody and registered a case under IPC Section 428 ( Mischief by killing or maiming cattle), Sections 11 (1) (I) of Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act 1960.

In a similar incident that took place in October last year, a dog which was being taken care of by the community, sustained multiple bleeding wounds after being attacked with an axe by a woman in an inebriated state.

The woman, in an inebriated condition, walked out of her home with an axe and proceeded to attack the dog which had been living in the area for several years. The woman has allegedly attacked and killed dogs in the past as well.

Speaking to TOI, Dr Purnima Nagaraja, mental health professional, Dhrithi Wellness Clinic, said, “Cruelty to animals can also be due to anti-social personality disorder. This can happen when there is no outlet for emotion. In some cases, people commit such crimes because they derive pleasure out of someone else’s pain. These are nothing but personality disorders.”

Stating that it was important to identify the behavioral patterns at an early stage and see that people do not commit such crimes, she said that it is likely for such people to hurt human beings in the same way they are cause harm to animals.

Title: Violence in JNU: Member in chat group is not party man, says Congress
Content:
A glass gate is seen vandalized inside the JNU campus after the attack on JNU students in New Delhi (File Phot... Read More

A Google search mentioned the phone number as that of a vendor hired by Congress party

NEW DELHI: A day after the JNU violence , Congress distanced itself from a person who was posting messages on a WhatsApp group allegedly involved in planning the attack .A Google search mentioned the phone number as that of a vendor hired by Congress. But the party tweeted on Monday that Anand Manganle was associated with it earlier. “The SM (social media) team of INC had hired the services of several private vendors to run the crowdfunding campaign for a limited period before Lok Sabha polls after which it was discontinued. The number belonged to a vendor and has nothing to do with INC,” Congress said.Manganle took to Facebook to claim that he had “infiltrated” the WhatsApp group to remain alert about ABVP’s plans and save the students . He also requested people not to “harass” Congress for his action.Manganle, whose Twitter handle was suspended on Monday for rumour mongering and inciting violence, posted a screenshot of his Tweet on Facebook, claiming “this number was used as a test number when I was a vendor who helped them (Congress) to set up the crowdfunding campaign two years ago & YES, I infiltrated that group to get more info so I could pass it to students and save them (sic)”.He claimed in another post that he had also joined Unity Against Left. “When it went a bit silent, I wrote... ‘Main Gate pe kya karna hai’ to get where people are & what they are planning... & also warn people who were coming outside main gate (sic),” he wrote.After some more people got themselves added to the group to get info, Manganle said, “they removed all new people... & eventually removed me”. Now, Manganle claimed, his screenshots are being circulated and he is getting “supporting calls... & all abuses, considering I am ABVP.”

Title: Killed in stampede, boy’s kin still waiting for govt aid
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sagir’s family has received financial assistance of Rs 3 lakh, which was collected through voluntary public co... Read More

Varanasi: Even 18 days after the police action on people protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC) in which an eight-year-old boy Sageer lost his life in the ensuing stampede, the aggrieved family is yet to get any compensation from the government.

A financial assistance of Rs. 3 lakh through public contributions was provided to the boy’s family immediately after the incident. “We were given Rs 3 lakh cash by the Bhelupur police, although we do not know if it was official contribution. The district magistrate too had promised official financial assistance, which is yet to come,” said the boy’s grandmother Shehnaz Akhtar.

District magistrate (DM) Kaushal Raj Sharma said, “The amount given to the kin of the boy was arranged through contributions from the public. The process for the compensation from the CM’s discretionary fund has been initiated. We can’t saw when the formalities will be over.”

The incident had occurred in the Muslim dominated Bajardiha locality on December 20 afternoon, when police resorted to cane charge to disperse an agitating mob. The police action resulted in total chaos and stampede. Later, Sageer was found dead and his body was handed over to his family around 4 am after post mortem on December 21, and within an hour his burial was performed amidst tight security.

Sageer was the third among the four sons of Wakil Ahmad, a weaver-turned-cook. The eldest Naseer Ahmad (15) is learning weaving. A 15X12-feet dingy room accommodates 15 family members, including the parents of Wakil and five members of his brother Shakil Ahmad’ s family.

“We had not imagined that Sageer, who had gone out to play with his friends, would never return home,” said Shehnaz. Someone on his phone showed her the picture of Sageer lying on the ground.

“We were told that he was taken to the Trauma Centre of Banaras Hindu University. We rushed to the trauma centre, but we did not see him live,” said the shocked grandmother. The boy’s father was out for his work when the TOI team visited his house on Monday.

Meanwhile, a sense of mistrust and fear against the administration still prevails among the local residents. The kin of those injured in cane charge avoid to meet unknown people, even mediapersons.

For the family members of an injured youth Khalid Zamal (22), who had to spend four days in ICU of BHUs trauma centre, every stranger is suspicious. Fearing the arrival of police, they initially did not open the doors, but allowed the TOI team in when convinced by the local dwellers. Khalid has been advised bed rest for some days after he was discharged from the hospital on December 31.

“I was going to attend a ‘dawat’ (party) of my relative when trapped in the crowed, and lost my sense,” he said.

“The scene of that fateful day still hounds people’s mind. The police used unnecessary force for no reason,” said a local resident, Mohammad Alam Ansari, adding, “The police picked up four persons from their houses and they are still in jail.”

Title: Goa: Five from UP try impersonation to get government accommodation
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The crime branch of Goa police arrested five persons from Uttar Pradesh , one of who was impersonating as state cabinet minister to avail the government’s Circuit House stay at Altinho, Panaji during their stay in Goa.

Police said that around 10 days back, the five individuals came to Goa and one impersonated as a cabinet minister. An email was sent as an official letter to avail the guest house facilities. Police said that the letter mentioned that the visiting guests enjoy privileges equivalent to a state cabinet minister but on verification, it was revealed that no such post existed.

During inquiry it came to light that the letter was fake and a police complaint was filed immediately. The crime branch contacted the UP police and got details of the accused. Police has registered a case of impersonation and cheating and said that the accused were calming that they were BJP members.

The accused also tried to get official appointments with cabinet ministers. Art and culture minister, Govind Gaude said they sought an appointment with him but he got suspicious when the official post was mentioned.

Police said surveillance was mounted and subsequently all five were arrested. They were produced before the judicial magistrate first class and have been remanded into police custody.

Police said an email was sent as an official letter to avail guest house facilities. It mentioned that the visiting guests, calming to be BJP members, enjoy privileges equivalent to a state cabinet minister

Title: Game pulls up officials for not removing illegal hoardings
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nashik: Civic officials, going slow in taking action against illegal hoardings , were taken to task by municipal commissioner Radhakrisha Game on Monday.

Over 300 illegal hoardings were found in the city during a survey carried out a month ago following which Game had directed the officials concerned to remove them at the earliest. Despite the orders, over 100 illegal hoardings are yet to be removed.

The issue of illegal hoardings came up during the meeting of head of departments on Monday where Game asked the officials concerned the reason behind the delay. In their defence, the officials said owing to lack of machineries to cut iron pillars they could not remove all the illegal hoardings.

Municipal commissioner then directed divisional officials to purchase all machineries in their power of purchases up to Rs 1 lakh and take out all the illegal hoardings at the earliest.

Illegal hoardings have mushroomed across the city and after Game’s instructions a survey was carried out in all six divisions of the NMC to check for hoardings with and without permissions.

During the survey, the NMC found over 300 illegal hoardings that were erected without permission. Around 2,000 hoardings were found legal and were erected following permissions by the NMC.

Around four months ago, the NMC had undertaken a special drive and removed over 100 illegal hoardings erected on dividers, electric poles and traffic islands. Most of the illegal hoardings were related to political leaders.

These illegal hoardings have again mushroomed in various parts of the city even after action taken by the civic body. Municipal commissioner has also directed the officials to register FIRs against those involved in putting such illegal banners and hoardings.

Title: HC seeks SEC response to woman’s plea to declare her elected panchayat president
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has sought a response from the state election commission (SEC) and state government on a plea moved by a woman seeking to declare her as the elected member to the post of panchayat president of T Punavasal village in Ramanathapuram district.

S Nagarani, a resident of Ramanathapuram district, in her petition stated that after notification was issued for the rural local body elections, she filed her nomination to contest for the post of panchayat president of T Punavasal village. She stated that another woman candidate A Devaki also filed her nomination for the same post. She claimed that Devaki is the candidate preferred by the ruling AIADMK party and several unethical tactics were used to make her win.

Nagarani submitted that a total of 1,895 votes were polled for electing in the panchayat election and counting of votes was done on January 2 as per schedule. While 27 votes were declared invalid, she secured 986 votes and Devaki secured 882 votes. The election officer had declared her as the winner in the presence of the election observer and started preparing Form 23 and Form 25.

She said that her name was also published in the official website of the SEC as the elected candidate. Following this, Devaki and her supporters caused a commotion inside the counting centre. She claimed that the police officials sent her supporters out of the counting centre instead of removing Devaki and her supporters.

Subsequently, the election officer had issued Form 25 in favour of Devaki, declaring her elected for the post of panchayat president and her name was also displayed in the election commission website. This shows that the election officer who was in connivance with Devaki had political influence. Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to declare the Form 25 issued by the election official in favour of Devaki as illegal and sought to declare her as elected candidate.

When the petition was heard on Monday, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran sought response from the SEC and government and adjourned the case for further hearing on January 7.

Title: Smart City projects face uncertain future
Content:
Representative image

KOCHI: Even while Cochin Smart Mission Ltd (CSML) authorities hope that they may be able to buy time from the Union government for implementing projects under SmartCity until March 31, 2020, many of the projects included in the scheme are entangled in controversies. Rows have cast shadow on many of the projects like the Rs 166-crore vacuum sewage project, the Rs 21-crore project to construct apartment complex for slum dwellers, the Rs 310-crore intelligent street poles project and the Rs 100-crore Ernakulam market renovation project.In fact, the deadline for beginning all works under SmartCity project was December 31, 2019. Now, the authorities hope that the Union government will grant an extension until March 31, 2020. Due to protests from local residents, CSML authorities are unable to go ahead with the project. The sewage project aims at collecting and treating sewage from all the households and other establishments in five divisions of Kochi corporation at Mattancherry and Fort Kochi areas. “We had awarded the work to a firm and they had started initial work. When the firm conducted soil inspection at the proposed site for the plant near Fort Kochi Taluk Hospital they had to stop the work due to the protests by local residents. It is a project which is beneficial to the residents. But they fear that the project will contaminate their drinking water sources if the pipes carrying sewage leaks,” an official with CSML said. “But the fact is that the plant works on vacuum system. Using the force of vacuum the waste is drawn into the plant through the pipelines. If there is any leak in the pipeline, the system will stop,” the official said. “We had held three rounds of talks with the residents and authorities of hospitals and schools. Now, MLA, mayor and councillors have agreed to convene a meeting of the residents for convincing them,” the official said. “If we lose the project, chances are least for us to get another round of funding for sewage project from the Centre,” the official said.Even while CSML authorities hope that they may be able to buy time from the Union government for implementing projects under SmartCity until March 31, 2020, many of the projects included in the scheme are entangled in controversiesSimilarly, the Ernakulam market renovation is in limbo due to unavailability of land for rehabilitating the merchants. “The land we identified for rehabilitating the merchants from the market is entangled in a legal dispute. Now, we plan to move the high court where a case over ownership of the land is pending. If high court allows our plea, we will be able to go ahead with the project,” said an official associated with the project.Another SmartCity project which has run into trouble is the construction of a ground-plus-eleven-storeyed apartment complex at Fort Kochi for rehabilitating slum dwellers. The plan is to complete the construction of the apartment complex at a cost of Rs 21 crore from SmartCity funds. But, the project is already mired in controversy. Originally, the project was designed and proposed to be implemented by Kochi corporation. Though the original cost of the project was Rs 14 crore, later it was increased to Rs 18 crore citing inclusion of additional features in the structure. Mayor Soumini Jain gave anticipatory approval for the contractor to withdraw security deposit of Rs 91.22 lakh after the contractor completed the work on the basement and half of the ground floor.The security deposit should have been given back only after completing the entire work and getting necessary certificates stating that the work on the building is satisfactory. Now, an inquiry by performance audit wing of the state government into the case is pending. Moreover, the opposition in the corporation council has lodged a complaint seeking vigilance inquiry into the matter.

Title: Ludhiana: Rs 650 crore plan for Buddha Nullah clean-up
Content:
Punjab government on Monday approved a Rs 650-crore project for rejuvenation of the polluted Buddha Nullah in ... Read More

The CM also directed additional chief secretary (local government) Sanjay Kumar to take all steps needed for the rejuvenation of the 47.55km drain, of which 14 km pass through Ludhiana

CHANDIGARH: Punjab government on Monday approved a Rs 650-crore project for rejuvenation of the polluted Buddha Nullah in Ludhiana. Presiding over a meeting here, chief minister Amarinder Singh asked the local government department to ensure the project is completed in two years.The CM also directed additional chief secretary (local government) Sanjay Kumar to take all steps needed for the rejuvenation of the 47.55km drain, of which 14 km pass through Ludhiana. The city is highly polluted by industrial and domestic waste, which is dumped into the nullah, causing a major threat to public health and environment.Accompanied by local government minister Brahm Mohindra, Capt Amarinder lauded Namdhari sect chief Satguru Thakur Uday Singh’s personal initiative in cleaning the drain in coordination with the city’s municipal corporation. The sect chief has also contributed Rs 30 lakh for buying machinery and other things for the cause.He said under the first phase, augmentation and refurbishment of sewage treatment facility, dairy effluent treatment, survey to find out missing links for industrial effluent and laying of dedicated conveyance system for industrial waste water to carry the same to common effluent treatment plant (CETP), if required, would be executed. The second phase, involving Rs 150 crore, would include reuse of treated effluent, and landscaping and beautification along the Buddha Nullah would also be undertaken at a cost of Rs 283 crore.Referring to the CETPs for treatment of the industrial waste, with total capacity of 105 MLD, local government secretary Ajoy Sharma said a plant having a capacity of 50 MLD would be installed at Tajpur Road, Jamalpur area by May this year. Another CETP at Focal Point Industrial Area, Jamalpur, having capacity of 40 MLD, would be commissioned by March 2020. A CETP at Bahadurke Road was already commissioned on December 31, 2019, he said.Notably, the actual waste discharge being generated in the city is 711 MLD, which includes 610 MLD of domestic sewage discharge, 15 MLD discharge from the dairy complex and industrial effluent discharge of 86 MLD (as per the consents given by Punjab Pollution Control Board). At present, the city has an installed sewage treatment capacity of 466 MLD and another 105 MLD capacity of CETPs for industrial waste water treatment is under installation.

Title: Varanasi: Booked for protest against CAA, bail granted to 3
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: Three persons in jail for allegedly taking part in protests against CAA and NRC on December 19 in the city were on Monday granted bail by the court of additional sessions judge SK Pandey.

The three persons granted bail are Manish Sharma, Anoop Shramik and SP Rai.

According to defence lawyer Anil Kumar Singh, the court while granting bail observed that “fair criticism does not come under the preview of these allegations, and criticism of the person of one political party and principles of opposite party even do not come under this purview”.

Among other sections, the trio had been booked under sections 153 (wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot), 153 B (imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of IPC.

They were arrested for distributing pamphlets in Lanka area on December 18, calling upon people to gather at Beniabagh on December 19 in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Altogether 59 persons were arrested on December 19, of which 56 were granted bail on January 1.

Title: Goa’s institutes preparing for national accreditation
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The state’s five engineering and two pharmacy colleges and institutes offering other degree and diploma technical programmes have started the process of preparing their self-assessment reports.Earlier, the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) had announced that accreditation by the National Accreditation Board (NAB) would soon be made essential for institutes offering technical undergraduate and postgraduate programmes.The cut-off was set at 2023 after which programmes without the accreditation would be considered unrecognised.NAB is an autonomous body of the MHRD to whom the detailed self-assessment report has to be submitted online by the institutes. Once the report is submitted, an expert committee of three experts for degree programmes and two experts in case of diploma programmes will carry out a physical inspection of the institute.Sources said that for institutes in the state, an internal deadline of July 2020 has been set to submit their self-assessment reports to the NAB.The NBA accredits individual programmes and not institutes, as given by National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC). NBA accredited fields include engineering and technology, management, pharmacy, architecture, applied arts and crafts, computer applications and hospitality and tourism management.Sources said that most programmes in Goa do not have NAB accreditation. While accreditation is voluntary, in 2017 the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) announced that it will not provide approval for institutes that failed to accredit at least half of their programmes.The purpose of the accreditation is to promote and recognise excellence in technical education in colleges and universities.The NAB was formed on the lines of the Accreditation Board of Engineering and Technology in the USA. In 2014, NBA was granted a full membership status in the Washington Accord.“The expert committee of the NAB is totally independent. Even the process of inspection is carried out in a manner that has no scope for the institute officials to influence the panel. The accreditation is a quality assurance of the institute. Institutes have to score on parameters with a total weightage of 1,000 points. If an institute scores 750 or above, they will be accredited for five to six years. Those in a lower range of up to 600 get provisional accreditation,” an official said.

Title: No enquiry from students to go unattended at SPPU sub-centre in Nashik
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

NASHIK: The Nashik sub-centre of Savitribai Phule Pune University ( SPPU ) has decided to answer all enquiry calls it receives from the students.

Authorities at the sub-centre have deployed a person to attend phone calls and transfer it to the respective personnel for dedicated service.

“We get most of the calls during the time of filling forms and examinations. More than 50 enquiries per day are entertained during these times as students need assistance,” Prashant Tope, co-ordinator of Nashik sub-centre, said.

On other days, the sub-centre receives around 30 enquiries per day. The authorities have also prepared a list of frequently asked questions (FAQs) with their answers for regular enquiries.

“The sheet also includes flow charts that help in guiding the students about how to go about filling a form on the website,” Tope said.

“We never like it if our phones go unanswered especially during urgent times. So, we have made it a point that as soon as our office opens at 10.30 am, students’ queries will be entertained over the phone until 6pm. Only during the lunch hour between 1.45 pm and 2.15 pm, we won’t be able to take calls,” he added.

The SPPU sub-centre is open on all working days as per the varsity in Pune. Various other facilities like issuance of migration certificates, display of subject change on the exam form, updating of course dropouts, among others are also being taken care of at the sub-centre.

“We are a link between the university and the students in the city. It would be best if we can help them with maximum services at the sub-centre and that is all we are trying to do,” Tope said, adding that the helpline numbers — 0253-2581434, 0253-2310661 —are available on the varsity website.

Title: Parayar community seeks representation
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: A public interest litigation (PIL) has been filed before the Madras high court seeking to include a representative from the parayar community in the jallikattu organizing committee at Palamedu.C Santhanam, a resident of Palamedu, stated in his petition that there are more than 15,000 people of different communities including those belonging to parayar, a scheduled caste community, at Palamedu town panchayat. While there are representatives of all communities in the ‘Grama Podhu Mahalinga Swamy Madathu Committee’ which is the organising committee for Palamedu jallikattu, their community (parayar) was not included. When members of the committee decided to conduct the jallikattu on January 16, their plea to include a representative from their community was denied. He stated that not including a representative from their community is discrimination as per Article 14 and Article 17 of the Constitution.

Though people from their community have submitted representation to the officials including the district collector to include their representative in the organizing committee, no steps were taken. Hence the petitioner moved the high court bench seeking direction to the authorities to convene a peace meeting to include a representative from their community in the jallikattu committee this year . The petition would be taken up for hearing on Tuesday.

Title: Madras high court grants anticipatory bail to two journalists
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has granted anticipatory bail to a Junior Vikatan journalist and a photojournalist in two cases which were registered against them for allegedly instigating the residents of a Sri Lankan refugee camp to create problems against the government over Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Kanyakumari district.

In their petition, the male journalist R Sindhu and photographer R Ramkumar stated based on the complaint of the VAOs concerned, a case was registered against them by the Kaliyakkavilai police under sections including the non-bailable Section 505 (1)(b) of the IPC (statements conducting to public mischief, with intent to cause, or which is likely to cause fear and alarm to the public, offence against the state or against the public tranquility).

Other IPC sections include 447 (punishment for criminal trespass) and 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant).

They stated that they were doing their job of collecting information relating to public issues and have not committed any offence as alleged by the prosecution. Another case was also registered against them by the Marthandam police in this regard, they said.

Hence, they filed two petitions before the high court Madurai bench seeking anticipatory bail in both cases.

When the petitions were heard on Monday, justice G R Swaminathan granted anticipatory bail to the petitioners without imposing any conditions.

Title: GHMC turns to social media to catch litterbugs
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: Ahead of Swachh Survekshan 2020, the GHMC’s Directorate of Enforcement Vigilance and Disaster Management (EVDM) wing has decided to monitor complaints raised on Twitter and other social networking sites to catch offenders littering public places.

After a complaint is posted on Twitter or Facebook with a picture of debris being dumped into a lake or a water body by a dump truck , the EVDM officials, with the help of the vehicle number, will catch the offender.

The GHMC, at present, penalises offenders through a mechanism by which the house number or vehicle number is recorded.

“If an individual throws debris or construction material in front of his house, we can catch him with the help of the house number. If someone resorts to open urination, it is not possible to penalise him as we don’t have a facial recognition system to catch hold of him. The aim is to create awareness among people littering the city and to let them know there is an enforcement team monitoring them,” said Kampati, who stressed that the onus of keeping the city clean also lies on the people.

Meanwhile, EVDM director Viswajit Kampati said that the GHMC zonal commissioners can penalise using e-challan system and that the service will be extended to citizens too.

“So far, 4,61,783 civic violations were recorded by EVDM staff who clicked pictures and uploaded them on EVDM portal. Raising flexi banners, sticking wall posters, wall writings and debris dumping were some of the offences reported,” read a statement issued by the EVDM.

Title: Clash averted between ABVP & other groups
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Protest at Maharshi Dayanand University on Monday against JNU violence

ROHTAK: A clash between Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) and Joint Students Action Committee (JSAC) was averted due to the presence of police on Monday. Both the parties reached gate number-1 of Maharshi Dayanand University to protest the attack in the Jawaharlal Nehru University campus on Sunday night.

Around 3pm, students bodies’ activists representing All India Democratic Student Organisation, Disha Chatr Sangathan, Students’ Federation of India (SFI), Chatra Yuva Sangharsh Samiti, Balmiki Chatr Mahasabha and National Students’ Union of India reached the venue, shouting slogans against ABVP alleging its role in the attack by masked miscreants inside JNU campus.

The protesters were being escorted by the police till they reached gate number-1 at MDU, but a section of ABVP protesters started shouting ‘Jai Shree Ram’ and ‘ Bharat Mata Ki Jai’. Tempers ran high when the protesters came face to face and started raising slogans against each other, but timely intervention by the policemen present on duty saved the situation. SFI activists said ABVP attempted to suppress their voice when they were protesting against the attack inside JNU campus.

Title: Bamu students condemn JNU attack, demand swift action against culprits
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Aurangabad: A day after students were attacked inside Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), a section of student unions on Monday carried out protests at Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University (BAMU) to condemn the act and show solidarity towards their counterparts in Delhi.

Among others, member of National Student Union of India (NSUI) held a spirited demonstration to condemn the JNU incident. Gathered in large number, the students first assembled near the statue of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar and later marched towards the main building by forming a human chain.

NSUI activists also raised slogans against the Union government and demanded action against the culprits.

“The JNU incident is blot on the education system of our country. Campuses of institutions of higher learning are no longer safer and students are being bullied by people having a leaning towards the extremist ideology. We condemn the cowardly act and demand immediate action against those behind the violence,” Kunal Kharat, one of the student leaders, said.

The students also tried to entry the main building, but were prevented by police and security guards. The students also staged a brief sit-in agitation before leaving the campus.

“We demand action against those who attacked students at JNU. Only stern action could set a strong deterrent in minds of anti-social elements who are trying to push their own agenda of hatred and fear,” Dhammapal Sonkamble, another student, said.

The campus of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) witnessed ugly scenes on Sunday evening when some masked miscreants armed with sticks, allegedly damaged the property and attacked people inside the campus.

Title: IMA condemns attack on health workers at JNU
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

T’puram: The Indian Medical Association has condemned the attack on the doctors and the para medical team which had rushed to treat the injured students and teachers at JNU on Sunday night.

“The situation in the country smacks of total anarchy and breakdown of law and order is complete. If the doctors and nurses are not safe in the capital of the country, it speaks about the volume of governance and lack of it,” said Dr R V Ashokan, national general secretary of IMA .

IMA has demanded of the Union health ministry to condemn the attack on doctors and ensure their safety for effectively carrying out their duty. The state branch of IMA too condemned the attack on the doctors in New Delhi. TNN

Title: Anti-encroachment cell by February
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The GHMC said an anti-encroachment cell will be set up to protect public properties. The cell will be under the EVDM wing. “The primary focus of the cell will be on lakes and open lands across the city. The cell will be set up by February first week,” said Vishwajit Kampati, director, EVDM. tnn

Title: Punjab CM Amarinder Singh for strict action against those behind JNU violence
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CM Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Demanding strictest of action against the perpetrators of mayhem at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), irrespective of their political affiliation or ideology, Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Monday asked the Centre and the Delhi governments to ensure urgent restoration of law and order in the country’s premier university.

Amarinder said he lamented the unprecedented attacks and clashes witnessed at Aligarh Muslim University , Jamia Millia University and JNU in recent weeks. He said these incidents had not just marred the country’s international image but caused irrevocable damaged to its education system – one of the key pillars of any nation’s progress and development.

In a statement that blamed Delhi Police and Union and Delhi governments for the unbridled and vicious attacks on students in JNU on Sunday night, Amarinder said, “Where was the Delhi Police when armed goons had a free run of the campus, indulging in brutal attacks on students, staff and teachers? Why did the police force, which had been ruthless in its actions when trouble had broken out in Jamia some days back, suddenly decide to stay back in the case of JNU? Whose orders were they acting on?”

Amarinder was also unsparing in his criticism of Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, saying, “How could he not rush to the spot? Was it enough for him to simply tweet his anguish? As chief minister, and more importantly as someone who claims to be the custodian of the welfare of Delhi’s citizens, why did he not intervene personally?”

Endorsing the demand raised by some individuals for Supreme Court to take suo motu cognisance of the developments in JNU, the chief minister said it was necessary to identify and act against not just the assailants behind what appeared to be a pre-planned attack but also those who became co-conspirators by virtue of allowing it to continue unabated. If this kind of incident goes unpunished in the national capital, one can only imagine what could happen in educational institutions in other parts of the country, he warned.

Title: Two bikers killed in road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Two bikers were killed in two separate road accidents which took place in Madurai city police limits on Sunday.
