A Chinnathambi 54-year-old man from Echaneri village near Thiruppuvanam was killed when a fast-moving van hit his two-wheeler near Kusavankundu. The van driver fled the scene without stopping the vehicle. Based on a complaint from the deceased’s son C Karuppasamy, 20, a hit and run case was registered with the Traffic Investigation Wing I police under the IPC section 304 (a)- causing death by negligence.

According to the police, they have identified the vehicle’s number, which caused the accident and are tracing the driver based on it. He will be arrested soon, they said.

In another incident, K Gopinath, 47, from Balaji Nagar from Thiruppalai died after he fell down from his bike after he applied sudden brake. The accident took place near Sheeba Nagar in Thirupalai on Sunday. He suffered head injuries and was rushed to a nearby hospital, where doctors declared him brought dead. Based on a complaint from his daughter G Abitha, a case was registered with traffic investigation wing II police.

Title: 4 held, 20t PDS rice seized from truck, flour mill
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Civil Supplies CID sleuths seized 20 tonnes of rice meant for the public distribution system (PDS) from a truck and a flour mill at Thiruvengadam near Sholavandan in the early hours of Monday. Four people including the kingpin of the PDS rice smuggling racket, which has apparently going on for years, were arrested.

A team pressed into action by Madurai zone superintendent of police (CSCID) G Stalin was checking vehicles near Sholavandan when it found a truck stationed in a suspicious manner near a flour mill in Thiruvengadam village.

When the team members checked the vehicle, they found 12,500 kg of rice packed in bags. An inspection was also carried out inside the private flour mill where 7,500 kg more of PDS rice was found. After seizing the rice and the truck, an inquiry was initiated to arrest the accused involved.

It led them to the kingpin of the illegal activity identified as S Muthu, 42, at Housing Board Colony. Three more people including the owner of the flour mill identified as Parthasarathi were also arrested.

The names of the driver and cleaner of the truck, who too have been arrested, have not been revealed.

According to the police, Muthu has already been detained under black marketers act five times and as many as 12 cases are pending against him. Officials said it was “Know Your Criminal”, a concept developed by DGP of civil supplies CID Prateep V Philip, that helped keep track of black marketers in the state and led to the arrest of Muthu.

Title: Allahabad district saw 130 cases of murder in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: With 130 cases reported between January 1 and December 15 in 2019, the district reported the highest number of murders among the eight districts comprising Allahabad zone, as per police data released on Monday.

The development comes a day after five of a family in Soraon. Police suspect a ‘ghumantu gang’ (nomadic gang) to be behind the crime, given the use of kitchen tools in the murder. According to statistics, in 2017 and 2018 the number of murder cases registered in Allahabad was 118 and 110. The highest number of cases in the district — 58 — were reported in Trans-Ganga localities this year. Personal vendetta and old enmity were behind 63% of the killings reported in Allahabad followed by illicit relations in these crimes.

The data shows that 351 murder cases were reported from Allahabad zone, which comprises Allahabad range and Banda range.

The Allahabad zone comprises eight districts — Kaushambi, Fatehpur, Pratapgarh, Banda, Hamirpur, Mahoba and Chitrakoot. The lowest number of murder cases (14) were registered in Mahoba between January 1 and December 15. The second highest number of murder cases were registered in Pratapgarh (62) followed by Banda (36), Fatehpur (35), Kaushambi (34), Hamirpur and Chitrakoot (20 each).

The three districts comprising Allahabad range — Pratapgarh, Kaushambi and Fatehpur — accounted for 131 murders during the six-month period. While a total of 261 cases of murder reported from Allahabad range between January 1 and December 15, 2019, 90 murder deaths were registered in Banda range. IG (Allahabad range) K P Singh instructed the police department to take up cases of disputes over property and personal rivalry on a priority, before they turn into a heinous crime.

Title: SGPC chief meets Rajoana, promises to fight his legal battles
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

PATIALA: Shiromani Gurdwara Prabandhak Committee (SGPC) president Gobind Singh Longowal called on former chief minister Beant Singh’s assassin Balwant Singh Rajoana , who is lodged at Patiala Central Jail, on Monday. He was accompanied by SGPC delegation and assured Rajoana that the committee would fight every legal battle to secure his release.

Rajoana had announced that he would go on a hunger strike from January 11 onwards, if a prompt decision on his clemency petition was not taken by the Union government. Longowal said SGPC would explore all possibilities and would even approach the Union government. After the assurance by the SGPC chief, Rajoana has decided to postpone his hunger strike.

Interacting with the mediapersons later, Longowal said during Guru Nanak Dev’s 550th birth anniversary celebrations, the Centre had announced commuting Rajoana’s death sentence to life imprisonment, which could have paved the way for his release from the jail. “However, it is sad that the Union government took a U-turn and Rajoana’s sentence was not commuted. It has hurt the sentiments of the entire Sikh community,” he claimed.

Longowal said that the Shiromani Akali Dal and SGPC were already pursuing Rajoana’s case and an appeal had also made to the President of India in this regard, but no decision had been taken even after eight years. He said the SGPC would even take up the matter with Prime Minister Narender Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah soon.

Title: CAA: Punjab and Haryana high court junks plea against imposition of preventive orders in Nuh
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab and Haryana high court on Monday dismissed a petition seeking directions for withdrawal of imposition of preventive orders under Section 144 of Criminal Procedure Code (CrPc) from Nuh district of Haryana, which was invoked by the district administration to maintain law and order situation in view of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Nuh is Haryana’s only district having a majority of Muslim population.

Nuh advocate Mohammad Arshad had filed a petition filed, seeking directions to set aside the order passed by the district administration on December 25, 2019, whereby the entire district was placed under Section 144, without identifying any imminent threat to public order and tranquility. According to the petitioner, the order is a disproportionate restriction on the rights of civilians, who are not even likely to cause an imminent threat to public order.

It was also submitted that such an action was a clear violation of fundamental rights guaranteed under Articles 19 and 21 of the Constitution. The petition also submitted that the Supreme Court has held that Section 144 orders must be issued against the wrongdoer and not against innocent civilians merely on grounds of convenience and expediency.

HC, however, was not convinced with the arguments preferred by the petitioner and dismissed his petition.

Title: Soraon killings: Police nab six but motive still unclear
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: A day after five members of a family were found murdered in their house in Soraon, police have arrested six persons named in the FIR but are yet to find out the motive behind brutal kilings.

SSP, Allahabad, Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said, “We have arrested six persons named in the FIR but we are yet to ascertain the motive. Police teams are constantly quizzing the accused. We have also roped in special task force (STF) to crack the case.”

As many as five police teams are working overtime to solve the case.

The SSP said a panel of two doctors performed the autopsy and found that deaths were caused due to deep injuries. “Post-mortem report has ruled out rape of the woman victim before murder,” he said.

Bodies of Somdutt Tiwari (32), owner of a small-scale transport business, his father Vijay Shankar Tiwari (60), wife Soni Tiwari (28) and the couple’s two sons, Kanha (7) and Kunj (2), were found in three separate rooms of their house on Sunday.

The assailants used home tools such as a kitchen knife and a grinding stone to murder them.

Brother of slain woman, Kartikeya Tiwari of Pratapgarh, lodged an FIR under section 147,148,149,302 and 120 B of IPC against seven persons including gram pradhan Pradeep Kumar, Sachidanand Tiwari, Sampurnanad Tiwari, Ambuj Tiwari, Jitendra Kumar Tiwari, Vikas Tiwari, and Satyam Tiwari.

Meanwhile, Congress leader Pramod Tiwari reached post-mortem house on Monday morning and met the kin of the deceased.

State law minister Brijesh Pathak also reached Rasoolabad ghat and assured the kin that the killers would be nabbed soon.

Title: Prep on for kite & sweet fest
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana government will organise three-day kite and sweet festival at Parade Ground in Secunderabad from January 13. A high-level meeting, chaired by tourism and excise minister Srinivas Goud, was conducted on Monday to take stock of the 5th International Kite Festival. Noted kite flyers from over 50 countries would participate in the event. Also, during the three-day festival, 25 states would display their culture and arts. tnn

Title: Joy, drama as civic body reps take charge
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Local body representatives elected to various posts in the recently held elections assumed charge on Monday in an atmosphere filled with joy and camaraderie. However, the occasion had its share of drama too as a ward member jumped the wall of the collectorate building allegedly to escape horse-trading. The winners were adorned with huge floral garlands and family members were seen going out of the way to celebrate the occasion. In Madurai district, DMK won 13 of the 23 district panchayat councilor seats as against the AIADMK’s nine while an independent candidate won the remaining seat. The winners assumed charge at a function got up in the hall of the old collectorate building in the presence of district collector Dr T G Vinay and assistant director of panchayats Chelladurai.

Senior AIADMK member and elected representative of the 16th ward, P Aiyappan, was the first to be sworn in by DRO incharge Kannan. The other members including Kasimayan, P Muthupandi (DMK), Akihla (AIADMK) and Rajarajan (DMK) took charge subsequently. DMK north district secretary P Moorthy, among others were present. DMK’s ward 22 member S Keerthika saw her jubilant brother and relatives putting gold rings on her fingers after assuming charge. P Muthupandi decided that it was an occasion to recognize her father-in-law’s contribution to her victory. She invited him on stage and honoured him with a shawl and ‘thalaipagai’.

In a show of strength, DMK MLA Moorthy made all his 13 councillors stand in a row but whisked them away as soon as the ceremony was over. This was to keep them in his control till the district chairman and vice-chairman assume charge on January 11. In Thirumangalam union, the panchayat union councillors of DMK — Muthupandi, Shanthi Murugan and Sonia Vijay — refused to take oath as AIADMK propaganda songs were played loudly in the hall. The ten AIADMK councillors and one each from the DMDK and BJP assumed charge on Monday.Unidentified people set fire to the celebration poster of Nagalakshmi Kasirajan, the newly elected panchayat president of Sakkimangalam in Madurai. Pandeeswari, an independent candidate who was elected president of Karcheri, thanked the villagers at the village square in the presence of her relatives. In Chellampatti, AIADMK has won nine of the 17 wards and the DMK seven. S Aravind, an independent candidate who was elected from ward 8 in the panchayat union, scaled the wall of the building and was whisked away in a waiting car. Sources said he was trying to dodge representatives of the two political parties which have been trying to indulge in horse trading.

Title: Eunuchs have no right to perform customary duties unless authorities say so: Punjab and Haryana high court
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab and Haryana high court has clarified that unless there is a declaration or decision by competent civil court empowering an eunuch to perform “traditional/customary duties,” the eunuch cannot seek protection of police authorities to ensure performance of such rights.

Justice Sanjay Kumar of the HC passed these orders while dismissing a petition filed by Suman Mahant, a transgender from Muktsar.

In this case, the petitioner had approached the high court as she has been stopped by some persons from performing her traditional or customary duty as an eunuch in the area. She also claimed that she had approached the local police on October 23, 2019 and submitted a representation. In her representation to police, she had sought interference of police in performing her right to carry out traditional/customary duties as a eunuch of Dera Guru Nank Nagari, Malout. As no action or assistance was provided to her by local police, she approached the high court and sought a direction to protect her life, liberty, and property from people who were creating problems for her in performing her customary duties as an eunuch.

Hearing the plea, the high court observed, “Without a competent civil court rendering a declaration/decision as to the petitioner’s claimed right, it would not be open to her to seek protection from the police authorities to give effect to such a right.”

While dismissing the plea, the judge, however, made it clear that this order shall, however, not preclude the petitioner from approaching the jurisdictional police authorities in case any criminal offence is committed warranting appropriate action being taken under the Indian Penal Code .

The HC order is significant as it has now been clarified that an eunuch has no specific right of legal protection for collection of ‘bhadhais (tips)’ as a matter of right in any particular area unless they are specifically empowered for such collection by the local authorities.

Although the authorities would hardly give any permission to eunuchs for collection in any area, some local organizations or group housing societies have fixed rates of tips to be given to the eunuchs in case of any family celebrations.

Title: Court pauses SEC notification for municipal election
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: Even as the State Election Commission (SEC) was preparing to issue a notification on Tuesday for municipal elections, the Telangana high court on Monday stopped it till Tuesday evening.

A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy gave this directive while hearing a PIL filed by Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee (TPCC) chief N Uttam Kumar Reddy, who challenged the action of SEC issuing the poll schedule on December 23 last year without first determining reservations of wards of municipalities and corporations.

The Chief Justice said: “In a democratic set-up, a candidate should be given sufficient time. Furnish us the entire chronology of dates and rules and poll manual by Tuesday.”

The crux of Monday’s hearing mainly revolved around two issues: Why did SEC issue the schedule even before it notified elections? Why did it go ahead before the quota was determined?

Generally, SEC releases the schedule and notification on the same day.

Senior counsel D Prakash Reddy, who appeared for Uttam, said SEC’s action in issuing the schedule first and preparing to release the notification on Tuesday was a violation of Rule 195(1) of the Telangana Municipalities Act. He said the Act clearly mentions that poll notification should be issued first.

The bench questioned SEC as to how it issued the schedule first when the poll notification was to be issued first. “Have reservations for the wards determined? How do you expect a candidate to prepare himself to contest without knowing if his ward is reserved and if so, it’s reserved under which category?” it asked.

The bench further asked: “How do you expect a candidate to obtain a caste certificate at short notice if the ward is indeed reserved to a category that suits him?” It further said if a candidate prepares himself regardless of reservation, there was no guarantee that the ward would be finally reserved for his community. “The plight of a general candidate is no different because he is also not sure whether his ward would remain general or fall into a reserved quota. Hence, finalisation of reservations is a must before issuing the poll schedule and notification,” the bench said.

Appearing for SEC, senior counsel CV Mohan Reddy said that reservation of wards was a task to be performed by the state government. “We issued the schedule on December 23, asking the voters to be ready to vote and that a poll notification would be issued on January 7,” Reddy said. He said they were working in coordination with the government.

The bench posted the matter to Tuesday.

Title: Experts laud T scope for growth as 60 EIAs await Centre’s nod
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: With as many as 60 projects under Centre’s scrutiny, Telangana stands fourth in the country in terms of number of environment impact assessments ( EIA ) behind Gujarat (108 projects), Maharashtra (87) and Delhi (64).

Industry experts suggest that EIAs are an indicators of the state’s appetitie for growth.

The figures for 2019 are the highest for the state in the past six years and do not include EIAs submitted at state level.

“The increase in EIAs is definitely a good indicator of the state’s growth trajectory,” IT secretary Jayesh Ranjan told TOI.

He said that Pharma City, Image Towers and second phase of T-hub were among the 60 projects for which EIAs were submitted last year. “The EIAs are only a small representation of projects in the state. There is an independent committee that scrutinises these assessments at state-level,” said special chief secretary for environment, Rajeshwar Tiwari

Projects that require the Union ministry of environment and forests clearance are those whose physical infrastructure in terms of size and cost is greater than the levels defined in Category-A of the Environmental Impact Assessment Notification, 2006 (EIA-2006).

These include projects in ports, highways, sanitation, urban transport as well as other industrial sectors.

All new national highways (NH) are classified as Category A. Expansion of NHs over 30 km, involving additional right of way over 20 metres, land acquisition and passing through more than one state also fall under Category-A.

According to NHAI sources, while there are several NH projects in the state, none required central clearance.

As per official records, 4,957 EIAs have been carried out by project proponents at central level since 2014.

Title: Former JNU VC seeks Centre’s intervention to resolve issue
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Former vice-chancellor Sudhir Kumar Sopory (Photo: JNU website)

NEW DELHI: A day after unprecedented violence rocked JNU with masked goons running amok and beating up teachers and students , former vice-chancellor Sudhir Kumar Sopory said the Centre should intervene if the university administration was unable to resolve the festering issues.

“I felt like crying yesterday. JNU completed 50 years and the university should have been celebrating instead of such violence. It’s so unfortunate,” Sopory said, adding that the unrest in the university had been dragging on for too long now. Urging all stakeholders to let go their egos and have a dialogue, he said protests were a part of the JNU tradition but till not long ago, disputes were resolved through talks and discussion. “Things have come to such a pass because of the ego of the vice-chancellor and the students. This is not the first time that the protests are happening, but they never dragged on for so long without talks.”

Sopory felt that the recommendations of a committee set up by the ministry of human resource development asking for a dialogue with students and withdrawal of cases against them should have been implemented. “Ideally, the university should have resolved the issue. But after the government set up a committee, its recommendations should have been taken into consideration. The government needs to intervene and restore normalcy now,” he said.

On claims and counter-claims on the genesis of the violence, Sopory said: “The point is not who started the fight. Shutting off academic and administrative blocks for such a long time is not correct and the administration should have restored normalcy.”

Title: What is your real intention on CAA, CM Pinarayi Vijayan asks Congress
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

KOZHIKODE: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Monday said that there were some suspicions on the intentions of the Congress party on the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ).

Speaking at the conclusion of the youth march organized by DYFI raising the slogan ‘India will not surrender, we will not remain silent’ at the Kozhikode Beach on Monday, he said that the stand taken by KPCC president Mullappally Ramachandran against holding joint agitations on the issue and the fact that chief ministers of Congress-ruled states except Punjab have not publically denounced CAA has raised some doubts.

“I had written to the chief ministers of some states who had taken stand against CAA after the Kerala Assembly unanimously passed a resolution against the Act asking them if they too can take steps to pass similar resolutions in their state assemblies. But I have not seen any Congress chief minister, expect the Punjab CM coming out in public denouncing the Act. Why is there a small hide-and-seek on the issue? Don’t fault us for some suspicions we are having while considering all these things. What is your real intention on the issue,” Vijayan said.

Condemning the attack against students of the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi on Sunday, Vijayan alleged that the attacks were carried out by criminals belonging to the RSS. “The police stayed away when the attackers came. The attackers didn't give the consideration that JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh was a woman,” the chief minister said. He said that what was of concern was that those in power in the Centre have not even come forward to condemn the brutal attack. “Now is the time for all secular minded people to come together and declare that the country will not accept the arrogance of the RSS,” he added.

The DYFI march which began from Tirur in Malappuram covered 54km to reach Kozhikode Beach.

Title: Don’t obstruct those wanting to work: HC
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kochi: The high court on Monday directed police to ensure that employees who come to the main office of Muthoot Finance to work are not physically obstructed or assaulted by employees on strike.

Justice A Muhamed Mustaque also ordered that the employees of Muthoot Securities Ltd’s office at Kadavanthra should be given adequate police protection. The court also directed that protests should not be allowed within 50 metres of the Kadavanthra office.

The court’s directive came on pleas by the manager and employees of the main office and by employees of the Kadavanthra office. They had alleged that employees who are willing to work are being threatened and assaulted by those on strike.

The petitions also said that the protests being conducted against the alleged move to dismiss some employees and close down some branches have turned violent. The protests are being conducted by Non-banking and Private Finance Employees Association (CITU). The protestors are not allowing those willing to work to enter their offices and are assaulting them, the petitions had said while seeking police protection.

The petitioners had also alleged that even though there is an earlier order banning protests within 15m of the offices, the protestors are not obeying the order.

The court, in its order, also directed for making the chief secretary, home secretary, and the state police chief parties in the case.

The court also asked the petitioners why the management was not made a party in the petitions and directed to make them a party. The court asked for making the company management a party in the cases after labour department alleged that management’s representatives are not participating in labour discussions regarding the strike.

Title: Corpn to act against pumping stns letting out untreated water
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Corporation commissioner S Visakan on Monday warned of strict action against officials if untreated sewage water is let out from pumping stations which are meant to pump water to treatment plants.

Madurai corporation has two sewage treatment plants at Vellaikkal and Sakkimangalam, where water is pumped through pumping stations located in various places in the city. While there are large-scale complaints that untreated water is being discharged from the pumping stations to the nearby water bodies, the commissioner warned against the activity at a meeting held at Anna Maaligai.

He also instructed engineering officials to identify the places where sewage water from residential areas enter river Vaigai. A detailed project report has to be prepared to address the issue and he also instructed them to levy fine from those who litter the river with garbage. He asked them to submit a report every day on the garbage processed at the micro composting yards.

Visakan also asked sanitation officials to visit toilets in the city and ensure they have 24 hours running water supply. Action has to be taken against contractors who are not maintaining the toilet clean. The commissioner also instructed officials to carry out inspections to effectively implement plastic ban. Meanwhile, a corporation health inspector found banned plastic bags in use at four shops on Monday and levied fines totalling Rs 17, 000. A total of 68 shops were inspected at Mattuthavani.

Title: Plea to amend state’s bovine breeding Act
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: The Tamil Nadu Bovine Breeding Act will destroy the native breeds of jallikattu bulls in the name of enhancing milk production and this should not be implemented, said the Jallikattu training centre.

In a petition, the state secretary of the centre, P Ranjith, has said that the Act paves way for production of female calves and eliminates males. This will affect the breeding and propagation of the native breeds of bulls, which are used for the jallikattu.

As the Act has made it mandatory for the bull owners to get fitness certificates for bulls from veterinarians, it will restrict natural cross breeding between the native breeds. The Rs 50,000 fine will further affect the breeding of native breeds.

The Act should be suitably amended to promote native breeds also. As this was the jallikattu season, they had decided to bring it to the notice of the collector, he said.

Ranjith says that the government should hold consultations with all the organisations working with native breeds of cows before implementing the Act. Also, the online registration of jallikattu bulls, which cannot be done by all the game players, should be withdrawn, he said.

Title: Delhi has more people than Greece & New Zealand
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi’s population is now higher than the population of countries like New Zealand, Greece, Sweden, Zimbabwe and the Netherlands. It has officially crossed two crore, according to the data released by the Election Commission of India, with the announcement of the upcoming assembly elections.

The officially estimated population of 2.01 crore in 2020 is more than the population of 140 countries/territories for which both population and area data is available, though Delhi’s area is tiny in comparison to many of them.

The largest country by area with fewer people than India’s capital is Kazakhstan. The country that is spread over 27 lakh square km has an estimated population of 1.88 crore. This means its population is 93.4% of Delhi’s, while its area is 1,819 times as large. Similarly Zimbabwe has 73.9% of Delhi’s population and is 261 times the area.

There are over 50 countries with higher populations than Delhi. Even among these, many have a slightly higher population but are over thousand times bigger in area. Canada for example has a population which is 1.9 times of Delhi and an area that is 6,128 times the size of India’s capital. Similarly, Australia is 5,183 times the size of Delhi with just 1.3 times its population. Argentina and Saudi Arabia are also over a thousand times Delhi’s size with only slightly higher population.

All of this is just the National Capital Territory. The population of the Delhi Urban Agglomeration (UA) — the continuous urban spread that includes Ghaziabad, Noida, Gurgaon and Faridabad — is by far the largest in the country. The UN estimates for Delhi UA’s population at three crore for 2020, a crore more than the Mumbai UA. Other UAs with population over a crore are Kolkata, Bengaluru, Chennai and Hyderabad.

Delhi UA was the second fastest growing among these six. Between 2010 and 2020, Delhi UA saw a decadal population growth of 38% less only than Bangalore’s 49% in this period.

Delhi UA is also, after Tokyo, the world’s second largest continuous urban spread. Tokyo has an estimated 3.7 crore people living in the city and adjoining overgrowths. Shanghai, Sao Paulo, Dhaka, Cairo and Beijing are next on the list of the world’s biggest UAs. Among the 10 largest, Dhaka saw the fastest growth between 2010 and 2020 while Delhi came second on this count.

Title: University exams: Kerala government may scrap internal marks in future
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

KOZHIKODE: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan , on Monday, said the government was planning to scrap internal marks for college students across the state in future.

Vijayan, who was taking part in the Chief Minister’s Student Leaders Conclave at Farook College , was responding to concerns raised by college union representatives about students being victimised in the name of internal marks. The event, aimed to engage student leaders and elicit their view in the state’s development, was attended by college union representatives from six universities and Kerala Kalamandalam ( deemed university ).

Vijayan, in his reply speech, said steps were being taken to ensure that students don’t fail because of poor performance in internals. “We are planning to do away with it (internal marks) in the future,” the chief minister said.

Later state higher education minister K T Jaleel told media that already the government had been able to partially put an end to victimisation of students in the name of internal marks by implementing a decision in Kerala Technological University (KTU) that there’s no need to have separate minimum marks for internal assessment. “We will make the decision applicable for other universities in the next academic year, he said.

Citing that protection of the Constitution was the need of the hour, the chief minister said steps would be taken to make reading of the Preamble of the Constitution in school assemblies mandatory.

Responding to a demand from students on the need to have 50% reservation for women in college unions, the chief minister said the demand was just and the government will give serious consideration to it as the proportion of women students in colleges was increasing.

He said steps would be taken to ensure that university libraries function round-the-clock. There would be no restrictions in library timings for girl students, he added.

Title: Activist Sadaf Jafar and ex-IPS officer SR Darapuri to walk out of jail today
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sadaf Jafar

LUCKNOW: Activist Sadaf Jafar and ex-IPS officer SR Darapuri will spend one more night in the jail because Legal formalities for their release could not be completed by Monday evening. They are expected to be released on Tuesday morning.

A local court had granted bail to them on Saturday. They were arrested on charges of instigating violence in Lucknow during anti-citizenship law protests on December 19.

The news of delay in release was broken by Sadaf’s sister Naheed Varma on her Facebook account. “Another day of wait…Sadaf Jafar and Darapuri ji get released tomorrow. The bail procedures take long!” (sic),” Naheed posted.

“Anxiously waiting for her release on Tuesday morning. A bit disappointed with a day’s delay. Had completed all the formalities by 4.30 pm but the person who takes the release order from court to jail had already left by that time because his working hours were over,” wrote Naheed.

Ved Darapuri, son of the ex-IPS officer, too, was disappointed. “The release will now take place on Tuesday, hopefully in the morning itself, because all our paperwork is now complete. Only release order has to be delivered to the jail,” Ved told TOI.

While Sadaf was arrested on December 19 from Parivartan Chowk in Lucknow while she was filming the violence and alerting police, Darapuri was placed under house arrest on December 19 but arrested the next day and booked for conspiracy.

There was nationwide uproar against their arrests.

Title: Hyderabad tops in bank frauds in south India
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: In a dubious distinction, Hyderabad has topped in banking frauds in south India. Out of 11 major frauds reported in 2019, seven cases have its origins in Hyderabad. Bengaluru and Chennai have two such cases each, according to a CBI data.

The fraud amount crossed Rs 4,500 crore involving Hyderabad-based companies alone, Banking Securities and Fraud Cell (BSFC), a unit of CBI based in Bengaluru, said.

In many cases, bank officials were not named as accused. Also, 2019 saw an increase in banking frauds when compared to 2018, a fact confirmed by the Central Crime Station (CCS) sleuths.

Apart from this, two cases of banking frauds pertaining to Telangana have been registered with the Economic Offences Bureau (EOB) of CBI, Chennai, and 11 cases of frauds with ACB, Hyderabad.

In the latest case involving Transstroy (India) Ltd, a construction company owned by former TDP MP Rayapati Sambasiva Rao, Rs 3,822 crore was diverted and Union Bank of India reported a loss of Rs 300 crore. The total NPA was Rs 8,500 crore, sleuths said.

According to CBI data, politician Vakati Narayana Reddy-owned VNR Infra duped banks of Rs 62 crore. The CBI-Bengaluru cell registered a case in July 2019 in this regard. In another case booked with CBI in the same month last year, Hyderabad-based Musaddilal Jewellers Exporters Private Ltd duped Indian Overseas Bank to the tune of Rs 75 crore.

Totem Infra duped IDBI of Rs 220 crore, while Union Bank of India was cheated by Minerva Executive Apartments of Rs 35 crore. Syndicate Bank suffered a loss of Rs 46 crore at the hands of South India Exim, while SBI suffered Rs 30-crore loss thanks to Quench Soft. PCH Corporation is accused of cheating banks of Rs 28 crore.

In cases booked with EOB-Chennai, BNR Infra was accused of causing a loss of Rs 8 crore to SBI. Sudhanshu Exim Pvt Ltd caused Rs 8.7 crore loss to the banks.

Anti-corruption activist M Padmanabha Reddy explained that no fraud can happen without active connivance of senior bank officials. “CBI should go after the bank officials and big corporates. In many cases, bankers are not even filing complaints against the companies,” he told TOI.

When contacted, CCS DCP Avinash Mohanty said banking frauds had seen a rise in 2019 when compared to 2018. “We have received several cases of banking frauds, with some running into several lakhs.

Title: Four decades after Behmai carnage, judgment expected on January 18
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

An accused dacoit Posa being taken to the court in Kanpur Dehat (left) and government counsel Rajiv Porwal

KANPUR: The specially-constituted dacoity affected area court of Kanpur Dehat is expected to pronounce verdict on January 18 on the massacre of 20 people in Behmai village, allegedly by bandit Phoolan Devi, nearly four decades ago.

The special court was expected to deliver the verdict in the 1981 Behmai massacre case on Monday. But it allowed the defence counsel to submit some citations of superior courts in favour of his clients by January 16. The court has now listed the case for January 18, when the judgment is expected on the role of the four arrested accused — Posa, Bhikha, Vishwanath and Ram Singh.

District government counsel (criminal) Rajiv Porwal told TOI, “On an application of defence counsel Girish Narain Dubey on previous date on December 19, the court had fixed January 6 for written arguments and delivery of judgment.”

“Dubey had urged before the court that he wanted to file some rulings and sought appropriate time, after which presiding officer Sudhir Kumar had fixed January 6 as submission of written argument and judgment order. But the defence counsel once again preferred an application today (January 6) and sought more time.”

“Allowing the application, the presiding judge asked the defence counsel to file citations by January 16 while the judgment would be delivered on January 18,” the district government counsel told TOI.

A large crowd of media persons was present in the Kanpur Dehat court premises to hear the verdict in the case, which had shocked the country on February 14, 1981. Phoolan Devi a.k.a. ‘Bandit Queen’, who later turned to politics, and her gang members were accused of killing 20 people belonging to the Thakur community at Behmai village under Sikandara police jurisdiction in Kanpur Dehat on February 14, 1981.

According to the case file, Phoolan with the help of four gangs of Ram Autar, Mustuqeem, Ramkesh and Lalloo had raided Behmai situated on the banks of river Yamuna to take revenge from Thakurs of the village and dacoit Lala Ram and Shri Ram, who had allegedly exploited her for several days in the village.

UP police had failed to arrest Phoolan after the massacre. She had later surrendered before the MP police and spent her jail period in Gwalior and Jabalpur jails.

Phoolan contested legal battle with UP police in Behmai case. She had challenged various orders passed by the Kanpur Dehat court but never appeared before the trial court in Kanpur Dehat. She was later elected as a member of Parliament on Samajwadi Party ticket. She was shot dead by one Sher Singh Rana in 2001 in New Delhi.

During the trial, besides Phoolan, other accused Ram Autar, Mustuqeem, Balram, Moti, Vrindavan, Ram Prakash, Rampal, Lallu Baghel, Balwan, Lallu Yadav, Ram Shankar, Jaggan, Prem, Nanda and Baladeen had died and cases against them abated.

The families of the victims were hopeful that justice, which has eluded them for the last 39 years after the carnage, would be delivered today but had to return disappointed.

Porwal said around two dozen villagers of Behmai were in court campus and several of them were in court when the hearing was going on in post-lunch session.

Title: BJP likely to announce new Kerala president by January 15
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BJP flag

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The BJP will announce its new state president by January 15. The process of identifying a candidate, most probably through consensus, is nearing completion.

BJP national spokesperson and central committee member GVL Narasimha Rao and BJP joint general secretary (organization) Shiv Prakash are expected to reach Kerala on Tuesday for the final round of discussions before the official announcement of the new state president of the party, a position that remained vacant after the appointment of former state president P S Sreedharan Pillai as Mizoram governor in October, 2019.

BJP state general secretaries K Surendran and M T Ramesh remain the frontrunners to the post, though a few other names, including that of party national executive member Sobha Surendran, are also doing the rounds. “An election to the post of state president is highly unlikely. There are more than one candidates, all from the state itself. But, as is to everybody’s knowledge, the central leadership reserves the right in choosing the ‘right’ candidate,” sources close to the developments said.

The leaders in Kerala appear more content this time around as the central leadership has at least stopped the practice of announcing the party chief without much consultations with the state leaders.

“If the opinion of RSS is decisive, chance rests with Ramesh than Surendran. But the preference of RSS state leadership is highly unlikely to influence the selection process this time and several key factors could work in favour of Surendran,” said a BJP leader.

Union minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan and BJP general secretary (organization) B L Santhosh, who dons the role of a main conduit between RSS and BJP, nationally, have already put their weight behind Surendran.

BJP former state president Kummanam Rajasekharan is likely to be asked to take over the organizational work at the national level. The list of new district presidents of the party would be ready by January 9.

BJP national secretary H Raja and BJP Karnataka president Nalin Kumar Kateel are among a group of national leaders with whom the party has entrusted the task of coordinating the election of district committee presidents.

District presidents have been finalized in Kasaragod, Kannur, Kozhikode and Wayanad in north Kerala and Thiruvananthapuram in south. Though efforts were on to evolve a consensus on candidates for key positions, the party is not averse to conducting elections in districts where more than one candidate stay put in the fray.

The party has set 55 years as upper age limit for state presidents. Though there is rumour that the upper age limit of state president would be 65, clarity is yet to descend on such matters.

Title: Stray cow attacks elderly priest in Wadi; owner booked
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Vadodara: A priest living in Wadi area was severely injured when a stray cow attacked him near his house on Sunday. The 68-year-old priest Dilip Rajgor registered a case against the owner of the cow on Monday.

According to Rajgor, when he was walking to a temple situated near Mandvi, a cow walked towards him. Rajgor moved towards the other side of the narrow street, but the cow too moved towards him and hit him with its horn. Rajgor fell on the road and a couple of women living there came to his rescue. The left side of his torso was badly injured and he began bleeding profusely.

Rajgor was taken to his home and his son rushed him to SSG Hopital for treatment. After treating his injury, doctors discharged Rajgor in the evening.

On Monday morning, Rajgor went to Wadi police station to lodge a complaint. He told police that the owner of the cow lets the bovine stray around due to which pedestrians’ and commuters’ lives are put at risk. Based on his complaint, cops registered an offence of attempt to culpable homicide against the unidentified cow rearer.

Lately, VMC has been going slow on impounding stray cattles. The menace had, however, reached alarming levels during monsoon. Even now the cow owners let their cattle loose on city roads late in the night and take them back in the early hours. Due to the presence of cows, the roads are littered with their droppings making them slippery for early morning commuters.

Title: Congress picks Reginaldo as chief party whip
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Porvorim: The Congress Legislature Party met on Monday at the Assembly complex where the five Congress MLAs decided to appoint Curtorim MLA Reginaldo Lo as the chief party whip. Opposition leader Digamabar Kamat made the announcement, and also said that the party had decided to question the state government’s financial policies.

“The financial condition of the state is bad. I have heard that schools have not got maintenance grants. Development grants for each constituency have not been released,” said Kamat.

Former chief minister Luizinho Faleiro said that for the last three years, the state government has failed to sanction the promised Rs 25 crores and Rs 5 crores for planned and unplanned development projects for each constituency. The decline in tourism, rise in drug trafficking and rising debt are other concerns that Congress plans to raise in the coming Assembly session. TNN

Title: Madurai: 80 held for stir over organizing jallikattu
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: As many as 80 people, including 21 women, were arrested by the police on Monday for trying to block the road at Avaniapuram in protest against the district collector’s order giving “secondary preference” to the traditional people in organizing the renowned jallikattu event there.

Tension prevailed in the region in the morning as police pickets were placed and announcements made through the public announcement system asking people to refrain from believing social media posts and attempting to gather unlawfully on the roads. However, many people came on to the streets around 11 am. Villagers say they have been conducting the sport for over a century till A K Kannan came in as organizer and renamed the organizing committee as Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal Sangam. He formed an eight-member committee to conduct the game under its name which was opposed by the other villagers who wanted proper representation.

The villagers say there are complex rules in the village which say that only those who own cultivable land can be members of Thenkal Vivasayigal Sangam. However, they point out that there are traditional families which have been living in the village for years but do not own land now. They allege that Kannan is an outsider who has gained entrance into their village by buying land in Avaniapuram and is now trying to usurp their rights with political influence. He was close to the local ministers and MLA as they all belong to the same community.

K R Murugan, organizer of Veerakulam Amarar Iyakkam, claims there are 14 communities in Avaniapuram. But, instead of giving importance to the real leaders of each community in the organizing committee, Kannan was handpicking members from other communities to support his activities. He was also denying first rights to the village head, (nattamai).

Two peace committee meetings have so far been conducted by the district administration in this regard. It was decided on January 3 to name the organizing committee “Avaniapuram oor makkal vizha kuzhu”. However, the collector told them it would have to be called Avaniapuram Grama Pothu Makkal mattrum Thenkal Pasana Vivasayigal Sangam and that Kannan would be the president of the organizing committee. The villagers say the name Thenkal Vivasayigal sangam should not come in the name of the committee. Cases were registered under sections 143 and 341 of the IPC against the protesting public and they were released in the evening.

When contacted, district collector Dr T G Vinay said since Kannan has the experience of conducting the game after the court order, they had asked him to continue. However, he does not have any right to choose the other members like treasurer and secretary. The villagers were authorised to unanimously decide on their choice for these posts. The district administration would also monitor the funds, he said.

Title: Two youths beaten to death in powerloom unit
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Erode: Two labourers from Bihar working in a powerloom unit were found beaten to death in the room they were staying in Erode district on Monday.

Police have arrested another Bihari youth on suspicion for the murders. Police suspect that three were peddling ganja and a dispute over sharing of money resulted in a fatal attack.

Police identified the deceased as L Navin Kumar, 25 and S Sukendra Kumar, 28. According to police, the deceased along with Ravindra Kumar, also hailing from Bihar, were working in the powerloom unit owned by Ramesh of Kavundhapadi in Erode. The three were staying in a room on the powerloom unit premises.

Preliminary investigations revealed that the three had consumed liquor on Sunday night when a quarrel erupted between them. In a fit of rage, Ravindra Kumar assaulted Navin and Sukendra with steel rod used in the unit.

The two collapsed in a pool of blood and died on the spot.

Ramesh, who came to the powerloom unit in the morning, saw the two lying on the floor dead and informed police, who reached the spot. A sniffer dog was also brought to the spot. Since Ravindra Kumar was the only other person who was at the unit along with the victims, police interrogated him, during which he spilled the beans.

Inquiries also revealed that the three were selling ganja in the locality and used to share the returns. Quarrels were frequent among the three over sharing of cash and one such quarrel broke out on Sunday night too which resulted in the double murder.

Police however are continuing the probe to find if anyone else was involved in the illegal ganja sale and the clash.

Title: In a first, IISER completes genome sequencing of wild tiger
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bhopal: For the first time, the genome sequencing of a wild tiger has been completed in the country. An IISER-Bhopal team has completed genome and transcriptome sequencing and analysis of a wild tiger for the first time in the country. Sequencing was done from the sample of a man-eater tiger, Bandhu, who was brought at Van Vihar two years ago. Genome sequencing is a way to figure out the order of DNA nucleotides, or bases, in a genome.

Their study was also recently published in international journal 'Nature Scientific Reports 2019'. The associate professor, department of biological sciences, Vineet K. Sharma, said the genomic studies on this highly endangered species are much needed since its population has rapidly declined in the past due to human interventions.

He said that tiger is the largest feild species and has diverse morphological and behavioural adaptations required for its survival and predation. “To study the genetic basis of such adaptations in tiger, our group generated the first genomic sequence of an Indian tiger,” said Sharma. “As we have done it now, further studies will be possible within country itself,” he added.

“An understanding of the genetic basis of its phenotypic adaptations may help in designing more effective strategies for conservation and breeding of tiger,,” said associate professor, Sharma. Other members of the team were Parul Mittal, Shubham K Jaiswal, Nagarjun Vijay and Rituja Saxena.

Sharma claimed that they have even found the correct genome sequencing in their study. “The tiger genome had been sequenced earlier by a Chinese group, but we noted that the genome assembly (PanTig1.0) consisted of several erroneous nucleotide substitutions, and thus it was giving wrong information. We have now corrected the study,” said Sharma.

He added that usage of the earlier assembly led to several incorrect results in previous studies. “We developed an assembly error correction tool ‘SeqBug’, and corrected almost one million bases in the tiger genome assembly, which map to 4,472 genes,” said Sharma.

The team deciphered the genetic basis of the evolution of tiger's lineage using the corrected genome which were further validated by the re-sequenced genome and transcriptome of the tiger.

Title: ‘No-vehicle day’ mandatory at Nanded University, its centres
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Aurangabad: In an eco-friendly measure, Swami Ramanand Teerth Marathwada (SRTM) University, Nanded, has started a ‘no vehicle day’ on its campus.

It is also mandatory for all to comply with the rules and those failing to do so will have to pay a fine of Rs 200.

Ashok Kadam, public relations officer of SRTM University said the initiative was a part of ‘clean & green’ campus movement launched by the university.

“The campaign is the brainchild of Vice-Chancellor Udhav Bhosle. We have appealed to all students, teachers, non-teaching staff and visitors to support the initiative. It is a small step towards making the entire campus an eco-friendly one,” he said.

The ‘no vehicle day’ has also been made mandatory for university sub-centres at Latur and Parbhani along with the university-managed degree college at Hingoli.

The maiden ‘no vehicle day’ observed at SRTM and other identified institutions recently witnessed 100% response, authorities said.

The visitors with the vehicles were asked to park their vehicles outside the campus.

“Youth have more receptive minds and it is an ideal age to inculcate the importance of the environment in them. The ‘clean & green’ campus movement aims to shape the minds of students in such a way that they would be aware of existing and future challenges related to the ecological balance,” Kadam said.

“Taking a cue from the university’s initiative, we hope that the affiliated colleges also observe ‘no vehicle day’, which aims to bring down the noise and air pollution,” university authorities said.

Title: Dahod girls set to hit disability out of ground
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Geeta Damor (in pic) and Lalita Damor have made the cut for the first camp for selection of girls for national... Read More

Vadodara: Hailing from nondescript villages in the tribal heartland of Gujarat, these two differently abled girls are eyeing to wield the willow and swing the cherry like any other man or woman who steps on the cricket ground. The two girls are among those who made the cut for the first camp for selection of girls for the first national disabled women’s cricket team.

The camp was organized in November and the two girls from Dahod were among the 31 women picked up for further training. The efforts for a disabled women’s cricket team for the country have been taken up by Divyang Cricket Control Board of India (DCCBI).

The two girls selected from Dahod had no previous experience of playing cricket and belong to remote villages where girls hardly play the game. It was their teacher at an Industrial Training Institute (ITI) in Ahmedabad who guided them to the camp organized by director (cricket operations) of DCCBI, Nitendra Singh.

Geeta Damor, who had completed her ITI course in computers and was working at a unit in Sanand, decided to give up her job to ensure that she could attend training sessions regularly. “I was not getting much at the job and was keen to play cricket and hence decided to attend the camp,” she said. Geeta’s father works as a mason and her mother takes up labour work when she is not busy with household work.

Like Geeta, Lalita Damor too was a student of the ITI, but had quit her beautician’s course. She had lost her father in 2007 and it was her mother who was bringing her up. The family was dependent on agriculture. Lalita has a disability in her left leg due to polio and has to use a stick. “I am interested in cricket and would like to continue playing,” she said.

Geeta, Lalita and others come to Vadodara every weekend for practice after the camp ended last month. They had interest in sports earlier too and a teacher at their ITI had directed them to Singh for cricket coaching.

Geeta (25) is from Pukda village of Fatehpura taluka and Lalita (23) hails from Dumka village of Dhanpura taluka in Dahod.

Title: CM Pinarayi Vijayan condoles death of former Kerala governor T N Chaturvedi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Monday condoled the death of former governor of the state Triloki Nath Chaturvedi. In his condolence message, the chief minister said as a governor and the comptroller and auditor general of the country, Chaturvedi did an exemplary service.

Ninety-year-old Chaturvedi, who was the governor of Karnataka, held the additional post of governor of the state for a brief period of four months. He was handed over the charge after the sudden demise of the then governor Sikader Bhakt. He handed over the post to R L Bhatia after holding the post from February 25, 2004 to June 23, 2004, a transition period from the first NDA government led by Atal Bihari Vajpayee to first UPA government led by Manmohan Singh.

Chaturvedi was the CAG from 1984 to 1989 and was the governor of Karnataka from 2002 to 2007. He also held several key posts after demitting the office of governor in 2007. As an IAS officer, he had held the posts of chief secretary of Delhi administration, chief commissioner of Chandigarh, director of Indian Institute of Public Administration, secretary of ministries including education, culture and sports and home affairs.

Title: State braces for 24-hr shutdown
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The 24-hour all-India strike called by 10 major trade unions, including CITU and INTUC, is all set to paralyze normal life in the state from Tuesday midnight. The joint action council, which comprises major trade unions except BMS which is affiliated to the BJP, told reporters on Monday that they expected a ‘joint strike’ the state or the country has never witnessed before.

Unlike during the previous occasions, the sentiments against the anti-people policies of the central government is much strong and widespread, union leaders said, adding that they expected even BMS, ‘which has not yet announced support or opposition’, to extend moral support. Vehicles, including private ones, will keep off the roads, while all trade and commercial establishments and shops will remain closed, they said.

The general strike has exempted tourism sector and vehicles carrying Sabarimala pilgrims, besides essential services like hospital, milk and newspaper. “The tourism sector has been raising this demand – to exempt the sector from hartals and strikes – and we have taken a favourable decision, especially in case of foreign tourists who are on packaged tours,” said MP Elamaram Kareem, who is CITU state general secretary.

Joining the strike will be Centre/state employees, those in banking and insurance sectors and BSNL employees besides farmers, who have called for a ‘grameena (rural) hartal’ on Wednesday.

“The strike, which is mainly against the anti-labour policies of the NDA government and privatization of PSUs, will also inspire to strengthen the ongoing and widespread agitation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. We make an appeal to people working in both organized and unorganized sectors, including those working in the IT sector and in shopping malls, to join the protest and strike work on Wednesday,” Kareem said.

Trade unions are demanding a hike in the minimum wage of workers to Rs 21,000, a minimum pension of Rs 10,000 for all workers, skip plans to privatize PSUs, back out from amending labour laws to favour employers, prevent price rise, strengthen public distribution system, ensure farmers a fair price for their products, waive off their debts, solve unemployment issues and prevent the spread of communalism.

Leaders also said that the strike will have a greater impact in states like West Bengal, Maharashtra , Bihar and Chhattisgarh . AISBIEA general secretary K S Krishna , in a statement, said, “Banking sector issues like burgeoning bad loans and their write-off, unwarranted bank mergers, diminishing interest rates and returns for depositors and staff shortage will be in focus”.

The Reserve Bank employees will also join the strike.

Title: Cops should immediately stop violence, restore peace: Delhi CM
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Politicians across party lines have condemned the attacks on the students and teachers of Jawaharlal Nehru University on Sunday night.

Aam Aadmi Party chief Arvind Kejriwal held a meeting with senior party functionaries at his residence to discuss the situation. “A woman professor was attacked and women students were subjected to violence. AAP is concerned. The Centre must immediately intervene and restore peace,” AAP Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh said. “Delhi is the capital of the country and it should remain peaceful. Such incidents of violence send out a bad image of the country,” Singh said. The pictures speak volume about the nature of violence, he added.

CM Kejriwal requested LG Anil Baijal to act. “I am so shocked to know about the violence at JNU . Students attacked brutally. Police should immediately stop violence and restore peace. How will the country progress if our students will not be safe inside univ campus?,” Kejriwal asked on Twitter after the attack.

Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra said that Union home minister Amit Shah should own up moral responsibility for the attack on students by goons and tender his resignation. People of Delhi were now living in fear, he added.

Union minister Prakash Javadekar blamed Congress, AAP and Left parties for violence. “Some elements along with a group from the Congress, the AAP and the Communists knowingly want to create an atmosphere of violence across the country and especially in universities,” he stated on Twitter seeking inquiry.

Title: Ex-CM Harish Rawat visits MP Baluni in Mumbai
Content: Dehradun: Former Uttarakhand chief minister and senior Congress leader Harish Rawat met BJP Rajya Sabha MP Anil Baluni , who is undergoing treatment for cancer, to inquire about his health. During the meeting, Rawat wished him a speedy recovery.“Baluni is young and energetic. I hope that he defeats cancer soon,” said Rawat. The ex-CM was accompanied by Congress Rajya Sabha MP Pradeep Tamta.According to Baluni’s doctors, his health is improving and he will be healthy soon.Earlier, cancer survivors Yuvraj Singh and Manisha Koirala had also met Baluni in the hospital.

Title: From Selection Of Site To Species, Plan Was Unscientific: Experts
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nagpur: An expert firm, a well-protected site and lessons from the past weren’t enough to resuscitate over a dozen mature trees that were uprooted for transplantation by MahaMetro.

In a hat-trick of disasters for the agency’s transplantation efforts, around 16 trees dug out from different birth places and replanted at a part of Ambazari reserve forest in Wadi look as dead as a doornail. Once-upon-a-time green and growing, today they are leafless and withered.

On entering the forest from the gate near Kachimet, Amravati Road, one is welcomed by a graveyard of trees, which looks similar to MahaMetro’s previous transplantation site at Patwardhan high school premises in Sitabuldi.

On receiving a tip-off about the failed transplantation, TOI first visited the spot on December 28 with honorary wildlife warden of Nagpur Jaydeep Das. Just like the relocated trees at Sitabuldi, the ones here stood barren, with no indications of regrowth of branches or leaves. The trunks were dried-up, with bark of many trees peeling off.

The first fault that Das pointed out was the site selection. “This part of Ambazari forest is grassland. Transplanting or even planting trees in this land type will damage the biodiversity of grassland habitat. Not only will the trees struggle to survive, the species of various birds and animals found in grassland will get adversely affected,” he said.

While experts suggest transplantation of only ficus species, exotic trees have also been transplanted. Pointing to an Ashoka tree, Das raised questions on the selection of tree species for the process. “The trees have also been transplanted right under a huge canopy of existing trees to camouflage the absence of leaf growth,” he alleged.

This is the third time that MahaMetro’s transplantation efforts have failed. Earlier, around 15 trees transplanted at a residential society in Mihan and 21 transplanted at the school premises could not survive. When TOI started digging out details of the botched up transplantations, this reporter received several polite requests not to publish the report.

In an official statement to TOI, MahaMetro stated that the transplanted trees were uprooted from different locations like Kadbi Square, Kamptee Road, Ambedkar Square and Central Avenue. “Overall, 16 trees were removed from their locations and transplanted at the site,” it added.

Further informing that the trees belong to different species like mango, drumstick, Ashoka, kadu-neem, umbar etc, the agency’s statement stressed that the all trees have shown signs of survival. “In case of transplantation, the growth of trees is slow and we expect them to grow more in the coming days. The fact that the bark of some trees is still green is an indication of their growth,” it stated.

While transplanting trees in Sitabuldi, Metro spent nearly Rs10 lakh of public money. “This time, we have not released any payment yet. As per our agreement, we will only pay the agency if the trees survive,” he said.

According to the spokesperson, MahaMetro has now given the transplantation work to a Hyderabad-based expert agency which has also conducted similar work in Pune.

To reaffirm the survival rate of trees, TOI revisited the spot with a transplantation expert who wished to remain anonymous. On checking the conditions of the bark, the expert concluded that almost all trees were dead and the transplantation process has failed. He peeled off the bark to show that there was no moisture or any signs of life in the trees.

As per MahaMetro, the trees were relocated during August last year. “If they had to re-grow, it would have happened latest by October. Despite various spells of rain, they didn’t regrow,” the expert said.

Apart from him, members of Green Vigil Foundation also accompanied TOI to the site. After inspecting the condition of all the transplanted trees, the group noted that the survival rate was abysmally low. “The process has gone miserably wrong. Huge trees have been planted at a distance of hardly 5-6 feet. How will they grow? It’s the same scene that we saw in Patwardhan ground in Sitabuldi where most of the trees have dried up,” said Kaustav Chatterjee, founder of Green Vigil.

While MahaMetro had stated that five trees have developed new foliage, all the experts disagreed. “In one or two tree, few leaves are growing at the bottom of the trunk. But most likely, they won’t survive as the upper trunk is completely dead,” said Chatterjee.

Environment activist Shrikant Deshpande, who also inspected the spot, agreed that the transplantation process had failed. “Many trees died because they were species which can’t be transplanted,” he said.

After validation from experts, the final official authentication came from the civic body. In the third and final visit to the spot on January 3, a team of officials from Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s garden department carried out a spot inspection. According to them, only pipal, banyan, umbar, drumstick and chaafa species can be transplanted.

Though officials appreciated MahaMetro’s efforts for taking up the process, they agreed that the survival rate was zero.

Title: PWD moots diaphragm wall to halt Shanghumugham erosion
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

restoration path: PWD received administrative sanction to revive Shanghumugham beach road at a cost of Rs 4.29... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Shanghumugham beach is at the mercy of the sea, which takes large chunks off it especially during the monsoon season. Now, the public works department has decided to fight back — experimenting with the diaphragm wall.

And when the PWD recently received administrative sanction to revive the stretch, at a cost of Rs 4.29 crore, it decided to tap the expertise of the Central Road Research Institute, which provided the design for the diaphragm wall, which can sustain high-intensity waves. To prevent scouring of the soil, an armour unit, mostly consisting of interlocked stone units of 120kg each, will be positioned in front of the wall, which will be 260m long, 0.50m wide and 8m high.

It is too early to cite a date for commencement of work, sources said, adding that the PWD will set up a technical team to review progress.

The diaphragm wall is a kind of retaining wall which can resist lateral pressure from soil or water. It is commonly used for construction of train subways. The wall is expected to have an inclination of 15 degrees.

The department had first invited tenders for the project in March 2019. However, it had to cancel the process as the election model code of conduct was in effect. It re-initiated the exercise last week. The office of the superintending engineer will open the documents on January 20. The chief minister’s distress relief fund will cough up the Rs 4.29 crore project cost.

In addition to construction of the wall, the PWD will renovate the beach road, which is currently in a dilapidated condition. Though a vast portion of the beach is damaged, people still throng the area, ignoring warnings. The contractor will have to dismantle existing concrete structures, the damaged Gabion wall and parts of the pavement for the work.

Title: Cops booked for injuring juvenile offender in station
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: A sub-inspector of police and a few unnamed policemen attached to the SS Colony police station were booked on Sunday on charges of injuring a juvenile offender during interrogation.

A five-member gang consisting of minors robbed a mobile phone and petty cash from Syed Hussain, 24, a data entry operator near Ellis Nagar Bridge late on December 18. Based on a complaint from Hussain from Pasumpon Nagar near Palanganatham, a case was registered under Section 395 of IPC (punishment for dacoity). The SS Colony police began a search and arrested a few people, including a juvenile.

When the police produced the juvenile to the Juvenile Justice Board (JJB) a few days after the incident so that he can be lodged in observation home in the city, the boy told the board about the torture that he underwent in the police station. He told the board that a police officer with two stars on his shoulder kicked him with his boots. A few more policemen in the station also joined and attacked him causing injuries. He was also beaten on his wrists using lathis.

While the boy was sent for medical treatment, based on a petition an internal inquiry was carried out on orders from the assistant commissioner of police Thilagar Thidal.

Meanwhile, an FIR was registered under IPC Section 323 – punishment for voluntarily causing hurt and Juvenile Justice (care and protection of children) Act, 2015 on a complaint from V Karthick, an assistant-cum-computer operator with the JJ Board.

Police officers said the name of the police sub-inspector or policemen have not been mentioned in the FIR.

A juvenile had died in hospital after developing complication in an alleged custodial torture in SS Colony police station in January last year. He was taken to the police station for theft-related inquiry.

Title: LUSU polls: TOI social media followers divided
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Lucknow: The high court’s decision to pave way for the Lucknow University Students’ Union (LUSU) elections has kept social media users busy of-late. After TOI reported a vertical split among LU students on LUSU polls on the campus after a gap of 15 years, reactions from people of the city flooded TOI’s social media handles. While many hailed the move saying that elections would be a good beginning for budding leaders, a few others stated that it would increase lawlessness on the campus.

Giving examples of social activists Kanhaiya Kumar and Shehla Rashid of JNU, Siddique Khan, a professor and former LU student, welcomed the move. “Student politics is an integral part of mainstream politics. If we have people like Kanhaiya and Shehla, it is only because of such opportunities,” said Khan.

Another Twitter user @vasvi1995 stated that conducting elections in universities can help young scions understand constitutional ideologies. “These elections help students know about the problems and loopholes in their education system and other issues related to students. Conducting elections in LU will be a good start for budding leaders,” said Vasvi Verma, adding that if students are considered to be the future of the nation, they should get a chance to serve in various fields, even politics and governance.

While a few supported the revival of elections, some social media users seemed to be against the LUSU polls owing to the past history of violence on the campus. An Instagram user posted that due to past instances where unions aligning with political parties resorted to violence on the campus, the elections should not be revived to save LU’s academic essence.

Saheba Ramzi Khan, an Instagram follower, said the definition of politics needs to be changed. “Politics has been majorly confused with bribery and gunda-gardi. It will be good to see well-groomed and educated politicians on the campus, but lawlessness should definitely be controlled.”

Title: Kochi students protest attack on JNU students & faculty
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

SFI workers at Maharaja’s College protest in Kochi on Monday

KOCHI: The mob attack at Jawaharlal Nehru University in Delhi has sparked a wave of protests among the students in Ernakulam.

SFI students of Maharajas College are conducting campaigns and protests inside their campus to make students aware of the prevailing situation at JNU. The college union and the sub-committee of the Association of Kerala Government College Teachers Bhavan organized a gathering inside the campus on Monday. It was inaugurated by senior lawyer Reshmitha Ramachandran who spoke about CAA and other violent acts happening in the country.

Neeraj Ramesh, a student from Maharajas said, “What happened at JNU is the death of democracy and this shouldn’t prevail. Students should stand together and raise their voice against the injustice.” Slogans and posters against the Centre reverberated in the campus. The students’ union will also conduct street plays and flash mobs around the city as part of the protest. They also aim to create public awareness about the situation. “We have coordinated with the drama club and dance club in organizing street plays and flash mobs around the city on Thursday,” said Bobins Joseph, SFI unit secretary, Maharaja’s College.

The Law College, Ernakulam is also conducting various campaigns and gathering in and around the campus in support of JNU students. A group of students gathered in front of the BSNL office around 2.30pm on Monday to voice their concern. They chanted slogans and burned the effigy of union home minister Amit Shah in front of the office.

Mohammad Rayan, one of the protesters said, “We blocked the entrance of the office and protested. The protest was peaceful.”

Title: Coimbatore: Woman lures man, blackmails him with video of them
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

Coimbatore: The rural police have formed a special team to nab a woman and four youths for recording private moments of a man with the woman and blackmailing him. The gang demanded Rs 25 lakh from the man and threatened him that they would release the video on social media if he refused to pay.

A police source said a businessman from RS Puram received a missed call two weeks ago. “When he called back the number, a woman attended the phone and told him that she wrongly dialed his number. However, she lured him by saying that she liked his voice. They started to chat and in three days, she invited him to her house near Anaimalai in Pollachi,” the source said.

“When the man went there, she left the door open to let the youths enter the house and record intimate moments between them. When the youths confronted him and snatched his mobile phones, gold chain and a ring as well as his car key, he came to know that the woman was part of the gang,” the source said.

A few days later, the gang demanded Rs 25 lakh from him. “They threatened to release the video in WhatsApp and other social media websites,” the source said. The man lodged a complaint with superintendent of police Sujit Kumar. Police said the woman was the mastermind behind the whole episode.

Title: Take strong action against drug peddlers: Commission
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala state commission for protection of child rights registered a suo-moto case against drug and narcotic peddlers whose presence in the precincts of schools in the state.

The commission chairman registered the case in view of various news reports in this regard.

“Sale of narcotics to children can attract jail term up to seven years as per the Child Rights Act . But, excise department is yet to get the nod for slapping this Act on those who peddle drugs to school children. Experience is such that people booked under feeble acts get out within hours after making payments of paltry sums as fine. It’s to firm up action against the drug and narcotic peddlers that commission intends to intervene,” a statement from the commission said here on Monday.

If police really cooperate with the drive against those who sell narcotic substance and drugs to children, culprits can be bundled into jails. Citing a rare instance, the commission pointed out the arrest and remand of persons who were hauled by excise officials in Kannur recently after they were caught red-handed with contrabands weighing 273kg stocked for sales among school children. Since the excise department officials were not given permission to use the laws effectively, culprits escape after paying a penalty of Rs 200, the statement said.

The commission asked chief secretary, state police chief, excise commissioner, general education director, LSGI director to file reports within two weeks on how they plan to implement the ban on sale of drugs and narcotics in the vicinity of schools.

Title: Conference of VCs begins at NI varsity
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Universities play a key role in helping teachers develop a strong pedagogical base, using which they shape the destiny of a multitude of students they interact with, Puducherry lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi said. She was inaugurating a conclave of university vice-chancellors at Noorul Islam University at Kuzhithurai in Kanyakumari district on Monday.

As many as 120 vice-chancellors participated in the two-day meeting organized by association of universities. All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) chairman Anil Sahasrabudhe delivered the keynote address at the inaugural function. The theme of the conference was ‘research, innovation and excellence in Indian universities’.

“Various papers on commercial outlook of research activities, its social impact were presented in the conference,” a statement from the university said.
