Noorul Islam University chancellor A P Majeed Khan, pro-chancellor M S Faizal Khan, academic pro-chancellor R Perumal Swamy would participate in the conference on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, representatives of save university campaign committee here called on the association of universities’ president M M Salunkhe and secretary general Pankaj Mittal.

The committee asked the association office bearers to press for a change in the alleged practice of governments not giving proper weightage to the academic excellence of candidates selected as vice-chancellors.

“The practice of giving weightage to some over the other because of political preferences should be abolished,” the committee chairman R S Sasikumar and convenor M Shajar Khan said in a memorandum submitted to the duo.

Title: Vyapam scam: STF registers four more FIRs
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh STF has registered four more FIRs related to Vyapam scam cases. This is in addition to the six FIRs that were registered by the STF in the scam during the last fortnight.

Fresh cases have been registered for impersonation in police constable recruitment scam, and submission of fake documents in medical entrance examination. With these four fresh cases, the agency has registered 10 cases so far.

ADG STF Ashok Awasthi told media that 197 old complaints were examined after which four candidates and their supporters were booked.

One of the accused has been identified as Bijendra Rawat. He had appeared for police constable exam in 2013. Investigations revealed mismatch in his signature and those found in the OMR sheet. Rawat is currently posted in Gwalior. ADG said that Rawat was impersonated in the entrance exam and therefore the signature mismatch has been detected.

Probe also revealed that three candidates had submitted forged domicile in the PMT 2009 and 2010 respectively. They were selected. The accused booked are Saurabh Sachan, Benezir Shah Farooqi and Vipin Kumar Singh. They had submitted forged domiciles of Rewa and Sidhi districts. They have completed their MBBS and their current posting is being inquired.

STF had initiated a probe into the 1,200 pending Vyapam complaints that haven’t been taken up by the CBI. Gwalior-based Ashish Chaturvedi and Indore-based Dr Anand Rai were summoned by the agency with documents related to around 150 complaints regarding ‘Vyapam scam’ that they had filed with the agency in the last four to five years.

CBI had taken over 180 of the 251 Vyapam cases from the STF after the Supreme Court handed over the probe to it in July 2015. At that time, STF had around 1,200 more complaints pending and they were all pushed to the backburner.

Nearly 3,000 people, including a state cabinet minister, MLAs and several high-ranking officials were booked or arrested by the STF in connection with the scam by the time CBI took over. Only a few cases are left where the central agency is yet to file charge-sheets.

Title: JNU officials apprise lieutenant governor of situation on campus
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Anil Baijal

NEW DELHI: Two top officials of Jawaharlal Nehru University on Monday met lieutenant governor Anil Baijal to apprise him of the situation in the wake of violence that broke out on the campus on Sunday, even as Delhi Police transferred the case to its crime branch.

Sources said the JNU registrar and pro-vice chancellor met the LG to brief him on Sunday’s events and the current situation on the campus. Earlier, home minister Amit Shah had spoken to Baijal and requested him to call representatives from JNU and hold talks.

Meanwhile, police have started collecting evidence by talking to JNU students , teachers and staff. The medico-legal case (MLC) formalities for 35 students, who were admitted to the AIIMS trauma centre and Safdarjung Hospital, have been completed.

Violence broke out at JNU on Sunday night as masked men armed with sticks and rods attacked students and teachers and damaged property on the campus, prompting the administration to call in police which conducted a flag march.

Title: Smart City gives a push to solar projects
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: SmartCity project has given a push to the solar energy projects in the city. Cochin Smart Mission Limited (CSML) has set up solar plants on the rooftops of 28 institutions in the city, thereby generating 1,000 kilowatts of energy.

Though CSML identified more than 60 institutions for setting up rooftop solar plants in the city, they could set up the plants at 28 institutions only.

“Most of the firms we identified were later proven to be not suitable for the project. Now, we have completed the works at 28 institutions,” an official with CSML said.

Presently, CSML authorities are carrying out the procedures to connect the plants at these firms to KSEB’s grid. “We have already connected the plants at six institutions, including Ernakulam General Hospital, with KSEB’s grid. Now, we are in the process of securing grid connectivity to other plants also,” the official said.

CSML has already earmarked Rs 10 crore for a public bicycle sharing project. As part of the project, they have procured 160 bicycles and set up 16 docking yards attached to the Metro stations in different parts of the city.

According to CSML, the green initiative will cut down the fuel consumption as well as pollution caused by fossil fuels.

“We are awaiting approvals from Kochi municipal corporation, Greater Cochin Development Authority (GCDA), Goshree Islands Development Authority (Gida), Kalamassery municipality and railways for opening docks at 34 more stations,” a CSML official said.

Title: Do you dig antique bells? This home museum will take its ‘toll’
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

‘BELL’WETHER: Latha Mahesh’s museum has 7,500 bells from over 90 countries

Thiruvananthapuram: When Latha Mahesh decided to ring the changes to her display cabinet she hit on the idea of adding antique bells. Thirty years and 7,500 pieces later, she has fondly christened the enclosure built to house her collection on the premises of her Vettakmukku , Thirumala residence as the Bell Museum

Latha is proud of the fact that all the bells in her collection are unique, with no repeats. “I have a collection of Ganesha idols and lamps, but there are many people who collect them. So, I hit on the idea of collecting bells from places I visit. Bells from three countries — Vietnam, Georgia and Azerbaijan — were sourced from friends and relatives. All the other ones were selected by me.”

The victory bell, made from the metal of a German warplane shot down over Britain during World War II holds a special place in the collection. She also has bells made from ceramic, metal, clay, porcelain, resin, amber stone, enamel, wedgewood, and cloisonne bells bought from over 90 countries, including the United States, Austria, China, Kenya, Latvia, Mexico, Japan, Italy and Croatia.

Her Indian collection includes brass and metal bells from Thanjavoor, Thiruvananthapuram, Jew Street in Kochi and the aramani (huge and heavy waist belt studded with bells) worn by velichappadu oracles in temples.

“I once went in search of bells in the UK based on information about a collection with a lady at Sevenoaks in Kent. I source around a hundred bells from every visit abroad. The whole house was earlier decorated with bells. I do not remember when it became a passion. It was only recently that I catalogued all the bells and got an enclosure where my collection is now displayed,” Latha said.

It was to support her passion that her husband N Mahesh built the enclosure. The structure is made of wood from a Canadian rainforest.

“I am the resource and Latha is the passion behind the museum. The idea was to make a lightweight structure, so we used timber,” said Mahesh.

A huge bell hanging near the glass ceiling is the most expensive piece here. The bell made of panchaloha (five metals) was bought from the bell metal town of Mannar for Rs 1.5 lakh.

Also displayed are wind chimes, Tibetan bowls and yak bells made of wood, which produce distinct sounds. Bells displaying Disney characters, US first ladies, birds, animals, bells for each month, Russian doll-shaped bells, prayer bells of Nepalese monks and a pewter bell with a handle engraving Jesus and his apostles add variety to the collection.

And Latha says she is far from done. She wishes to add a bell made from material used to fashion the Aranmula kannadi, which was suggested by a friend ... a real ‘bell’wether!

Title: Doc suspended for death of woman, foetus in Ramnad
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: A doctor at Ramanathapuram Government Hospital has been placed under suspension after a probe by a special team into the death of a pregnant woman and her foetus at the hospital during delivery.

On December 29, 23-year-old pregnant woman Keerthika and her foetus died due to a fatal allergic reaction that developed when she was administered a drug to induce labour pain at the hospital. Later, the angry kin of Keerthika had protested outside the hospital alleging medical negligence by doctors and an inquiry was initiated. A state team reporting directly to Tamil Nadu health secretary Dr Beela Rajesh, comprising a paediatrician, gynaecologist and an anaesthetist, conducted an inquiry into the incident at the hospital till the late hours on December 30. On December 31 at 6 pm, a suspension order was issued to Dr Manimozhi, who had attended to the patient. “Though medical negligence has not been established as the reason for the suspension, the doctor still has to take some responsibility because the case has resulted in deaths. Investigation revealed that the doctor was not present during the procedure for 10 minutes,” said a source from the health department.

While the health department sources said that the allergic reaction was not the only reason for the death of the woman and the foetus, sources from the Ramanathapuram GH maintained that the best possible treatment was given to the patient.

Title: Women students ‘take to streets’ to spread road safety message
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madurai: Around 40 women students from a city college performed flash mobs on Monday at two major public spots in the city to create awareness about road safety and wearing helmets.

Students from Fatima College’s Department of Journalism and Mass Communication performed flash mobs at Goripalayam junction and outside Madurai Railway Station, carrying the message of wearing helmets and staying safe on roads. “The inspiration for coming up with such an activity started within the college. We noticed that many students didn’t wear helmets properly or they used to wear them only on seeing the police. It is sad to see that many of us, even after being aware of safety rules tend to ignore it. So, we did a program to make students understand the importance of road safety. Then, we had the thought of taking the message directly to the public through such an activity,” said Dr Saira Banu S, Assistant Professor, Department of Journalism and Mass Communication, Fatima College.

The performances of the students reminded the public about safe practices to be followed while on road. The need for people on two-wheelers including the pillion riders to wear helmets, the necessity for wearing seat belts and following road safety rules. Dr Saira Banu further said that the students received full support of the local police, including district Commissioner of Police, S Davidson Desirvatham. “The police stressed on the need for such awareness events. Our journalism students not only benefited from organizing the flash mob but also by covering it as budding reporters, talking to the public and police about road safety in the city,” she said.

Title: Vadodara to house India’s 1st nuclear-grade sodium plant
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

DAE secretary KN Vyas laying the foundation stone for the plant in Fertilizernagar

VADODARA: The Department of Atomic Energy (DAE) is setting up India’s first plant to produce nuclear grade sodium in Vadodara. The plant will produce 600 metric tonnes of sodium per year.

K N Vyas, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and DAE secretary, laid the foundation stone for the production of nuclear grade sodium at Heavy Water Plant (HWP), Baroda on Sunday.

Presently, high purity sodium is imported. High purity sodium is used for manufacturing insecticides, synthetic detergent, dyes, various vitamins and drugs. It also has its application in fast breeder nuclear reactors.

The foundation stone was laid for the industrial level production of high purity sodium based on the successful operation of the demonstration plant.

“After the successful completion of phase-I and phase-2 of the plant, it will have a capacity to produce 600 metric tonnes of sodium per year,” a release issued by the HWP, Baroda said.

HWP, Baroda is also expanding its capacity to manufacture specially deuterated compounds which are presently imported.

“Initial development of the special compounds has already been carried out, which will be manufactured at an industrial scale,” the release further mentioned.

The HWP, Baroda is planning to initiate collaboration with M S University for the development of deuterated drug compounds.

“With these programmes, the HWP, Baroda will become a centre for yet another innovative technology development and demonstration for ‘Make in India’ for speciality materials,” the release stated. Dr U Kamachi Mudali, chairman and chief executive of the HWP, Baroda and other senior officials of the plant were present during the foundation stone laying ceremony.

Title: JNU violence: ABVP, NSUI protesters come head-to-head on Agra varsity campus, police intervene
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AGRA: Following violence unleashed by masked goons at JNU on Sunday, students associated with the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad ( ABVP ) and National Students Union of India (NSUI) staged protest against each other at the Paliwal Park campus of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University on Monday afternoon.

Student leaders of both the organizations made allegations against each other for the violence in JNU.

Both sides indulged in high-pitch sloganeering against each other for over half an hour. Some of the protesters misbehaved with the varsity’s chief proctor and security guards. Later, the protesters dispersed after senior police officials intervened.

Agra university chief proctor Manoj Srivastava said, “ABVP had sought permission to hand over a memorandum to the university administration over the issue of violence in JNU. However, some of the students carried placards and started raising slogans outside the office of registrar. NSUI leaders along with a few Samajwadi Chatra Sabha workers, who were already on the campus, gathered on the spot to counter ABVP. We asked them to peacefully provide memorandum, but they continued to raise slogans. This led a situation of confrontation. We had to call the police to maintain peace on campus.”

Earlier on Monday, ABVP activists burnt an effigy of “Communists” outside Agra College.

ABVP spokesperson Shivam Jain said, “Communists are trying to control the educational institutions. We will not allow this to happen. In the memorandum handed over to registrar KN Singh, we have demanded complete ban on the Left-wing activities to ensure uninterrupted teaching and learning activities.”

NSUI district president Vilal Ahmed said, “ABVP is trying to create disturbance on the campus. In Agra university, they did not protest on any genuine issue concerning the students in the last two years.”

Superintendent of police (city) Botre Rohan Pramod told TOI, “We interacted with the student leaders staging protest on the varsity campus and asked to them to address their issues to the university administration. Based on the information provided by the university administration and other evidence, action will be taken against those who tried to create disturbance. Student leaders have been warned not to organize any gathering or stage protest as CrPC section 144 remains in force.”

Title: Agra: Couple on bike plunge into canal due to fog, man dead
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Repredentative image

AGRA: A man who heading back to his native village with his wife, was killed when he plunged the bike he was riding into a canal due to heavy fog. The accident occurred at around 9.30pm on Sunday on Fatehabad road under Tajganj police station of Agra district.

The deceased was identified as Mukesh of Phoolpur village under Iradatnagar police station. He was heading home with his wife Asha from their son’s home in Rajpur Chungi under Sadar police jurisdiction.

Tajganj SHO Anuj Kumar said, “Due to dense fog, the deceased was probably unsighted, lost control over his bike and plunged into the canal. While he drowned with his bike, his wife, who was rescued by villagers, sustained injuries.”

“On Monday morning, the victim’s body was fished out of the canal along with his motorbike. The body has been sent for autopsy,” he added.

In another road accident, a SUV plunged into a 30-feet-deep trench on Etmadpur-Khandauli road, after a nilgai came in front of the car late night on Sunday. Four men were injured in the accident, including driver Mukesh Kumar and his employer Sunil Kumar, but all were saved after locals rushed to extract them from the car.

Title: Panchayat union chairpersons to be elected on January 11
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: Indirect elections to elect panchayat union chairpersons and vice-chairpersons will be held on January 11, said collector K Rajamani.

A total of 91 cases have been filed on as many people for violating the election code of conduct during the panchayat local body elections held recently, he told reporters on Monday after swearing in candidates who had won in the elections.

A total of 17 newly elected district panchayat ward members were sworn in at the district collectorate. Of these, 10 were from AIADMK, five from DMK and two from BJP. While the BJP members swore in by saying ‘Bharat Mata Ki Jai’, the AIADMK members thanked Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami, deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam and minister for municipal administration S P Velumani. DMK candidates evoked the names of Anna, Karunanidhi and Stalin.

The collector said the local body elections had taken place peacefully than expected. Elected panchayat ward members would elect panchayat union chairpersons and vice-chairpersons in the indirect election to be held on January 11. The election would be held properly without allowing any kind of violations, he said.

When asked about absenteeism by government servants during the election duty training sessions, he said in the first phase of training, 14% of people was absent and in the second phase, 8% was absent. However, if they have valid reasons, no action would be taken against them, he said.

Title: Lucknow: Prices of staple vegetables go over the TOP, public fumes
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Prices of vegetables considered staple to Indian kitchen continue to go over the top.In last 3-4 months, the cost of three standard meals you take daily has increased by Rs 21 due to rise in prices of TOP (tomato, onion and potato) vegetables. This means a family of four is now spending about Rs 2,500 more per month as compared to August-September last year.The spike has upset the monthly budget of the common man forcing many to change their food habits.“We have done away with our weekly family visit to the restaurant so that we are able to check the monthly expenses,” said Madhu Tiwari of Gomtinagar.Alpana Mishra of Gomtinagar said, “This is the first time in so many years that we are actually buying more of green, leafy vegetables than the staple due to price hike.”“We are getting green and unripe tomatoes in market while the ripe and red ones are insanely overpriced. Gravy at our homes are cooked without essential element of tang these days,” said Madhu Tiwari, a resident of Gomtinagar.Sameer, a vendor at Dandaiya Bazar vegetable market in Aliganj, said: “Prices initially rose due to crop damage this monsoon and later cold weather took the toll.”Potato supply mostly comes from west UP, tomatoes from neighbouring districts like Barabanki, and onion from Maharashtra and Karnataka.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Medical teachers back down, withdraw resignations
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: The decision of directorate of medical education (DME) to not pay heed to threat by medical teachers paid off on Monday when Central Medical Teachers Association of MP (CMTA-MP) withdrew its proposed call to resign en masse on January 9. It is the third time in over a year, that teachers have backed out after threating action if their demands were not met.

The decision was announced after a meeting with MP chief secretary SR Mohanty here on Monday. Some 3,000 teaching faculty from 13-government medical colleges of MP, had submitted their resignation to respective deans and threatened to resign if their demands are not met by January 9.

“State government officials have assured the medical teachers that our demands would be fulfilled within a determined time frame,” said CMTA-MP secretary, Rakesh Malviya, here on Monday. The meeting lasted over two hours. That state government had agreed to come out with a promotion policy for medical teachers within a month, he added.

Other key demands, including implementation of 7th CPC effective April 2018 is being considered. However, it is unlikely to be implemented before the new budget. DME is also expected to announce the name of a new full time dean for Gandhi Medical College (GMC), Bhopal . GMC is being headed by Dr TN Dubey, who is acting dean.

Title: Agra: Obesity root cause of diseases, say doctors
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Obesity is the root cause of diabetes, heart disease, knee pain, kidney disease, fatty liver problems. By 2030, India will become the capital of diabetes, said renowned doctors.

On the first day of the Association of Physicians of India’s 75th Annual Conference, APICON, at Hotel KNCC on Fatehabad Road, discussions took place on prevention and treatment of diabetes, heart disease and other non-communicable diseases.

APICON will continue till January 9. More than 12 thousand doctors from different states of the country and abroad will discuss various subjects related to medical science. Dr MC Gupta inaugurated the scientific session simultaneously in 12 halls.

President of the Association of Physicians of India (API) Dr KK Pareek said, “Every third person is suffering from high blood pressure. Diabetes has increased up to four times in the past few years in India. Lack of physical activity and increased consumption of packaged food items is the reason behind this alarming situation. Even children are suffering from obesity which is the root cause of the majority of non-communicable diseases.”

Secretary of the Uttar Pradesh chapter of API, Dr Sanjay Tandon , along with his entire team received the all India best state chapter award from the president of API on Monday at the inaugural ceremony of APICON 2020.

Title: KCZMA gets caught in middle of inland navigation dept muddle
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority ( KCZMA ) has found itself stuck in the middle of a tussle between officials of the inland navigation department over alleged violations pertaining to construction of a shopping mall in Akkulam.

An executive engineer with the department’s Kollam office had brought to the attention of KCZMA encroachments that were noticed in the area where construction work on the proposed complex was progressing. The official also raised the issue of the property’s boundary wall encroaching on the Parvathi Puthannaar canal area and construction waste being dumped into the water body, and sought information on the CRZ categorization of the canal that runs from Kovalam to Akkulam.

Following this, KCZMA received a letter from the chief engineer of inland navigation & Kuttanad package in October 2019 which confounded the findings of the executive engineer. Questioning the executive engineer’s findings, the chief engineer said an inspection of the canal area in October 2019 did not reveal any dumping of waste material.

He recalled the report of the tahsildar which said the disputed property was not owned by the project’s developer and that it was in the name of other parties. The chief engineer added that the executive engineer intended to mislead the government and its agencies.

The KCZMA, at its 105th meeting, noted the chief engineer’s request that it need not consider the erroneous report furnished by the executive engineer. The matter was raised at the meeting as an out-of-agenda item. The authority had to decide whether a site inspection was called for.

It is learned that KCZMA deliberated on the matter and concluded that as a case is pending in the high court it will not take a call on site inspection, unless specifically directed by the court. “Besides, KCZMA had earlier reported that the project was outside CRZ limits and if court directs KCZMA to revise its decision, a site inspection may be necessitated. Otherwise, the matter has to be settled by the inland navigation department itself,’’ said an official.

The State Environment Impact Assessment Authority had earlier cleared the mall project of any violations of environmental clearance (EC) norms. The authority concluded that the land in possession of the project’s proponent does not include any puramboke (government) land and that this was verified by viewing Google Earth data of various periods. An examination of land records and conditions of EC to detect any violations was initiated by the authority in the wake of a petition filed in the high court in July saying that EC was granted in violation of norms.

Title: Hours after announcing dates, admin defers Mahotsava again
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

dashed plans

Lucknow: In a sudden twist, district administration on Monday evening deferred Lucknow Mahotsava till further orders citing ‘unavoidable reasons’, just hours after holding a press conference to announce the events of the popular cultural fest which was scheduled from January 17-23.

District magistrate Abhishek Prakash said the decision to defer mahotsava was taken in a meeting of senior district officials in the evening. He, however, did not cite any specific reason. Other administrative officers said the postponement was done in the wake of security reasons and preparations for the upcoming Defence Expo in the city.

The 10-day Lucknow Mahotsava is held every year from November 25 and showcases food, culture and heritage of the city. Its another attraction are the entertainment programmes. But, it was deferred last November in the wake of Ayodhya verdict by the Supreme court.

All preparations for mahotsava are complete. In fact, DM held a curtain raiser press conference along with divisional commissioner Mukesh Meshram on Monday afternoon announcing that the venue would be Ramabai Ambedkar Maidan, though mahotsava would be formally inaugurated at the Residency.

Even names of celebrity performers, along with schedule of indoor and outdoor programmes, at the extravaganza were also released.

Divisional commissioner Meshram, who is also head of the Mahotsav committee, said the inaugural event will coincide with the re-launch of light and sound show at the Residency, depicting the history and culture of Lucknow.

However, the decision of postponement of Mahotsava was announced in a single line press note released on Monday evening.

Title: Migrant Hindus in Doon condemn killing of Sikh man in Pak
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Dehradun: Migrant Hindus from Pakistan living in Dehradun — there are around 200 of them — condemned the killing of a Sikh man in Pakistan, saying the incident was an indictment of persecution of Sikhs and Hindus in the country.

Jeet Chandhok, a Hindu migrant who runs a sanitary hardware shop in Dehradun, said, “Hindu families face discrimination and persecution every day in Pakistan. The Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) will prove to be a boon for migrant Hindu families. However, the government must make sure that Pakistan residents get easy visa clearances.” The Hindu migrants in India are living on extended visas but can be eligible for citizenship once CAA comes into effect.

Ishwar Lal, who used to run a chemist’s shop in Battagram, Pakistan before migrating to Dehradun and becoming an auto-rickshaw driver, said, “Persecution of Hindus goes on unabated in Pakistan and no one intervenes. The Sikh boy belonged to the family of a famous doctor. If he was targeted, can you imagine the fate of less fortunate members of minority communities in Pakistan?” Lal added.

Title: Delhi: Krishna Nagar market goes vehicle-free, relief from congestion woes
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Krishna Nagar market

NEW DELHI: Visitors to the Krishna Nagar market were pleasantly surprised on Monday, to see the beautification work on Lal Quarter stretch with demarcation by yellow lines for pedestrians, flower pots, benches and fancy lights installed at regular intervals.

As part of the pedestrianisation and parking management plan for Krishna Nagar, the East Delhi Municipal Corporation has restricted vehicle movement on the 1.5km Lal Quarter stretch. When TOI visited the place on Monday, there was no unauthorised parking on roads or hawkers on pavements. This made shopping even more fun for the hundreds of people coming to the market.

There were guards deployed at every corner of the road, to guide visitors and commuters. In addition, the civic body had also installed signages.

“The otherwise chaotic stretch looked peaceful and happening today. I hope, this arrangement will sustain forever and extend to other roads in the markets,” said Deependra Gupta, a resident of C-block, adding that after 30 years he could walk so freely on this stretch.

The best part about the changes in this market was the new seating arrangement, according to visitors. “We can sit, rest and shop some more. This has always been my favourite market in Delhi, but there was too much hustle-bustle earlier,” said Ananya Kaushik, who had come for her wedding shopping.

While the vehicle-free stretch was punctuated at three crossings, where vehicles was running perpendicular to it, shoppers and pedestrians were strolling down at rest of the streets meant only for them.

Title: MSU physics professor loses Rs 60,000 to cyber fraud
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A physics professor of M S University (MSU) lost Rs 59,749 to a cyber fraud when he tried selling a cupboard on an online marketplace on January 4.

Professor Surjit Mukherjee was approached by a man named Sunil Kumar on January 4 morning after he posted advertisement on an online platform. Kumar, who claimed to be from Rajasthan, showed interest in buying the cupboard which was put on sale for Rs 2,500.

However, he said that another person will pick up the cupboard and will contact him.

“The other person immediately called me up and insisted on making payment through online platform. I told him to pay in cash since it is a small amount but as he kept insisting, I agreed with him,” said Mukherjee.

Mukherjee received a QR code on his phone through WhatsApp which he was asked to scan. The fraudsters told him that they will be able to make the payment only after he scans the code.

“I was unaware how the payments are made as I had never made payments using a QR code, so I did it as per their instructions,” Mukherjee added. The accused kept him busy on the call and simultaneously asked him to scan the code. They made him scan the code four times by saying that they are not able to make the payment.

Later, another QR code was sent to him and he was asked to scan eight times. Mukherjee became suspicious when they mentioned about his wife’s bank account and asked for his debit card’s details so he hung up the call.

By that time he had received SMSs from his bank mentioning that Rs 59,749 had been debited from his bank account in different amounts. Mukherjee called back on the numbers from which he had received the calls, but the calls went unanswered.

The physicist then went to his bank to seek the account statement and inform the bank about the fraud. On advice of the bank officials, he went to Cyber Crime police station and submitted an application to lodge an offence.

The cops have not yet registered the case. Mukherjee has also registered a complaint on Reserve Bank of India’s grievance portal.

Title: Agra: Private companies duped AMC of Rs 22 crore in garbage collection
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Private companies entrusted with the task of door-to-door garbage collection in the city were paid Rs 22.65 crore without verification of work done, according to a probe report. Investigation revealed that only 10.5% garbage collection was done in 83 wards of the city. Mayor Naveen Jain said action would be taken against them and the money recovered.

Five companies were entrusted with the task of collecting garbage door to door. However, they did not perform the task properly. Several complaints to the effect were made by councilors to Mayor Naveen Jain, He set up a three-member committee headed by additional municipal commissioner Vinod Kumar to investigate the matter.

On Monday, Jain presented the investigation report at a special house session.

The investigation revealed that the companies did only 10.5% of the garbage collection work in 83 wards of the city. The companies produced fake bills to get payments. It was also found that a majority of the addresses and details of residents given by the companies as evidence of door-to-door garbage collection were fake.

During the board meeting, councilors claimed that some of the civic body officials were hand in glove with the five private companies. They demanded recovery of the money paid from the companies and strict action against the officials concerned.

Agra MP SP Singh Baghel, Agra, South, MLA Yogendra Upadhyaya and Agra, North, MLA Purshottam Khandelwal also attended the municipal house session.

Legislator Upadhyaya said, “This is the biggest scam in the history of the municipal corporation. Officials failed a good plan of door-to-door garbage collection to fill their pockets. The civic body administration must register an FIR. And recovery should be made from the private companies.”

Another MLA Purshottam Khandelwal said, “The companies have been indulging in corruption in door-to-door collection work since 2018. Over the past several months, councilors have been complaining about it. But officials without even verifying the work done by the companies have made payments to them. There should be no leniency in the entire matter. The process of recovery of public funds looted by the private companies in connivance with the civic body officials should be initiated. Severe action should be taken against the officials involved in the entire scam.”

Mayor Jain said, “The five companies involved in the entire scam will be blacklisted. They will have to pay back the money paid to them on the basis of fake bills. Departmental action will be taken against the sanitation inspectors. Environment engineer Rajiv Rathi will be relieved of all charges. State government will be requested to take strict action against him. Our councillors and officials who conducted the investigation have done a commendable job in revealing the entire scam.”

Title: Sewage project scrapped after locals protest
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Efforts by the Cochin Smart Mission Ltd ( CSML ) to construct a sewage treatment plant at Mundamvely in West Kochi had to be stopped due to protests from local residents. As a result, pipes worth Rs 39 crore procured for the project and the remaining amount of the Rs 200-crore project funded by Asian Development Bank (ADB) had gone down the drain.

It was in the beginning of 2010 that the project was designed under Kerala Sustainable Urban Development Project (KSUDP). The project was first delayed after Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority (KCZMA) and Kerala State Pollution Control Board (PCB) raised objection against setting up the plant by reclaiming the wetland at Mundamvely. Later, the authorities decided to set up the plant at Fort Kochi. But that plan too didn’t work following objection from local residents. After Kerala Water Authority (KWA), the nodal agency, failed to implement the project even after receiving an extension by six months, ADB cancelled the funding for the project in 2016.

Interestingly, Kochi corporation had not given sanction to dig over 100km of roads to lay the pipeline network as part of the project mooted by the local body itself. It was the protests from the local residents that forced the authorities to deny permission to dig up the roads. There were also stiff opposition from the locals against constructing sumps in different locations for storing the waste collected from the locality and pumping it to the treatment plant.

Title: Transplantation moves a bid to make case for Bharat Van road?
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HOGWASH: Sources say, by doing transplantation, the Metro is trying to impress the higher authorities that it ... Read More

Nagpur: The MahaMetro is going through the motions of transplantation, even at the cost of public money, to allegedly create a case to construct a road through Bharat Van mini-forest in Bharat Nagar, according to some activists and officials. The road is being opposed by citizens who feel that there is no need for the connecting road from Bharat Nagar Square towards Telangkhedi as it will destroy a thriving biodiversity habitat.

A well-placed source told TOI that by constantly mentioning transplantation, the Metro is trying to impress the authorities that it is not against environment and is doing utmost to save trees. “What however is being left unsaid is the survival rate which is very poor,” the source said.

For the third time in a row, MahaMetro’s transplantation efforts have completely failed. In December 2017, the agency transplanted 15 trees of different species at a newly built residential society in Mihan. When TOI re-visited the site in July last year, hardly two-three trees could be called ‘alive’.

The second transplantation was carried out at Patwardhan high school premises in Sitabuldi, where the agency transplanted 21 trees. Though in a Right to Information (RTI) query MahaMetro claimed that all the trees were “alive and growing”, the reality was completely different. Hardly two trees showed little signs of life, with the rest of them being dead.

Environment activists and citizens, who have been fighting to save Bharat Van since over a year, are of the strong opinion that MahaMetro’s transplantation initiatives are a “tactic to pave way for the proposed road”.

The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court is hearing a suo motu public interest litigation (PIL) based on a letter by honorary wildlife warden of Nagpur Jaydeep Das.

TOI has access to affidavits submitted by MahaMetro in the court. At four-to-five places, the agency has stated that it plans to transplant over 500 trees of Bharat Van. In one of the affidavits, MahaMetro has even stated that the process will be done using “latest scientific methods”.

Pointing out that the latest scientific methods have been a complete failure three times, activists said that MahaMetro is trying to hoodwink the judiciary. “The agency is making dubious claims of transplantation to destroy Bharat Van, even when it is clearly proved that the process is a big failure. Before taking any decision, the judiciary should take into account the ground reality,” said Das.

Stating that Metro’s transplantation is a 100% failure, environment activist Surbhi Jaiswal said, “To ensure that the concerned authorities are not misled, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation should inform the court about the findings of its spot inspections and failed transplantation of trees.”

Title: Scramble to lure independents begins
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The residents of rural local bodies could heave a sigh of relief for getting their civic representatives after a gap of three years. But an independent councillor jumping off the compound wall soon after taking oath on Monday to escape being whisked away by political party members has come as a stark reminder of the challenges ahead for effective functioning of rural civic bodies.

The smooth functioning of the civic bodies appears a difficult task as both the primary rivals – DMK and AIADMK – have more or less equal strength in the district panchayat and panchayat union councils.

Irrespective of whether DMK manages to grab the chairperson’s post or the AIADMK gets it, the civic body chief will have a tough time keeping the house in order, say partymen.

There were enough indications of the likely confrontations between the two parties on Monday, the day of swearing in. While Aravind, the independent councillor from Chellampatti panchayat union in Madurai jumped off the compound wall of the union office to flee from the partymen waiting outside to get him, there were instances of either of the parties whisking away such independent councillors in other places.

Worse, in Thiruvarankulam in Pudukottai and Mannargudi in Tiruvarur, the partymen from AIADMK and DMK clashed with each other, police said. At Kovilpatti, the AIADMK men staged a protest alleging that DMK workers had whisked away independent candidates. “If one party enjoys majority in the council, then there would be no issues. But when the rival parties have equal number of councillors, then the support of independents becomes crucial for electing the chairperson and vice chairperson. Hence, the partymen want to keep independent councillors under their control to prevent them from supporting the rival party,’’ a police officer said.

In some places, where the independent councillors wield heft, they are demanding the civic chief posts, he said.

In Krishnagiri district, police arrested six people and booked cases on 13 more after a clash erupted between residents of two villages in getting their natives to the civic chief post. The villagers of Puthupatti and Moongileri near Uthangarai started attacking each other even as the swearing in was underway.

The public though, hope that the councillors would set aside their party differences and work together. All these while it was the special officers who were running the day to day affairs of the rural civic bodies. Once the district panchayat councillors and panchayat union councillors elect their chairperson, the civic bodies would take over the financial functions from the special officers who were carrying out the work for the past three years in the absence of the council.

Title: Student organisations flay attack on JNU students
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: Several outfits including students organisations in the city on Monday held demonstrations condemning the violence against the students of the Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi.

The protesters also demanded the arrest of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) members, who allegedly attacked and injured the students and faculty members on JNU campus.

Members of the Students Federation of India (SFI) held a protest at the gate of the Government Arts College. Members of the All India Democratic Women’s Association (AIDWA) and Democratic Youth Federation of India (DYFI) held a protest near the south taluk office. JNU alumni from the city also participated in the protest.

On Monday evening, members of SFI, All India Students Federation (AISF), Students Islamic Organisation of India (SIO) and Campus Front of India (CFI) held a joint protest at Aathupaalam in the city.

District representative of SFI Dhinesh Raja said the attack on JNU students was a premeditated one. “How else could 50 masked goons enter the campus and wreak havoc? ABVP has been inciting violence on the campus. Aishe Ghosh, the president of Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union and SFI’s central committee member, has been brutally attacked. Teachers were also attacked. Those responsible for this must be arrested and brought to justice,” he said.

Title: Dejected by scolding, class X boy ends life
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A Class X student living on Harni Road ended his life by jumping into Narmada canal near Motnath Mahadev Temple in Harni area on January 4.

The boy’s body was fished out from the canal at Ankodiya by fire brigade officials on Monday evening. Police said the deceased, identified as Ritwik Karnik, was dejected after being pulled up by his father over studies.

Ritwik had left his home on a scooter on the afternoon of January 4. When his parents returned from work in the evening, they could not find him anywhere. His father Nikhil asked his elderly mother about his whereabouts. She said that Ritwik had left around 1pm saying that he would be back in a while. But as the 15-year-old did not return till late evening, his parents started inquiring with their relatives and the boy’s friends. His father works as a purchase manager in a local tobacco company.

Police said that when nobody had any idea about the boy, the parents went towards the canal to search for him. They found the scooter with the key intact with the vehicle around late night, but the boy was nowhere to be found. Next day they approached the police and filed a missing person’s complaint. Nikhil told the cops that he had scolded his son, asking him to focus on his studies as it was a crucial year for his career.

On receiving the complaint, the cops asked the fire department to search for Ritwik in the canal but they could not find him till late in the evening. On Monday evening, Ritwik’s body was found floating in the canal water near Ankodiya village on the outskirts of the city. “The boy was dejected by the scolding he received from his father. Hence, he left the house and ended his life,” said an official from Harni police station.

Title: Students take out ‘Tiranga march’ on AMU campus to express solidarity with JNU students and teachers
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AGRA: Hundreds of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) students took out a ‘Tiranga march’ on the varsity campus on Monday to express solidarity with the JNU students and teachers who were targeted by masked goons in Delhi on Sunday.

AMU teachers also took out a peaceful candle protest march on Monday evening in support of the JNU students and teachers. Noted historian and Professor emeritus Irfan Habib claimed that whatever happened in JNU on Sunday was unprecedented in the country’s history. He said, “Protest is very much required to express solidarity with JNU.”

Speaking on the amended citizenship law, Habib said that CAA is not only against Muslims but also affects poor people, orphans and illiterate persons.

AMU students shouted anti-BJP and anti-RSS slogans during the Tiranga march and pledged their full support to JNU and Jamia Millia students, urging them to put up a fight.

Students’ leader Faizul Hassan, who led the ‘Tiranga March’, said, “We held the tri-colour in our hand to show that we belong to this country. It doesn’t represent any religion or community. We want to convey it to the government that they must withdraw CAA and NRC.”

Giving a memorandum to the President through local administration, the students demanded that the university should open at the earliest and the academic session must begin.

“We strongly condemn the violence unleashed on the students and teachers at JNU, in the presence of Delhi Police. We urge you to direct the police to find and punish the culprits immediately,” the memorandum said.

The students also alleged that the state police have been using communal slurs and harassing minority communities.

Police forces were deployed outside the campus in order to maintain law and order.

Aligarh SSP Akash Kulhary said that the students took out a peaceful march. “I have received the memorandum from students and will send it to the President,” he said.

Title: Sub-inspector, 2 constables suspended for serving notices to dead man and two 90-year-olds
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AGRA: Firozabad superintendent of police Sachindra Patel on Monday shunted Nalband Chouraha police outpost in-charge sub-inspector Rajeev Kumar Chitransh and two beat constables to Police Lines, after a probe by CO (city) blamed the three cops of negligence. This, days after a dead man and two 90-year-olds, one of whom is bedridden while the other is a pneumonic patient, were served notice of CrPc 107/116 by Firozabad police in the wake of anti-CAA violence.

Speaking to TOI, SP Patel said, “Three cops, including SI Rajeev Kumar Chitransh and constables Pushpender and Mahendra, have been sent to Police Lines. In his probe, CO (city) Arun Kumar found all three were guilty of negligence. They didn’t cross check details of the three men they notified, before sending their names to the magistrate for bound notices.”

After the violence on December 20, district administration invoked CrPc sections 107/116(3) against nearly 200 men whom they considered “troublemakers”, forcing these men to seek bail against a personal bond with sureties. Proceedings under these sections are drawn when the magistrate receives information and believes there is substantial ground for proceeding against the person(s) named. Police identify potential troublemakers on the basis of intelligence, mostly provided by beat constables, SIs or reports by police outpost in-charges.

Among the recipients of these notices were Banne Khan (87), who died six years ago, Fasahat Meer Khan (93) of Kotla Mohalla, who is bedridden for months and Sufi Ansar Hussain (90) of Kotla Pathanan, who is suffering from pneumonia and has just returned after treatment from Delhi’s Sir Ganga Ram Hospital.

SI Chitransh is also the complainant in the case on the December 20 violence. In his FIR, he had accused oral cancer patient Ahemad Nabi (52) and another local Faraz Khan (19) as prime accused for leading “violent anti-CAA protests and raising anti-BJP slogans”.

Vakeel Nabi (48), younger brother of Ahemad Nabi, said, “How can we trust the FIRs against six men, including an oral cancer patient, by an officer who filed wrong reports against a deceased man and a bedridden patient to the magistrate for issuing bound notices?”

Title: Caught in gridlock, min turns traffic cop
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Minister Kadakampally Surendran rushed to the aid of the lone traffic home guard on duty at Edapazhanji juncti... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Motorists stuck in a traffic jam at Edapazhanji on Monday morning were in for a surprise when tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran rushed to the aid of the lone traffic home guard on duty at the junction. It was utter chaos at the junction with vehicles coming from all four direction converging, with the traffic signal flashing orange, leading to long queues on the connecting roads from Jagathy, Poojappura, Sasthamangalam and Vazhuthacaud.

Kadakampally was on his way to attend a programme in Kattakkada when his official vehicle got caught up in the gridlock at around 9.30am. After waiting for a few minutes, he got out of his car to analyse the situation. When he realised that there is only one home guard on duty, the minister too joined to regulate the movement of vehicles.

Nedumanagad DSP Stuart Keeler who was also stuck in traffic soon joined the minister before help arrived from the traffic department.

With four major roads converging at the junction, with a major hospital and prominent market in close proximity the junction a very busy zone. Traffic snarls are a regular feature here during morning and evening peak hours.

The minister later told reporters that he will contact the officials concerned and direct them to clear the issue at the earliest.

“The junction requires at least four or five traffic officers to handle the volume of vehicles,” he said.

DSP Keeler said he was on his way to a special conference called by rural SP B Asokan which was scheduled at 11am when he too got caught in traffic. “My vehicle had passed SK Hospital but which time the traffic slowed to a crawl. So I decided to intervene and on reaching the junction, I was told by the tourism minister’s gunman that Kadakampally Surendran is also stuck in traffic. As we started clearing the traffic near the hospital, the minister stepped out and started helping the home guard on duty at the junction. Eventually, we managed to clear the initial bottleneck of vehicles at the junction and traffic enforcement arriving soon afterwards helped clear the issue completely,” he told TOI.

Title: Heads must roll or you will be held responsible: Digvijaya Singh to Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Digvijaya Singh

BHOPAL: Senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh has expressed deep anguish over Sunday’s attack on students at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), and called it “gross intelligence failure”.

“Heads must roll, or else home minister Amit Shah will be held responsible for violence in the most prestigious university of India,” Digvijaya said on Monday.

In a series of tweets on the incident, the former CM questioned the role of ABVP activists and Delhi Police , and wondered why the cops couldn’t prevent violence.

“JNU has an alumni list of eminent persons, ranging from Prime Ministers, ministers in GOI, ministers in state governments, Nobel laureate and civil servants to activists in civil society and members of Parliament cutting across party lines and other fields that we are proud of,” he tweeted.

In a second tweet, he pointed out that the finance minister and external affairs minister of the Modi government, too, are JNU alumni. “Shouldn't they all stand together not only to condemn on social media, but to force the home minister to take strong action against the ABVP goons? What was Delhi Police doing? Couldn’t they have prevented it?” he said.

He attributed the JNU violence to intelligence failure and asked Amit Shah to ensure strong action against those responsible for “letting such an unfortunate incident take place”. “If it is not done, Shah, himself, will be held responsible for the violence. Isn’t it a gross intelligence failure? What was IB or the intelligence wing of Delhi Police doing? Amit Shah, heads must roll, or else we shall hold you responsible for this violence against students of our most prestigious university which has given us leaders of such eminence,” he wrote.

Title: ABVP, BASA may come face-to-face today
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nagpur: Ideologically opposed camps of students seem to be headed for a face off as Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) and Babasaheb Ambedkar Students Association (BASA) have called for a protest in front of Nagpur University campus on Amravati Road at the same time on Tuesday.

The development comes after a series of protests were held in the city by ABVP and Left parties, which were supported by BASA, on Monday itself to condemn the violence by masked goons on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus in Delhi a day before.

It seems both the sides have not taken police permission for the protests or else either of them would have been shifted or denied permission for the same spot. As per social media posts, the protests are scheduled at 9.30am, a fact confirmed by office-bearers too.

ABVP’s city secretary Amit Patle ruled out any move for confrontation or deliberate attempt to hold the protests at the same time near NU campus. Patle said he was aware of the BASA protest. “If they are present at the spot, we will shift to another square near the campus. I have instructed all the members to not fall prey to any mischief or provocation,” he said.

Patle said Tuesday’s protest will be peaceful. “We organized several peaceful demonstrations at colleges across the city on Monday. We informed students about the reality of JNU violence and how ABVP members were attacked and injured. We want to make more students aware of the ongoing smear campaign by Leftists organizations,” he said.

BASA president Bhushan Waghmare said the association members are university students and would be accompanied by teachers during the peaceful protest hence there’s no need for police permission. “We are students and bound by university rules. We are only going to demand justice for aggrieved students and teachers of JNU. We are not taking any sides or pointing finger at any organization,” he said.

While ABVP expects around 100 members to participate, the BASA too may attract equal numbers as it has mass following among the students.

Meanwhile, a group of youth, which protested against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and the proposed NRC at Samvidhan Square in the city on January 4 under the banner of Nagpur Youth Organisation (NYO), submitted a memorandum to collector Ravindra Thakre, demanding repeal of the amended Act and for protecting the Constitution.

The group was accompanied by lawyer Akshay Samarth. The delegation included Shalaka Bhandarkar, Tejaswini Kalmegh, Ishaan Wasu, Javed Iqbal, Swaroop Bhartiya, Tuba Sanobar, Kunal Chandel, Faizan Khan, Preeti Sarvey, Yashas Mahajan, Sultan Sheikh, Bhushan Dahat, Uzma Ahmad, Fouzia Ahmad, Riddhi Lad, Rushank Lad, Parag Dahat, Adiba Seher and others.

Title: Lucknow: 470 illegal commercial buildings, but LDA razed only five in 3 years
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: In last three years, Lucknow Development Authority (LDA) has ordered razing of 470 commercial buildings constructed in violation of norms but officials have so far been able to demolish only three buildings.During inspections, LDA officials found that owners had either constructed the entire building or a part of it without getting the map approved or were not following fire safety norms.“In some cases, the entire construction was illegal while in others, builders added more floors and units than approved in the map. There were many who had not taken ‘no objection certificate’ from fire department,” an LDA official said.Officials found that in some cases, area marked for parking of vehicles was also encroached by builders for additional construction which led to traffic snarls.Notices were slapped on the owners to get things rectified and pay the fine that amounted to around Rs 70 crore. However, nothing significant was done thereafter.LDA vice-chairman SK Dwivedi, who took charge last week, admitted lapses in action against illegal buildings and assured that a probe would be conducted to fix responsibilities.“An internal probe will be carried out into the role of zonal and junior engineers who were supposed to carry out demolitions,” he told TOI.Dwivedi said fresh notices would be issued to owners of buildings to pay fine and complete all official requirements within seven days, failing which their establishments would be demolished and FIRs lodged against them on charges of illegal construction and not following government orders.

Title: Nagpur: With NPR, NRC looming, Muslims look for papers to prove citizenship
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The Mominpura burial ground committee is now charging Rs 200 for issuing 'ghat copy' while the service is free... Read More

NAGPUR: Alarmed by the imminent implementation of National Population Register ( NPR ) exercise to be followed by National Register of Citizens (NRC), several city Muslims are now running from pillar to post trying to gather their own documents as well as those of their forefathers to prove citizenship.

Though there is no clarity yet on what documentation will be needed, people are starting with birth and death certificates. Civic officials have observed a spurt in number of Muslims applicants compared to others and the rush is getting bigger.

The basic reason Muslims are first in the queue is the fear of becoming stateless in case they fail to make it to NRC as Citizenship (Amendment) Act has excluded the community from seeking citizenship.

For many, the first destination are Qabristans (cemeteries) where their parents and grandparents are buried. The unusual visits are necessitated by incomplete birth and death records of their parents and grandparents beside their own.

On Monday, TOI visited NMC birth and death department, burial grounds at Jaripatka and Mominpura, which are said to be the oldest in city dating back to 1857. Officials at all three places confirmed that there is a sudden rush for retrieving birth and death records.

NMC health officer and sub-registrar Atequr Raheman Khan said so far many didn’t care to keep decades old death certificates or have misplaced them. “We are yet to get any guidelines but people want to keep all records in place,” he said.

Khan said people can search their records online too on NMC website or visit his department.

Worried citizens queuing up since morning at NMC’s Civil Lines office are directed to bring a ‘ghat copy’ or acknowledgement from the place where last rites were held for further processing of a delayed birth/death certificate.

At Mominpura, records are available from 1938 while they received a request for 1925 death certificate a couple of days back. Jaripatka officials said they have records from 1965. People need to show slips issued by Qabristan committee at the time of burial to get a ‘ghat copy’ or burial acknowledment letter.

Several document seekers are those whose parents passed away and they don’t have their birth/death certificates. Surprisingly they have their grandparents documents. “People feel death certificate will be matched with birth/death certificate of grandparents to show their parents were legitimate Indian citizens beside their own papers,” an official said.

Another provision under Section 13(3) of Registration of Births and Deaths 1969 permits issuance of certificates subject to certain condidtions. An applicant has to bring a ‘ghat copy’ and submit it with ID proof of deceased to the department which conducts a police verification and get prepares a non-avialiablity (NA) proposal to be put before JMFC. The applicant then has to get an favourable order based on which the NMC issues the certificate. For delayed birth certificates, school leaving certificate and ID proof has to be submitted for preparing the NA proposal.

Title: JNU violence: Protests feed off social media outrage
Content:
JNU student union (JNUSU) President Aishe Ghosh

KOLKATA: The photograph of the bloodied face of JNU students’ union president Aishe Ghosh, who was assaulted by allegedly masked armed goons on the campus on Sunday evening, was widely circulated on social media within minutes, instantaneously triggering a nationwide protest against the JNU attack .In fact, the wide reach of the social media helped students’ groups organise impromptu rallies within an hour on Sunday night. It was on social media that the schedules and venues for rallies on Monday were announced far and wide. Like the rest of the country, Kolkatans shared and retweeted the image, along with hashtags #StandwithJNU and #JNUterrorattack, making it one of the top-5 trending topics on Twitter from Sunday night till most part of Monday.“I was attending an invitation when I came to know about the assault on JNU students from WhatsApp messages and Facebook posts. Immediately, discussions over the attack began on our friends’ groups and it was decided that we will take out a protest march on Sunday night itself. Accordingly, all of us began sharing on our social media profiles and WhatsApp groups, asking people to join us in the protest. We all reached the university by 10.15pm,” said Debadrita Bose, a BEd student at Jadavpur University.Some of the students who were already hanging out on the campus and those who could manage to reach quickly began writing posters, pasting the photo of Aishe’s bloodied face. A group of 200-odd students took out a rally around 10.30pm and walked up to the BJP party office at Sulekha crossing, where they staged a demonstration and stayed back till 12.30am. Several students made live videos on social media, which was again shared several times.Sympathisers, like photographer Ronny Sen, who could not travel to the protest march gave updates on his social media page, asking people to join the protest. Many others even shared numbers of those who were at the rally. “The entire rally was orchestrated over social media. I was at my home in Jadavpur, when I joined in seeing the Facebook live video of a friend,” said Subhasis Ghosh, a former JU student.Not only the march from JU on Sunday night, but all the other major students’ rallies that were organised on Monday were also decided over WhatsApp groups and shared over Facebook, Twitter and Instagram. “Monday’s rally was decided on the WhatsApp group of our students’ union. Posters were added to the posts announcing the rallies. Once we had the materials, we kept on sharing posters of the protest meet through Monday morning and by afternoon, 600 students and sympathisers joined the rally,” said Sneha Nandy, one of the protesters who was part of the rally from Jadavpur University to Baghajatin crossing and back to the university on Monday.Students at Presidency University and Calcutta University, too, followed the digital move to garner support for their rallies. Same did students of Rabindra Bharati University, who took out a rally along BT Road on Monday morning, slamming the assault on JNU students and teachers.Several netizens, who could not make it to the rallies, expressed their solidarity, hosting multiple “watch parties” of the rallies and sharing it on social media. Many even changed their display pictures to black or with a black badge.

Title: Fire of protest catches across Thiruvananthapuram
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Blazing dissent: ‘We the People’, a citizens’ movement, stages a protest against CAA in front of Secretariat i... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The riot in Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi triggered protests in the city since Sunday midnight. SFI activists organized a Raj Bhavan march at midnight to launch the protest in the city, which culminated with the ‘Protest Fire’ campaign held at Gandhi Park on Monday night. The protest fire event went on till Monday midnight and concluded with all participants lighting a torch and taking a pledge to protect the Constitution of India.

The 5,000-odd protesters who gathered at Gandhi Park were shocked to hear the narrative by Surya Krishnan, a student of JNU who was on the campus on Sunday. “Six people rounded me up and brutally attacked. They tried to break my left hand. I have suffered bruises on my right hand, and I cannot lift that up,” said Surya who reached the city on Monday.

“The ABVP members would walk in front of us with outsiders and they would point their fingers right at us, saying ‘They were at the protests, we should do something about it’. You can see there are stitches on my head and my hand is bruised, this is their so called ‘Aarsha Bharatha’ culture,” he said. After a brief appearance at the gathering, Surya was taken to a city hospital for treatment.

Palayam Imam Suhaib Maulavi also addressed the Gandhi Park event organised by CPM Chalai area committee. “Our constitution has given us the right to profess any faith, follow any religion and even to be an atheist. That is the beauty of our democracy , but now, a malicious campaign has been organised by the Modi government to divide this country and rule in order to establish a religious–fascist country. We should resist this by standing united,” the Imam said.

Members of citizens’ movement titled ‘We the People’ also conducted a protest march on the assault against students of JNU, along with raising demands of rejecting CAA and boycott of NRC. The march began at Gandhi Park on Monday evening and concluded in front of the Secretariat. Academic and social critic J Devika, who addressed the gathering, said there is still a belief that CAA and NRC will only affect a certain community; this needs to change. “The Centre is tricking all the citizens with the fake coin called tribunal. Has any promise made by Narendra Modi ever been fulfilled before?,” she said.

Researchers and faculty members of Centre for Development Studies organised a protest march from CDS campus Akkulam to Ulloor Junction in the evening.

Activists of AIYF took out a march to AG’s office in the evening to register protest against the attack on JNU students. State secretary Mahesh Kakkath inaugurated the march.

Title: Shivraj Singh Chouhan’s defamation suit against K K Mishra dismissed
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Madhya Pradesh Congress chief spokesperson K K Mishra coming out of court building after he was sentenced to t... Read More

BHOPAL: The court of judicial magistrate first class (JMFC), Rohit Shrivastava, on Monday dismissed the defamation suit filed by former chief minister, Shivraj Singh Chouhan , against Congress leader K K Mishra.

Mishra, in his capacity as chief spokesperson of state Congress, had accused the then chief minister and his wife of being involved in Vyapam scam following which a defamation suit on behalf of state government was filed by the public prosecutor charging that Mishra had defamed the MP government by levelling “wild” charges against its chief minister.

Mishra was held guilty by then additional district & sessions judge, Kashinath Singh who sentenced him to 2 years of imprisonment and imposed a penalty of Rs 25,000.

However, a Supreme Court bench headed by Justice Ranjan Gogoi discharged him, holding that the defamation suit should have been filed by Shivraj Singh Chouhan in his individual capacity if he had felt that Mishra sought to publicly defame him and not by the state government as it had nothing to do with the state government and charges were against Chouhan and not the state government. He had, however, allowed Chouhan to file a defamation suit in his personal capacity in the court of JMFC, Bhopal .

Chouhan, later, filed the defamation suit in his individual capacity and his counsel sought condonation of delay in filing the suit, which was strongly opposed by counsel for Mishra, who argued that while public prosecutor filed defamation suit on behalf of the state government, Chouhan should have filed a parallel suit in his personal capacity but he was not serious about the suit then nor is he serious now. He was trying his luck then and is doing it again, which amounts to abuse of the process of law, he argued.

The court convinced with arguments of Mishra’s counsel on Tuesday ordered dismissal of Chouhan’s defamation suit.

Title: 2 Maithan Ispat officers held for GST tax fraud
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Goods and service tax (GST) officials have arrested two top executives of Maithan Ispat Limited, a Mesco Steel subsidiary, for allegedly acquiring Rs 23 crore input tax credit (ITC) without furnishing requisite documents.

“Maithan’s assistant general manager (taxation) Surendra Patra and general manager (finance) Manas Ranjan Padhi were arrested on Thursday for allegedly masterminding a fraud,” GST officials said on Monday.

“We found that Maithan Ispat Ltd at Kalinga Nagar in Jajpur district acquired fictitious input tax credit between April 2018 and November 2018 without the due support of relevant documents,” Santosh Kumar Mohanty, additional director (directorate general of GST intelligence, Bhubaneswar), said. “They took inflated ITC in their GST return without receipts of any goods and services. They had no requisite documents to claim the credit,” he added.

The directorate general of GST intelligence began an investigation after it received information about the alleged tax fraud. Following this, GST officials raided Maithan’s factory and office premises in Jajpur and found evidence of the alleged tax offence. They also found that the company had ‘illegally’ applied for Rs 23 crore ITC while filing GST return from April 2018 to November 2018. Report said the two executives allegedly claimed the money as their GST liability in a ‘fraudulent manner’.

GST authorities said the alleged offence of the company caused a loss of Rs 23 crore to the government exchequer.

“Further investigation revealed that Patra and Padhi were behind the manipulation. Efforts are on to recover the government dues along with interest and penalty,” Mohanty said.

Patra, who was arrested in Bhubaneswar, was produced him in the court of sub-divisional judicial magistrate (SDJM). On the other hand, Padhi was caught in Kolkata and produced in the court of additional chief judicial magistrate, Sealdah, in Kolkata. The two were sent to 14-day judicial custody. Maithan Ispat authorities were not available for comment.

Title: Haridwar: Leopard strays into house in Tehri district, rescued
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The leopard was sent to chiriyapur rescue centre at Haridwar

HARIDWAR: A leopard was rescued from a house in Anguda village of Bhilangna block of Tehri on Monday. The animal had strayed into the house while chasing the owner’s pet dog. The forest department managed to trap it in a cage and sent it to Chidiyapur rescue centre at Haridwar.

The leopard was chasing the dog of a man, Nagendera Singh. As the dog took refuge in the family’s storeroom, the animals followed it there. The dog escaped and Singh’s nephew, who had witnessed the episode, locked the leopard in the room. The forest department has increased patrolling in the area, anticipating the presence of more leopards, as villagers complained of the threat.

In Dehradun , an animal rescue team has been put on alert after two leopards were sighted near IPS colony in the city on Monday. The entire belt stretching from the foothills of Mussoorie, Raipur range, Jhajhra to Asharodi, has leopards in it. The animals are sighted every day as they travel at least 25 to 30 kms per day. Rapid urbanisation is another reason for frequent leopard sightings.

Another leopard was rescued recently from Pauri. The wild cat had entered the bathroom of a house and the owner locked the door from outside

Title: Former JNU students reach out to teachers, juniors; some fly to Delhi to stand by them
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Police and students in JNU campus, after some masked miscreants attacked the campus (PTI Phot)

KOLKATA: As news of the attack on their alma mater flashed across TV screens on Sunday evening, former students of Jawaharlal Nehru University reached out, calling up current students to offer help and solidarity and posting updates on social media.

Some, like Abhinav Sharma, who had stayed at Sabarmati Hostel—where masked, lathi-wielding goons entered and assaulted students and professors indiscriminately—took a flight to Delhi the very next day to stand by the people he had been so close to. “I couldn’t stay calm. I saw photos and videos of the assault on some of my juniors and teachers and rushed to JNU on Monday to meet them. In a WhatsApp video, I saw my guide, professor Sucharita Sen, being severely injured. I have come here to meet her. I couldn’t speak to her at length as she said she was still in pain and trauma. But as a former student of JNU, my blood boils at the sight of the carnage at the institute and we will see an end to it,” Sharma told TOI over phone. From Kolkata, Sharma passed out of JNU last year after completing his PhD and now, teaches at an institute in Shillong.

Another such protester is Indrani Dutt, a political science student from Presidency College, who did her MA in JNU and is now employed with a top Indian business conglomerate in its communications wing. “I have been writing on closed WhatsApp groups and trying to collect news about my juniors. In the morning, I put out a Facebook post. I was amazed how some tried to justify the attacks. I have stayed at Sabarmati. Some of my closest friends there never shared my political ideology but we never stooped this low. I wonder what happened to good old days,” she said.

The Facebook post she mentioned was: “My post did not have any political party mentioned nor do I wish to support or shame anyone. I feel extremely disturbed looking at the situation in the country and especially my alma mater. Please allow me my space to show my disappointment... hope this answers all your questions!!! As regards the university and its history... This has been the hub of intellectual brilliance over ages and given the world eminent scholars and academicians only. Don’t know why and on whose insistence this violence crept into every educational institution across d country only in recent times!!”

The more politically vocal former students wondered if the impunity with which the attack was carried out was a well-laid plan. Prasenjit Bose, one of the most recognizable faces of the SFI at JNU even after years of leaving the university did not mince his words, sharing alleged screenshots of what he claimed “were preparations for the attack”. “Having accomplished their terror attacks across campus, the fascist Stormtroopers left JNU with full impunity. Delhi Police will act only after they leave…” he wrote, blaming top central ministers for failing to stop the attack.

Dwaipayan Bera, who studied economics at Presidency and did MA at JNU, updated every detail he got through the night. “Who says it’s just Italian fascist blackshirts , last night they were vintage hooded Klu Klux Klan!” he said, in a reference to an American much-hated supremacist gang. “The violence is unheard of. But the students must be united at this time of crisis,” he wrote.

Title: Rehabilitation centre for disabled people cries for new equipment
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: At least 20 people suffering from various forms of physical disabilities come to the department for disabled people daily at the collectorate on weekdays to undergo free physiotherapy and access muscle strengthening and flexibility equipment free of cost. Ironically, most of the equipment in the department are outdated and rusting.

Though the department had requested for replacement and upgradation of the equipment at its rehabilitation centre, the government is yet to sanction fund. Instead, the department has been asked to move out of the current space. Neither the department was able to find a new space nor get the fund from the government.

Sikkandar Basha, 36, suffered a stroke six years ago with his entire right side paralyzed and trouble in speaking.

His mother and brother used to bring him in their vehicle and leave him at the rehabilitation centre within the district administration hoping for some improvement.

“I can now take a bus, come to the centre on my own, eat on my own and return. Earlier I could not even walk,” Basha said when asked about the improvement he has had after coming to the centre.
