“Besides becoming physically independent, this place is my confidence booster, because its free to use. They get us a bus pass, so even that is free. And now they have given me a job as a sweeper, helping me earn close to Rs 1,000 a month, making me slightly financially independent too,” another beneficiary Sebastian said.

The rehabilitation centre that was started nearly 21 years back has one physiotherapist, two physiotherapy students interning with them and 12 machines which primarily focus on muscle strengthening. This includes the exercise cycle to focus on lower limb and ankle strengthening, the sliding chair which helps strengthen quadriceps muscles, abduction reduction for shoulder strengthening and finger ladders for finger strengthening, among others.

“While some machines are very old, the other came around six years back after the collector issued us a special grant. Though the majority work, updated versions are available in the market,” an official said. The ultrasound machine for pain relief has stopped working too. “Newer equipment will work better on our new patients and will attract more poor people to use our centre which is free, rather than go to private places which charge at least Rs 1,000 a month plus Rs 300 with a physiotherapist or not get treated at all,” the official said.

The disabled department commissioner has agreed to replace the equipment but has put it on hold since the disability welfare department has been asked to shift premises by the district administration. The district administration plans to demolish the old buildings. “We are constantly searching for a new space,” district disabled welfare officer Thangamani said.

“Because, if we get the new equipment now, we will have to install it and then remove it during shifting to the new space,” he said.

Title: Tejas departs 1 hr late, rlys to compensate passengers
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Lucknow: Country’s first private semi-high speed train Tejas Express departed late by one hour from Lucknow on Monday. Officials said passengers are entitled for compensation due to the delay.

Tejas Express leaves Lucknow at 6.10am and reaches New Delhi railway station at 12.25pm. On return, it leaves Delhi at 3.35pm and reaches here at 10.05pm. The maximum delay was on Saturday, when the train arrived at Lucknow station 3.56 hours late.

Passengers said that they prefer shelling out more for booking Tejas ticket because it is said to be safe and punctual, but now it is also running late like other trains.

Tamanna Seth, who came to drop her parents at Lucknow junction, said, “My septuagenarian parents avoid air journey, hence they opted for Tejas Express... They had to wait in the cold weather on the platform for an hour due to the delay.”

Chief regional manager, IRCTC, Lucknow, Ashwini Srivastava said, “The train is running late mainly because of fog. If the delay is between one and two hours, passengers are given Rs 100 as compensation. If the delay exceeds two hours, they get Rs 250.”

Besides Tejas, 24 other trains arrived and departed late from various Lucknow stations on Monday. They included Rajdhani Express, Gomti Express, Marudhar Express, Doon Express, Avadh Assam Express, Rapti Sagar Express and Kota-Patna Express.

Senior divisional commercial manager, northern railway, Lucknow division, Jagtosh Shukla said, “Dense fog in various parts of northern region is the main reason behind late arrival and departure of trains.”

Title: Replace poorly maintained vehicles, urge ‘108’ ambulance drivers
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: A group of ‘108’ ambulance drivers on Monday petitioned the collector requesting him to buy new ambulance vehicles.

The drivers, members of the Tamil Nadu 108 Ambulance Drivers Welfare Association, said that most of the ambulances in the city have three lakh kilometres and are badly maintained. “It is important that ambulances run well and smoothly as they carry hundreds of people fighting for their lives. But most of our vehicles are not fit for use. They are also not maintained well. We demand that these vehicles be changed,” said driver M Guna. “There are no proper sheds to park the vehicles and clean them regularly. Many of the patients vomit and bleed while being carried to hospitals. We just park the vehicles on the road and clean them.”

As many as 39 such vehicles operate in the district, including two bike ambulances and two neonatal ambulances.

The drivers demanded an increase in salaries and complained about forced transfer to other states and districts. “Despite being paid just Rs 12,000 a month, we get penalized even for small damages to the vehicles. We have to pay up even if a tree branch falls on the roof of the vehicles,” said the petition. “Those who protest are forcibly transferred to Kerala or to other districts. From every district, five to six people are transferred to Kerala. If we refuse, the administration threatens to fire us. This has to be stopped.”

Meanwhile, ‘108’ ambulance authorities said they had just begun operations in Kerala and technicians from Tamil Nadu are sent to the neighbouring state on two to three weeks deputations to train the staff there.

Muthukrishnan, ‘108’ ambulance administrator in Coimbatore, told TOI that many vehicles have crossed 3 lakh kilometres. “We have sent the list to the state government. The officials usually inspect the condemned vehicles and decide whether they can be used further or be used for the free hearse service. Regional transport officials inspect the vehicles for fitness every year and we have a maintenance schedule, which is followed strictly.”

The vehicles don’t have a specific parking shed or washing area as of now, the official said. “We are in talks with Coimbatore Medical College Hospital (CMCH) dean B Ashokan for a space to wash the vehicles. But since the hospital is a place of mass gathering, the threat of infections is high. It also requires a corporation clearance. We are working on it,” he added.

Title: Kolkata: Cops file FIR against BJP supporters for burning tyre at rally
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Members of Chhatra Parishad and DSO take out rallies on College Street on Monday to protest against the attack... Read More

KOLKATA: Police on Monday registered a suo motu FIR against BJP supporters for setting fire to a tyre on the road after their protest rally was stopped at Sulekha More in Jadavpur.

BJP workers took to the streets on Monday evening to protest against an alleged attack on their party office at Sulekha More on Sunday night. A group of students from Jadavpur University had allegedly defaced the BJP office, tore down banners and burnt the party’s flag.

“It was around 11.45pm on Sunday that a mob of around 200 youths gathered in front of our house. The BJP party office is on the ground floor,” said Arun Bardhan, the owner of the property. “They painted abusive words across the wall and tore down Syama Prasad Mukherjee’s poster. Some of them even removed BJP flags and set them on fire. My family is now too scared to stay here.”

Echoing him, Dibakar Pal, a member of the local BJP unit, said, “There were around 200 students who came with rods and torches and vandalized the office. They tried to break into the residence of a party worker at midnight. We have never seen such violence in Bagha Jatin area.”

In protest more than 200 BJP workers started a rally from Bagha Jatin on Monday evening but the procession was stopped midway at Sulekha More, where the cops put up a three-layer barricade to prevent any face- off. In spite of reportedly being stopped at the first barricade, BJP leader Anupam Hazra said they would continue the march till Jadavpur police station. Meanwhile, BJP supporters brought a tyre and set it on fire.

A group of BJP workers reportedly tried to breach the barricade after nearly 40 minutes and police stopped them. Some of the BJP workers allegedly started throwing stones.

Title: Nagpur: Poor maintenance, filthy buses draw civic body's ire
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Newly-elected transport committee chairman Balya Borkar on Monday directed the civic administration to slap Rs5 lakh fine each on the three red bus operators and Rs2 lakh fine on programme manager DIMTS for keeping Aapli buses filthy.

On January 2 and 3, Borkar along with NMC’s transport department officials visited all three depots of red bus operators — Orange Street depot (Hingna), Patwardhan ground depot, and Khapri depot at 5am, and inspected 223 buses. “During the spot inspection, the team found poor maintenance of NMC run Aapli buses,” Borkar told TOI.

NMC had roped in three bus operators — Travel Times Car Rentals, RK City Operations, and Hansa City Bus Services — and is plying around 380 buses. Over 1.50 lakh commuters use the city bus service daily. TOI has been highlighting the issue of poor maintenance and other irregularities. In the recent past, TOI also reported many buses were stranded on the road, causing hardship to commuters. Of the over 380 buses plying every day, at least 200 have already completed 10 years.

Most standard buses emit thick black smoke, have damaged seats and broken windowpanes, hinting at poor maintenance. Even mayor Sandip Joshi had in December warned the operators to improve Aapli bus condition by month-end or ill-maintained buses will not be allowed to ply on city roads.

Despite repeated warnings nothing has improved, said Borkar. Som he along with transport department administrative officer Ravindra Page, executive engineer Kedar Mishra, labour officer Arun Pipurde and accounts officer Vinay Bharadwaj conducted surprise inspection of the bus depots.

Borkar said there was a provision to penalize red bus operators for poor maintenance of city buses. Despite this clause in the tender agreement, the programme manager DIMTS has not done anything and as a result commuters were facing inconvenience in travelling in the ill-maintained buses, he pointed out. “I have also directed the administration to impose Rs2 lakh fine on DIMTS,” he said.

Title: Sri Lanka plans to renovate Sita Temple
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BHOPAL: The Sri Lankan government is considering the Madhya Pradesh’s proposal for renovation of Sita Mata temple in Nuwara Eliya . Taking a step closer to strengthen relations with India, Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksha said he would soon visit famous Boddh shrine in Sanchi .

State public relations and spiritual minister, PC Sharma, during his short visit to Sri Lanka, met Rajapaksha and invited him to Sanchi on behalf of chief minister Kamal Nath . Sharma also shared view on the development of religious and tourist places in the both the countries.

Accepting the invitation, Rajapaksha said he would soon plan a visit to Sanchi. He said Sri Lankan government was seriously considering the proposal by MP government to renovate the hold Sita Mata temple in Sri Lanka."President Rajapaksa expressed happiness over the proposal of a cultural exchange programme based on folk culture, between Sri Lanka and India. The President of Sri Lanka also agreed to the proposal to start Bhopal-Colombo direct air service," said Sharma in a statement here.

The two leaders also discussed in detail, the development of World Buddhist Museum, educational institute, training and spiritual centre for monks and Buddhist Chanting Center in Sanchi.

On this occasion, the International President of Mahabodhi Society, Bhikkhu Wangal Uptis Nayak Thero, additional chief secretary of spirituality department, Manoj Shrivastava and adviser VK Amar were present in the MP delegation. Minister Sharma also handed over a momentum to Sri Lankan President on behalf of the MP government.

Title: Vadodara: 169 properties sealed to recover taxes
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) sealed 169 commercial properties across the city to recover pending property taxes on Monday.

The civic body has started sealing drive for commercial properties as the financial year nears its end. In the coming days, it is also expected to start a drive for severing water and drainage connections of residential properties.

Detailed provided by VMC officials reveal that out of the 169 properties sealed on Monday, the highest number of properties were from ward 6 where 30 establishments were sealed. The lowest number of properties were from ward nine where only seven properties were sealed. Officials said that tax amounting to Rs 119.54crore was due from the properties that were sealed.

On Saturday, officials had sealed 123 commercial properties across the city to recover pending taxes.

Title: VGL MD withdraws anticipatory bail plea
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Cap

Vadodara: The managing director of Vadodara Gas Ltd (VGL), who is also the chief general manager of Gail India Ltd, withdrew his anticipatory bail plea which had come up for hearing in the court of principal district judge here on Monday morning.

The bail applicant Ashokkumar Das had sought anticipatory bail in connection with the PNG blast case in which four persons had died in 2018 although he had not been named as an accused in the case.

In response to Das’s application, the investigating officer had requested the court that the bail application be cancelled. The complainant’s advocate too opposed the application as Das has been summoned by police for his statement.

“They reiterated the same thing as it was in the application that they only handle the CNG operations while the PNG operations are handled by the commercial director,” said complainant’s advocate Viraj Thakkar. He added that Das informed the court that he was under the fear of getting arrested to which the court said that if he had not done anything wrong then why he is under fear.

The sub-inspector of police informed the court that he had not summoned Das for arresting him but only to record his statements. The sub-inspector gave in writing to the court that Das would not be arrested without evidence against him.

“The police have assured that if evidence found against him, they will inform the MD 48 hours before arresting him,” Thakkar said.

Title: Nagpur: 21 crimes/day in city last year: Police data
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

NAGPUR: The latest crime data released by the city police department revealed that state’s second capital witnessed 21 offences, including serious ones, in 2019. Commissioner of police BK Upadhyay on Monday claimed that prohibitory actions against goons and anti-social elements helped police decrease crime rate by 10% as compared to 2018.

In 2019, the city police registered 7,722 offences, including 83 murders and 75 attempt to murder cases. The total offences are 863 less than 2018 when 8,585 cases were registered.

Interacting with the media, the top cop said that 2019 was challenging for the department due to general and state assembly elections, winter session and several protests, including rallies on CAA-NRC and NPR issues.

In 2019, police cracked around 5,006 cases, while 2,716 remained unsolved. The detection rate increased by 3% as compared to 2018 when 5,369 cases were solved. CCTV cameras installed across the city helped cops crack many crimes in 2019, the CP said.

There was overall decline in major crimes in 2019 as compared to 2018, except in cases of domestic violence, criminal breach of trust and murder. In 2018, 77 murder cases were registered, which are six less as compared to 2019. On this, the CP said that of the 83 murders in 2019, 39 took place due to domestic issues.

On the recent attack on mayor Sandip Joshi, Upadhyay said the case should have been detected by now. “No major clue or motive has come to fore. We have narrowed our investigation to a person following some technical clues but there is no concrete proof yet,” he said.

The CP also set the agenda for this year, laying emphasis on women’s safety and police welfare. “In 2019, around 30 police constables had died. Out of them, 22 deaths were due to cardiac arrests. So, we are planning to create awareness regarding health and fitness among police personnel,” he said.

There are plans to categorize police constables on the basis of their health. According to the CP, those having heart problems will be assigned duties with less workload.

The CP also claimed that initiatives like Bharosa Cell, Damini Pathak and regular visits to college and school increased awareness among citizens about the law. “We are planning to give special focus on cyber crimes against women as it has become a big concern. The police chief urged citizens to not upload any private information on social media which can be used against them.

The city police chief has also said that undetected cases, including some murders, will be reviewed.

Joint CP Ravindra Kadam, additional CP (north region), additional CP (crime) Nilesh Bharne along with most of the DCPs were present at the press conference.

Title: Nagpur: A family outing on bicycles, for over 500km through Western Ghats
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The family hailing from city covered the distance in just nine days

NAGPUR: Cycling runs (or should we say pedals) in this family of four from the city. The quartet, comprising two girls aged 14 and 10, recently “pedalled over 500km” to complete anexpedition covering the stretch of Western Ghats from Goa to Sindhudurg, Ratnagiri and Raigad districts in Konkan in just nine days.

Hasan Shafiq, Sarah Shafiq, along with their elder daughter Batul and her sibling Fatema started the cycling expedition from Panaji (Goa) on December 23 and reached Nagaon village in Alibaugh tehsil of Raigad on December 30.

The expedition organized by Youth Hostels Association of India (YHAI) saw participation by 29 cyclists from across the country. The family trained, physically as well as mentally, for a month to participate in the adventure ride. “We are not big time into fitness activities but were passionate about participating in this expedition and trained for it in the city itself,” said Hasan Shafiq.

Batul and Fatema left no stone unturned to complete the expedition successfully. “I love sports and also exercise regularly. The enthusiastic participation by so many people made it really exciting and a thrilling experience,” said Batul. According to the family, Fatema was the youngest cyclist in the expedition to pedal the entire stretch on her own.

According to Hasan, they pedalled for a total of 573km. “Every day we would start at 7 in the morning, ride on an average 65km for almost 12 hours to reach the day’s destination before sunset,” he said. The Western Ghats terrain with its steep ups and downs presented challenges that would get tougher whenever the cyclists encountered heavy traffic while riding in the high temperature and humidity.

The family took utmost care to overcome fatigue and also kept with it tools needed to repair the bicycles in case of an emergency.

The tiring schedule was made charming by the beautiful view of nature that awaited them all along the route, the family said. The tough terrain became bearable thanks to the serene and mesmerizing coastline.

Apart from being physically demanding, the expedition required great mental strength and conviction. “As a mother I was equal parts nervous and excited for the trip. My daughters displayed true sportsman spirit. I am very proud of them,” said Sarah.

“We are really grateful to the entire team of YHAI for allowing us to participate in this expedition,” said Hasan.

The expedition was led by Santosh Shirke of Mumbai and Ramesh Kene was the chief coordinator and tour manager.

Title: Dehradun: Scam in payment of sanitation worker salaries
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sanitation workers have often held protests over their wages getting stalled

DEHRADUN: Following complaints by several sanitation workers regarding untimely payment of salaries, mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama has asked all the 100 ward councillors in the city to submit the salary payment records of the sweepers working in their respective areas.

Last year, 635 sanitation workers were appointed and the responsibility to transfer their payment and maintain other records was given to the local ward councillors. Each sanitation worker was promised a salary of Rs 8,000 per month. However, many of them have not been receiving this amount regularly. Even though the DMC doesn’t possess records of these sanitation workers, it releases a cumulative salary amount which is put directly into the bank account of the ‘Mohalla Swachhta Samiti’, a body set up by ward councillors to improve sanitation of the city.

There have been allegations of mishandling of the DMC funds by ward councillors, many of whom it is alleged are not transferring the due amount to the accounts of sanitary workers. It is also alleged that the exact number of sanitary workers in each area have not been properly communicated by the councillors to the DMC.

When queried on the issue, ward councillors denied the allegations. “Not even a single ward councillor in the city is mishandling salaries of sanitation workers. We have proper salary records of all the sanitation workers in our respective wards. The salaries of sanitation workers are being transferred regularly to their bank accounts,” claimed Amita Singh, councillor from Balliwala ward.

Dheeraj Bharti, secretary of Akhil Bhartiya Safai Mazdoor Sangh, the body representing the sanitation workers meanwhile said, “It is not certain if any of the ward councillors is involved in mishandling of funds, but we feel that DMC should transfer the amount directly into the bank accounts of sanitary workers rather than sending it into the account of Mohalla Swacchta Samiti. That would be a more transparent thing to do.”

Title: Who brought kids to anti-CAA agitation? None has an answer
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

A girl raises slogans at the anti-CAA stir organised by an NGO at Chepauk on Monday.

CHENNAI: At least 10 children were used as pawns on Monday during the protest against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register for Citizens (NRC) organised by NGO Makkal Athikaram .

The protesters, who encouraged their children to raise slogans and wield placards, refused to prove they were their parents or legal guardians. Police, who took the children away, threatened to hand them over to a children’s home if their parents did not reveal more information. Police said it sought help from the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) during the operation but CWC members said they weren’t informed.

The organisation, which planned a rally towards the Secretariat, changed its venue to Chepauk after police blocked Kamarajar Salai.

Around 750 members of Makkal Athikaram then sat on protest near the Chepauk Guest House, blocking vehicular movement from Bells Road Junction on Wallajah Road towards University of Madras. They raised slogans against the central and state governments. Police detained the protesters at marriage halls and corporation community centres.

Police said they called CWC and asked them to take away the children. The agitation went on for nearly four hours before the protesters were arrested.

“Everyone who was arrested gave their address as Makkal Athikaram state office, #4, Maduravoyal, Chennai. We did not know where to issue summons to the agitators while moving the court. Also, we were not able to verify the details of the children. We thought they will reveal their address if we hold back the kids. So we wanted to hand them over to the CWC as per rules,” said police inspector Mohandas. But CWC members refused to take them, he said. Police said frisking members also did not help.

CWC member Isabel R told TOI that the committee was not intimated about the children. Later, when police released the protesters, they demanded that the children should also be sent with them. “We did send them away,” police said.

Title: Pune: Protesters take over street corners, education campuses after JNU violence
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

People, mostly students, raise slogans on the SPPU campus and on Fergusson College Road against the violence a... Read More

PUNE: The anger over Sunday’s attack on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) students and teachers spilled onto the roads and educational campuses in the city on Monday.

Members of students’ organisations, social outfits and civil society groups came out to protest the assault on JNU pupils and teachers. The Aniket canteen at the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) became the central rallying point of the protesters.

One group of the protesters blamed the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) and, in turn, BJP for the attack on the JNU students. The other group of protesters was of the ABVP’s city unit, which blamed the JNU Students’ Union (JNUSU) for the violence.

The biggest protest of the day was seen at SPPU’s Aniket canteen, where around 500 students and members of the civil society groups gathered around 7pm and raised slogans against the ABVP for the JNU violence.

“The Delhi police come under the Union home ministry, of which Amit Shah is in charge. This means he is also responsible for the attack on the JNU students and teachers,” former inspector general of police (Maharashtra) S M Mushrif said.

Minister of state Vishwajit Kadam said, “These people are afraid of democracy and free speech. Students are living in an environment of fear. Let me assure you as a minister of this state that nobody can touch you (students) in this land of Shivaji-Phule-Shahu-Ambedkar.”

On Monday morning, around 20 ABVP supporters staged a protest in front of Aniket canteen and blamed leftist groups for the JNU violence. “ABVP did not spread violence on the JNU campus. Rather, the left wing students’ union attacked ABVP students. Over 20 students, who are ABVP members, were injured and admitted to the All India Institute of Medical Sciences. The Delhi police should punish the guilty,” said Dayanand Shinde, ABVP president at SPPU.

Around 5pm, members of several organisations gathered at the district collectorate under the banner of “Hum Bharat ke log”. Besides students from various educational institutes, the rally was attended by representatives of the Rashtra Seva Dal, Yuvak Kranti Dal (Yukrand) Poona College, Samyak Vidyarthi Andolan, All India Democratic Women’s Association) and the Students’ Federation of India to express their solidarity with the JNU students.

Film and Television Institute of India (FTII) students, who started their agitation from Sunday night, also protested on Monday. Some students took part in the demonstration outside the collectorate, while others joined a march from the FTII’s Law College Road campus to the Aniket canteen in the evening.

Another group of FTII students staged a protest outside Cafe Goodluck on Fergusson College Road, which was largely organized by social organization Lokayat and saw a turnout of nearly 200 people.

“On Tuesday, we will organize a march from FTII to the SPPU grounds, for which we have permission from the Pune police,” FTII Students Association general secretary Rajorshi Majumder said.

Title: CM Naveen Patnaik condemns JNU attack, seeks action against culprits
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CM Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Monday condemned the violence at Jawaharlal Nehru University ( JNU ) in New Delhi and demanded action against the culprits.

“Shocked to know about the violent #JNUattack. Violence has no space in democracy and such attacks on students must be condemned unequivocally. Appeal law enforcement agencies to take swift action to apprehend the culprits and wish the injured students a speedy recovery,” Naveen tweeted.

Leaders across political divide condemned the incident in which masked miscreants attacked students and teachers of JNU.

Terming the attack as heinous, BJD spokesperson Sasmit Patra said, “The university administration and police must take strong steps to arrest the culprits and ensure a safe and secure ecosystem for students at JNU.”

BJD’s Amar Patnaik wondered, “How such organised violence could not be prevented in the national capital of an emerging super power!”

Odisha Pradesh Congress Committee president Niranjan Patnaik said the planned attack on JNU is meant to suppress its autonomy and pursuit of intellectual freedom. “It is highly condemnable & shameful. It is a matter of grave concern that fascist forces want to de-democratize India through violence. Every Indian must stand up against it,” he said.

Addressing a news conference here, Congress leader Debasis Patnaik termed the attack as ‘government sponsored.’ “The BJP leadership is unwilling to accept any democratic voice of dissent. The attack in JNU after a similar incident in Jamia Milia Islamia shows country’s democracy is in serious danger,” Debasis said.

Members of the All India Democratic Students Organisation (AIDSO) put up a demonstration in front of Rama Devi Women’s University expressing their anguish against the JNU attack. “The JNU violence was perpetrated to crush the countrywide protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act and plan for National Register of Citizens,” a statement issued by AIDSO Bhubaneswar city committee said. CPI activists staged a demonstration holding placards blaming ABVP for the attack while the ABVP blamed the Left for it.

State BJP vice-president Sameer Mohanty said the police investigation will reveal the truth. “The violence is condemnable. However, instead of indulging in a blame-game, one should wait for the investigation findings. The academic glory must be restored.”

Title: Despite animal slaughter ban, meat shops flouting rules in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Haridwar: Residents have complained that meat shops continue to operate in the city and slaughter animals in the open, in defiance of an Uttarakhand high court (HC) order passed last year, and that the district administration and police have failed to take action against them.

The HC in its order had said meat should be procured only from licensed slaughterhouses, and no animal should be slaughtered in individual meat shops in the district. Yet, several meat shops where animal are slaughtered are being run in the Haridwar municipal area and adjoining places.

Activist J P Badoni told TOI that despite the HC ban on slaughter of animals for meat in shops in residential area of the district, police, municipal and food safety authorities haven’t taken action against the rule breakers.

However, Haridwar police claimed they had asked meat shop owners to procure meat only from authorised slaughterhouses. SSP Haridwar Senthil Abudai Krishna Raj S said, “Food safety department and municipal authority are responsible for giving permits and checking status. We just give NOC regarding law and order. We have alerted meat shop owners not to slaughter animals inside their shops.”

Food safety officials said their department has given permission to just six meat shops to sell chicken, that too, after procuring meat from authorised slaughterhouses.

Food safety officer Kapil Dev told TOI, “Slaughtering animals in meat shops was banned by Nainital high court. We have handed out only six licenses to sell meat, keep regular check on these shops time to time and take strict action against law breakers.”

However, a survey by TOI found that several other shops are being run illegally where animals are slaughtered in the open. With no slaughterhouse in Haridwar district, meat sellers have to buy from ones in western UP. This raises their overheads, which is why they are slaughtering animals on their own.

Title: Money in pockets talk was sarcastic, in jest: Min Thakur
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nagpur: Trolled and targeted by opposition for “money in pockets” remark, state women and child development minister Yashomati Thakur said she was only repeating the words of a former BJP state president and those were “sarcastic in nature”. Thakur was speaking on Saturday in Washim while campaigning for zilla parishad elections to be held on Tuesday.

In a video that went viral, Thakur allegedly told voters that “they (Maha Vikas Aghadi ministers) had just taken oath and their pockets are yet to be filled up”. “The pockets of BJP leaders are full. If they approach voters’ homes with Laxmi (money), don’t say no to them. But ensure that you will vote for panja (Congress symbol),” she said in her speech.

According to BJP activists, party neta Kirit Somaiyya lodged a complaint with the state election commission (SEC) claiming Thakur was instigating people to indulge in corrupt practices.

On Monday, Thakur told TOI: “It was just an election rally where I was quoting the BJP leader without naming him. It was a tongue-in-cheek comment but the BJP has blown it out of proportion.”

Accusing the BJP of targeting her, the Teosa MLA said, “I was indirectly targeting a ZP president who was sitting with other people in the audience. He’s highly corrupt. I was reminding the ZP president and voters of what the state BJP president had said and it was sort of an informal conversation with them. These are all opposition’s tactics to divert the attention from main problems plaguing the nation.”

Stating that she was an upcoming face of the Congress, the daughter of former MLA Bhaiyyasaheb Thakur, charged BJP of “not respecting women”. “How many women netas do you see in the assembly? Is it really good to troll them when you talked about equality? The opposition is misleading people by spreading rumours. My intent was never wrong, it was in jest,” she said.

Leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis also targeted Thakur, without naming her directly, during campaigning for ZP polls in Nagpur. “This government is not formed for governance, but for filling up of their coffers at the exchequer’s expense. One of their ministers stated that as they were sworn in recently, they would need time to fill up pockets, and therefore can’t offer money to voters,” he said.

Title: Haridwar admin unable to open godown as it’s filled to brim, HC orders auction
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nainital: In a somewhat unusual submission before the Uttarakhand high court (HC), the Haridwar district administration said that it is not able to open a sugar godown because it has been filled to the brim.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma while hearing a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) had directed the Haridwar district magistrate on December 13 to assess the quantity of sugar in the godown. The administration in its reply to court said, “Godown has been filled to the brim with sugar bags and the officials are not in a position to enter the godown for physical verification.”

The PIL filed by Haridwar resident Nitin has raised the issue of high-level mismanagement and misappropriation of public money by a sugar mill in Roorkee area of Haridwar district.

Speaking to TOI, the petitioner said that the mill has siphoned off farmers’ money and has taken loans fraudulently by telling the banks that the sugar in its godown is owned by them. “The government, in December 2018, made the DM receiver of the sugar mill as it had not made payments to the farmers for the season 2017-18. The main purpose of appointing DM as receiver was to make payments to farmers from the sale,” the petition read.

The petitioner told the court that despite more than a year passing since the DM was appointed receiver, the auction is yet to take place and over Rs 200 crore of almost 15,000 farmers is still due.

After this, the court ordered the DM to assess the quantity of the sugar in mill and auction and thereafter file a compliance report before February 10 when the case will be heard next.

Title: Lucknow: Gun ‘missing’, man says forgot where he kept it
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: An official at UP stamp and registration department on Monday informed Gomtinagar police that his licensed revolver has gone “missing” and he is unable to recall where he has kept it.

In his complaint, Ramanand Singh, 44, said as he was a government servant and overburdened with work, he did not remember when he last saw the revolver in his house.

Singh, who hails from Gorakhpur but has permanent address in Vineet Khand, Gomtinagar, said he searched for his revolver at his house after police started an audit of licensed firearms but could not find it.

“I searched all probable places where I could have kept the gun, but could not locate it. I am a government employee and overburdened with work. I can’t recall when I last saw the gun in my house,” Singh informed cops. He said he was lodging complaint to inform police that the revolver could be misused.

Police have registered a case of theft against him.

Station house officer of Gomtinagar police station, Amit Kumar Dubey said: “Since the last location of the revolver was in Lucknow, he has lodged a complaint here. We will record his statement and take action accordingly.”

Title: Retail investors should avoid kneejerk reaction: Experts
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Small and retail investors should not panic and take a hasty decision with their money and other investments in the current volatile market, brokers and investment advisers have said. They add that it's the geopolitical situation in the Middle East which is leading to jitters in global markets.While it is also impacting India, the domestic market is likely to be less affected than those that are more closely linked to the stand-off between the US and Iran."For retail investors, the safest thing now is not to do anything in this volatile situation," said KR Choksey Investment Managers MD Deven Choksey. "Allow some clarity to emerge...it's always better to operate when there's clarity about the investment environment," he added.Choksey believes that since Iran is already under economic and trade sanctions imposed by the US, not much of its oil is coming into the global market.However, what could change this situation is if Iran blocks the Strait of Hormuz - one of the world's most important sea passages through which about a fourth of global crude is shipped, said another broker. Investment advisers too believe that it's difficult to pinpoint for how long the current geopolitical tensions could continue and how it could end."The main factor that is currently pulling the Indian market down has its origin outside the country. So it's difficult to predict when it could end and how," said Arun Kejriwal, director of investment advisory firm KRIS. Kejriwal also believes that once the current volatility subsides, small and midcap stocks, which witnessed lacklustre trades during the past several months, could be the sectors to watch out for.Brokers also believe that foreign portfolio investors (FPIs), who pumped over $14 billion into Indian stocks in 2019 and nearly $20 billion across all assets classes - including debt and hybrid instruments - may not be in a hurry to take money out of the country. However, among the various types of foreign investors, exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are expected to be the first to sell in a major way in case the slide continues for some more time. On Monday, the sensex and Nifty both lost nearly 2% each.Investment advisers also said that in case an investor has extra cash to invest, he should put the same either in savings bank account, short-term FDs or liquid funds. They also said that if an investor already has a financial plan in place and has been investing according to that to reach life's financial goals, investments under such plans should not be stopped or changed just because the market has turned volatile.

Title: Maharashtra’s NPR rollout in May hits uncertain waters
Content:
Congress cabinet minister Varsha Gaikwad

PUNE: Congress cabinet minister Varsha Gaikwad has issued a statement that the Maha Vikas Aghadi will not allow the rollout of the drive for the National Population Register in May.She said it would be “unconstitutional”. Her statement has created confusion among Census officials who have to start the Census and NPR drive in May-June in the state.Chief minister Uddhav Thackeray has yet to issue a formal statement about the rollout of the National Population Register drive.Gaikwad told TOI that she would meet the chief minister with a request to stop the NPR process in the state.“The chief ministers of West Bengal , Punjab, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh and Chhatisgarh announced that the Citizenship Amendment Act was unconstitutional and had no place in their respective states. It can be done for Maharashtra too,’’ Gaikwad, who recently took oath as the school education minister, said.Gaikwad was at a function on Sunday. She said the government will "try not to implement" the Citizenship Amendment Act in the state.The CAA, NRC and NPR are against the Constitution, she added. “I had gone to a function to assure the students that our government will try not to implement the CAA and NRC here in Maharashtra,” she told TOI.She said students across the country are protesting and the Centre will have to take notice. The NPR is to be carried out with the census drive according to officials. “We are awaiting guidelines,’’ senior officials from the department said.Citizens, civil societies and the opposition in the Centre are protesting against CAA and have expressed fear over NPR and NRC.The first phase of the National Population Register (NPR) and Census 2021 for the state will be completed between May 1 and June 15 next year. The NPR and census exercise will be carried out in all states between April and September 2020.

Title: Vijayvargiya will be arrested as soon as police probe is over: Minister
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kolkata, Sep 25 (ANI): BJP leader Kailash Vijayvargiya holds ektara and poses with the artists during a devoti... Read More

Bhopal: Trouble seems to deepen for BJP national general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya. A minister of the Kamal Nath government said on Monday that the BJP leader could soon be arrested for “threatening to set Indore on fire”.

“Vijayvargiya will be arrested after police complete their investigation,” minister for cooperatives Dr Govind Singh told mediapersons in Gwalior. “The law will take its course and punitive action will be taken for the threat to set Indore on fire. Investigation is not yet complete. Some more statements will be recorded and several new sections will be added to the case. Once all this process is over, arrest will follow. This government is not so weak that it cannot arrest Kailash Vijayvargiya,” he added. On Sunday, police registered cases against Vijayvargiya and 350 BJP workers for allegedly threatening government officials.

Referring to the infamous pension scam that the state government plans to reinvestigate, Singh asked Vijayvargiya to “look inward, at his conscience”. “I want to ask Kailash Vijayvargiya, what was the golden tree he planted that today he has property and assets worth crores of rupees? Lakhs of poor persons, who needed pension, were deprived of it. The scam occurred during Vijayvargiya’s tenure as mayor of Indore. The committee that probed the scam found him guilty. This government will again investigate the irregularities.”

Unfazed, Vijayvargiya said, “I have seen police stations and jails before, so I am not anxious. Those who haven’t experience of police and jails may be afraid. I have been in Mamata Banerjee’s jail in West Bengal and continue to fight there. So, what are Madhya Pradesh prisons in comparison? Hum sarkar ka galat aacharan ka virodh karte rahenge (I will keep opposing the government’s wrongdoings).”

On Sunday, despite the firestorm over his ‘nahin to Indore mein aag laga deta’ remark, Vijayvargiya had allegedly said, “Eeit se eeit baja dunga (will decimate the Kamal Nath government).”

In response, PCC spokesman and CM Kamal Nath’s media convener Narendra Saluja tweeted, “Kailash Vijayvargiyaji, how will you take on the Kamal Nath government? You just keep counting the falling bricks of the mafia. No poor person is affected, only the mafia is shaken. And you, as their advocator, keep counting their falling bricks and thereafter, set fire to the bricks of Indore.”

State Congress media department vice-president Abhay Dubey said, “The erstwhile government was BJP’s, and mafia gathered strength during that time. If Kailash Vijayvargiya wants to remain a leader of the mafia, then he has no right to be a people’s leader. He was silent on the Kamal Nath government’s action against mafia until his own people came in the firing line. And then, Vijayvargiya started shouting. Everyone is equal before the law and Madhya Pradesh will be rid of mafia.”

Title: Two city labs to study Lakshadweep coast
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Chennai: After mapping the entire mainland of India for vulnerability to erosion and implementing measures to restore disappearing beaches, city scientists have now turned their attention to Lakshadweep islands.

Researchers from two city laboratories — National Centre for Coastal Research (NCCR) and National Institute of Ocean Technology (NIOT) — are now mapping the shorelines of the slowly eroding islands of Lakshadweep to come up with an intervention. Lakshadweep has 36 small islands.

“The coastal erosion in Lakshadweep is moderate. But if we do not act now, it will worsen,” said M V Ramana Murthy, director, NCCR, on the sidelines of a two-day workshop on Monday. The workshop organised by NIOT was on regional framework for coastal vulnerability towards the safety, security and sustainable development of member states in the Indian Ocean. “We are preparing a shoreline management plan based on which we will come up with an environment friendly solution and deploy devices. Only a few places may have artificial reefs,” he added.

Researchers said the shoreline management plan will have comprehensive data on the changes along the shoreline of the group of islands as well as sand movement and wave activity. As a first step, NIOT director M A Atmanand said bathymetry (study of underwater depth) studies have been completed.

Research vessel Sagar Manjusha was deployed to conduct the first round of studies in the deep sea around the islands. Another vessel Sagar Tara along with help from fishing trawlers is being used for shallow water survey.

“Erosion is mainly due to climate change besides construction of structures along the coast ,” the NCCR director said.

The labs had provided solutions to eroding coasts in Puduchery, where a massive steel caisson was deployed closer to the coast, and Kadalur villages located near Kalpakkam, where dykes were submerged near the coast, to reduce wave activity. “We may have an intervention similar to Kadalur in Lakshadweep,” Atmanand said.

“We prepared a coastal vulnerability index for our country and have shared it with the state government. This index will help in deciding specific areas along the coast to focus on or alert during the events instead of the entire region,” he said.

The NIOT director said following the workshop, a document to guide other member states in the Indian Ocean on the methodology to be adopted to prepare coastal vulnerability index, which will help in decision making during events that may affect the coast. The document will be submitted to Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission for dissemination to other member states.

Title: Students in Doon express solidarity with JNU, organise protest marches
Content: Dehradun: Members of Students’ Federation of India (SFI), National Students’ Union of India (NSUI) and J&K Students’ Association on Monday organised separate protest marches in the city to express solidarity with JNU students who were beaten up by masked goons inside the varsity campus on Sunday. The protesters also demanded immediate arrest of those who thrashed the students and teachers at JNU and vandalised the university.With banners and posters in hand, the students along with members of various NGOs staged protest at the city’s Gandhi park raising slogans and also burnt the effigy of the central government. The protesters demanded the intervention of President Ram Nath Kovind in the matter and urged him to have the issue probed by a non-governmental organisation to ensure an unbiased inquiry.Himanshu Chauhan from SFI said, “The worst part is how the Delhi police remained totally silent throughout the violence. The JNU administration has shamelessly blamed the left and democratic organisations for the attack which reminds one of the Reichstag fire incident during Nazi Germany. This is an attempt to terrorise the ongoing wave of people’s resistance against the Citizenship Amendment Act, National Register of Citizens & National Population Register, which is being led by the student community all over the country. JNU has always been a centre of resistance, hence it is being targeted.”Spokesperson of J&K Students’ Association Nasir Khuehami who was present during the protests said, “We strongly condemn the attack on JNU students and the students’ union president Aishe Ghosh. The heinous masked attack on professors and students is shocking and appalling.”

Title: Ready to sit outside Mantralaya to work for people: Bachhu
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

SHRIRAM VERNEKAR

Amravati: Bachhu Kadu, four-time MLA from Achalpur, continues to flaunt his aggressive style of politicking even after becoming a state minister in Maharashtra government for the first time.

Kadu, minister of state for irrigation, school education, women and child welfare, labour and OBCs, expressed his resolve to serve the people by sitting outside Mantralaya, the power centre of the state government in Mumbai, even if he doesn’t get a chamber there as a minister. “If there are complaints that people’s issues are not being resolved in the Mantralaya, I will sit outside and ensure justice to them,” Kadu said.

Talking to reporters at circuit house here, Kadu, MLA for four consecutive terms from 2004 to 2019, said he got more than expected in the form of ministries and believed that justice could be done to people even without a chamber or a government bungalow.

“I did not demand any specific portfolio, but it was my desire to get social justice department as I wanted to serve differently-abled persons and the poor. Normally, nobody demands this department, but I got many other departments too and it would be my endeavour to solve the problems of the people through the ministries allotted,” Kadu said.

Stating that irrigation issues concerning Vidarbha and Marathwada have become serious problems due to non-completion of many projects or due to non-supply of water to farmers even after completion of projects, Kadu said efforts are now needed to take water directly to the farms.

Kadu, who is known for his unique style of agitations including the Sholay-styled overhead water tank stir, reaffirmed his commitment to the people. “I will not hesitate in praising and felicitating good officers, but if they shirk from their duty, I will not hesitate in showing them their place,” Kadu said.

“Officers indulging in delaying tactics must be dealt with sternly,” Kadu said, adding, “I will not mind losing my ministry if erring officers punished by me take out morchas against me. My commitment lies with the people.”

Title: IMA slams attack on docs, nurses
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pune: The Indian Medical Association’s (IMA) state unit has in a statement condemned the “attack on doctors and nurses” by some unidentified people while they were giving first aid to students injured in Sunday’s violence on the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus.

“The situation in the country smacks of anarchy and the breakdown of law and order is complete. That the doctors and nurses are unsafe in the national capital speaks volumes about the governance and lack of it,” IMA-Maharashtra president Avinash Bhondwe said on Monday. “IMA reiterates its stand that doctors and nurses have the right of way to treat the injured and everyone has the right to life and access to care,” he said.

The IMA said in the statement that the health services personnel and clinical establishments (Prohibition of Violence and Damage to Property) bill, 2019, was drafted, seeking punishment for people assaulting doctors and other healthcare professionals on duty. “The bill had proposed a jail term of up to 10 years, but was dismissed by the home ministry,” it stated.
