Title: Telangana: Toddler dies after uncle drops him accidentally
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 14-month-old boy died in Kothaguda on Sunday evening after his uncle accidentally dropped him while they were walking from Kothaguda to Cyber Towers. The boy’s father also accompanied them. They were returning home after purchasing household items.

Police said Raj Kumar was hit by a speeding bike driven by S Chinna (20), a resident of Madhapur . Due to the impact, he lost his balance and his nephew, Shiva Kumar, fell from his arms and suffered head injury. The boy was rushed to a nearby private hospital, but he was declared dead on arrival. Raj Kumar also suffered minor injuries.

The boy and his family are natives of MP and residents of Madhapur.

The accused was taken into custody and the police registered a case under sections 304a (negligence causing death), 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) of IPC and various sections of Motor Vehicle Act.

In a separate incident in Gachibowli on Monday morning, a police patrol vehicle hit a road median and then a tree after the driver lost control of the car. Two policemen inside the Toyota Innova were also injured. The mishap occured in the IT corridor.

Title: Cybercrime cops trace missing 16-year-old boy
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: City’s cybercrime police managed to trace the 16-year-old intermediate student, who had been missing November 27 last year, on Monday.

According to the police, they were able to trace the missing boy—identified as Maturi Jagadish Sai—after he opened his Facebook account on December 14, 2019. The boy , who hails from Martur of Prakasam district, was pursuing first year intermediate course in a private college in Nidamanuru village in the suburban area of the city. Cops said that he left the college campus on November 27 and went to Hyderabad, leaving a message to his parents saying ‘do not search for me’.

Cops kept an eye on his social media activity. On December 14, Sai sent a Facebook message to his cousin.

When his cousin informed his parents, they alerted the cops who then took the help of cybercrime sleuths to trace Sai using the IP address. They found him working as a private helper at a resort at Shameerpet in Hyderabad. Cops then counselled him and he was reunited with his parents

Title: Dehradun: Special session of Uttrakhand assembly on January 7
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

DEHRADUN: A special session of the Uttarakhand assembly will be convened on January 7 to ratify the Constitution (126th) amendment bill, which proposes to extend quota to SC/ST in Lok Sabha and state assemblies by another 10 years. On Monday, a meeting of business advisory committee was held at the assembly complex to discuss the proposed agenda of the day, along the matters, which will be tabled in the assembly.

Speaker Premchandra Agarwal said that the meeting was successfully held for the smooth conduct of the assembly session.

Incidentally, the reservation for members of SC and ST community, given to them for past 70 years in Lok Sabha and state assemblies, is due to end on January 25, 2020.

The Lok Sabha passed the constitutional amendment bill to this effect in early December last year, which now has to be ratified by at least 50% of the assemblies before it comes into force.

According to sources, the ruling party is also likely to bring the issue of reservation for Anglo-Indian in the state assembly.

Title: Tamils in Australia share woes as bushfire smothers nation
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

A long exposure picture shows a car commuting on a road as the sky turns red from smoke of the Snowy Valley bu... Read More

CHENNAI: Most Tamils living in Australia are among those most affected by the bushfire as they live in Sydney and Melbourne. The continent is home to about one lakh Tamil migrants, of whom 50% are from Tamil Nadu. The rest are from Sri Lanka.

G Kiruthiga from Chennai, who is residing in western Sydney, about 100km from the epicentre of bushfire, said carbon emissions were bad.

“I can still feel the smoke and have breathing difficulties. We would airdry clothes in the balcony and find black powdery specks on them the next day,” she said. The Indian community is assisting with relief work, she added.

According to media reports, the deadly southern-summer fires have destroyed more than eight million hectares of bushland in Australia, killing at least 24 people. The disaster has also taken a heavy toll on wildlife, charring thousands of birds and animals to death.

Anagan Babu, president of Tamil Arts and Culture Association in Australia, said Tamils largely reside in Sydney and Melbourne.

“This is the largest drought that the residents of Sydney have faced in the past two decades. Water is being rationed and restricted for domestic use,” he told TOI from Sydney on Monday. Soaring temperatures breached new record due to the inferno last week, he added.

The devastating bushfire has also taken a heavy toll on tourism sector, with a section of city residents who had plans to tour Australia putting it off. Manish Kriplani of Outbound Tour Operators Association of India, said approximately 50,000 tourists from South India fly to Australia every year.

“Those planning to travel to Australia in the next two to three weeks have cancelled their trips following the bushfire. However, we are bullish that the development will not hit the upcoming season starting from May,” he added.

Tourism is an important sector for Australia. “In fact, Australian authorities went ahead with the annual fireworks event on the eve of New Year despite protests as the event in Sydney draws international tourists, generating 130 million Australian dollars revenue,” Anagan Babu said.

Tourism industry sources said people are looking for alternate destinations. Chairman of tourism sub committee of Travel Agents Association of India, Sriharan Balan, said European destinations such as Georgia and Hungary are being suggested as alternate destinations to those who have already explored northern Europe and the US.

Title: BJP MP calls for assembly session in Kurnool
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: BJP Rajya Sabha member TG Venkatesh has demanded for a mini secretariat and an assembly session in Kurnool . The chairman of parliamentary standing committee on transport, shipping, civil aviation, railways, tourism and culture spoke to reporters in the city on Monday.

He said the state government has reportedly decided to set up high court benches in Amaravati and Visakhapatnam. Since the chief minister has proposed three capitals, Rayalaseema deserves a mini secretariat and an assembly session.

Venkatesh said, while welcoming the three-capital proposal, “Jagan should not focus only on development of north Andhra, he should develop all three regions equally otherwise the state would divide on regional basis,” he said.

On difference of opinion in BJP leaders over the capital city, the MP said there is no difference of opinion on the issue. “We have freedom of speech. Every leader in the party wishes his region should become the capital. Whatever I am saying is my personal opinion.

Title: Nagpur: Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar museum to be ready by month end
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

NAGPUR: The museum of Dalit icon Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar at Chicholi will be ready by the end of the month, say officials of Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT). The statue of Dr Ambedkar in the museum will, however, take some more time. “Finishing touches are being given and the buildings are being cleaned,” said an official.

NIT is facing a finance problem in the project, which, to some extent, is the reason for the delay. “The cost of the project is Rs41 crore and it is being funded by the social justice department. Till date we have not received a single penny. The contractors have not been paid and they regularly complain to us about non-payment of bills,” said an official.

The official further said that with Dalit MLA Nitin Raut becoming a minister, he expected the government to sanction the required amount soon.

The museum is located at Chicholi, which is 20 kilometre from the city centre on Katol Road. It is spread over an area of 11.5 acre. It also has a vipassana centre, hostel for students, anapan sati centre, monks’ quarters, a grand entrance gate, cafeteria and wash rooms.

The museum will house 988 articles of personal use of Dr Ambedkar. They were collected by his close aide Wamanrao Godbole, who built a small museum on his own. National Research Laboratory for Conservation of Cultural Property (NRLCCP), Lucknow, restored these articles and now their life has been extended by 100 years.

Godbole had conceived the museum way back in 1956, when the father of the Indian Constitution passed away. He started work on it after retiring from the railways in 1985. He developed the museum bit by bit with his own money and taking donations from friends and acquaintances. He continued the process till his death in 2006.

After Godbole’s death, the Indian Buddhist Council (IBC) urged the state government to build a grand museum to showcase these articles. The Congress-NCP government agreed in principle but the then chief minister Prithviraj Chavan refused to change the reservation of Chicholi land, which was reserved for a stone quarry. His successor Devendra Fadnavis of BJP did the job and the project took off.

Title: Tram service from RK beach to Bheemili?
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy conducted a review meeting with officials of various civic bodies of the state, including the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC), on Monday in Vijayawada.

The CM asked officials to ensure that Visakhapatnam gets continuous water supply by laying a direct underground pipeline from the Polavaram project and asked them to prepare proposals for the same. He also reviewed the Vizag metro rail project and asked officials to explore the option of tram-model public transport system on the beach road — from RK beach in the city to Bheemili — as part of the metro rail project. “A consultant will be appointed to prepare a DPR for the metro rail project. We are getting ready to distribute 1.5 lakh housing plots to the public in Visakhapatnam,” the CM said.

Jagan also touched upon using desalinated water for industrial purposes. “Supplying tertiary treated water to the industries can be another option. Freshwater should only be used for drinking purpose. If needed, a separate Act should be made on the same,” he said.

He asked officials to appoint special officers for Tadepalli, Mangalagiri and Pulivendula municipalities to monitor the developmental activities. The officials concerned were told to come up with developmental proposals for these three towns, to which the officials said they are in the process of preparing DPRs for the same. They further added that they have identified 10,794 eligible beneficiaries for distribution of housing plots in Tadepalli and Mangalagiri.

The chief minister directed officials to speed up the retaining wall works on Krishna river to prevent inundation of the areas along its bank. He also agreed to upgrade Kamalapuram and Kuppam as municipalities. “The officials should gear up for the upcoming municipal elections,” he said.

Title: 4 burglars arrested in Meerpet, police recover 47-tola gold
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: Four members of a burglary gang were arrested by LB Nagar central crime station (CCS) police with the help of Meerpet police on Monday. The cops also recovered 47.5 tolas of gold, 2 kg silver, an air pistol along with pellets, two pepper sprays, three bikes, and three TV sets worth Rs 22 lakh from their possession.

The arrested were identified as the mastermind V Manikandan (37) from Madanapet, P Yadaiah (38) from Choutuppal, Sk Syed (33) from Kompally and M Upendra Chary (38) from Bhongir. Another accused, A Laxminarayana of Dhoolpet, was arrested by Meerpet police in December last year.

Meerpet police had stopped a bike at Maruti Nagar during vehicle check on the night of December 12. It was being driven by Manikandan with Laxminarayana as pillion rider. Manikandan initially tried to introduce himself as a taskforce cop and even showed an air pistol, but the cops noticed a pouch with tools usually used by burglars. The accused then used pepper spray on them and fled from the spot. However, the cops managed to nab Laxminarayana.

During interrogation, Laxminarayana confessed he was part of a burglary gang and said that they have committed 27 burglaries in Uppal, Thurkapally, Hayathnagar, Abdullapurmet, Meerpet, Valigonda, Vanasthalipuram, Saroornagar, LB Nagar and Balapur in a span of three years. Based on details provided by him, the cops arrested the others at Nandi Hills Colony.

“The accused had mortgaged some stolen items at Choutuppal and kept some at Manikandan’s house,” Rachakonda commissioner Mahesh Bhagwat said.

Title: Amit Shah in talks with states opposing CAA: Narendra Singh Tomar
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amit Shah

BHOPAL: Amidst protests on Citizenship (amendment) Act and non-BJP states' denial to implement the newly-enacted law, Union agriculture minister Narendra Singh Tomar said the home minister was talking to the states on the issue.

Earlier two BJP MPs- Khajuraho's VD Sharma and Hoshangabad 's Uday Pratap Singh- had threatened “action” against the governments that have refused to implement the new law.

On December 25, the chief minister of Madhya Pradesh Kamal Nath had led a protest march against the CAA during which he had refused to implement it in the state.

Similar statements have also come from other non-BJP ruled states like West Bengal, Chattisgarh and Rajasthan among others.

On Saturday night, Union agriculture minister Narendra Singh Tomar reached Morena, his constituency, to create awareness among the people for the new law.

Later talking to a group of reporters, Tomar said that “this is an amendment in the constitution and it was passed by two-third majority. It was passed in Lok Sabha as well as in Rajya Sabha.”

When asked to react on the statement of BJP MP VD Sharma in Morena that the Centre would initiate action against the governments which would not implement it, Tomar said, “the Union Home minister is authorised to talk to the states which are opposing it and he is talking to them.”

He claimed, “Opposition parties are misleading the people. They (parties) can consult legal experts also to know that the act is already implemented in their states.”

Soon after VD Sharma’s veiled threat, BJP MP from Hoshangabad Uday Pratap Singh issued a direct threat.

Two days ago, Singh in Hoshangabad said article 370 may be invoked for imposition of the President’s rule in the states that have refused to implement the law.

Title: Nagpur: Police book 15 for setting truck on fire
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The torched truck

NAGPUR: Kalamna police on Monday registered a case against 15 unidentified persons who had allegedly set a stationary truck on fire after two persons were killed in an accident on Chikhli flyover on Sunday late night.

The accused have been booked for rioting, unlawful assembly and arson. Police have identified the victims killed in the accident. They are Devlal Shahu, a resident of Vinoba Bhave Nagar, and his friend Santosh Mahale. Anand Katekar was injured in the accident.

According to police, the three were on a bike travelling from vegetable market when they initially went past the trailer. They slowed down their bike as another truck was parked on the bridge and the trailer coming from behind hit them. Devlal and Mahale were crushed under the wheels of the trailer while Katekar escaped with injuries. Katekar was rushed to the hospital by passers-by.

Kalamna police reached the spot. “It was hard for us to take out the bodies as we could not move the trailer or the bodies would have been crushed even more. We somehow managed to drag the body out and sent them to Mayo Hospital. By that time a mob had started to gather,” said night officer API Rahul Dongre who was present at the scene.

While the police were busy sending bodies to hospital, some miscreants set the truck parked on the flyover on fire causing damage worth Rs7 lakh. It also resulted in a traffic jam. Police then called NMC’s fire tender. “We tried to control the fire but couldn’t do anything. Even the fire tender reached after 50 minutes,” added Dongre.

It took cops several hours to normalize the traffic. Kalamna police have seized the trailer and registered a case of rash driving and death due to negligence against the trailer driver who is on the run.

Title: Police seize 420kg of ganja, two held
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Guntur urban police intercepted a van, arrested two persons and seized 420 kilograms of ganja produce from them near Kaza Toll Plaza, near Mangalagiri town on Monday.

The accused were identified as E Paneerselvam, the driver, and Chellakamu. According to Mangalagiri cops, they received credible information about the illegal consignment being procured from Paderu area in Vizag district and being taken to Theni in Tamil Nadu .

They then immediately set up a check post at the toll plaza and intercepted the vehicle bearing a fake registration number. Cops found the large packets of ganja filled in the dickey of the van.

Cops seized the vehicle and produce and placed both the accused under arrest. The accused were booked under relevant sections of Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985.

Title: Former Western Army commander Lt Gen Hoon dies
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Lt Gen PN Hoon

CHANDIGARH: Lt Gen P N Hoon, one of the senior most military veterans of the Tricity and former commander of the Army’s Western Command, breathed his last on Monday. He was 90.

Lt Gen Hoon was born at Abbottabad in Pakistan and commissioned into the Army in 1947.

His cremation would take place on Tuesday.

Lt Gen Hoon had served during the Chinese aggression in 1962, 1965 Indo-Pak war and carried out one of the most difficult attacks on the Siachen glacier in 1984, re-capturing over 7,500 square kilometres of strategic Indian territory occupied by Pakistan which was being gradually ceded to China. He had commanded mountain and infantry brigades, infantry division and the 15 Corps in Kashmir. He also served as director general military operations and retired in 1987 as Army Commander, Western Command, Chandimandir.

Post-retirement, he was engaged in several social activities and very vocal on various national security issues. He had once approached the Supreme Court seeking voting rights for serving soldiers at their places of posting. His main plea was that the soldiers should be allowed to go and cast their votes directly at the polling booths, which can be set up in the cantonment areas and there should not be any condition of tenure of deployment in that area.

In October 2015, he had launched his book, “The Untold Truth”, in which he claimed that there was a plot to topple Rajiv Gandhi government in 1987 and three crack Para-Commando battalions, including one from the Western Command, were told to move for action in Delhi. In his book he had also hinted that the coup was apparently at behest of the then President, Giani Zail Singh, as his relations with Rajiv Gandhi were not cordial.

Title: Uttrakhand: 18-year-old commits suicide in Rudrapur
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: An 18-year-old boy was found hanging in his room in Rudrapur area of Udham Singh Nagar district on Monday morning.

Police told TOI that the boy named Prince was dead by the time they reached the spot, but there was no suicide note. “Prima facie, it looks like the boy committed suicide. However we could not find a suicide note, which is why we have sent the body for postmortem and are awaiting a report,” said inspector Kailash Chandra Bhatt.

According to Bhatt, Prince used to live with his family. After having dinner on Sunday night, he went to his room. “Despite repeated calls, Prince didn’t open his door on Monday morning. When it was broken down, he was found dead,” Bhatt said. He added that the boy’s family had no idea as to what could have caused the suicide.

Meanwhile, a similar incident was reported from Haldwani, where a 52-year-old dental hygienist was found hanging in his room.

According to police, the deceased, Narayan Singh Rautela was a dental hygienist at the district hospital and used to live in a rented room in Haldwani. “We were informed about the incident by the landlord. However, we could not find a suicide note at the spot. The body has been sent for postmortem and we have also informed his family,” said a police official who was present at the spot.

Title: Dehradun: Heavy snowfall in offing in hills of U’khand in next 48 hrs
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Tourists enjoying the snowfall in Mussoorie

DEHRADUN: High-altitude places in Uttarakhand, including the prominent hill stations, are likely to get heavy to very heavy snowfall during the next 48 hours and severe cold conditions will prevail in both hills and plains of the state.

According to the regional meteorological centre, a strong western disturbance is going to affect the western Himalayan region from January 6 to January 8. As a result, places located at 2000-2500m and above in Uttarakhand are likely to receive heavy snowfall during the period.

Bikram Singh, director of regional meteorological centre, told TOI that hill stations such as Mussoorie , Chakrata and Nainital might end up receiving one to two feet of snowfall cumulatively. While other places located at much higher altitude such as Auli and Munsyari are expected to witness snowfall up to five to six feet.

“Although the snow and rain activity will being from January 6 night onwards, it will be more intense on January 8,” Met officials said.

Besides, hail is likely to occur at isolated places in the plains and foothill areas of Dehradun , Haridwar, Udham Singh Nagar, Pauri and Nainital districts during the same period,” Singh said.

Moreover, Met office has issued a yellow-coloured warning of cold day to sever cold day conditions in both hills and plains of Uttarakhand during the next 48 hours starting from Tuesday morning.

The heavy snowfall in the hills might also cause road blockages and the met office has issued an advisory to the state government to take necessary steps in advance so that residents and tourists face minimum inconvenience.

Meanwhile, days after Mussoorie received the year’s first snowfall, accumulated snow and frost continued to pose a threat to traffic movement in several places in the hill town.

On Monday, several vehicles were stuck up owing to slippery road conditions caused due to snow and frost between Picture Palace and Landour. This led to traffic congestion on the road. Two-wheeler riders were also finding it difficult to negotiate the slippery road and several cases of skidding of two wheelers was reported.

However, with the help of local residents and police, the situation was brought under control and the stuck vehicles were removed. Speaking to TOI, station officer Vidhya Bhushan Negi said that by late afternoon normal traffic was resumed between Picture Palace and Landour.

Several stretches across the town, including Zero-point towards Kempty falls, Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration (LBSNAA) to Municipal Gardens, Waverly Convent School to Clouds end, Harnam Singh Road continued to be slippery with very little movement of traffic.

Meanwhile, tourists going towards Dhanaulti were stopped at Bata Ghat owing to the slippery condition of roads. “Tourists, particularly two-wheelers, going for sightseeing towards Dhanolit were stopped near Bata Ghat owing to security reasons as the roads are still very slippery. However, those who had valid hotel bookings at Dhanolti were allowed to pass but were asked to drive with caution,” Negi told.

Title: Singapore to be placed on destination wedding map for Indians
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Chennai: Singapore Tourism is looking at attracting more visitors by promoting the island as a destination for weddings, cruises and overseas excursions this year.

G B Srithar, regional director, India, Middle East and South Asia of Singapore Tourism Board said, “We will focus on these elements to encourage more visitors. We used to promote school excursions years ago.” Destination weddings are becoming a thing among Indians, he said, adding, “We want people from Tamil Nadu to hold their weddings in Singapore.”

In a bid to promote educational institutions to take up excursions, Singapore tourism will encourage travel agents to offer incentives, he added. Singapore Tourism Board conducted a roadshow in the city where officials interacted with around 100 travel and tour operators.

“South India is an important region for us with direct flights available from nine cities, including Chennai, Trichy and Coimbatore,” he said.

Cruise tours are a great hit among Indians as they’ve hopped aboard cruises to the island most. “This makes it important for us. Indian cruise travellers are the youngest, with an average age of less that 30 years against the global average of 40. A good number of people who take cruise tours also stay in Singapore.”

Similarly, Indians top the number of tourists who visit Sentosa island, he added. India is number one source market for cruise tours and 1.6 lakh people have gone on cruises to Singapore in 2018.

Till October 2019, 1.19 million tourists from India visited Singapore.

Title: Nagpur: Stage set for Zilla Parishad, Panchayat Samiti polling today
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

representative image

NAGPUR: Rural areas of the district are all set for zilla parishad (ZP) and panchayat samiti (PS) elections on Tuesday. Counting will take place on Wednesday at 13 tehsil headquarters.

In view of the prevailing fluid political situation, the prestige of cabinet ministers Anil Deshmukh and Sunil Kedar and BJP leaders Nitin Gadkari and Devendra Fadnavis is at stake.

Nagpur ZP has 58 circles or seats while there are 116 PS seats. There are 1,828 polling booths for the election. Out of these, 182 centres have been declared as model ones. There are about 14.19 lakh voters eligible to cast vote during the polling to be held between 7.30 am and 5.30pm.

Out of the 58 ZP circles, 10 are reserved for SC, seven for ST and 16 for OBCs, leaving 25 seats for general category. In all these categories, 50% seats are reserved for women. Thus, there are 29 seats for the fairer sex. There are 270 candidates in the fray for these seats, while 497 candidates are contesting the PS polls.

Thirteen tehsildars have been appointed as assistant returning officers (AROs) for their respective areas. A total 225 zones have been created for 58 circles. In all, 2,012 control units and 4,024 ballot units will be used in the election, while 10% machines have been kept ready for replacing faulty ones, if any. There will be no VVPATs in these elections.

Congress and NCP have a pre-poll alliance for these elections. Congress is contesting 42 ZP seats while NCP is fighting on 16. Congress candidates are in the fray in 97 PS seats, while the corresponding figure for NCP is 19. Shiv Sena and BJP are contesting separately. Sena has not fielded its candidates in a couple of seats apparently to help Congress-NCP candidates. Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) has fielded candidates at 20 ZP seats while 13 Prahar candidates are also in the fray.

Deshmukh, Kedar, Fadnavis, Gadkari, Sena-supporter MLA Ashish Jaiswal and others have campaigned extensively for these elections. Before the earlier body was dissolved, BJP had 21 members, Sena eight, Congress 19, NCP seven and smaller parties three. BJP and Sena had ruled the bodies with the help of smaller parties. This time though, an alliance between Congress, NCP and Sena is expected and BJP has little chance of retaining power.

Title: Three booked for misbehaviour
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: A 50-year-old mason and two of his friends on Monday were booked on the charges of outraging the modesty of a 20-year-old housewife in LB Nagar. However, no arrests have been effected yet.

According to police, the woman, in her complaint, said the accused barged into her mother’s house at Mansoorabad and misbehaved with her. “They fled when she raised an alarm and neighbours gathered at the house,” inspector Ashok Reddy said.

A case was filed against the accused under sections 448, 354 and 506 (r/w 34) of the IPC. The complainant, who hails from Peddapuram mandal in Kalwakurthy district, came to Mansoorabad to be with her mother. tnn

Title: Farmers ignore police curbs, march for 8km demanding govt not to shift capital
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

People from the capital region protest against the proposal of three capital cities

AMARAVATI: Ignoring police restrictions, capital city farmers held maha padayatra from Thullur to Mandadam village on Monday. Hundreds of farmers took part in the rally demanding that the state government not shift the capital city from Amaravati.

A little while before the launch of the padayatra, additional SP Chakravarthi advised the farmers to keep away from angry protests as no permission had been granted. “Although, every citizen has the right to protest , it should not be at the cost of others convenience,” the additional SP said. He warned of serious action if locals violated restrictions. He said that the police had not granted any permission to the farmers as section 144 of Cr PC and Section 30 of Police Act were in force in the capital city area.

Paying no heed to the police restrictions, farmers gathered in huge numbers in Thullur village by 10am. Hundreds of women also joined the protest, which made it difficult for the police to manage the situation. With numbers swelling, police remained silent to avoid confrontation. Holding green flags, farmers walked for about 8km. They shouted slogans that state should have only one capital city not three capital cities. “We have voluntarily given away our green fields for the capital city for the future generations in the state. It is inhumane of the ministers to insult our sacrifices,” said Venkata Lakshmi of Thullur village.

Farmers demanded that the government honour the promises made through LPS Act. CPI national secretary K Narayana alleged that YSRC leaders have set their eyes on the lands in Visakhapatnam and are planning to shift the capital city only to reap rich dividends.

Meanwhile, additional SP Chakravarthi clarified that the women police did not behave harshly with any women protester in Mandadam village two days ago. He said that women protesters had, in fact, had behaved rudely with the cops prompting the latter to take them into custody. He said that police were deployed only for the protection of the people not to harass them. “Police are compelled to act when people do not co-operate with them as per the laws. It is not correct to say that police are depending on the locals for food and water. Our men are making their own arrangements for food,” Chakravarthi said.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: BJP protests atrocities against minorities in Pakistan
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sikh community members protest against attack on Gurudwara Nankana Sahib in Pakistan, in Bhopal on Monday.

BHOPAL: The state BJP on Monday staged protests against attacks on minorities in Pakistan and set the Pakistani flag on fire against the attack on Gurudwara and killing of Sikh community members. BJP leaders claimed that the citizenship law enacted by the Modi government will safeguard the interest of minorities facing torture in countries like Pakistan.

BJP leader and convener of Sadbhavna Manch, Durgesh Keswani, said: "Frequent attacks on Hindus, Sikhs and other minorities in Pakistan have exposed the brutal face of the neighbouring country. Incidents like attack on devotees in Gurudwara Nankana Sahib , killing of Sikh youths and atrocities committed on Hindus have exposed the pathetic condition in Pakistan. We would like to draw the attention of world towards human rights violation in Pakistan."

The members of the forum held demonstrations against the incidents in Pakistan and also burnt the Pakistani flag as a mark of protest. Slamming the Congress, BJP state president Rakesh Singh said that those opposing CAA should realise the importance of citizenship law. "It's shameful to attack devotees in Gurudwara Nankana Sahib in Pakistan. More shameful is the silence of leaders who are opposing citizenship act, but are silent regarding the plight of Sikhs and Hindus facing torture in Pakistan," said Singh. He said that the party would launch a campaign to draw worldwide attention towards atrocities on minorities in Pakistan.

Title: Shift on the horizon? Mohan Babu meets PM Modi, Amit Shah
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Prime Minister Narendra Modi (centre) with actor Mohan Babu and his family, in New Delhi on Monday

AMARAVATI: Ending the day-long suspense after meeting the Prime Minister Narendra Modi and BJP supremo Amit Shah, famous Tollywood actor and former MP Manchu Mohan Babu has said that he had not cut-off his bond with chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy. He, however, showered praises on the Prime Minister and Amit Shah for making the country proud. He also praised chief minister Jagan for extending wonderful governance in the state. Mohanbabu told the media that he would shortly reveal as to what transpired during the meeting with Amit Shah.

Mohan Babu, along with his family members, spent close to 40 minutes with the PM. Later in the evening, Mohan Babu met BJP supremo and union home minister Amit Shah. Although it was widely speculated that Mohan Babu would formally join BJP in the presence of Amit Shah, it did not happen. When asked by the media whether Amit Shah had invited him to join the party, the actor-turned-politician said that he could not reveal what had transpired during the meeting with the Union home minister.

He, however, said that they had invited the PM to visit their educational institution, Sri Vidya Nikethan in Tirupati. Mohanbabu is believed to have apprised the PM of the latest political situation in AP.

Mohan Babu had joined YSRC just before the last general elections. He served as a member of Rajya Sabha when NTR was the TDP chief. He parted ways with TDP after Chandrababu Naidu became CM and almost quit active politics.

Mohan Babu returned to active politics just before the previous elections and campaigned for YSRC. Mohan Babu’s daughter-in-law Viranica is relative of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.

Title: Central team tours Vizag beaches
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A central government team , comprising eight officials from tourism and forest departments, visited the city to identify beaches for Blue Flag recognition.

Joint Collector L Siva Sankar stated that the team toured various beaches. The Blue Flag is an eco-label given to boat tourism operators and beaches for practising strict rules in terms of safety and eco-friendly practices.

He said that Rushikonda, Bheemili, Thotlakonda and Yaradakonda beaches have been identified by the eight-member team for the Blue Flag. The visiting team members interacted with the general public and locals during their tour of the beaches. tnn

Title: Samsung India's two top executives resign
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

(File photo)

NEW DELHI: Samsung 's two honchos, chief marketing officer (CMO) Ranjivjit Singh and enterprise business head Sukesh Jain, have resigned from the company with sources attributing the departure to the tough conditions and competitive heat that the consumer electronics giant faces in India.

It's also learnt that the company has let go of nearly 150 people by merging some functions, and not hiring in some areas where vacancies had come up after certain people made their way out. The company did not answer questions specifically on the top departures, but said it "continuously realigns resources as per business priorities to make our business more robust and efficient for long term success."

It added that it has been expanding its business operations in the country, and this includes through fresh hiring .

"Samsung is committed to India and continues to invest significantly across its businesses… In the past one year, we have generated 2,000 new jobs… (and) Samsung India 's business continues to grow and expand, hence we will hire more talent across businesses through the year… As regards to business, with new products across categories, we have been able to consolidate our market share further, and we are confident of another record year," the company said in a statement.

Singh, the CMO for Samsung's India business, joined the company in April 2014.

Title: Making farmers suffer isn’t right: Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: “Shifting capital from Amaravati is an issue related to five crore residents of Andhra Pradesh , and everyone should come forward to stall the proposal of shifting capital from this place,” said Telugu Desam party chief N Chandrababu Naidu . He expressed solidarity with the 24-hour-long hunger strike conducted by Vijayawada East legislator Gadde Ramamohana Rao here on Monday and alleged that the state government was ignoring farmers of the Amaravati region.

Addressing huge gathering Naidu said that people of Vijayawada can easily understand the crooked plans of the government to shift the capital from this region. “Making the farmers of the capital region suffer is not correct. The Sivarama Krishnan Committee suggested the capital be established between Guntur and Vijayawada, so I began Amaravati,” Naidu said.

Naidu condemned the arrests of Amaravati farmers. Naidu also appreciated the woman who donated her gold ring for the fight of Amaravati Parirakshana Samithi. tnn

Title: HSL plans bid for submarine project
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Vijayawada: Hindustan Shipyard Ltd (HSL) is laying the ground to bid for and win the contract to build at least six submarines for Indian Navy , in partnership with Adani group, even as it is focused on completing its pending contracts on time, HSL chairman and managing director Rear Admiral (Retd) LV Sarat Babu said on Monday.

Speaking to TOI from Visakhapatnam, Sarat Babu said HSL has decided ‘in principle’ to set up a special purpose vehicle (SPV) with the Adani group. “The decision is in principle because it will have to be approved by the ministry of defence (MoD). Adani group and HSL have not reached a stage to decide on the shareholding in the SPV,” he said, while adding that the partnership is aimed at leveraging its balance sheet.

“Adani group will give us the financial muscle to bid for the six submarines. We would be providing the technical expertise,” he said. Asked whether HSL had the technical expertise to build a highly sophisticated vessel like a submarine , Sarat Babu said the shipyard has a long experience in retrofitting submarines. “We have retrofitted several submarines from scratch, so we have the expertise in what goes into its construction. Some of our competitors have expertise in constructing the hull of the submarine. We will be able to source this expertise as well if we win the contract,” he added.

The six submarines are estimated to cost Rs 50,000 crore. Sarat Babu said besides its technical expertise, HSL has also developed a workforce which can execute the submarine project.

Meanwhile, as it waits for the MoD to release its request for proposal (RfP) for the project, HSL, which was set up in 1941 by Seth Walchand Hirachand, is focused on meeting its other deadlines. “We will be delivering a retrofitted submarine to the Indian Navy on January 31. ahead of schedule. In November, we had delivered two of the last six 10-tonne bollard pull tugs to the Navy two weeks ahead of schedule,” he informed.

Title: Six more waste-to-energy plants soon: CM
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kozhikode: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan here on Monday said that state government plans to construct centralized Waste to Energy (WtE) plants in six more districts in the state.

Addressing the gathering after the work inauguration of the Rs 250 crore WtE plant at Njeliyanparamba, he said that the state government will set up advanced WtE plants in Kollam, Thrissur, Kannur, Thiruvananthapuram, Malappuram and Palakkad districts on Design, Built, Finance, Operate and Transfer (DBFOT) under public private partnership (PPP) model to resolve existing waste menace. Referring to people’s apprehensions about the proposed WtE plant at Njeliyanparamba, CM said the proposed plant at the Njeliyanparamba is a very advanced one and will generate 6MW of electricity. The generated electricity will be sold to KSEB and the project will be executed as a model project in the state. He said that people will not face any problem due to draining of waste water and foul smell from the plant. The proposed plant will be set up at a cost of Rs 250 crore on 12.67 acres handed over to the Kerala State Industrial Development Corporation (KSIDC), nodal agency for the project execution by the corporation. The plant will be first-of-its-kind in the south India. At present, there are four WtE plants in the country, three of them functioning at New Delhi and one at Jamalpur in Bihar. Though the state government has taken initiative to set up a WtE at Brahmapuram in 2016, the plant has not been commissioned so far . The LDF government took steps to set up seven WtE plants across the state and Njeliyanparamba is one among them. Though the original proposal was to construct a WTE plant having capacity to treat 350 tonnes per day at Njeliyanparamba, the revised detailed project report has increased it to 450 tonnes per day. The civic body will supply 200 tonnes of waste per day to the plant making use of its existing waste collection network. The remaining waste will be supplied by the municipalities of Feroke, Koyilandy and Ramanttukkara and municipalities of Kunnamangalam, Kadalundy and Olavanna. KSIDC entrusted Zonta infratech private limited after floating global tender for the project execution. Zonta formed Malabar Waste Management Private Limited for the construction of WtE plant on DBFOT under PPP model and will hand over it to the city corporation after 25 years. The plant construction will be completed within two years. In the initial phase, the company will remove the 1.29 lakh meter cubes of legacy waste piled up at the site using biomining and biocapping methods at a cost of Rs 7.7 crore. Bio-methanation plant will be set up for the disposal of wet waste within a year of commencement of construction work and the plant for the disposal of dry waste will come up in the second phase.

Title: Crowds throng city temples on Vaikunta Ekadasi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The sacred shrine of Lord Varaha Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy witnessed unprecedented rush of devotees on Vaikunta Ekadasi.

Devotees were allowed to enter the temple through the north gate, where the temple management has set up a separate pandal for the diety.

The ghat road leading to the shrine witnessed heavy traffic througout the day. Over 20,000 pilgrims visited the temple on Monday, alone, due to Vaikunta Ekadasi.

Special police force was deployed to monitor the crowd.

Title: Telangana: Ahead of exam season, chief secretary reviews arrangements
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With intermediate and SSC ( Secondary School Certificate ) examinations around the corner, Telangana chief secretary, Somesh Kumar, has directed officials to make foolproof arrangements to ensure the exams are conducted smoothly.

In a meeting organised with officials of the Board of Intermediate, SSC Board, Centre for Good Governance, and Telangana State Technology Services (TSTS), he reviewed the arrangements and emphasised the need to ascertain that last year’s mistakes are not repeated this time around.

He said that the recommendations of the three-member committee, formed after the inter result goof-up, must be studied and implemented by both school and intermediate boards. The chief secretary also said that additional measures will be taken to avoid any mistake. He advised officials to test the IT modules properly to avoid errors before publishing results.

“Every evaluator will be trained in detail and made aware of the mistakes which generally occur so that the students will not have to suffer,” said Kumar. He said that the online grievance redressal system will be in place for the benefit of students. He also directed officials to prepare a regular calendar of events from admission to the final publication of results.

As many as 9.65 lakh students will be appearing for intermediate students between March 4 and March 23 and 5.8 lakh students will take their SSC exams from March 19 to April 6.

Title: Couple severely burnt after cylinder explodes
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Two persons suffered severe burn injuries due to a fire caused by a cylinder blast at their home in Kankipadu town in Krishna district on Sunday.

The injured were identified as Sivaramakrishna and Yamini. According to Kankipadu police, the incident happened around 12 noon when they were cooking, when a cylinder gas leak caused the fire to spread and set Yamini’s saree on fire. Hearing her scream, her husband Sivaramakrishna rushed to save her but he too was burnt, after his clothes were caught in the blaze.

Locals woke up to the panicked screams and immediately rushed to the spot and put out the fire, before taking them to a private hospital near Nidamanuru.

Cops who were alerted later in the night reached and found that Yamini had suffered 50% burn injuries while Sivaramakrishna was out of danger. Kankipadu SI Shariff said that the couple didn’t call either the fire department nor the police at the time of the incident. After examining the scene, cops found that the gas pipe was burnt fully and ascertained that the leak was ignited by the stove’s flame.

An accidental fire case has been registered.

Title: 390 students take aptitude test
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: As many as 390 students participated in round two of the School Super League (SSL), a school-level aptitude test organised by Byju’s The Learning App in association with Times NIE, here on Sunday .

The event held at Brindavan Auditorium in the city covered a range of parameters like verbal and numerical ability, critical thinking, mechanical, abstract and special reasoning to test the aptitude of students.

The event was held in two categories. Category one had students from Class IV to VI and category two from class VII to IX. Speaking at the event, Siddhesh Joglekar, AVP, marketing of Byju’s, said that SSL had become the biggest platform for students to showcase their math and science skill.

Top two winners from the city will get to the national finals to be held in Mumbai shortly. The national winners will be taken on an all-expense paid trip to US space agency National Aeronautics and Space Administration. TNN

Title: Telangana: Construction work delays trains by 7 hours; 24 locals cancelled
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In the last three days, three long distance trains — between Hyderabad and Delhi — were inordinately delayed by up to seven hours, courtesy construction activity in the south central railway (SCR) zone. Worse, at least 24 local trains were cancelled or partially terminated, leaving hundreds of travellers inconvenienced.Among the trains that took the beating are: Telangana Express (train no 12724) from New Delhi to Hyderabad that was six-and-half hours late on January 5. On its return journey, (train no 12723) it was delayed by four-and-half hours on Monday. The Karnataka Sampark Kranti Express (train no 12650) from New Delhi to Yesvantpur, via Kacheguda, was also running late on Monday by over four hours. Locally, the trains that were cancelled were from the Secunderabad, Guntur and Nanded divisions.While there were some speculation about weather playing truant, railway sources confirmed the disruptions were because of the construction activity. Furious, many passengers took to social networking sites to express their anguish. Tirupati Bala Singh posted: “@SCRailwayIndia @RailMinIndia @PiyushGoyalOffc: I understnd that weather is the major reason bt this is not the only reason for the extreme 9+hrs delay of this train. Pssngrs are really frustrated and exhausted due to this. What's the railways rspnsblty towards such situations? Pssngrs are taken for granted. (sic)”Another aggrieved passenger, Ankur Pathak wrote: “My father is travelling alone in 12724 with pnr 2853151597. The train is 9hrs late he has high BP, other health issues so request you all to please check his well being. Train is near ODG.” tagging a host of railway authorities and the Prime Minister.Locally too, complaints poured in from across the city. “I travel to Lingampally every day for work. When I reached the station on Monday, I found out that not only my train but all trains from Falaknuma to Lingampally had been cancelled,” said Amjed Amir, 39, a resident of Tank Bund.But there seems to be no respite for travellers over the next few weeks, with SCR confirming more local train cancellations between January 7 and February 14. “Due to traffic block for widening of road over bridge between Secunderabad and Kazipet section of Secunderabad Division, train no 67277 Falaknuma-Jangaon (in both directions) are cancelled,” a release stated.Attributing the disruptions to approaching targets, sources said that construction work has suddenly picked up pace. “Because of various issues, including land acquisition, fund crunch and economic slowdown, the construction and electrification work was getting delayed. Now, with targets approaching, the authorities have no choice but to speed up the work. Hence, the delays and cancellations are more frequent,” the source added.As per SCR authorities, the zone had set itself a target of building 465 km of track, including doubling or tripling of existing lines, by end of 2020. However, of this, only 20% has been completed so far.

Title: Eluru hosp chief lets staff party for hours, suspended
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Eluru: Superintendent of Eluru Government Hospital, Dr. AVR Mohan, was on Monday suspended after patients complained that he failed to crack the whip on staffers for dereliction of duty.

Vydya Vidhana Parishad commissioner Dr U Ramakrishna issued orders appointing in Mohan’s place senior ophthalmologist Dr AS Ram as incharge superintendent after health minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas asked him to bring erring authorities to book.

Complainants TOI spoke to said several of the government hospital’s staff partied from 11 am to 3 pm earlier this month, ringing in the new year and “felicitating the superintendent”. “Nursing college students, hospital medical officers, staff and workers danced for hours to popular film songs completely ignoring patients and leaving them to their fate,” a patient said. The furious patients and bystanders accused Dr Mohan of doing little to control the revelry or asking the staffers to resume duty.

The issue was brought to the notice of medical and health minister and deputy chief minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas by the attendants of a few patients admitted in the hospital.

The minister then directed the commissioner of AP Vydya Vidhana Parishad to take immediate action against the superintendent if guilty. After conducting inquiry into the matter, the authorities relieved Dr Mohan form duty temporarily.

The patients said the staffers were gone for hours and they were left in the lurch, causing grave inconvenience to most and putting the lives of a few others in danger.

Title: Opposition unites for adjournment motion over Mhadei
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Porvorim: Congress , GFP and MGP joined hands with independent MLAs to table an adjournment motion on Tuesday ahead of governor Satya Pal Malik’s customary address before the first assembly session of the year.

The House will meet for a day to pass a central Bill, which allows the continuation of the SC/ST reservation for another 10 years.

The adjournment motion is being moved by the opposition to draw attention to the Mhadei water diversion issue and to corner the government on the floor of the House, said the MLAs.

The adjournment motion, addressed to the assembly secretary, has been moved to “discuss the approval given to Karnataka by the ministry of environment, forests and climate change (MoEF&CC) for taking up the so-called drinking water project,” GFP stated in the filed motion.

“This session will continue. It will be adjourned till February 3 and then it will continue. In that session, the budget will be presented,” speaker Rajesh Patnekar said.

He also said that he had not received any adjournment motion or private member’s bill from any of the MLAs.

The second business before the House is a GST amendment. “It should have been passed by December 31 but since the House was not in session, they are taking it up now,” opposition leader Digambar Kamat said, after the meeting of the Business Advisory Committee.

Former transport minister Ramkrishna Dhavalikar also declared MGP’s support. Dhavalikar said that 27% water has been diverted by Karnataka from Mhadei river. He also sought a site inspection by the environment ministry to find out the actual situation. “Till date this has not been held. The Mhadei impact would be more than mining,” he said.

GFP and MGP, both former alliance partners of BJP , have alleged that the Pramod Sawant led-BJP government has failed to protect the interest of Goa even as Karnataka has diverted water from the Mhadei river basin.

“The Mhadei issue is a serious issue for which the adjournment motion will be moved. Vijai Sardesai and Dhavalikar came and met me and they suggested that all of us move the adjournment motion together,” Kamat said after a meeting of the Congress Legislature Party.

Just ahead of the Karnataka bypolls, the environment ministry had issued a letter allowing Karnataka to go ahead with the Rs 841 crore Kalsa Bhandura project without an environment impact assessment (EIA). Despite strong objections from Goa, environment and forests minister (MoEF) Prakash Javadekar refused to withdraw the letter issued by the central ministry but recently announced that the letter was being kept in abeyance.

It was GFP which first floated the idea to move an adjournment motion under Section 68 of the Rules of Procedures and Conduct of Business of the House. In order to be valid, the motion needs at least seven members to support the move in the 40-member House. Congress has five MLAs while GFP has three and MGP one. With Khaunte’s support, there are 10 signatories for the adjournment motion.

The primary object of an adjournment motion is to draw the attention of the House to a recent matter of urgent public importance having serious implications on the state. “Mhadei is an issue that requires to be discussed with urgency and for that there must be consensus,” Sardesai had said two days ago.

The adjournment motion says that there is a likelihood of Karnataka misusing the Centre’s approval to divert water from Mhadei into the Malaprabha river which in turn would increase salinity in the Mandovi.

Title: Riders to the sea: After over a year, detained Andhra fishermen to return home tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Srikakulam: The 22 fishermen from Andhra Pradesh arrested by the Pakistan Maritime Security Agency (PMSA) in November 2018 were handed over to Indian authorities at the Wagah border on Monday. The fishermen are expected to reach Srikakulam on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, at the coastal village of D Matyalesa in Srikakulam district, Nokamma waits for her husband, G Rama Rao, to return. When he was detained 450 km north of Okha off the Arabian Sea in November 2018, Nokamma had been pregnant. She gave birth to a girl in February last year.

On Monday afternoon, however, Nokamma was a happy woman. With her eleven-month-old daughter on her lap, she was watching television when news of the release of the fishermen flashed on a local channel. “I am eagerly waiting to see the reaction of my younger daughter when she sees her father for the first time. We have named her Grishma (summer), but her name will ultimately be decided after my husband comes home ,” she told TOI.

Her neighbour, S Mugathamma, has been alone at home for the last 15 months. Her husband—S Appa Rao—and her sons Kalyan and Kishore had left home in September 2018 and were lodged in a Karachi jail since since November 2018.

Financial support came from her brothers who stay in a neighbouring village and who would also pay her frequent visits. “I thank god that I will soon have my husband and sons with me, but I will not allow them to migrate to Gujarat again. The place has been unlucky for us,” rued Mugathamma.

But for the fishing families of D Matyalesa, migration may not be a choice. The village, which lies on the coast, lacks basic fishing infrastructure like a jetty. Nor do the villagers’ means allow them to buy mechanised boats. Fishermen venture out to sea on small boats and return with a paltry catch. The absence of viable livelihood options has forced their seasonal migration to Gujarat.

Out of a population of 6,000 villagers, over 130 migrate to Gujarat from September to April every year. “Boat owners in Gujarat are well-off. Although it is hard being at sea for eight months, at the end of the month, we get a handsome amount. It is very difficult for us to sustain our familites by fishing only in Andhra Pradesh,” said B Laxman, a boat operator who has been migrating to Gujarat every year for 15 years, and returned early this year to attend a family event.

On Monday, when TOI visited the village, signs of celebration were few and far between. “It is good that the fishermen are returning home after being in custody of a foreign country for more than 12 months,” said Laxman. He explained, “But how will they run their families now? Since they were arrested, their ‘sethji’ (employer) will not pay them any salary. They are coming back without a single rupee and have to start all over again.”

Title: MVA retains power in Amt ZP as BJP skips polls
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amravati: Aniruddha alias Bablu Deshmukh of Congress and Vitthal Chavan of Shiv Sena were elected unopposed as president and vice-president, respectively, of Amravati Zilla Parishad on Monday.

As was anticipated, the Congress-Shiv Sena-NCP’s Maha Vikas Aghadi retained power for the next two-and-a-half years.

BJP-led opposition decided not to contest the polls as it was too short of reaching the winning figure of 29. When the two-hour time was given for submission of nomination forms this morning, returning officer Udaysingh Rajput, SDO, received the sole nomination of Deshmukh for the post of president and that of Chavan for the post of vice-president.

At the special election meeting, Rajput declared both of them elected unopposed. He then congratulated the newly elected office-bearers along with ZP CEO Amol Yedge and deputy CEO (GAD) Tukaram Kale.

In the 59-member House, two seats are vacant following the election of Balasaheb Wankhade and Devendra Bhuyar as MLAs. Of the remaining 57 members, 55 were present at the meeting while of the 14 panchayat samiti chairpersons, 12 were present.

Title: BJP wins Wardha Zila Parishad poll despite Maha Vikas Aghadi challenge
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

WARDHA: BJP overcame the challenge from Maha Vikas Aghadi (Congress-NCP-Shiv Sena) candidates to retain the posts of Wardha Zilla Parishad president and vice-president after the election held on Monday. Sarita Gakhare of Ganamwargram circle in Karanja tehsil was elected president while Vaishali Yerawar from Sonegaon circle in Deoli tehsil the vice-president.

Wardha ZP president post is reserved for women from backwards category. BJP secured 34 votes in the 52-member house. BJP has 32 members but its votes increased after Sena member from Jam circle Jayashree Chokhe and Girad circle’s Gaur Mahesh Rajpalsingh voted for BJP at the last moment.

Ujjwala Deshmukh was BSP candidate for president’s post while Umesh Jinde for vice-president’s post.

It was clear from the start that MVA didn’t have the numbers to claim the posts. Prior to the election, BJP took all its members to Tadoba to avoid horse trading. They directly reached for voting on Monday.

Title: Mercury rising in Rajasthan, brace for rain & hail in coming days
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

As the mercury increased tourists thronged Jantar Mantar in the city on Monday

JAIPUR: Mercury continued to take an upward swing across the state on Monday. Jaipur Met office said that rainfall, lightning and hailstorm will occur at various places in northern and eastern parts of the state during the next couple of days. Fatehpur (Sikar) remained coldest in the state where a minimum temperature of 4.5°C was recorded.

Attributing the continued rise in the mercury and cloudy conditions to the active upper air cyclonic circulation, Jaipur Met office said that till Thursday most places would witness rainfall, lightning and hailstorm.

Jaipur Met office said that the districts including Jaipur, Jhunjhunu, Sikar, Churu, Bharatpur, Sawai Madhopur, Dausa, Alwar, Kota, Udaipur , Jhalawar, Bundi and Baran will get rainfall and hailstorm in the next couple of days.

People in Jaipur woke up to a comparatively warm morning as a minimum temperature of 9.8°C, almost 2 degrees above the normal notch was recorded. Cloudy conditions prevailed in the city throughout the day. In the afternoon a maximum temperature of 22.6, almost 1 degree above the normal notch was recorded.

Fog and mist also affected air, road and rail traffic across the state. At least a dozen early morning trains were running late while traffic on the highways connecting Jaipur to Agra, Jaipur to Delhi and Jaipur to Ajmer was chaotic due to poor visibility in the morning. A few early morning flights also landed late at the Jaipur airport.

Fatehpur was followed by Udaipur where a minimum temperature of 7.2°C was recorded, Kota 9°C, Jodhpur 9.3°C, Sriganganagar 9.4°C, Jaisalmer 9.6°C, Ajmer 10.5°C, Barmer 10.9°C, Churu 13°C and a minimum temperature of 14°C was recorded in Bikaner.

For almost a week the mercury continued to take an upward swing. Mild showers were witnessed in the Hadauti region including Kota, Jhalawar and Baran districts of the state.

With a forecast of rainfall, Jaipur Met office said that mercury will start dipping Friday onwards.

Title: SAD wants to fight on seven seats in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Chandigarh: BJP ’s alliance partner Shiromani Akali Dal ( SAD ) is eyeing seven assembly segments in Delhi, where polling for the 70-member legislative assembly will be held on February 8. The election commission (EC) announced the polling date on Monday.

In the 2013 and 2015 Delhi assembly elections, the Akali Dal had contested four assembly seats — Rajouri Garden, Hari Nagar, Kalkaji and Shahdara. This time, SAD also wants to field its candidates on west Delhi’s Moti Nagar assembly seat, east Delhi’s Rohtas Nagar, and Rajinder Nagar assembly seat under New Delhi Lok Sabha constituency. In the 2013 assembly elections, SAD won only Rajouri Garden seat and in the 2015 assembly polls, it lost all four seats.

SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal on Monday constituted a three-member committee, comprising MPs Balwinder Singh Bhundur, Prem Singh Chandumajra and Naresh Gujral. Sukhbir said that the committee would hold discussions with the Delhi BJP unit, as well as, the central leadership to ensure smooth coordination between the alliance partners during the elections.

SAD’s Rajouri Garden MLA Manjinder Singh Sirsa told TOI that party’s Delhi unit has already communicated its recommendation for contesting seven assembly seats to the top leadership, which would now hold discussions with the alliance partner BJP. He said SAD can also clinch Moti Nagar, Rohtas Nagar and Rajinder Nagar assembly seats in the forthcoming elections as there is sizeable population of Sikhs and Punjabi voters in these segments. “We have Gurmeet Singh Shunty in Moti Nagar and Paramjit Singh Rana in Rajinder Nagar, who can be SAD’s strong candidates,” said Sirsa, who is also president of the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee (DSGMC).

In the April 2017 bypoll, SAD’s Sirsa registered a win on BJP ticket from Rajouri Garden assembly segment. Rajouri The had fallen vacant as AAP’s Jarnail Singh had resigned to unsuccessfully contest Punjab assembly elections from Lambi constituency against SAD patron Parkash Singh Badal .

Results of the Delhi assembly polls in which a total of 1.46 crore voters are eligible to exercise their franchise would be declared on February 11.

In the 2015 assembly elections, AAP had won 67 out of the total 70 assembly seats in Delhi. The remaining three seats were won by BJP.

Title: Organic certification centres to be functional in all districts by Aug
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: The Tamil Nadu organic certification department (TNOCD) is getting ready to set up organic certification centres in all districts this year.

The centres will be operational by August, TNOCD officials said.

Presently, farmers from across the state have to visit the TNOCD office in Coimbatore to get their fields and produce certified organic. The department had been mulling to start the centres in all districts as more people are getting interested in organic farming. The plan was announced in the assembly last year.

The centres will act as facilitation centres, said an official. “While organic certificates will be issued from the TNOCD office in Coimbatore, farmers and organic agriculture enthusiasts need not come here to get to know about the certification process or to submit forms,” he said.

“It takes half-an-hour to 45 minutes to explain the certification procedure to farmers over phone. Many a time, we request them to come in person to the Coimbatore office so as to guide them better. If the centres are set up in all districts, there will be a better system to guide the newcomers. They can fill in the forms and submit it in their district centres,” said the official.

Organic certification involves two levels. First, inspectors visit fields and verify records such as input register and harvest register. Based on them, farmers are provided a scope certificate, using which they can sell produce directly to consumers.

If farmers seek to market their produce through retailers, they have to subject samples of produce to residual analysis, after which they are issued transactional certificate. Using this, they can label their produce organic and sell through retailers.

Since 2007, when TNOCD was established, till 2017, as many as 480 farmers had got organic certification. In 2018-2019 alone, 100 farmers were certified. Officials attributed this increase to the increase in awareness.

The department of agriculture aims to increase the area under organic cultivation from 25,400 acres to one lakh acres in the current financial year.

Title: Aspirants to declare they have functional toilets at home
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaipur: As the notification for the first phase of panchayat elections, scheduled to be held on January 17, would be issued on Tuesday, the state commission (SEC) has made it mandatory for all the candidates to give an undertaking along with their nomination papers that they possess clean and functional toilets at their homes.

The nominations can be filed on January 8 from 10:30 am to 4:30 pm. In the first phase, panches and sarpanches of 3487 gram panchayats will be elected.

The SEC has directed that handwritten nomination papers will not be allowed. Commissioner P S Mehra said it was necessary to submit the declaration form or an undertaking along with the nomination form in the format prescribed by the commission with respect to having clean/functional toilets in the house.

Scrutiny of nomination papers will be done on January 9 from 10.30 am and the candidates can withdraw their candidature by 3 pm on the same day.

The allocation of election symbols and the list of candidates contesting elections will be published immediately after the withdrawal of nominations. Jaipur district collector Joga Ram on Monday gave instructions to all the 443 petrol pumps in the city to ensure that have sufficient stock of petrol, diesel and oil to be provided to the vehicles engaged in the work of panchayat elections.

As per the order, every petrol petrol pump must keep a stock of minimum 1000 litres of petrol, 2000 thousand litres of diesel and 200 litres of oil.

Title: Betting rackets busted, 22 held
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Police on Monday busted several cockfighting rings and betting rackets in Vizianagaram and Srikakulam, arresting 22 persons in the crackdown ahead of Sankranti.

Srikakulam police conducted a raid at Mettaguda and nabbed 18 persons for betting on cockfights. Six roosters, Rs 37,000 and mobile phones were seized from the organisers of the blood sport. Acting on a tip-off, Vizianagaram police raided the outskirts of Pedakudama and busted a cockfighting ring. Four roosters, Rs 7,000, mobile phones and a bike were seized from the arrested four.

The organisers of the cockfights who were booked under AP Gaming Act, 1974 were produced before court and remanded in judicial custody.

Police said that more betting rackets would come into the scene once the three-day festival begins on January 14. The organisers of the blood sport are finding new locations to secretly hold cockfights, they added.

Title: Tourists stranded on the first day of Manyam bandh
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: With public and private transport off the roads and commercial establishments downing their shutters, normal life was affected due to bandh in all 11 mandals of Vizag Agency on Monday. The call for a two-day bandh—which will last on January 6 and 7—was given by tribals under the banner of Girijana Joint Action Committee (JAC) demanding implementation of AP Scheduled Areas Land Transfer Regulation Act 1959 (Amendment 1/1970), (LTR 1/70). Some tourists were stranded for hours together at Araku Valley and Ananthagiri following disruption of transportation due to the Manyam Bandh.

Stating that the bandh was peaceful on day one, CPM’s Killo Surendra said that LTR 1/70 banned land transactions in tribals pockets, and non-tribals cannot own land in tribal areas. “We are demanding the revenue and ITDA officials take action against the non-tribals who are behind the mushrooming commercial establishments in Vizag Agency and that the non-tribals hand over the establishments to the tribals, who are the true owners of the land the establishments are built on,” Surendra added.

Due to the two-day bandh, majority of the tourists cancelled their bookings and left on Monday. “Very few tourists stayed in Araku Valley. Even the ones who stayed back,remained confined to their rooms,” said K Venkatesh, the owner of a lodge in Araku Valley.

The APSRTC has suspended its bus services and private vehicles were also off the roads on Monday. Managements of private schools and colleges and officials of government schools and colleges announced that Monday and Tuesday would be holidays.

JAC members said that the situation would remain same on Tuesday also and they advised tourists not to visit Araku on Tuesday.

Left parties’ leaders said that despite the growth of tourism in Araku Valley, tribals failed to get any employment as the owners of the resorts and others engaged non-tribals as the staff for their business. Some non-tribals set up the tents in the tribals’ land and by cheating the tribals and enjoying the huge profits as several tourists stay in the rented tents, they added.

Title: Min hands over home keys to lanslide victims
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kozhikode: Education minister C Raveendranath, on Monday, handed over keys of the newly-constructed houses to the Karinchola landslide victims . The houses were constructed by the national service scheme (NSS) volunteers from higher secondary schools in the district.

Two beneficiaries Ananya Anil Kumar and Sumathi Karinchola received the keys to the houses. The houses were constructed in 10 cents of land at a cost of Rs 14 lakh collected by the NSS volunteers.

The NSS students also handed over furniture and home appliances for the two houses during the function. The minister inaugurated the construction work of the third house for the victims.

In the inaugural address, Raveendranath applauded the NSS for its social commitment. “NSS has engaged in real education by letting students empathize with the pain of the landslide victims,” he said.

Mostly, the lessons learnt in classrooms are forgotten after examinations. But the purpose of real education could be realized when the classroom lessons are used for the benefit of the society, the minister added.

Two houses were constructed by 13,900 NSS volunteers from 139 NSS units in the district. Students and teachers actively participated in all the phases of construction activities.

“We had collected Rs 16 lakh for the construction of the house. We decided to start the work of the third house as we managed to complete the work of the two houses with Rs 14 lakh,” said S Sreechith, district coordinator of the NSS.

The NSS volunteers are hoping to garner people’s support for completing the third house.

MLA Karat Razaq presided over the programme. Regional deputy director of higher secondary education P Gopalakrishnan, NSS regional programme convener Manoj Kanichukulangara and Thamarassery tahsildar C Mohammed Rafeeq were also present.

Title: Kotwal Nagar ( Nagpur): Recycle waste, not your thoughts
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kotwal Nagar resident Saroj Desai composts kitchen waste for her garden plants, adding cow dung-which is a bio... Read More

KOTWAL NAGAR (NAGPUR): I am a resident of Kotwal Nagar. Since I come from a botany background, I believe in the idea of composting to manage kitchen waste in an effective manner. I have been segregating wet and dry waste and processing it to use as compost for plants in my house garden. I have also organized a number of workshops to spread awareness for the same.

The waste collected from my kitchen, like fruit and vegetable peels, eggshells etc is broken into small pieces and dumped in the compost bin. Then, I add the decomposer and cow dung — which is a bio-fertilizer — to accelerate the process. The compost bin is perforated to allow aeration. I keep adding soil to the mixture and stir it regularly. The soil prevents bacteria from breeding and tarnishing the waste.

It takes around 2 to 3 days to collect 2kg of kitchen waste. This waste takes nearly 40 days to convert into compost.

If the compost is slightly dry, one can spray a few droplets of buttermilk on it to restore moisture. During monsoons, the compost mixture tends to become soggy. In this case, dry leaves can be mixed to maintain a balance in the moisture content.

Chemical fertilizers are harmful for plants and the surroundings as well. Their residue may enter our bloodstream and cause cancerous diseases. On the other hand, using organic waste for house plants is good for our health. Also, instead of dumping kitchen waste in a haphazard fashion, we can lessen the burden on NMC.

Everyone must imbibe the habit of segregating their waste at home itself. Non-biodegradable waste like plastic must be recycled. As most households nurture plants, it is better to use green waste that we obtain from the kitchen, instead of buying hazardous chemicals. The philosophy of 4 Rs (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle and Refuse) is an important one to save the environment.
