Title: Farmers propose cooperative model to run Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AMARAVATI: As uncertainty over the fate of Amaravati continues, a section of farmers in the capital city region has floated the idea of building the city along the lines of a cooperative . With no formal announcement yet on the three capital cities proposal, some farmers are of the opinion that taking back land given to the government under the land pooling scheme (LPS) and taking over the planning of the city is the way forward.

Ram Nutakki, a farmer in Thullur mandal, has given a call to farmers of the 29 villages in the capital region to boycott political parties, including YSR Congress (YSRC) and opposition Telugu Desam Party (TDP). “Peaceful protests are our democratic right. However, there is no guarantee that our protests will yield results. Instead, we must move in a strategic manner,” he appealed in an open letter to farmers in the region.

The proposal has already drawn the support of one Gadde Butchaiah, a specialist with the United Nations (UN) who comes from a family of cultivators in Rayapudi in Amaravati. Stating that the land pooling scheme initiated by the previous TDP-led state government suffered from inherent flaws, farmers in the region should come together to build a cooperative movement. “Whatever happened, happened. Why should farmers continue to be victims of political one-upmanship?” he said.

Other farmers who support the idea have raised the demand that the government hand back their land. “Let the government shift the secretariat and other departments from Amaravati. We can show the world in Amaravati that building a city through a farmers’ society is a viable option,” said Ram, adding that they would ready master plans for the city by roping in experts and inviting world-class educational institutions.

Local youth would be provided employment in the cooperative-run society, managed by retired IAS and judicial officers, Ram said.

Farmers who gave up their lands under the LPS and other interested farmers would be made stakeholders in the project . The government should hand over construction work in the area to the cooperative or pay rent to it if it is interested in continuing operating the buildings.

Title: Three murders in 24 hours rock Bareilly district
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bareilly: Back-to-back murders of three persons, including of two youths within the city limits, in the past 24 hours have sent a shock wave across Bareilly district.

A youth was stabbed to death in the ensuing fight over peeing in the open in Baradari area, while the bullet-ridden body of another youth was found in Subhash Nagar area — both murders took place in Bareilly city — whereas, in a locality close to Faridpur, a guard on the duty at a gurdwara was shot dead by unidentified assailants.

As the murders have cops swung into action and intensified patrolling, Bareilly senior superintendent of police (SSP) Shailesh Pandey ordered all tea stall owners shut by 11pm in a bid to prevent unlawful gatherings.

The first crime was reported around 9.30pm on Sunday. Jugal Kishore, 25, a carpenter hailing from Siklapur locality, along with his friends Kalua and Pradeep, was on his way home after having tea at a tea stall close to their house when Jugal reportedly peed in the open close to a house and in the ensuing fight three locals — identified as Ashwik, alias, Ashu, Manoj and one unidentified person — allegedly stabbed Jugal while Pradeep also sustained injuries in attempt to save his friend.

Upon receiving information, police rushed to the spot and shifted Jugal and Pradeep to a hospital, where the former succumbed to his injuries.

Baradari police station SHO Naresh Tyagi told TOI, “An FIR was registered against all the three accused under IPC sections 307 (attempt to murder) and 302 (murder). We will arrest the accused, who are absconding, soon.”

On Monday, Jugal’s family members and neighbours staged a protest by placing his body in the middle of the road and demanding immediate arrest the accused. The protest was lifted only after assurance from senior police officers.

The second murder was reported from Babbanpurva locality under the jurisdiction of Subhash Nagar area, where Jaiwant Dean, a driver, was found shot dead in his bedroom. His father Samuel Chandra Dean informed police about the murder on Monday afternoon.

Police, meanwhile, detained Samuel suspecting him to be the prime suspect. “Samuel delayed in informing police. He quarreled with his son, because he was an alcoholic. Moreover, he was the last person who saw Jaiwant alive” said police sources.

Samuel told TOI, “I had gone to meet another son Jaswant, who lives in Parsa Khera. Upon returning home on Monday, I found Jaiwant dead. Jaiwant was depressed after death of his wife Pinky nearly a year ago. He might have committed suicide”.

Subhash Nagar SHO Harishchandra Joshi said, “We are suspecting his father, because the victim had no enmity with anyone and he used to remain inside his house mostly. His father said Jaiwant might have committed suicide, but we have not recovered the pistol. We are questioning the father and speaking to their neighbours.”

In the third incident, a guard at Dashmesh Gurdwara in Faridpur, Abhi Kuneta (30), was shot dead in the midnight.

Faridpur police station SHO Dhananjay Singh said, “An FIR has been registered against unidentified assailants and police are investigating the case and have detained few suspects for questioning.”

Title: Reservation for non-tribals riles locals in Vizag Agency
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With some of the zilla parishad ( ZPTC ) and mandal parishad territorial constituencies ( MPTC ) seats in scheduled areas of Visakhapatnam district being reserved for non-tribal categories in the ensuing local body elections, tribals in the Agency has decided to launch agitations and threatened to boycott the elections.

In a notification on categorisation, publised a few days ago, the government allocated 10 of the 11 ZPTC seats in Agency mandals to non-tribals, which include four for BCs. Similarly, only four were reserved for MPTCs for tribals.

Speaking to TOI, Killo Surendra of CPM said how can the government promote non-tribals who grabbed land in tribals areas. As per the provisions of the Panchayat Act, reservation in ZPTC and MPTC seats in tribals pockets (scheduled areas) must be in proportion to the population of the communities. In all the 11 tribal mandals in Visakhapatnam Agency, the population of tribals is more, he said.

“We will boycott the elections and intensify our agitation till the government cancels the reservations for the non-tribals in the local body elections in the Agency,” Surendra added. Most tribals leaders are against the move. It will only aggravate ongoing agitation against non-tribals in the Agency, said convener of the joint action committee of Adivasi Hakkula Parirakshana, Samithi Rama Rao Dora. tnn

Title: Soon, eat street & tribal haat at Araku
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In a major boost to tourism in Araku Valley, the Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation (APTDC) with technical support from Mumbai-based Structwel Designers and Consultants Private Limited is building a craft and culture village, which will allow tourists to take a closer look at the indigenous aspects of the region.

There are several reasons why this project is of importance. First, because it will help generate employment as nearly 90 per cent of the workforce will be drawn from the local population. Second, it adds to the number of tourist attractions in the hill station. Explaining this aspect, APTDC executive engineer D Satyannarayana said, “Till now, people visited nearby tourist spots such as waterfalls, Brindavan Gardens and Chaparai. Except these, there are no major tourist attractions and the project seeks to change that.”

“It is a first-of-its-kind project in the two Telugu states and is unique from the other state tourism projects. It is a part of the corporation’s efforts to develop ‘day life tourism’. It has been taken up at a cost of Rs 7.7 crore,” said DVM Prasada Reddy, Visakhapatam tourism divisional manager.

The project, located near Mayuri Resorts of APTDC, is divided into two components — Eat Street, which will be built with an estimated Rs 2.2 crore, and Tribal Haat, which will be built with Rs 5.5 crore. The Tribal Haat is likely have about 45 shops where tribals will sell their handicraft, like woodcarvings, mud carvings, iron and brass articles.

“Work has already started and we are expecting the project to be completed by June 2020. We may open it to tourists in the next tourism season,” Reddy told TOI.

Title: BJP killing democracy: CPM
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Protest against attack on JNU students, at Gandhi Park on Monday

Visakhapatnam: Goons belonging to ABVP and RSS attacking students of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) in New Delhi with iron rods, sticks and acid was a barbarous act, CPM state secretariat member and former SFI leader Ch Narasinga Rao said on Monday.

SFI Vizag unit staged a protest against the attacks at Mahatma Gandhi statue near GVMC office. Narasinga Rao said the students of JNU had been protesting against indiscriminate fee hike in a peaceful manner. “But some 200 masked goons entered the campus on Sunday night and unleashed violence. In the chaos tens of students suffered severe injuries at the hands of the vandals. BJP murdered the democracy of the country through the heinous act. This is reminiscent of the dark days of Emergency,” said Narasinga Rao. Forum for Development of North Andhra secretary A Aja Sarma alleged the ABVP workers attacked JNU students under the direction of the BJP government.

Title: Akal Takht jathedar asks Sikhs to unite ‘for their own safety’
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amritsar: Claiming that Sikhs were neither safe in India nor Pakistan , Acting Jathedar of Akal Takht Giani Harpreet Singh on Monday called upon the community to come together to end targeting of Sikhs and their religious places.

While talking to media persons, Harpreet Singh said, “In India, Sikhs are being uprooted from Madhya Pradesh and Shillong, while in Pakistan they are scared after the Gurdwara Nankana Sahib attack and killing of Sikh youth Parvinder Singh in Peshawar.”

Continuing in similar vein, he said, “I have no hope that anyone will deliver justice to us, I appeal to Sikhs to unite and only then can we contain such attacks to some extent.” Condemning the back-to-back incidents of attack on a Sikh religious place and targeting of the minority community in neighbouring Pakistan, the jathedar said these unfortunate incidents can't be tolerated.

He said he had spoken to Harmeet Singh, the elder brother of Parvinder Singh over the phone, and the latter had explained the situation in detail. Parvinder was shot dead in Peshawar just two days after the attack on Gurdwara Nankana Sahib by a local mob.

The jathedar urged the Centre to mount pressure on the Pakistan government to ensure that those responsible for both incidents were given exemplary punishment.

Asked why Sikhs were being targeted, he shot back, “Thieves always steal diamonds and not the pebbles.”

He said he had directed the Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC) and the Delhi Sikh Gurdwara Management Committee (DSGMC) to take up the issue of Pakistan Sikhs’ safety with the Centre.

The Sikh high priest also condemned Sunday’s attack on students and professors at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU). “Students protest is natural if they find something going wrong,” he said.

Meanwhile, Harpreet Singh bestowed siropas (robes of honour) on relatives of Satwant Singh and Kehar Singh, assassins of former PM Indira Gandhi, at a SGPC function held at Gurdwara Jhandae Bungae on their death anniversary.

Title: CM vs PM: An election like none before
Content:
Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Seeking re-election in Delhi, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal ’s Aam Aadmi Party is pitching the performance of its government and its achievements to outfox rivals BJP and Congress in a contest the stage for which was set on Monday.A by-product of the India Against Corruption campaign of 2011-12, AAP came into existence in November 2012 and won 28 seats in the Delhi assembly in 2013 to form a minority government with Congress supporting it from outside. But 49 days later, Kejriwal resigned as CM after failing to table the Jan Lokpal Bill in the assembly. In 2015, AAP stunned everyone by winning 67 of Delhi’s 70 assembly constituencies, establishing Kejriwal as the new political hero.Will Kejriwal continue to be a hero? The polls on February 8 will decide the fate of the CM and his political start-up. Delhi may have only three Rajya Sabha seats and seven Lok Sabha seats, but it is power territory and has created a strong brand recognition for Kejriwal across India. He commands far greater influence on social media than many CMs.Since assuming power in Delhi in 2015, AAP made efforts to expand elsewhere, but except in Punjab, in the other states, including in Jharkhand during the recent assembly polls, AAP garnered less votes than NOTA. In Delhi, AAP’s vote share has seen a decline in various elections, going from a 54.3% vote share in the 2015 assembly polls to 26% in the 2017 Delhi municipal polls and 18% in the 2019 LS polls.AAP goes to the 2020 polls with the catchy slogan of ‘Achhe beete panch saal, lage raho Kejriwal’ and a report card that lists how education and health got huge budget hikes, from Rs 6,600 crore to Rs 15,600 crore and Rs 3,500 crore to Rs 7,500, respectively. It will showcase the free water and electricity schemes, installation of 1.4 lakh CCTV cameras and access piped water to 93% houses. Infrastructure development worth Rs 8,000 crore in unauthorised colonies also figures significantly in AAP’s campaign armoury and it expects the 25-odd seats dominated by voters of such areas to side with it.AAP’s carefully crafted approach to a poll win is centred on Kejriwal, who has undergone a significant image transition in the last seven months. Known as an agitationist, Kejriwal has supported the protests against CAA and NRC from a distance. AAP has roped in political strategist Prashant Kishor’s consultancy firm, I-PAC, and is preparing an army of part-time volunteers for the campaigning.The party is opting for the stump model that worked for it in 2015: personal interaction with voters through small jan sabhas and corner meetings with the discussions revolving around sops like free electricity and water, bus rides for women and pilgrimage for senior. AAP has been claiming that the ownership rights conferred by the Centre to dwellers of unauthorised colonies are “fake”. If people believe this, BJP may find a poll weapon blunted.In Video: Delhi elections 2020: BJP banks on Modi magic to counter Kejriwal charisma

Title: 23 motorists slapped with Rs 10K fine each for fitting multicolour LED lights
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: The judicial magistrate court-VIII on Monday slapped Rs 10,000 fine on the motorists, who had fitted multicolour LED lights on their vehicles. Of the 23 motorists who faced the court’s wrath, 15 have coughed up the fine.

City police commissioner Sumit Sharan had directed deputy commissioner of police (traffic) R Mutharasu to seize the vehicles that have the lights after it was found that the bright lights affected the vision of other motorists and lead to accidents.

On December 28, traffic police conducted vehicle checks on Avinashi Road, Thadagam Road, Kalappatti Road, Sathy Road and Marudhamalai Road, and seized 52 vehicles including 35 two-wheelers that had the LEDs. The motorists were booked under Section 190 (2) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

“Fifteen motorists, who paid the fine amount, got their vehicles back on Monday,” Mutharasu said. “The drive against multicolour LED lights will continue and we plan to seize more vehicles in the coming days,” he added.

Title: West Bengal: Bird count soars to 5-year high in Santragachhi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

KOLKATA: The early clean-up of Santragachhi Jheel paid rich dividends with a count on Sunday registering the highest number of birds in the past five years.

Ecstatic about the results, conservationists and members of the birder community said Santragachhi Jheel has become a perfect example of how concerted efforts could reverse urban degradation and revive a habitat. The official census will be carried out on January 17.

Even before the count began on Sunday morning, it was clear that the figure would be higher than what had been recorded in the recent past. When the figures were collated, the optimism turned to jubilation.

The count was 5,694 water birds spread across 16 species. What makes Sunday’s count remarkable is that so many birds arrived, despite the cyclone Bulbul and the death of 20,000 migratory birds in October-November 2019.

“With so many birds flocking Santragachhi since early December, we had anticipated more numbers but the figure that finally emerged was beyond expectation. This will not only encourage conservationists like us but also be a huge fillip to stakeholders like South Eastern Railway (SER), Howrah Municipal Corporation ( HMC ), Howrah Police , bird lovers and nature activists,” said Arjan Basu Roy of Nature Mates, who had coordinated the clean-up of the jheel.

West Bengal Biodiversity Board funded the clean-up that saw around 1,500 man-hours being spent between October 28 and November 20 to remove the hyacinth, which had covered 90% of the 13.5 acre jheel. Around 30% of hyacinth cover was retained to enable birds to perch and rest.

An unsupervised clean-up drive by the HMC had removed all the hyacinth, leaving no place for the birds to rest in 2017 when only 800 birds had arrived at the jheel, down from 2,920 the previous year.

Nature Mates had stepped in last year and the sensitive clean-up, assisted by crowd-funding, saw the count rise to 2,889.

Along with the early clean-up of the lake, this year’s cold spell also contributed to the sharp rise in the number of migratory birds. Birds usually arrive when the minimum temperature is around 15-16°C and maximum temperature is under 30°C.

“The return of birds shows that the efforts towards restoring Santragachhi Jheel are moving in the right direction. What is needed next is a comprehensive management plan,” said Kushal Mukherjee of Prakriti Sansad.

A committee comprising representatives of SER, West Bengal Biodiversity Board, HMC, bird lovers and aviation experts has been set up to prepare a five-year management plan for Santragachhi Jheel. The blueprint will chalk out a mid-term and long-term management strategy for the lake that draws thousands of migratory birds every winter.

Title: Drugs worth 3L seized near Kondotty
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Malappuram: In a major drug haul, a special team of excise seized MDMA , Ganja and brown sugar from a house at Ekkapparambu near Kondotty on Sunday night.

The excise team led by Manjeri range inspector E Janish arrested Kacherikkal Shafeeq, 35, in connection with the incident.

The excise intelligence had received an information regarding Shafeeq, who engaged in the retail sale of narcotic drugs for the New Year celebration parties in various parts of the district and the team conducted a surprise inspection at his house on Sunday night and managed to seize 1.5kg of ganja, 13.270g of MDMA and 50g of brown sugar.

The excise team has confirmed that the accused has confessed that he distributed the drug items, which were collected form Kalasipalayam in Bengaluru, to different persons in the district for New Year programmes.

Excise authorities have also identified the ‘delivery boys’ who helped Shafeeq to distribute small packets of the narcotic items to local agents in different areas. The gang is charging Rs 1,000 for each small packet of brown sugar. The team distributed the items in some parts of Kozhikode districts also.

Inspector has informed that the search for other accused of the case has already been started and they would be nabbed soon.

Title: Lucky escape for family as car falls into 25-foot-deep pit
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: Five members of a family sustained injuries after the car they were travelling in fell into a 25-foot-deep pit dug for the construction of the flyover at Sungam here on Sunday night. The car carrying Pradeep of Ramanathapuram and his family was heading towards Olympus. There were no streetlights on the road and the highways department had failed to place barricades around the pit, sources said. Fire and rescue services personnel rescued the family members and sent them to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital. The traffic investigation wing (TIW-East) of the city police reached the spot and lifted the car using a crane. Police have registered a case. TNN

Title: Rajasthan: Elderly woman beaten to death by three sons, daughters-in-law
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Three men and their wives allegedly beat their 65-year-old mother to death with sticks and iron rods and injured their father in a village in Bundi district late on Sunday night following a brawl over property dispute.

All the six have been booked for murder at Hindoli police station. The body was handed over to family members after autopsy on Monday.

“Kamla Devi Saini, a resident of Badanaya Gaun village, was allegedly beaten to death with sticks and iron rods by her three sons and their wives at their home on intervening night of Sunday and Monday,” said Hindoli SHO Shivraj Gurjar. The husband of the deceased woman Ramkishan Saini was injured in the attack, the SHO added.

According to the members in the extended family, a dispute over property triggered a brawl between the sons and their parents on Sunday night, the SHO said.

The sons and their wives allegedly attacked the old parents with sticks and iron rods killing their mother on the spot and injuring her husband; he said, adding that police were informed of the incident around 5am on Monday.

The blood-stained body of the woman bore fatal injuries on her head and back, he added.

On a report by Sitaram Saini, brother of injured Ramkishan, police on Monday lodged a case of murder under Sections 302, 323 and 34 of IPC against the three identified as Phoolchand Saini, Mangilal and Mukesh and their wives, the SHO said.

The accused have not been arrested as initial investigation into the matter was underway, he added.

Title: Nankana Sahib security upped, senior bureaucrats visit shrine
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amritsar: A day after Pakistan’s political leaders visited at Gurdwara Nankana Sahib to restore the shaken confidence of local Sikh community, senior civil and police officials of Pakistan Punjab made similar attempts. They officials visited Nankana Sahib to sink differences between the two communities that were on brink of clash following attack on Sikhs ’ holy place on Friday.

According to sources, Lahore divisional commissioner Saif Anjum, regional police officer Shiekhupura Farooq Mazhar, Nankana Sahib deputy commissioner Raja Mansoor, Nankana Sahib district police officer Ismael ur Rehman and others visited the gurdwara and interacted with local Sikhs.

On Sunday, Pakistan’s interior minister Brig Ijaj Ahmad Shah (retd) and Pakistan Punjab’s minister for housing Mian Mehmood ur Rashid had visited the gurdwara.

In a video of their visit uploaded on social media, Pakistani pro-Khalistan leader Gopal Singh Chawla was seen welcoming the bureaucrats and informing him about the incident.

Surprisingly, despite being shown the door from the Pakistan Sikh Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (PSGPC) and the Evacuee Trust Property Board (ETPB), as claimed by Pakistan government, Pakistan’s prominent anti-Indian Sikh face Chawla appears to have been given full authority by Pakistan government to lead the Sikh issues.

Pakisan’s Sikh member provincial assembly (MPA) and parliamentary secretary Mahinderpal Singh told TOI on Monday that Imran Chishti, main accused who had led the mob to attack gurdwara Nankana Sahib, had been arrested. “The most hateful person Imran Chishti, who had tried to vitiate the peaceful atmosphere and communal harmony of Nankana Sahib, has been arrested and an FIR registered against him,” he added.

Sources said fearing regrouping of Muslims under Pakistan’s firebrand, moulvi who in recent past had been spewing venom against India, the local administration of Nankana Sahib has doubled the deployment of forces in the town, especially in the gurdwara vicinity.

Meanwhile, Shiv Sena activists protested against Pakistan government and burnt its effigy in Amritsar.

Title: Capital plans: High-power body to study expert panel reports today
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amaravati: Notwithstanding the ongoing protests over the proposed shifting of capital city, the government seems determined to move out of Amaravati . The high-power committee, comprising ministers and top officials, will hold its first meeting on Tuesday and study the reports submitted by the GN Rao committee and Boston Consulting Group (BCG).

Chief secretary Nilam Sawhney has directed officials to make arrangements for the meeting at the CRDA office. About 10 cabinet ministers, including finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy, municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana, chief secretary Sawhney and DGP Gautham Sawang, are part of the high-power committee.

Sources said the committee is expected to endorse the expert panels’ recommendations and route the same to the cabinet for taking the appropriate decision. Meanwhile, the state cabinet meeting has also been scheduled for Wednesday to discuss the committees’ reports on decentralization of government administration. It is being speculated that the cabinet will stamp its final nod for shifting of capital city to Visakhapatnam at the meeting. The government has also reportedly decided to hold the Republic Day parade in Visakhapatnam as a prelude to the shifting of the administration.

An emergency session of the assembly would be convened either on January 20 or 21 to finalise the decentralization plans. The government wants to ensure that the plans get the stamp of the legislature to avoid any legal complications. Though opposition TDP is expected to oppose the resolution, there should not be any problems in its passing due the YSRC’s overwhelming majority in the House.

Sources further said that some buildings have already been finalised in Visakhapatnam for relocation of offices from Velagapudi. Though a big section of secretariat staffers are believed to be against the shifting plans, the government is counting on secretariat employees’ association president Venkatramireddy to smoothly execute the plans. “We will abide by whatever decision the government takes,” said Venkatramireddy.

According to information, the government has readied a blueprint to shift some key sections from the GAD, home, law, education, panchayat raj, municipal administration, agriculture, industries, IT and transport departments to Visakhapatnam in the first phase.

Title: Also on offer at IIM: Management programme in digital governance
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Digital platforms typically end up becoming the dominant force whichever sector they touch, said Ajay Prakash Sawhney, secretary, Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY).

He launched the first batch of the postgraduate program in digital governance and management (PGP-DGM) of the Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam on Monday as chief guest. Quoting the staggering growth in the number of UPI transactions over the years, Sawhney said digital platforms sometimes result in the creation of near monopolies. “The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) provided us a fairly conventional and stable banking system by bringing all banking features onto one platform.

The UPI system started its journey in 2016 with just 1 lakh transactions a month, when there were 90 crore debit cards, clocking nearly 32 crore transactions a month. While the number of debit card transactions grew to 42 crore in three years, the UPI transactions recorded a near 11,000 times growth with 110 crore transactions a month. If we get the right policy and instrumentation, the Indian ecosystem will itself unleash exponential growth,” said Sawhney. Chief secretary of Meghalaya and former president &CEO, national e-governance division, MeitY, MS Rao explained how the PG program in digital governance and management was conceived during the first stakeholder meeting in February, 2019 to launch the programme on Monday. “Only some prestigious institutions like Kellogg School of Management, Columbia Business School, ESCP Business School offer courses of six months to one year on digital transformation,” said MS Rao.

Twenty-seven candidates, including four women, from 10 states enrolled for the course. MeitY is sponsoring the fee of 20 candidates selected from the government sector.

Title: Salary during PG course if you serve in hills, CM tells docs
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Dehradun: CM Trivendra Singh Rawat on Monday announced to give full salary to government doctors, who opt for a post-graduation (PG) course and pledge to serve in the hill areas of the state, during their entire course.

“The doctors going for PG courses who pledge to give their services in remote areas, will be given full salary during the entire course by the state government. We need doctors and therefore we will ensure to give them all the comforts so that they do not deter from serving in hills,” the CM said while speaking at the oath-taking ceremony of the newly-constituted working committee of Prantiya Chiktisa Evam Swasthya Seva Sangh, an association of government doctors..

The CM also assured the doctors that the state government would consider increasing their retirement age. hile felicitating the outstanding performers in healthcare sector from across the state during the ceremony, Rawat asked the doctors to remain cautious while using technology as it could be “misused to malign their image.”

“Recently, an unnecessary controversy was sparked in IIT- Kanpur because of a poem. This shows how technology and social media can be harmful. So, I suggest all of you to focus on your work and maintain distance from controversy,” said Rawat, while congratulating the newly-elected president and vice- president of the association.

Director general (health) Dr Amita Upreti urged the doctors to work more in hill areas and motivate others to do the same. The DG also ordered all the concerned heads of health department to take strict action against the missing staffers from their team.

“We must ensure that notices are sent to all those who remain missing for more than 15 days without information. Strict action should be taken against those who take their jobs lightly,” she added.

Title: Explosives seized in Dungarpur
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The accused in police custody. (Right) Gelatine sticks

UDAIPUR: A cache of explosives meant for illegal mining was confiscated from the Ramsagda police station area in Dungarpur district on Monday.

In a joint action by the district special team and the local police station, the team stopped a tractor carrying huge quantity of explosive items that are used in illegal mining. The police seized 230 electronic detonators along with 250 gelatine sticks, 100 feet cable, 2 dynamos and one drilling machine.

The tractor driver Kamlesh is a resident of Bhilwara. He told the police that he did not have any licence or permit to transport the explosive material. “Explosives are used in stone quarries. In a few cases, legal miners also source explosives for unofficial blasts. The explosives seized since last two days are all illegal shipment. These explosives are often brought in for use in illegal mining,” Jai Yadav, superintendent of police, Dungarpur told TOI.

On Sunday, the team from Sagwada police station had seized 250 detonator caps, compressor, dynamo and drill machines from an open garage at Punarwas colony . Two accused had managed to flee when the teams raided the area.

Title: Three murders in 24 hours rock Bareilly district
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bareilly: Back-to-back murders of three persons, including of two youths within the city limits, in the past 24 hours have sent a shock wave across Bareilly district.

A youth was stabbed to death in the ensuing fight over peeing in the open in Baradari area, while the bullet-ridden body of another youth was found in Subhash Nagar area — both murders took place in Bareilly city — whereas, in a locality close to Faridpur, a guard on the duty at a gurdwara was shot dead by unidentified assailants.

As the murders have cops swung into action and intensified patrolling, Bareilly senior superintendent of police (SSP) Shailesh Pandey ordered all tea stall owners shut by 11pm in a bid to prevent unlawful gatherings.

The first crime was reported around 9.30pm on Sunday. Jugal Kishore, 25, a carpenter hailing from Siklapur locality, along with his friends Kalua and Pradeep, was on his way home after having tea at a tea stall close to their house when Jugal reportedly peed in the open close to a house and in the ensuing fight three locals — identified as Ashwik, alias, Ashu, Manoj and one unidentified person — allegedly stabbed Jugal while Pradeep also sustained injuries in attempt to save his friend.

Upon receiving information, police rushed to the spot and shifted Jugal and Pradeep to a hospital, where the former succumbed to his injuries.

Baradari police station SHO Naresh Tyagi told TOI, “An FIR was registered against all the three accused under IPC sections 307 (attempt to murder) and 302 (murder). We will arrest the accused, who are absconding, soon.”

On Monday, Jugal’s family members and neighbours staged a protest by placing his body in the middle of the road and demanding immediate arrest the accused. The protest was lifted only after assurance from senior police officers.

The second murder was reported from Babbanpurva locality under the jurisdiction of Subhash Nagar area, where Jaiwant Dean, a driver, was found shot dead in his bedroom. His father Samuel Chandra Dean informed police about the murder on Monday afternoon.

Police, meanwhile, detained Samuel suspecting him to be the prime suspect. “Samuel delayed in informing police. He quarreled with his son, because he was an alcoholic. Moreover, he was the last person who saw Jaiwant alive” said police sources.

Samuel told TOI, “I had gone to meet another son Jaswant, who lives in Parsa Khera. Upon returning home on Monday, I found Jaiwant dead. Jaiwant was depressed after death of his wife Pinky nearly a year ago. He might have committed suicide”.

Subhash Nagar SHO Harishchandra Joshi said, “We are suspecting his father, because the victim had no enmity with anyone and he used to remain inside his house mostly. His father said Jaiwant might have committed suicide, but we have not recovered the pistol. We are questioning the father and speaking to their neighbours.”

In the third incident, a guard at Dashmesh Gurdwara in Faridpur, Abhi Kuneta (30), was shot dead in the midnight.

Faridpur police station SHO Dhananjay Singh said, “An FIR has been registered against unidentified assailants and police are investigating the case and have detained few suspects for questioning.”

Title: Min finds thermal plant top officials stealing electricity
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Chandigarh: A midnight swoop by Haryana power minister Ranjeet Singh Chautala on the intervening night of Saturday and Sunday detected power theft by the higher ups at Thermal Power Colony of Panipat Thermal Power Plant (PTPP).

As many as eight top officials, who include the head of PTPP chief engineer, seven superintending engineers and principal of DAV School Thermal colony were found to be stealing power by puncturing the lines of street lights.

According to information, Chautala quietly checked into the guesthouse where teams from CM flying squad, vigilance wing of Uttar Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (UHBVN) were already present.

Sources informed that the operations began at at 10.30pm and went on till 2am. The entire staff submitted its report to minister.

Sources also said the staff of sub-divisional office concerned of Uttar Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam is gathering data of daily consumption by the errant officials and the electricity bills paid by them. Consequently, the officials will be penalised and will be asked to deposit the fine with immediate effect.

Chautala confirmed the raid by his team. “We shall submit the report to CM. He has to take the call,’’ he said.

Meanwhile, when contacted, UHBVN chairman-cum-managing director Shatrujeet Singh Kapoor said that the defaulters of power theft officers are faced with action as it happens in the case of common man.

“We have standard operative procedure in the cases of power theft. These are compoundable offences. Besides penalty prepared by the field officials, the errant persons are faced with criminal action as well. This colony comes under the jurisdiction of HPGCL, hence their MD too might take administrative action against the offenders,’’ said Kapoor.

This is not the first such instance, we had been detecting power thefts at government colonies and have been acting against them, he added.

Title: Disabled high, higher secondary school students to be given aid
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: For the first time this year , the Samagra Shiksha for secondary level school education would give aid and equipment individually to disabled students and students with learning disabilities from government and government aided schools of classes IX to XII, under the Inclusive Education for Disabled at Secondary Stage (IEDSS) scheme.

While disabled students from classes I to VIII get their aid individually, students from secondary schools don’t. The Samagra Shiksha for secondary level purchases equipment for its special training centres through the district administration. The equipment would be common for students taught through these centres. But now, officials said they have given requirements for individual students.

An official said Artificial Limbs Manufacturing Corporation of India (Alimco) would give the equipment for the students at 60% subsidy, while Samagra Shiksha would put in the rest. This year, 48 students with various disabilities would receive equipment such as wheelchairs, hearing aid, cerebral palsy chairs, rollators, knee ankle foot orthosis (KAFO) and ankle foot orthosis (AFO), elbow crutches, braille kits, and multi-sensory inclusive educational (MSIED) kits.

“We would put in Rs 1.22lakh for purchasing these equipment. Alimco would give us the equipment in subsidized rates,” the official said. He said they had conducted a medical camp to identify students with disabilities. “Usually these camps would be conducted for students from classes I to VIII. This time we also held a camp for students from classes IX and above. Unidentified disabled students in lower classes will also benefit from the scheme,” the official said.

For disabled children in secondary schooling, there are 19 special training centres with 21 special educators in 15 blocks of the district. A total of 656 disabled students benefit from these centres. The students go to regular schools and once in a week visit these centres where special educators would teach them. Depending on the students’ disability, he or she can visit the centres for more number of times, the official said.

A special educator from the district said if students get individual braille kits or walkers, they would be benefitted more. “We teach physiotherapy exercises in our centres. If students have a walker at their home, they can practise it there,” she said.

Title: Telangana: Man burns bags full of Aadhaar cards and letters
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The accused burnt around four bags in the complainant’s plots

HYDERABAD: A complaint was lodged at Keesara police station after a man carrying bags from the Indian postal department, including thousands of letters and Aadhaar cards, burnt them at a plot located in the area. “On Friday, one Gangi Shetti Bikshapathi from Chintal came to the plot at Ahmedguda in a drunken condition. He brought about 10 bags comprising letters, Aadhaar cards, each weighing about 30 to 40 kgs,” the police said.

The accused burnt around four bags in the complainant’s plots opposite to Prajasai Gardens, Ahmedguda. The complainant, Ramidi Raji Reddy, said he had purchased the plots in the March 2015. Police said investigation was being carried out regarding the thousands of abandoned or undelivered public mails.

“About 12 bags of undelivered mails were handed to assistant superintendent of post offices, C Pavan Kumar, for inquiry and for necessary action,” said Keesara inspector J Narender Goud. He said that following inquiry by postal departments further action will be taken.

Title: Dalit basti in Kotputli to boycott panchayat polls
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: At least 88 families, with a population of nearly 500, of a Dalit basti , named Rangaura (Ambedkar Colony), under Sundarpura village in Kotputli will boycott the panchayat elections scheduled on February 1. The families are going to boycott elections for not having a link/public road to connect their basti with Sundarpura village.

The residents complain that neither ambulances nor midday meal, to be distributed to the children at the Angawadi centre, could reach their basti because of no connectivity. “Children living in the basti have to walk 2-3 kms to reach their schools in Kotputli. We have to carry the patients on our shoulders or on the bike to reach the hospital (in Kotputli). In cases of deaths too, since there is no crematorium or burial ground here, the bodies are carried on the shoulders to Sundarpura,” said Kailash Chand Arya, who runs a private school in the basti.

“In 1962, the government had allotted land for a colony for people belonging to Dalit community. But, since then no public/link road has been constructed for us to connect with Sundarpura village. The colony is surrounded by agricultural lands and the farmers, who owns the land, had blocked the way to enter the Dalit basti with wire fencing and boulders. Even as the distance is just 500 metres, nothing has been done so far,” said Arya.

Most of the residents at Rangaura basti are daily wage labourers. Some of them work at the Anganwadi centre, community centre and primary school that is being run in the colony (basti). “There are about 300 voters in this basti. We all will boycott panchayat elections this time,” he added.

A public interest litigation (PIL) was filed in the Rajasthan High Court last year pleading with the court to direct the state government to construct a public road/aam rasta to connect Rangaura Basti with Kripa Ka Tibara Village, Sundarpura link road, by acquiring private land for the public purposes.

A division bench of the high court had asked the petitioners in August 2019 to approach district collector, Jaipur, by way of filing detailed representation mentioning all the facts mentioned in the petition along with all the relevant documents, who shall have the grievances of the petitioners examined by deputing SDO or tehsildar concerned to enquire into the matter and do the needful in accordance with law or otherwise decide the representation by passing speaking order within a period of three months from the date of filing of the representation.

Following which on August 26, Jaipur district collector had directed the sub-divisional officer (SDO) of Kotputli tehsil to take appropriate action in the matter within 15 days and send a report to the collectorate. A report was sent to the collectorate by the SDO in October, 2019. But no action has been taken after that.

Title: Bengaluru: 2 killed as BMTC bus with failed brakes rams eight vehicles
Content:
The accident led to hours of traffic snarls on the busy Magadi Road.

One of the two-wheelers which was hit by the BMTC bus on Monday.

Bus driver brought faulty brake to manager’s notice 15 days ago

Chaos on Magadi Road

2 officials suspended

BENGALURU: After its brakes failed, a BMTC bus ploughed through eight vehicles, killing two men and injuring three others before ramming a Metro barricade and coming to a halt near Kottigepalya, Magadi Road, west Bengaluru, on Monday morning.The bus dragged a car, an autorickshaw and six other vehicles for 200 metres down an inclined stretch. Bus driver Venkatesh, arrested and booked for causing death due to negligence and rash driving, said he had informed his depot manager that its brakes were weak and had to be fixed a fortnight earlier.The bus, plying on route 245-M, was going from Vaddarahalli to Majestic when the accident occurred around 9.30am. Venkatesh averted a bigger tragedy by avoiding ramming a congregation of 500 devotees in front of Mutturayaswami temple waiting for darshan on the occasion of Vaikunta Ekadashi.Ramakant U, who was on the bus, said, “The driver told the conductor that the brakes were not working and effectively cut the speed of the vehicle. If he had swerved left, he would have hit the devotees. He took a sharp right turn. Since the bus could not climb up a heap of mud on the margins of the road, it began knocking down other vehicles on the road.”Venkatesh succeeded in his second attempt to make the climb and ram the barricades before stopping the bus.The driver of the BMTC bus (KA 57-F-696), which mowed down two bikers on Magadi Road on Monday morning, told police that his depot manager forced him to take out the vehicle though its brake was weak and could fail any time.“The brake was weak and I had been complaining about it for 15 days. But my manager never heard my pleas and I was forced to drive the same vehicle,” Venkatesh told police.Joint commissioner of police (traffic) BR Ravikanthe Gowda said probe will be carried out by a police officer of the rank of assistant commissioner of police. “We have recorded Venkatesh’s statement about the depot manager’s callousness. We will do the investigation and book the manager, if he is found to be guilty,” he added.A road user said the bus suddenly began moving in a zig-zag manner while going down an inclined stretch. “It was a terrifying sight. After ramming the vehicles, it halted near the barricade. First, we dragged the mangled car and autorickshaw to the side, thinking there could someone inside. Luckily, the drivers of these vehicles were thrown out due to the impact of the collision. Then we found two bikers lying on the road. One had died instantly, while the other was gasping for breath. He died while being stretchered into the ambulance,” the eyewitness, who helped clear the vehicles and shift the injured to hospital, said.The deceased are M Bylappa, 43, of Magadi Road and Vishwaradhya, 48, of Sunkadakatte. While Bylappa worked as an assistant at the General Post Office, Vishwaradhya worked as a teacher with a private high school near Byadarahalli.Cabbie Nagaraj, 34, and private company employees Abhishek, 23, and Harshit, 28, suffered injures and were rushed to a nearby hospital. The injured are stable and undergoing treatment.“The driver claims to have written in the logbook about the faulty brake. But there are possibilities of the logbook being tampered by the mechanical staff. A thorough investigation will reveal the exact cause. Often mechanical staff cite low availability of spare parts as an excuse. Senior depot officials should be made accountable for these accidents,” a senior BMTC official said.BMTC sources say they have a logbook, where bus crew reports defects in buses, including brake, radiator and electrical parts at the end of the duty. The mechanical department staff is responsible for attending to such complaints before the next trip.BMTC managing director C Shikha said they have formed a special team to investigate the case. “We are looking at various angles and the real cause of the accident. We are yet to question the driver as he is still in police custody.”The mishap on busy Magadi Road threw peak-hour traffic into disarray. With policemen in the area deployed for Vaikunta Ekadashi duty at temples, there was none to clear the traffic pile-up. The snarl lasted for over an hour.The vehicle was operated by driver Venkatesh and conductor Neelamma Hiremath. An inquiry into the accident is pending and depot manager Shivalingaiah and assistant work superintendent Madhusudhan have been suspended. An ex-gratia amount of Rs 25,000 will be given to the next of kin of the two dead men. BMTC will bear the cost of treatment of those injured.

Title: Haryana: Ensure 55 litres drinking water per day per person in rural areas
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Haryana chief secretary Keshni Anand Arora has directed all the deputy commissioners (DCs) to work on priority basis to provide 55 litres of pure drinking water per person per day in rural households, under Jal Jeevan Mission, so that the target of providing 100% Functional Household Tap Connection (FHTC) in every rural household can be completed by June 30, 2022.

The chief secretary gave these directions on Monday during a review meeting of the ‘Jal Jeevan Mission’ with senior officers and DCs via video conferencing.

She instructed the officers to conduct a survey in rural areas to get complete information about the households getting piped water and those with illegal water connections. The survey results will then have to be matched with billing information system for water and sewerage data, she said and added that Suksham Yuvas should be involved in the task.

Under the Jal Jeevan Mission, to provide Functional Household Tap Connection (FHTC), road cut charges of Rs 2,000 have been waived off by the government and households would be provided two options — either to pay Rs 500 upfront as new connection charges and or pay Rs 50 (ie Rs 40 flat rate + Rs 10 extra) for general connection and Rs 30 (ie Rs 20 flat rate +Rs 10 extra) for SC connection, as per prevailing government tariff. in this way, payment of Rs 500 as connection fee would be collected, Arora said.

According to the 2011 Census, Haryana has a total of 31.32 lakh houses in rural area and on the basis of survey data, 16.67 lakh houses have functional household tap connections and the survey of the remaining 14.56 lakh houses will be completed by March 31, this year.

Under the scheme, a three-phase action plan has been prepared to provide 100% functional household tap connections by 2022. In the first phase, 22.07 lakh houses will be provided tap connections by September 30, 2020. In the second phase, 25.2 lakh houses and in the third phase, 31.32 lakh houses will be provided tap connections.
