Title: Gaganyaan mission: Gagannauts can choose from biryani, suji halwa & more
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BENGALURU: From suji halwa to chicken biryani, a menu of about 30 dishes has been readied for astronauts proposed to be sent to space as part of India’s first human spaceflight mission ( Gaganyaan ). The menu will now be evaluated by the Indian Space Research Organisation ( Isro ) and the astronauts.

The special ready-to-eat dishes — an elaborate spread ranging from fruit juices to energy bars and regular Indian cuisines — are being developed by the Defence Food Research Laboratory (DFRL), a Mysuru-based lab under the Defence Research and Development Organisation ( DRDO ).

DFRL director Anil Semwal told TOI: “It’s now for them (Isro and astronauts) to finalise which dishes they would like and then we can even make modifications. Apart from the food, we are also tasked with providing food-warmer technology, stainless steel cutlery and a waste disposal pack.”

Confirming this, Isro chairman K Sivan said Isro has funded a part of this specific project — DFRL has been working on ready-to-eat food for the armed forces for decades — and that Gaganyaan astronauts will be using Indian food when they go to space. “We are not depending on Russia for this. We are in the process of evaluating the dishes,” he said.

Another DFRL official said among the challenges faced is the modification needed in packaging. “We have to modify the packaging to suit the no-gravity situation in space. Whenever food is removed from the packet, there’s a possibility of it escaping into the space capsule, which has to be avoided. Also, there are chances of water molecules escaping into the space shuttle and because there’s no gravity, they will start floating around,” the official said.

Semwal said among the dishes developed by DFRL are chapatis, chicken biryani, suji halwa, chicken curry, almonds, spinach and paneer.

“The number of astronauts doesn’t concern us as we do research. We are developing the products keeping in mind the Indian palate, the kind of spiciness required and so on,” the DFRL official said, adding that the standards used to develop these products are that of US space agency NASA .

Human space facility at Challakere

Isro is planning a massive facility at Challakere in Chitradurga district to carry out future human spaceflight mission activities. While the first mission under this programme is Gaganyaan, which envisages sending humans to space and bringing them back safely in 2022, Isro will continue the programme thereafter.

The space agency has begun work on the masterplan for this facility. The Human Space Flight Centre, which is implementing Gaganyaan and is responsible for future human space programmes, is currently headquartered in Bengaluru.

This will eventually be shifted to Challakere, and all astronaut and human spaceflight-related activities will be housed there.

Title: Absent for years, Telangana government wields axe on 14 AWOL teachers
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Months after sacking six teachers of Telangana State Model Schools for taking unauthorised long leaves, the state has now sacked another 14 teachers working in government schools for being AWOL (absent without leave) for a period ranging up to 14 years.

The commissioner and director of school education (C&DSE) T Vijaya Kumar said that they have terminated the services of these teachers as per procedure. “Disciplinary proceeding against another 92 teachers are under process,” said Kumar adding that action will be initiated against them as per procedure.

The issue of 106 teachers being AWOL came to light in September 2019, after the various district education officers (DEOs) sent in their reports to the C&DSE. The director then directed the regional joint directors (RJDs) and district education officers (DEOs) to initiate action against the concerned teachers and submit a compliance report.

As per the rules, an employee cannot stay away from his/her duty without the sanction of leave from the competent authority. In such cases where the government servant is absent from duty wilfully, without any grant of leave, he/she is liable to be removed from service.

District education officer (DEO) of Hyderabad, B Venkata Narasamma, said of these teachers, two of them are working in schools in Hyderabad district. “In another two to three days, seven more teachers will be sacked,” Narasamma said adding that in the district there are teachers who are on authorised leaves for a period ranging from one year to 14 years.

The DEO said that despite sending notices, the teachers had failed to respond or submit an explanation. She added that a majority of these teachers had moved to some other country and added that the education department had details from the bureau of immigration to prove their case. Of the 14 teachers who have been sacked, three each are from Nagarkurnool and Karimnagar, two each are from Hyderabad, Jagtial, and Kamareddy, and one each from Khammam and Nirmal.

Title: Sack JNU vice-chancellor to restore order: CPM
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury

NEW DELHI: The clamour for the immediate sacking of JNU vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar grew louder on Monday with JNU alumnus and CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury leading the charge and accusing Kumar of “complicity” in orchestrating the violent attacks on students and teachers of the varsity.

CPM alleged Kumar had allowed the rampage against students to continue on the premises, adding that the Union home minister owed it to students and the public to fix accountability and punish those responsible for the vandalism and violence . “JNU teaches a very deep commitment to democracy and secularism,” Yechury said.

“The VC, who has been instrumental in systematically undermining and dismantling India’s premier university, had permitted this rampage to go on unchecked for hours...Sacking the VC is essential for restoring normalcy on campus,” CPM said.

Party MP Elmaram Kareem also petitioned the President of India to intervene immediately and “sack the VC to ensure that normalcy prevails on campus.”

Title: Ex-employee resorts to black magic to avenge sacking
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BENGALURU: Angry over being fired, a former staffer sought to cast a black magic spell on his employer in Kurubarahalli, Mahalakshmipuram, northwest Bengaluru.

It began last week when the owner of Bhuvaneshwari Hardware, Vishwanath, fired his assistant, Srinivas, on suspicion of theft. A resident of Gelayara Balaga, Srinivas, in his late 20s, had joined the shop in mid-2019.

Srinivas, after being fired, told Vishwanath that he would not repeat the mistake and sought another chance. However, Vishwanath did not budge.

“Vishwanath opened the shop on Sunday morning and found vermilion, lemon, hair, nails and torn footwear, indicating that someone had performed black magic. Footage from CCTV camera in front of the shop showed Srinivas throwing away the material earlier in the morning,” neighbouring shop owners said.

Vishwanath promptly cleaned up the place and threw the black magic material into a drain, they added. No complaint has been filed, Mahalakshmi Layout police said.

Title: Man missing for 3 days found dead
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pilibhit: A 40-year-old man identified as Imran who was missing for the past three days was found dead near a railway track close to Bhopatpur railway station at Barkhera block headquarters on Monday morning.

The spot is 20 km from his house at Deshnagar locality in Pilibhit city under Pilibhit Kotwali police station. Police have sent his body for an autopsy to ascertain the reason of his death.

According to Umesh Solanki, SHO of Barkhera police station, the man could be identified by his Aadhaar card which he had in his pocket. His family was informed thereafter.

Referring to the information given by the deceased’s family, Solanki said Imran had left home three days ago for work. He worked as a daily wager at the Agricultural Produce Marketing Committee in Pilibhit.

The SHO said prima facie, there were no injury marks on the body. “We shall wait for the autopsy report to precisely know whether it was a murder or suicide. The police are yet to receive any complaint in the matter,” he added.

Title: Tita begins six-day programme to teach coding in schools
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana Information Technology Association (Tita) on Monday began a pilot project for introducing coding in schools. The six-day programme is being held in 18 government schools in Makhtal constituency across Wanaparthy district.

“Two students one from class 8 and another from class 9 and one teacher from the school will be trained in Scratch programming and Phython language for artificial intelligence,” Tita global president Sundeep Kumar Makthala said and added that they were using unique methods such as helping students understand concepts through the use of legos.

Makthala said Tita will prepare a report on the outcomes and make recommendations to the government to scale up the programme and introduce coding in schools from the next academic year. IT Minister K T Rama Rao has asked departments of school education and IT to collaborate and devise a programme to introduce coding at school level. The objective is to ensure that students are exposed to possibilities and careers in coding.

“Students are excited. In fact, we found many girls participating. Many were reluctant to leave the campus even after 5pm,” said mandal education officer, Bhasker Singh.

Title: Hooda, Chautala predict mid-term polls
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Rohtak: Former Haryana chief minister OP Chautala on Monday said the present regime of the BJP and the Jannayak Janta Party (JJP) formed two months ago would not survive for long as it lacked proper co-ordination and matching of ideologies.

Predicting mid-term polls, Chautala, who was in Rohtak on Monday, claimed that since there was no co-ordination between the BJP and the JJP that has formed alliance to run the government, it would fall soon.

“Such government does not run for long time that is formed by political parties lacking proper understanding and co-ordination. All sections of society are facing hurdles in this government,” he added.

Training guns at JJP leader Dushyant Chautala, Chautala said youths were roaming jobless in this regime while it had promised to give jobs to every unemployed by going door to door. He claimed that his party, Indian National Lok Dal (INLD), was the only political party that had always honoured its commitment.

Meanwhile, former CM and main opposition leader Bhupinder Singh Hooda, who was also in Rohtak, supported INLD supremo O P Chautala’s claim of mid-term polls by saying that there was always a possibility in politics.

“If Chautala has issued such a statement, he must have made observation after proper analysis. To me, no possibility can be ruled out in politics and everything is possible,” Hooda added.

Hitting on the BJP-JJP government, Hooda said on one side Maharashtra coalition government had started working on their common minimum program, on the other the BJP-JJP government was yet to form its common minimum program. On the hike of Rs 250 in social security pension, Hooda said it was no achievement by the government as it had hiked only Rs 50 additionally.

Title: HC to Telangana government: What is your policy to rehabilitate missing children?
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Monday sought to know from the state its policy to deal with missing children . The court also asked the state how it dealt with other states when it came to handing over rescued children to their native places.The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy issued notices to the state and its authorities following a PIL filed by advocate Rapolu Bhaskar who urged the court to look at the numbers of missing children in the state, which rose by 2,000 between 2015 to 2018. He also urged the court to take cognisance of the alleged manner in which the police were closing cases without tracing the children.“Bihar was refusing to accept its children even when they were rescued by other states like Rajasthan. This is because the state has to pay to the parents Rs 20,000 for each rescued child,” the bench said and added it was alarming that due to this, rescued children are unable to reunite with their parents.“When several tribal girls from Rajasthan were rescued in Gujarat, that (latter) state had made a false claim that the girls came on their own in search of employment. No tribal girl from Rajasthan would go to Gujarat for employment. They were trafficked into prostitution. The state of Gujarat had given a wrong explanation,” the bench said and added that many were being trafficked to other major cities.The bench sought to remind state counsel, T Srikanth Reddy, representing the home department that human trafficking is happening for two purposes. “If it is girls, they are trafficked into prostitution. If its boys, they are turned into bonded labourers,” the bench said while asking the state counsel the number of bonded labourers the state has. “How many are from Telangana and how many of them are from other states?” the bench asked.“Unless you raid brothel houses, you will not know the details of the victims. Jodhpur is a conduit point in Rajasthan. Similarly several states have exit points to traffic children. Most of them situated at the borders and trafficked kids are usually from the tribal and other weaker communities,” the bench said and asked the state to conduct a sociological survey of the rescued and missing children.The bench, while tagging a PIL filed by Prajwala to the current PIL, requested senior counsel L Ravichandar to assist as amicus curiae. It also sought counters from the state mainly from the home and labour departments. “Don’t be bureaucratic in your approach and file sensible counters,” Chief Justice Chauhan said while posting the case to February.

Title: Prosecution seeks death for Hajipur case accused
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The prosecution in the Hajipur rape and murder cases has sought death penalty for the accused, 28-year-old Marri Srinivas Reddy . It urged the court to consider it as a ‘rarest of the rare’ case. “Under the Pocso Act, the accused deserves death penalty and no mercy should be given to him,” the prosecution argued in the court on Monday. The prosecution said under the Supreme Court guidelines, rape and murder of a minor girl by an accused should be considered as the rarest of rare case deserving death by hanging.

“To satisfy his carnal desires, he killed the girl,” the prosecution said and added that persons like Srinivas were a danger to society. “The case should not just be seen as another crime but a disease in the society. The accused showed no mercy on his victim and killed her. Hanging him to death is a well-deserved punishment and will also act as a deterrent to others,” the prosecution said.

Srinivas, a lift mechanic, was arrested on April 30 last year in connection with the crime. The girl had gone missing on April 25 and a police complaint had been lodged the same day. Her body was found in an agricultural well belonging to the accused the next day. Police have also accused him of committing rape and murder of two more girls.

The prosecution will present its case in connection with the rape and murder of a 17-year-old girl and a 11-year-old girl in the court on Tuesday. The crimes were committed in Hajipur village of Bommalaramaram mandal in Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri district.

The accused has already denied his involvement in the cases by telling the court that he was framed. He said last week that he was impotent and that he did not have a smartphone as police had presented it as an evidence to show that he was addicted to porn and also the photographs of the girls were found on his cellphone.

Title: IIM-V to launch fellow prog in marketing, decision science
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam (IIM-V) will launch two new doctoral programmes this year in decision sciences and marketing. A notification to this effect will be released in the next few days.

Declared as an Institution of National Importance, the institute started its first batch of Fellow Programme in Management, leading to the awarding of PhD in finance and accounting and production and operations management in 2019. Now, the IIM-V will add these two new doctoral programmes to its bouquet of courses.

The usual duration of FPM is five years, comprising two years of course work, an examination and thesis work. The Indian Institutes of Management Bill, 2017, which came into effect from January 2018, allows IIM-V to award PhD degrees instead of the earlier Fellow Programme in Management (equivalent to PhD) offered by the IIMs. Speaking to TOI, director of IIM-V, Prof M Chandrasekhar said IIM-V is keen on building its identity as a knowledge entity, focusing on research of high quality and large impact.

“IIM-V believes that the new doctoral programmes will advance knowledge and innovation in management theory and practice. We want to start the new doctoral programmes by having at least two candidates in each FPM discipline. In the context of new challenges emerging in the business and non-business organisations, the research programmes will groom the research scholars to conduct cutting-edge research and emerge as innovative solution providers” said Prof Chandrasekhar.

Explaining the benefits offered under the FPM programme, Prof Chandrasekhar said the PhD students will be offered Rs 30,000 monthly stipend for the first two years and Rs 33,000 for the remaining three years. “They will be offered a startup grant of Rs 50,000 in the first year and Rs 25,000 annual contingency grant to purchase books, out-of-station visits for data collection and other research-related work. They can attend two international conferences and three national conferences and the expenditure will be borne by the institute,” he said.

Meanwhile, the IIM-V introduced two foreign languages, German and Spanish, as part of its flagship postgraduate programme in management programme this year. While 40 students opted for Spanish, 15 students chose German as part of the course.

Title: Cows in 300 Pilibhit villages to undergo artificial insemination
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pilibhit: The animal husbandry department in Pilibhit has launched a project to artificially inseminate cows and buffaloes in 300 villages which have considerable population of milch cattle.

Under the plan, which is an integral part of the Union government’s ‘Rashtriya Gokul Mission’, the artificial insemination facility is to be provided to beneficiaries at their doorstep free of cost.

“The plan is aimed at improving the breed of nondescript indigenous cows which have come to the brink of extinction as their keepers have developed a tendency to abandon them due to their low capacity of milk production,” said Dr Gyan Prakash Singh, chief veterinary officer (CVO) at Pilibhit.

As per the latest census of milch cattle, the district has 1.65 lakh cows and 2.70 lakh buffaloes. Of these, the cows of indigenous species comprise nearly 40 to 50 thousand. The district had been assigned a target of inseminating 20,000 cows and buffaloes by March 31, said the CVO.

“We have deployed one artificial insemination worker (AIW) in each of the 300 selected villages who will carry the frozen semen of enriched species of bulls using liquid nitrogen to maintain the prescribed temperature and to keep it safe. The AIW will visit door to door in the villages and will provide three free cycles of artificial insemination to one cow. Even if the cow or buffalo fails to conceive, the keeper concerned will be advised to bring the cattle to the nearest veterinary hospital for proper medical checkup and treatment,” said Singh.

This plan will bring about a revolutionary change in milking capacity of indigenous species of cows and buffaloes, he explained.

The report of artificial insemination is to be uploaded daily on the prescribed website of the Indian Agriculture Research Institute (IARI) or else the performance of the district will be counted as zero, he pointed out.

Meanwhile, marginal and small farmers have welcomed the scheme. “The plan will save us from meeting the cost of artificial insemination as well as transporting the cattle to centre concerned,” one of them said.

Title: US violated int’l law: Iran consulate
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The Consulate General of the Islamic Republic of Iran in Hyderabad through a statement on Monday said that the killing of Genral Suleimani was an attempt to bring back terrorists in the region by US. The consulate has also opened a book of condolence at its premises.

“The United States’ action to assassinate General Qassem Suleimani and his associates is an unlawful, illegitimate, inhumane and a terrorist act, contrary to the principles and norms of international law and in clear violation of human rights and international humanitarian law,” said consul general Mohammad Haghbin Ghomi and added that Suleimani was a pioneer in the fight against terrorist and extremist groups, including ISIS, in the region.

“Had it not been for the bravery of Gen. Suleimani and his companions, Syria and Iraq would have fallen into the hands of ISIS long ago. US action to assassinate this brave commander reflects the nation’s hollow slogans and false claims to fight terrorism,” the consulate’s statement said.

Title: Banking on PM Modi, BJP set to go to polls without CM candidate
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

NEW DELHI: In a departure from previous polls, BJP is set to contest the Delhi assembly elections without naming its chief ministerial candidate as the party seeks votes in the name of PM Narendra Modi and the performance of the central government under him.

“I am confident that through this 'mahaparva' (festival) of democracy, people will choose the government which fulfils the aspirations of the people of Delhi under the leadership of PM Narendra Modi by defeating those who misled them for five years by making only hollow promises,” BJP chief Amit Shah tweeted.

Shah’s mention of the PM, whom he has been repeatedly invoking while seeking votes in Delhi, makes it obvious that the party is banking heavily on Modi’s charisma to repeat its performance in the Lok Sabha polls, in which BJP had registered a clean sweep winning all seven seats.

There was speculation about the party naming one of its Delhi leaders as its chief ministerial candidate. However, party sources said it was decided to wait for the polls to be over.

BJP had named Sushma Swaraj as its face in 1998 followed by V K Malhotra (2003, 2008), Harsh Vardhan (2013) and Kiran Bedi (2015). However, the party’s decision to name Bedi as its CM candidate was seen as one of several factors that led to its defeat as a section of party leaders was unhappy at the decision.

BJP has launched its campaign in the national capital and is leaving no stone unturned to win the polls with Modi and Shah leading from the front. Hoardings depicting legalisation of unauthorised colonies, a key poll plank of the party, have been put up in large numbers with photographs of Modi, who addressed a huge rally at Ramlila ground recently.

BJP is hoping to repeat its Lok Sabha polls feat of 2019 when it had bagged 57% votes. The party believes the decision to confer ownership rights to residents of unauthorised colonies will help it win over people living there. The party claims the decision will benefit up to five million people.

Title: Man stabbed to death, brother injured in brawl
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

KURUKSHETRA: Raj Kumar of Gandhi Nagar , Thanesar City in Kurukshetra district , was stabbed to death and his brother Roshan injured on Sunday late evening after they were allegedly attacked in Kurukshetra.

Raj Kumar was rushed to LNJP civil hospital in Kurukshetra, where he succumbed to his injuries.

On Sunday, the family members of the deceased staged protest in Kurukshetra and obstructed traffic, demanding the arrests of the accused involved in the murder. They ended the protest after police assured them action agains the accused at the earliest.

On the complaint of Raj’s brother Karamjit Singh, a case against five accused, all residents of Kurukshetra has been registered at Thanesar City police station.

Title: TRS sets eyes on Medchal-Malkajgiri
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: By roping in half a dozen ministers and scores of leaders for campaigning for the January 22 civic elections, TRS is leaving no stone unturned to capture civic bodies in Medchal-Malkajgiri district. Reason: The semi-urban area has four municipal corporations and nine municipalities, making it the only district with four municipal corporations in its jurisdiction, and poll outcome has a direct bearing on three Assembly constituencies of Greater Hyderabad.TRS sources said special focus on campaigning in the district has been given as it encompasses Medchal, Kukatpally and Qutbullapur Assembly constituencies, which are part of the Malkajgiri parliamentary constituency represented by Congress MP A Revanth Reddy. TRS leadership reportedly told minister Ch Malla Reddy, who hails from the district, that the party should win all 13 urban bodies (4 corporations and 9 municipalities) in the district without giving any scope to either Congress or BJP.The sources said though Malla Reddy wields considerable influence in the district, the party wants to deploy other minsters too to address people at the hustings. The first round of preparatory meetings was held at Boduppal, Jawaharnagar and Medchal. Ministers from the district, Sabita Indra Reddy, A Indrakaran Reddy and T Harish Rao also participated in the meetings. Though Harish Rao is in-charge minister of the erstwhile Medak district (now Medak, Siddipet and Sangareddy districts), the party has decided to utilise his services in Medchal too.The party’s earlier strategy was to confine ministers to their respective districts, but in Medchal, Harish Rao and other ministers have been asked to campaign on the invitation of Malla Reddy when and wherever required. Municipal minister KT Rama Rao , who said he would be campaigning in his pocket borough, Sircilla constituency, might participate in meetings and road shows in Medchal district. He had participated in road shows in the Malkajgiri Lok Sabha constituency during the Lok Sabha elections in May, 2019.“We are ahead of other parties with regard to campaigning. The first round of canvassing has been completed. Our party wants to reach each and every voter and tell them about the welfare schemes being implemented by the government such as Kalyana Lakshmi, Shaadi Mubharak or housing scheme. Every household has benefited from one government scheme or the other, which might turn the tide in our favour during the municipal elections,” TRS parliamentary party incharge Marri Rajasekhar Reddy told TOI.Since internecine wars might damage party’s prospects in elections, TRS is worried about differences between minister Malla Reddy and former Medchal MLA M Sudheer Reddy. Chief minister and TRS chief K Chandrasekhar Rao has already warned Sudheer Reddy and directed him to work with the minister. Sources said Sudheer Reddy has been reportedly seeking seats for his followers in the Medchal assembly constituency, which he had represented earlier.

Title: TJS decides to go it alone in civic polls
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Telangana Jana Samithi (TJS) will go it alone in the January 22 municipal elections . The party will soon come out with a manifesto. Speaking to media on Monday, TJS founder-president M Kodandaram said party members and cadre are enthusiastic about the elections.

TJS will contest in about 500 wards of the total 4,000 seats in 120 municipalities and municipal corporations. “The main objective of contesting the elections on our own is to create an awareness about TJS,” Kodandaram said.

TJS general secretary G Venkat Reddy said they are looking at expanding the party base and strengthening it from the grassroots. Reddy also said the polls would be an acid test for even TRS working president KT Rama Rao.“If KTR fails to ensure a TRS sweep in the coming elections, it will become difficult for him to become chief minister,” the TJS general secretary said.

Title: Bad weather stalls demolition of 83 structures near the Chandigarh airport
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

On September 18, a 15-day notice was given to 98 owners of structures falling within 100-metre vicinity of the... Read More

MOHALI: Immense cold wave and bad weather conditions have stalled the demolition of 83 odd illegal structures by the Mohali administration .

“Zirakpur municipal council (MC) is yet to seek police protection to conduct the drive,” said Sukhvinder Singh Randhawa, executive officer (EO).

He said, “We have decided to defer the demolition drive due to immense cold wave conditions and bad weather. We do not want anyone to be displaced from their dwellings in adverse weather conditions. We will also write a letter to the SSP Mohali seeking security cover which may take a week or 10 days after which the demolition will be carried out.”

Following the high court orders, the Mohali administration had issued notices to the owners of 83 such structures, which have been constructed within the radius of 100 metres from the boundary wall of the defence installation, giving them two-week time till January 7.

Earlier, 15 days’ notice was given to 98 owners of illegal structures falling within the radius of 100-metre vicinity of the airport boundary wall under the Works of Defence Act, 1903, on September 18 following orders of the Punjab and Haryana high court to carryout demolition of illegal structures constructed after March 9, 2011, at Bhabat village and after March 11, 2011, at Jagatpura village in the vicinity of the Air Force station, Chandigarh. All such structures have been termed illegal under the Works of Defence Act, 1903. The high court had ordered to carry out demolition following due course of law.

Out of the 98 owners of the illegal structures who were issued notices earlier, 65 have not disputed the position that their structures have been raised after the public notice of March 9, 2011. Of these, 16 have not been able to substantiate their claim that their structures were existing prior to the said date.

The remaining 16 owners were able to adduce evidence that their structures were existing prior to March 9, 2011. One referred owner had submitted that his structure was outside the 100-metre periphery. Therefore, all the remaining 81 structures are raised in contravention of the Act, therefore, they are liable to be demolished since their action of raising the same were illegal, there is no question of paying any compensation qua the structure, rather they may be liable for paying the cost of demolition leaving 83 structures to face immediate demolition.

Title: Bellandur, Varthur lake silt to go to farmers, brick kilns
Content:
Foaming at Bellandur and Varthur lakes has often made global headlines in the past years.

BENGALURU: The National Green Tribunal-mandated revival of Bellandur and Varthur lakes is set to enter a crucial stage: desilting . Farmers and residents looking for manure for their fields and gardens, and brick kilns in need of raw material, are set to be the beneficiaries.While farmers will get the silt for free, BDA, custodian of the two lakes, is yet to work out the modalities of charging residents and brick kilns.Foaming at Bellandur and Varthur lakes, spread over 516 acres and 17 guntas and 439 acres 34 guntas, respectively, has often made global headlines, prompting NGT to virtually steer and oversee revival efforts. Treated water from these water bodies is being released into lakes in Kolar district.The biggest challenge BDA had to grapple with before taking up desilting was what to do with the silt. Things fell into place once the authority found the solution.“Silt has huge demand among farmers and brick kiln owners. Farmers can get it for free after showing their KISAN/Aadhaar card and use it as manure,” a senior BDA official said. Silt is a major raw material for brick kilns and they need to submit letters detailing their requirements to the authority, which will approve them, he added.Tenders for desilting were floated last week and work is expected to start next month. A senior BDA official said desilting is the only way to save the lakes, which have been contaminated by sewage for many decades. “For now, sewage inflow has been stopped and diverted. BWSSB has assured us no sewage will be let into the lakes,” he added.A bathymetric (study of water depth) survey by Indian Institute of Science (IISc) and Madras Engineering Group and Centre in 2017 put the worth of silt in Bellandur and Varthur lakes at Rs 1,800 crore. While 6.6 million cubic metres of sediment on Bellandur lake bed has reduced its water-holding capacity to 5.5 MCM, 1.6 million cubic metres of silt has shrunk Varthur lake ’s holding capacity to 0.6 MCM. BDA has estimated that about 85 lakh cubic metres of silt will have to be removed from the water bodies. Once the lakes are desilted, bunds will be built and walkways developed. Only treated water will be let in, the official added.Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike commissioner BH Anil Kumar told TOI that giving away silt is better than transporting it. “Silt was earlier used to create artificial islands, something we can’t do now due to court orders. Transporting it to landfills is another option but it’s not viable,” Kumar said, adding: “Heavy trucks are required to transport silt, which will end up damaging roads.”

Title: Acid attack: Woman, 2 others held for shopkeeper’s murder in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Razia Begum (Left) and Lingaraju.

BENGALURU: The murder of a 51-year-old provision store owner, who was attacked with acid and set afire near Anekal on Friday night, has been cracked with two men and a woman being arrested. The shopkeeper had lent money to the woman and had allegedly demanded sexual favours from her in return.

Jyothappa M of Hennagara Hosahalli village was attacked by two unidentified men near his village when he was riding back from Hebbagodi on Friday night. The arrested are Razia Begum, 29, and Lingaraju, 40, of Sriramapura near Jigani and their associate Sathish, 26, a resident of Jigani.

After being attacked with acid, Jyothappa was hacked to death with a machete and his body was burnt. The incident had sent shockwaves in the area. Jyothappa succumbed to burns in hospital on Saturday morning.

Suryanagara police formed a team headed by DSP (Anekal sub-division) Nanjunde Gowda to nab the accused. “Before his death, Jyothappa had said he had lent Rs 30,000 to Razia and suspected her involvement in the attack. Based on his statement, Razia was picked up and she confessed to the crime,” a police officer said.

Preliminary probe revealed Razia and Lingaraju, from Ballari, had setted down in Sriramapura. Razia had complained to her neighbour Lingaraju, a painter, that she had borrowed Rs 30,000 from Jyothappa and he had been demanding sexual favours from her. The duo planned to eliminate Jyothappa and sought Sathish’s help to execute the murder plan.

Police said Lingaraju also sustained burn injuries as he dropped some acid on his hand while throwing it on Jyothappa. The duo also set Jyothappa’s bike on fire before escaping.

“We have seized the murder weapons from them,” an officer said, adding they’ve been produced before court, which has remanded them in judicial custody.

Title: Worried over pollution levels, HC issues notice to state, PCB
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

In a dire state

HYDERABAD: Expressing concern over the increasing levels of pollution in the state and particularly in Hyderabad, the Telangana high court on Monday decided to hear together all cases of pollution pending with it.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy issued notices to the state and the pollution control board asking them to file their replies to a petition that charged them with “negligence while industrial pollution playing havoc with the lives of people” at Jeedimetla in the outskirts of the city.

The bench took up the case on its own after converting a news item in a vernacular daily that narrated the deplorable conditions prevailing at Jeedimetla area due to the alleged reckless and selfish attitude of the industrial polluters in the area who are turning the area into an uninhabitable one.

“Give us a list of cases filed against pollution control board and we will club them all,” the bench said addressing the board’s counsel. “The board should tell us how many PILs are pending against various kinds of pollution. There is a need to club and hear them. People are entitled to have clean air and water,” the bench added. The news item that moved the bench spoke about conditions prevailing at Jeedimetla, which falls under the GHMC.

Title: Religious fervour marks Vaikunta Ekadasi celebration
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: Religious fervour marked the celebration of Vaikunta Ekadasi at various Vaishnava temples in the city on Monday. Huge number of devotees waited in serpentine queue lines for darshan through the north gate of temples from the wee hours.

The rush of devotees continued throughout the day at Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy Devasthanams in Mangalagiri town of Guntur district. Temple authorities arranged special queue lines through the north gate, also called ‘Vaikunta Dwaram’ of the temple, to regulate the huge rush. Rathothsavam (chariot ride) of Lakshmi Narasimha was the big attraction of the day.

Tirumala Tirupati Devastanams authorities also made huge arrangements at its temples in Kalyanamantapam and Labbipet. Devotees were allowed for darshan from 4.am, with thousands thronging to the temples during ‘brahma muhurta ’ which is considered auspicious. “Vaikunta Ekadasi is the auspicious day to worship Lord Maha Vishnu. Offering special prayers on this day and visiting the temple through ‘Vaikunta Dwaram’ is believed to give salvation. Abhishekam, archana, maha shanti homam and other pujas are performed for world peace,” said Vishnubotsla Krishna Sharma, a local priest.

Speical counters were arranged to facilitate the devotees who wore ‘govinda maalas’. The temple turned yellow with hundreds of Govinda devotees in yellow robes. Sri Venkateswara Swami Devasthanams in Tirumalagiri village of Krishna district and Srikakulandhra Mahavishnu temple in Srikakulam village of Krishna district also witnessed huge turnout of devotees.

Title: Eluru hosp chief lets staff party for hours, suspended
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Eluru: Superintendent of Eluru Government Hospital, Dr. AVR Mohan, was on Monday suspended after patients complained that he failed to crack the whip on staffers for dereliction of duty.

Vydya Vidhana Parishad commissioner Dr U Ramakrishna issued orders appointing in Mohan’s place senior ophthalmologist Dr AS Ram as incharge superintendent after health minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas asked him to bring erring authorities to book.

Complainants TOI spoke to said several of the government hospital’s staff partied from 11 am to 3 pm earlier this month, ringing in the new year and “felicitating the superintendent”. “Nursing college students, hospital medical officers, staff and workers danced for hours to popular film songs completely ignoring patients and leaving them to their fate,” a patient said. The furious patients and bystanders accused Dr Mohan of doing little to control the revelry or asking the staffers to resume duty.

The issue was brought to the notice of medical and health minister and deputy chief minister Alla Kali Krishna Srinivas by the attendants of a few patients admitted in the hospital.

The minister then directed the commissioner of AP Vydya Vidhana Parishad to take immediate action against the superintendent if guilty. After conducting inquiry into the matter, the authorities relieved Dr Mohan form duty temporarily.

The patients said the staffers were gone for hours and they were left in the lurch, causing grave inconvenience to most and putting the lives of a few others in danger.

Title: Parents suspect foul play in man’s death
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Coimbatore: A couple from Karamadai approached collector K Rajamani seeking reopening of the investigation into their son’s death that happened a month ago. The couple said the death, which was registered as a road accident , could be a case of caste-related murder.

Selvam and Chandiramani said their 22-year-old son Arun kumar was last seen riding a two-wheeler with two boys from another caste. “He was last seen riding with the boys around 5.20pm on December 8. However, at 6.30pm, I got a call from one of the boys stating that my son had got injured and was lying unconscious,” said Chandiramani.

“But by the time we reached, my son had been sent to GH by some villagers. The postmortem said my son died due to a head injury. We didn’t suspect any foul play at first,” she said.

However, the family became suspicious after realizing that the other two boys suffered no injuries and the two-wheeler was in a good condition.

Social activist Dhandapani said that the police personnel, who investigated the case, had failed to check the footage from the CCTV camera installed in a nearby bank. “The boys’ parents and the victim’s father had a caste clash in 2017. The boys belong to OC (other caste) and Arun Kumar was a scheduled caste boy. So, Arun Kumar riding with the boys itself seems suspicious.”

The Karamadai police had registered a case of death due to road accident after the vehicle was found hit by an unidentified vehicle.

Title: Hopeful for justice, says slain Sikh’s brother
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amritsar: Two days after attack on Nankana Sahib gurdwara, Sikh man Parvinder Singh was killed in Peshawar, but his elder brother Harmeet Singh has not lost all hope. Though he accepts that such cases related to minorities are suppressed, he believes assassins of his brother will soon be thrown behind bars.

He also feels that despite a general sense of fear among Pakistani Sikhs , there are not many chances of minorities’ exodus.

While talking to TOI over phone from his village Chakesar in Shangla district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) province of Pakistan on Monday, Harmeet said, “Police are narrowing down on the killers of my brother, but I wonder why he was targeted.”

Harmeet, Pakistan’s first Islamabad-based Sikh TV anchor, said, “I am from your community. I come across people of all faith, including Hindu, Sikhs, Muslim, and even those who are forcibly converted. However, following killing of my brother, I didn’t see fear in the community, not even in my family.”

He said if he or his family would have been scared, he would have not been sitting in his hilly home town.

“At present, it is snowing in this remote hill town and I am with my family and friends,” he said.

On Sunday, two days after attack on Nankana Sahib gurdwara, Harmeet’s younger brother, Parvinder Singh, who was settled in Malaysia, was shot dead in Chamkani area of Peshawar. He was there for his wedding shopping.

Asked whether there was any possibility of exodus of Hindus and Sikhs to India out of fear, Harmeet replied, “I don’t think so, a few people had been exaggerating the issue. Police are working on the case. We are also part of this society and government and ministers are in touch with me.”

However, he added, it was the media upon which he had maximum confidence to mount pressure on the government to bring culprits to the book. “After all, we are a minority here. Most such cases of minority community are suppressed, unless they are voiced through media,” he said.

He also denied that there could be any connection of his brother’s killing with attack on gurdwara Nankana Sahib.

“Police claims to have cracked 70% of the case, but they are yet to catch hold of the culprits. Let police arrest them, only then truth will be known,” he said.

Title: RK Roja caught in spat between YSRC factions in Chittoor dist
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

RK Roja

Infighting within YSR Congress (YSRC) took an ugly turn after followers of YSRC ’s Nagari legislator RK Roja lodged a complaint against a rival faction in Chittoor district .

The spat between the two groups at Nagari assembly constituency almost grew into a clash when RK Roja was returning from a foundation stone-laying ceremony in KBR Puram under Puttur mandal on Sunday.

A group of over 30 YSRC activists obstructed the legislator’s vehicle and raised slogans against her for her support to local party functionaries who shifted to YSRC from Telugu Desam Party ( TDP ). The activists questioned Roja for not extending similar support to party workers who have been with YSRC since its inception.

Sources in YSRC said Roja had sidelined local party functionary DK Yelumalai after the party came to power in the state. Yelumalai’s followers alleged that the actress-turned-politician was instead supporting a group of local YSRC activists who had shifted from TDP.

It is also alleged that Roja overlooked Yelumalai’s suggestion for the location of the village secretariat and instead chose another location near KBR Puram village proposed by a rival group.

Following the blockade, Roja’s followers lodged a complaint against party functionaries involved in the incident. Cases have been registered against 37 YSRC activists under sections 143, 341 and 427 of the IPC.

Title: For Republic-Day, Mohali cops tighten security at VR Punjab mall
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The checking is being conducted twice a week to prevent any mishap

MOHALI: Ahead of the Republic Day , the Mohali police have tightened security and are conducting special checking at VR Punjab mall , Sector 118, Mohali.

According to the police officials, the checking is being conducted twice a week to prevent any mishap and to make sure that the surroundings are peaceful.

Inspector Manphul Singh, SHO, Balongi, said, “Our team along with the security officials of the mall check the entire mall along with dog squad of the Mohali police. We have told the security guards to keep an eye and check suspicious vehicles coming into the mall.”

Manphul said criminals used fake number plates on their vehicles so the guards had been instructed to check the registration number of every vehicle whether it is genuine or not.

“The complete process takes around 3 hours,” he added.

According to the police officials, along with checking the mall, marriage palaces, paying guests accommodation and hotels are also being checked and people are told to contact the police if any suspicious person rents a room.

Title: 1,700 apply for 90 posts of Haryana law officers
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CHANDIGARH: Despite a strict criterion for appointment as law officers in the Haryana advocate general (AG) office, the authorities have received around 1,700 applications for the 90 advertised posts. It means around 18 advocates would be competing for one post.

Sources confirmed to TOI that the authorities may not take interviews of applicants because of such a high number of applications and the final list may be released by the end of January on the basis of scrutiny of advocates’ professional record.

“We have received around 1,700 applications and considering such a high number of applications, it may not be possible to interview each and every candidate. The merit list would be prepared on the basis of profile and professional record of a candidate provided in the application form. We have started the process to scrutinise applications and expected to finalise the final list by the end of January,” Haryana advocate general Baldev Raj Mahajan told TOI.

Mahajan said that besides advocate general, home secretary and legal remembrancer (LR) of the state are members of the selection committee. He added that some more experts from the field of law may be involved in the selection process, if required. AG also accepted that despite a strict criteria for selection of law officers, the number of applications received by his office are significantly high.

Recently, the AG office Haryana had issued advertisement inviting applications for 90 posts of law officers. According to the criterion, an advocate having professional income of Rs 12 lakh for additional AG, Rs 8 lakh for deputy AG and Rs 5 lakh for assistant AG, would only be eligible to apply for the post.

For the first time, the Haryana AG office had issued advertisement for appointment of law officers in the AG office. As per the new criterion, those lawyers conducting practice before the district court are not eligible to apply this time.

Similarly, experience of practice as an advocate has also been fixed as 12, 8 and 5 years and should have conducted at least 55, 35 and 25 cases to become eligible for appointment on the post of additional, deputy and assistant AG, respectively. The cases should have been conducted only in the high court or before the Supreme court.

However, the criterion has also been challenged before the Punjab and Haryana high court for being arbitrary and the matter is present pending before the court for hearing.

These law officers are temporarily engaged by the state government for a particular period and reprsents the state government before various judicial platforms. As per the convention, people having affliation with the rulling party of the state are mainly engaged on such posts.

Title: Mohali: Women devotees harassed at temple, management locks toilet
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Manisha Gulati, chairperson of the Punjab State Women Commission, unlocked the toilet on Monday

MOHALI: Women devotes visiting the Sat Narayan Mandir, Mataur village in Mohali were a harried lot when the management of the temple allegedly locked the toilet.

Facing harassment and misconduct with women, Manisha Gulati, chairperson of the Punjab State Women Commission, on Monday unlocked the toilet.

She along with a group of women devotees visited the temple premises and in the presence of the police team, a group of women unlocked the toilet and summoned the temple committee Sanatan Dharam Welfare Society for January 7.

Listening to the grievances of the members of the mahila mandal of Sat Narayan Mandar Mataur, apart from summoning the temple committee in her office, the chairperson also directed the SHO, Rajiv Kumar, to provide security to women inside the temple.

Dayawanti Bansal, president of the mahila mandal, and Abha Bansal, vice-president, apprised the chairperson that the president of the Sanatan Dharam Welfare Society was allegedly harassing women and had locked women’s toilet.

On this, Gulati warned that harassment and misconduct with women would not be tolerated at all. The chairperson further said she would take up the matter with the deputy commissioner, SAS Nagar, and urge him to provide women with 50 per cent representation in the new management of the temple committee.

Title: 60 Hisar villages say no to liquor vends
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HISAR: The panchayats of 60 villages in Hisar district have put in their applications at the excise department to join the alcohol prohibition scheme. However, it is not yet clear whether the application is valid according to rules. The list of these villages will be sent to the headquarters by January 15 after investigation. Last time around, 20 villages from the district had also requested for prohibition.

Haryana government introduced the Haryana Panchayati Raj (Second Amendment) Bill, 2019, in the House last year to remove liquor contracts from villages, which was passed unanimously. After the passage of the Bill, the power to close liquor contracts in villages came to the gram sabhas, with the consent of 10% citizens.

According to DC of taxation, Vijay Kaushik, till December 31, he has received applications for liquor ban from around 60 villages, which are under scrutiny at the moment. He said according to the scheme, the proposal has to be passed by 10% villagers and it will be investigated whether signatures have been faked.

Title: Vote for growth, Delhi CM urges voters
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: Describing the assembly election as a referendum on the performance of AAP government, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday appealed to people to put their political preferences behind and vote in favour of progress and development. He said AAP would run a positive election campaign because “we do not know the politics of mudslinging”, adding that the party was open to suggestions from the opposition to add to its manifesto.

At the party headquarters, Kejriwal said AAP was ready for the election. “People have decided to vote on the basis of the improvement in infrastructure of government schools and hospitals. We count these as positive votes, which will be in our favour,” he said.

Kejriwal exuded confidence that AAP would outdo its performance in the previous assembly polls in 2015 where it bagged 67 out of 70 seats. The party currently has 61 MLAs and speculation is rife that at least a dozen of them may not get tickets again.

The CM said the people of Delhi had entrusted BJP with the responsibility of administering police, municipal corporations and DDA, and AAP with handling education, health, PWD, DJB and several other departments. “In the polls, people will compare the work done by BJP and AAP in their respective fields... People are happy with the progress made in the terms of education, health, power, water, etc,” he claimed.

He said people should not vote for AAP if they felt that the government had not performed. “I want you to vote for us only if you believe that we have worked for you. We are worthy of your votes if you believe we have done something for you. It takes a lot of strength to say something like this to your voters just before the election.”

Kejriwal said AAP functionaries would seek votes from the supporters of BJP and Congress for development. The CM claimed that if AAP didn’t return to office, schools and hospitals would relapse to their old condition.

He also slammed BJP’s Amit Shah for making personal attacks against him, but added that “we will never reply in the same manner” . “The progress of Delhi is running at a speed of 100km/hour. People will accelerate it to 200km/hour on February 8,” Kejriwal said.
