Title: Barmer cops arrest 2 for Dec 31 gang war
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaisalmer: Barmer police arrested one person and caught another who is now undergoing treatment at MDM Hospital, Jodhpur. The two were involved in gangwar on December 31 in which one person was killed.

Barmer SP Sharad Choudhary said that Suraj Singh (30) was arrested from Jodhpur while Lalit Bhati (29), who was injured and undergoing treatment at a private hospital, was taken to MDM Hospital by them. Prithvi Singh, the mastermind is absconding. Barmer SP told TOI that Ganpat Singh in his report stated that his son Chotu Singh (24) was murdered by Prithvi Singh and others in firing. His relative Malam Singh too was injured in the case.

Malam and Prithvi had old enmity over a plot in Siwana town. Both had lodged several cases against each other. A year ago, Chotu had attacked Prithvi. Since then Prithvi had planned to kill Chotu and Malam.

The SP added that search is on for the absconding accused.

Title: Chandigarh: Bring ducks back to Sukhna lake, says environmentalist
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The water birds were removed from Sukhna Lake in 2014 after the culling drive owing to avian flu

CHANDIGARH: A city-based environmentalist has written to the ministry of fisheries and animal husbandry to order the authorities in the city to bring ducks and geese back to Sukhna Lake .

The water birds were removed in 2014 after the culling drive owing to avian flu.

Rahul Mahajan, in his letter, said his NGO is willing to take care of the birds. The letter, “Birds at Sukhna Lake/cows in gaushala, Sector 45” has been sent to Giriraj Singh, minister of fisheries and animal husbandry and dairying.

The letter reads, “It is a humble request that we want ducks/geese back at Sukhna Lake, which were removed from the lake in December 2014 due to culling by the department of animal husbandry and fisheries, UT.” “We request you to kindly ask the concerned department to provide the birds again at the lake.”

Talking to TOI, he said, “Sukhna Lake was famous for the ducks and geese. The citizens of Chandigarh have sentiments attached with these birds. This is why I wrote to cabinet minister to allow them at Sukhna.”

He said their NGO had earlier as well been taking care of the ducks at Sukhna. “Disease is always possible but that does not mean to finish their habitat. The disease can be from migratory birds but the domestic should be allowed,” he said.

In the letter, he has also requested the minister to allow a gaushala in Sector 45 by using the vacant land managed by forest department, UT. He said the land could be given to gaushala only for temporary basis.

In 2014, a report from Bhopal-based National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases had confirmed that H5N1 avian flu virus was present in one of the domestic birds which had died at the lake. Following directions from the Union ministry of agriculture, action was taken and around 250 ducks were culled.

Title: CM directs review of tram service in Vizag
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AMARAVATI: In an indication of the government’s choice of capital city, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Monday directed officials to appoint a consultant to study the tram service in Vizag from RK Beach to Bheemili.

The CM reviewed the progress of urban development projects in the state with senior officials, with a focus on Vizag. On the proposed metro train project in Vizag, the CM said that trams would be a cost-effective public transport option for Vizag. He said the project could be launched between RK Beach and Bheemili in the first phase.

The CM also directed officials to expedite drinking water projects planned for Vizag city and asked officials to lay dedicated underground pipelines from the Polavaram project to Vizag city for uninterrupted supply of water.

The chief minister had also directed officials to upgrade Kuppam to a municipality. He asked the officials to construct model housing colonies in both Mangalagiri and Tadepalle towns. Officials explained that over 10,000 people have been identified as beneficiaries to receive housing sites. Detailed project reports (DPRs) are under preparation for development of Tadepalle, Mangalagiri and Pulivendula, said officials.

The CM also directed officials to make town planning wings corruption free in order for building plans to be granted without official interference.

Title: 200 home guards waiting for remunerations since August in Pilibhit
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

PILIBHIT: Home guards in Pilibhit district , who play a pivotal role in assisting police in maintaining law and order, haven’t been paid since August last year. Their total arrears have gone up to over Rs 2.50 crore. The backlog is persisting despite the superintendent of police sending a number of reminders to state police administration without effect.

According to SP Abhishek Dixit, district police administration has engaged 200 home guards as supplementary force to carry out policing duty to ensure safety, security and peace at certain occasions like festivals, national holidays, elections for assembly and parliament, etc.

“Each home guard is paid Rs 702 a day. As their payment is pending since August 1, 2019, their total arrears have accumulated to Rs 2,56,95,500. The department had been allocated Rs 10.62 crore to meet the payment of home guards in March 2019, with which their arrears up to July 31 were cleared,” he said.

“The requisite funds for home guards have been regularly released every quarter by state police administration in the past, but despite three reminders between August 20, 2019 and January 2, 2020, it has been delayed this time,” he added.

The accounts section at district police headquarters informed that four other daily wagers deployed by the department have also not been paid wages since August 1. Their cumulative dues have now gone up to Rs 3 lakh.

The affected home guards, who preferred to remain anonymous, described how they were surviving without pay. They said those who were from rural areas and had agricultural lands were not starving as they had surplus produce, but around 40% of them who are from urban areas and were totally dependent on their salary for survival, were borrowing money from usurers at heavy interest rates to pay their children’s school fees and run their families.

Title: Taapsee, Zoya protest at Carter Rd; Deepika, Alia speak up
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Mumbai: As protests against the attacks at JNU gathered momentum, several film personalities joined in to show solidarity with the students, holding an impromptu meeting at Carter Road, Bandra, on Monday night.

The two-hour sit-in from 8pm to 10pm saw actors and directors, including Anurag Kashyap , Anubhav Sinha, Sudhir Mishra, Vishal Bharadwaj, Dia Mirza, Zoya Akhtar, Taapsee Pannu, Richa Chadha, Rahul Bose, Saurabh Shukla, Ali Fazal, Mohammed Zeeshan Ayub, Swara Bhasker and stand-up comedian Kunal Kamra condemn Sunday’s violence . The group sang the poem ‘Hum Dekhenge’ by Faiz Ahmed Faiz.

Participants held posters and placards that read: “Modiji, Ilaaka yeh sabka, go back to your gully” and a pun on the word “religion” that read, “Our country is all about ‘jan’ (where the word “religion” was broken into two and “reli” crossed out).”

Many in the film industry , which had come under fire on Twitter for not taking a stand on the Citizenshhip Amendment Act, called Sunday’s violence at JNU “horrifying”, “heartbreaking” and “barbaric”. Anil Kapoor, Alia Bhatt , Rajkummar Rao, Twinkle Khanna, Sonam Kapoor Ahuja, Shabana Azmi and Richa Chadha spoke against the violence on Monday.

Others, including Deepika Padukone , Pooja Bhatt, Vishal Dadlani, Meghna Gulzar and Aanand Rai, expressed their views too.

Padukone told a news channel, “I am proud of them (the students). They are not afraid. The fact that they are expressing themselves, that they are thinking of the country and its future. Whatever be our point of view, it is important to express it if we wish to see change in our lives or in our country.”

Alia Bhatt said it is time to “strongly oppose any ideology that seeks to divide, oppress and promote violence”.

Kriti Sanon said violence was never the solution and what happened in the varsity was inhuman.

Rajkummar Rao called the attack “heartbreaking”.

Filmmaker Hansal Mehta urged celebrities to speak up.

Actor Renuka Shahane termed the attacks “unbelievable, shameful and scary”.

Earlier, Taapsee Pannu had tweeted, “Coz with great power comes greater responsibility and I don’t want to shy away from it. JNU, you have our love and support.”

Title: Kolkata: Bhatpara board meeting on Tuesday
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Cop on duty in Bhatpara after a shooting in June last year

KOLKATA: The Calcutta High Court has directed the Bhatpara Municipality chairman to hold the meeting of the board of councillors at 1pm on Tuesday.

The court has also asked the North 24 Parganas DM to attend the meeting and file a report to the court on the outcome of the no-trust notice served on the municipality chairman on Thursday.

A division bench of Justice Dipankar Datta and Justice Protik Prakash Banerjee brought forward the date of the meeting to January 7 when Bhatpara Municipality chairman Saurav Singh had issued a notice for the no-trust meeting on January 20.

The bench passed the order after senior lawyer and MP Kalyan Bandyopadhyay representing the appellant and Bhatpara councillor Himangshu Sarkar pointed out that BJP moved court after the board of councillors in presence of 19 Trinamool councillors out of total 33 had adopted a resolution to remove the present chairman. “A writ petition was filed, challenging the notice served by three Trinamool councillors. It didn’t pray for setting aside the resolution,” Bandyopadhyay said. Calling the single-bench order setting aside the entire proceedings of the board meeting “illegal”, the senior lawyer urged the court to set aside the single-bench order.

The division bench didn’t make any observation on the single-bench order. It instead directed the municipality chairman to hold the meeting on Tuesday. Chairman’s lawyer Saptangsu Basu urged for at least a day’s time on grounds that the chairman might not be in town on Tuesday. The bench, however, directed both the chairman and DM to issue notice for the meeting on Tuesday.

TMC councillors served a no-trust notice on Saurav Singh on December 6, after regaining a majority in the municipality. The chairman acknowledged the notice and issued a circular on December 21 fixing the board meeting on January 20. Calling it “illegal”, three Trinamool councillors served another notice, fixing the meeting date on January 2. They argued that the chairman should have called the meeting within a fortnight. Ninteen TMC councillors turned up for the meeting on Thursday and passed the no-trust resolution against the chairman. BJP councillors didn’t turn up.

Title: Medical officer, lab technician held for bribe
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

UDAIPUR: A medical officer and a lab technician were arrested by the ACB on Monday for accepting a bribe of Rs 9,000.

The complaint was lodged by contractor Punjilal Gayari, a resident of Delwada in Ghatol tehsil of Banswara district .

Gayari complained to the ACB that he was granted sanitation and cleaning tender for the model primary healthcare centre (PHC) at Bassi Adha village. PHC incharge Dr Jaswant and lab technician Dinesh Meena demanded a bribe for clearing payment for two and issuing a certificate for satisfactory work.

Title: Bareilly: Owners of 15-year-old vehicles get January 31 deadline for renewal of RCs
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BAREILLY: The Bareilly Regional Transport Office (RTO) has given a final opportunity to the owners who have vehicles older than 15 years to get their registration certificates renewed by January 31. Failing which, said officials, their vehicles will be impounded.

RTO officials said once the deadline got over, they would launch a drive during which such vehicles would be checked for RCs and the vehicles plying without renewed RCs would be impounded.

According to RTO record, till August 2018, around 58,000 vehicles were found to be more than 15-year-old; of these, only around 4,000 owners got their RCs renewed.

Speaking to TOI, Bareilly senior assistant regional transport officer (ARTO) RP Singh said, “Nearly, 60,000 vehicles, including two-wheelers and four-wheelers (up to seven seats), were identified to be more than 15-year-old. The owners had been served notices six times in the past year, but only around 4,000 of them got the RCs renewed. Others are, however, operating their vehicles even after the expiration of RCs. Now, as a final reminder, we ask them to get their RCs renewed on or before January 31. Failing which may result in permanent cancellation of RCs. If such vehicles are found operating without renewed RCs, in violation of the Motor Vehicles Act, the transport authority will impound them.”

Moreover, according to RTO officials, the department has exempted vehicle owners from paying a penalty for the delay, and they now only require paying the RC renewal fee. The renewed RCs will be valid for five years.

“Earlier, there was a penalty of Rs 500 on four-wheelers and Rs 300 on two-wheelers for the delay in getting the RCs renewed. But, now, the owners have to pay only a renewal fee of Rs 600 for four-wheelers and Rs 300 for two-wheelers, along with a Green Tax of 10%,” added the ARTO.

RTO officials said a fresh report would be compiled in March to update the list of 15-year-old vehicles and the owners of the newly-added vehicles would get a deadline for getting their RCs renewed.

Title: Settle feud, Supreme Court tells Ratan Tata, Nusli Wadia
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nusli Wadia (File photo)

NEW DELHI: A last-minute threat from businessman Nusli Wadia 's counsel on Monday to pursue a civil defamation case against Tata Sons chairman emeritus Ratan Tata put paid to the efforts of the Supreme Court for an amicable settlement of criminal defamation proceedings initiated by Wadia against Tata.

Wadia had initiated the proceedings against Tata and other directors of Tata Group companies after he was ousted as director from Tata Steel, Tata Chemicals and Tata Motors following his support to Cyrus Mistry , who was voted out as executive chairman of Tata Sons in 2016.

The criminal defamation proceedings were quashed by the Bombay high court, which had recorded that there was no intention to defame Wadia through the resolution circulated among the boards. However, Wadia's counsel CA Sundaram told a bench of CJI S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant that it was a clear case of defamation and the matter should be taken to trial.

Sundaram said Wadia had no grievance against his ouster as director of Tata Group companies. "What has hurt and defamed him was the resolution circulated among board members. I am against the persons who requisitioned the meeting by making false and defamatory statements," he said.

CJI Bobde said Tata and Wadia were respected industry leaders and it did not behove them to fight like this. "We are not on the merits of the case. You people should not pursue litigation like this. If both of you want, we can appoint a reputed mediator.

Or why can't both of you sit down and talk it out?" the CJI asked. Sundaram said if the allegations made in the resolutions were withdrawn, Wadia would cease the case. Appearing for Tata, A M Singhvi said, "It was Wadia who admitted that he had circulated a copy of the resolution and now he accuses others of defaming him."

Along with Mukul Rohatgi, Singhvi said Tata was ready to say that he had no intention to defame Wadia, as was found by the HC. When the bench was a bout to record Singhvi's statement on behalf of Tata and dispose of the criminal defamation litigation, it heard one of the counsels for Wadia saying this would not preclude him from initiating civil defamation proceedings for damages. This got the court's goat and the CJI said, "This is not fair". It decided to adjourn hearing in Wadia's appeal for a week and asked Sundaram to get instructions from his client about full settlement.

Title: Kolkata: Mom keeps mum, woman’s body found after a week
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The house in New Alipore where the body was found

KOLKATA: The heavily decomposed body of a 26-year-old woman, a BCom (Honours) graduate found in the Sahapur Colony area in New Alipore on Monday initially led cops to wonder if she might have been a victim of homicide. Autopsy sergeants hinted she could have died on December 23.

Victim Guddan alias Kavya Dhannani’s death was reported when her mother Neelam, 51, called her relative from a hospital on Monday to inform them that Kavya had committed suicide .

“The mother’s revelation came under a dramatic situation. Neelam claimed she had locked up her house on December 29 and was on her way to Bihar’s Katihar — her ancestral residence — when she lost consciousness at Howrah station. She was taken to the Howrah General Hospital by the GRP. Around 4pm on Monday, Neelam called up her brother-in-law and told him about Kavya. He, in turn, informed New Alipore police. When we went to the house, we found the heavily decomposed body on the bed. We didn’t find any external injuries on it,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma.

Cops said they have also recovered a purported suicide note that said that both women were going to commit suicide. The police, though, believe the handwriting to be Neelam’s. Cops have also found a noose hanging from the ceiling.

“They might have tried to commit suicide together, but Neelam survived or developed cold feet. A detailed post-mortem will give us the time and cause of death. We will question Neelam once she recovers,” said an officer.

The cops said they have recorded statements from neighbours who said they picked up a foul smell during a New year’s Eve party but had thought it was from a dead animal.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Small parties aim to gain a foothold
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Manoj Jha (ANI Photo)

NEW DELHI: Political parties with tiny footprints in Delhi are dreaming big ahead of Delhi assembly polls. Bihar-based parties like Rashtriya Janata Dal, Janata Dal (United) and Lok Janshakti Party, apart from Bahujan Samaj Party, Samajwadi Party , National Lok Dal and several other political parties are eyeing the vote share in the capital to make their presence felt.

They have thin support, but are high on confidence. BSP Delhi in-charge ML Tomar said that the party will not only contest the 70 assembly seats but also win them. “In 2008, the party had won Gokalpur and Badarpur assembly constituencies. We also have three councillors here,” added Tomar. BSP will contest the election on the issue of water quality, inflation and unemployment.

RJD and JD(U) are seeking an opportunity to capitalise on the growing influence of Poorvanchali voters in Delhi. “We will contest a limited number of seats where people want RJD to represent them,” said RJD’s Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha adding that RJD will pitch the election on the issue of CAA-NRC, unemployment, disempowerment of Poorvanchalis, lack of quality higher education, etc. In past, Delhi had one RJD MLA.

JD(U) is likely to contest around 20 assembly seats. “We have provided tap water to 50% people of Bihar and by the end of this year all of Bihar will get piped drinking water. But in Delhi not all get piped water. The AAP government has not done anything to improve water quality,” said Sanjay Kumar Jha, JD(U) Delhi in-charge. JD(U) will focus on local issues like infrastructure, water quality, etc. It has represented Matia Mahal assembly constituency in past.

LJP’s supremo Ram Vilas Paswan had recently locked horns with CM Arvind Kejriwal on the issue of water quality. The party is preparing to contest the polls, but not yet decided on the number of seats.

All these parties are expected to finalise their list of candidates by the end of the week.

Title: Tirumala celebrates Vaikunta Ekadasi on a grand scale
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Best of arrangements

TIRUPATI: The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams ( TTD ) won accolades from VIPs and common devotees alike for making the best of arrangements for the annual Vaikunta Ekadasi festival, which was conducted on a grand scale on Monday.

Proceedings at the Tirumala temple began as early as 12.30 am when priests performed Dhanurmasam rituals and opened the ‘Uttara dwaram’ — also referred to as ‘Vaikunta dwaram’ — located adjacent to the sanctum sanctorum. Union and state ministers, around 15 judges, elected representatives, bureaucrats and several top officials offered prayers to Lord Venkateswara between 1.15 am and 3.45 am.

TTD sources said over 3,800 VIP passes were issued for Vaikunta Ekadasi this year. Though the temple administration had earlier declared that the VIP darshan slot would be from 2 am to 5 am, TTD advanced the slot from 1.15 am to 3.45 am to advance the darshan timings for common devotees who were awaiting their turn in large numbers in the outside queue lines.

Darshan for common devotees began sharp at 3.45 am and went on uninterrupted. TTD allowed 2,500 devotees, who donated to the Srivani trust, for darshan at around 10 am on Monday. Around 90,000 devotees offered prayers to Lord Venkateswara and had the opportunity to tread through the ‘Vaikunta dwaram’, considered to relieve those passing through it from the cycle of rebirth.

Spiritual dioramas set up by the garden wing of the TTD stood out as a special attraction. TTD spent Rs 25 lakh to design the concepts of Dasavatara Vaibhavam and Asta Lakshmi, set up near the Vaibhavotsava mandapam.

Among those who visited the temple were Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy, state ministers Peddireddy Ramachandra Reddy and Vellampalle Srinivas, Telangana ministers KT Rama Rao and T Harish Rao and elected representatives from AP and Telangana.

Title: Dehradun: Over 2000 homestays registered in state
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

DEHRADUN: In a meeting held on Monday chaired by chief secretary Utpal Kumar Singh to review work done by the tourism and civil aviation department, it was disclosed by tourism secretary Dilip Jawalkar that 2006 homestays had been registered in Uttarakhand till date. The chief secretary said that the homestay registration process should be speeded up further. Disclosing about the preparations being undertaken for the Char Dham Yatra, Jawalkar said that all works regarding the yatra will be completed before the yatra season begins. He added that talks are ongoing with private companies for construction of a proposed five-star hotel and the tendering process has begun for the Himalaya Darshan project to be undertaken by the civil aviation department, for which tenders will open on January 7.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Small parties aim to gain a foothold
Content:
Manoj Jha (ANI Photo)

NEW DELHI: Political parties with tiny footprints in Delhi are dreaming big ahead of Delhi assembly polls. Bihar-based parties like Rashtriya Janata Dal, Janata Dal (United) and Lok Janshakti Party, apart from Bahujan Samaj Party, Samajwadi Party , National Lok Dal and several other political parties are eyeing the vote share in the capital to make their presence felt.They have thin support, but are high on confidence. BSP Delhi in-charge ML Tomar said that the party will not only contest the 70 assembly seats but also win them. “In 2008, the party had won Gokalpur and Badarpur assembly constituencies. We also have three councillors here,” added Tomar. BSP will contest the election on the issue of water quality, inflation and unemployment.RJD and JD(U) are seeking an opportunity to capitalise on the growing influence of Poorvanchali voters in Delhi. “We will contest a limited number of seats where people want RJD to represent them,” said RJD’s Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha adding that RJD will pitch the election on the issue of CAA-NRC, unemployment, disempowerment of Poorvanchalis, lack of quality higher education, etc. In past, Delhi had one RJD MLA.JD(U) is likely to contest around 20 assembly seats. “We have provided tap water to 50% people of Bihar and by the end of this year all of Bihar will get piped drinking water. But in Delhi not all get piped water. The AAP government has not done anything to improve water quality,” said Sanjay Kumar Jha, JD(U) Delhi in-charge. JD(U) will focus on local issues like infrastructure, water quality, etc. It has represented Matia Mahal assembly constituency in past.LJP’s supremo Ram Vilas Paswan had recently locked horns with CM Arvind Kejriwal on the issue of water quality. The party is preparing to contest the polls, but not yet decided on the number of seats.All these parties are expected to finalise their list of candidates by the end of the week.

Title: Anil Deshmukh vows check on crime in big cities
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

PUNE: State home minister Anil Deshmukh on Monday said his priority would be to keep a check on crime in big cities, including Nagpur “which is now considered a city of crimes”.

“I am planning to take charge of the home department on January 8. I will meet the top authorities in the department and decide my action plan following the discussions with them,” the newly appointed minister said.

“My top priority will be to keep a check on crime in all major cities. It is unfortunate that Nagpur is now considered a city of crimes though the former chief minister was from that city and was in charge of the home department for the past five years,” Deshmukh said.

Considered close to Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) chief Sharad Pawar, Deshmukh said he took charge of the home ministry because he liked to accept challenges.

On his stand about Pawar’s recent demand to conduct an independent probe into the police action against human rights activists in the Elgar Parishad case, Deshmukh said he would meet the NCP chief and Pune police officers concerned to understand their views on the issue.

Pawar had sought the formation of a special investigation team to conduct an “independent inquiry” into the cases filed against human rights activists in connection with the Elgar Parishad case. He had asserted that prima facie it looked like the Pune police had misused its authority while probing the case.

Deshmukh said he had plans to hold a meeting of the Pune and Pimpri and Chinchwad police to review law and order in the city.

BOX

MLA raises incomplete police station issue

Wadgaonsheri MLA Sunil Tingre on Monday submitted a letter to home minister Anil Deshmukh about the incomplete police station work near Inorbit Mall on Ahmednagar Road. Tingre said, “The foundation laying ceremony was done about four years ago. But there has been no progress on the construction of the police station. We have requested the home minister to look into the matter and initiate the process for the residents’ benefit.”

The foundation laying ceremony was conducted in 2016 by the then Pune guardian minister, Girish Bapat.

Title: Nobel laureate bats for mechanism design theory
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pune: Nobel laureate Eric Maskin urged the graduating students of Gokhale Institute of Politics and Economics to study mechanism design theory.

Maskin — who was awarded the Nobel Prize for economics in 2007 — was delivering the Kale Memorial Lecture on the occasion of the institute’s convocation on Monday. As many as 158 graduates and scholars were awarded degrees.

Maskin said less than 10% of the world’s economists focus on this discipline, which is the art of starting with the outcome and then figuring out the institutions or concepts to build in order to get there.

To drive home his point, Maskin spoke about the ‘first past the post’ electoral method in which, sometimes, parties that win as few as a third of the total votes polled get to form governments. He said this can be solved by the application of mechanism design, and said he was working with other global economists, including fellow Nobel laureate Amartya Sen, to find a solution.

“Many countries — India included — have adopted this system and oftentimes, parties or candidates with only 30-40% of the votes end up in power. We are working on alternative voting systems and I am sure mechanism design will play a role,” Maskin said.

The decorated economist also said mechanism design can be used to in devise policies to prevent a 2008-like global financial crisis, when the banks overleveraged, or in designing an international treaty to get countries commit to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions. “Regulators can play an important role in preventing banks from overleveraging, and mechanism design as a concept can help them devise strategies,” Maskin said.

He said the concept can also be used to discover the right value of and allocation of prized resources, such as radio frequencies. He said, however, that the theory will have to be used with caution as there is a chance that the participants could overstate or understate the value put on a resource.

Title: Gandikota fest on Jan 11, 12
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Tirupati: The historic Gandikota fort is getting a facelift ahead of the annual Gandikota festival, to be observed on January 11 and 12. The district machinery is taking measures to conduct the festival in a grand manner reflecting the cultural legacy of the region.

Joint collector M Gauthami directed officials to barricade the complex, create parking area, set up temporary toilets and make lighting arrangements.

Adventure sports like jumaring, kayaking and paragliding will be added attractions at the water body this year.

Title: No free bungalow for ex-CMs, apex court upholds HC order
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Refusing interference in the order passed by the Rajasthan High Court in connection to the facilities and bungalows allotted to former chief ministers, a division bench of Supreme Court on Monday upheld the decision of the high court. The HC had ruled that former CMs cannot avail lifelong facilities including government bungalow , telephone and car, and declared the Rajasthan Ministers Salaries(Amendment) Act, 2017 “illegal” The Apex Court has dismissed the special leave petition(SLP) filed in the Supreme Court by the government of Rajasthan and thus upheld the decision of the Rajasthan High Court.

The Rajasthan government had filed the SLP in the Supreme Court challenging the September 4, 2019 decision of the High Court.

On Monday, the bench comprising Justice Uday U Lalit and Justice Vineet Saran dismissed the state government's appeal on the grounds that there was no reason to interfere in the case.

Earlier, on September, 4, 2019 the Rajasthan High court on a petition filed by veteran journalists Milapchand Dandia had declared the amendment to Rajasthan Ministers Salaries Act, 1956 as “unconstitutional,” under which the former Chief Ministers, who had governed for 5 years, were entitled to free bungalows, personal secretaries, stenographers, a grade 1 staff, driver, 3 grade 4 staff for a lifetime. During November, 2019 Milap Chand Dandia a veteran journalist had filed a contempt petition in the High Court in this regard.

The contempt petition has been filed, as per Dandia, as the government did not respond to the letter sent to the chief secretary, seeking implementation of the court's order.

Title: Rajasthan HC stays tribunal order to pay firm refund of Rs 48 crore
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A division bench of Rajasthan High court in an interim order stayed the decision of Central Excise and Service Tax Tribunal which allowed a refund claim of Rs 48.32 crores to a firm involved in importing mobile phones. The court while listing the case for February, 6 had also issued notices to respondent company.

The bench comprising Justice Sangeet Lodha and Judge Mahendra Kumar Goyal stayed the tribunal's decision.

As per the case M/s Trust Marketing engaged in the import of mobile phones. filed refund claim in respect of Customs duty and Cess paid on impugned goods. However, the assistant commissioner of Customs dismissed the claim on February 26, 2016, against which an appeal was made to the Commissioner. “Thereafter the Appeal Commissioner, on July 26, 2018, considered the claim and ordered that refund amount should be deposited in the Consumer Welfare Fund,” said Kinshuk Jain, counsel for Customs central excise and Service Tax(Cce and ST).

The company thereafter filed an appeal in the Central Excise and Service Tax Tribunal. “The tribunal on 16 September said that the refund should be paid to the company. Thus, we appealed against it,” he added.

Title: CM Arvind Kejriwal failed to deliver on 80% of his promises: Amit Shah
Content:
Amit Shah

NEW DELHI: Unfazed by AAP’s confidence that the Kejriwal government’s performance will fetch it another term, BJP has decided to attack the ruling dispensation over what it considers to be a huge gap between what the chief minister promised five years ago and what he has been able to deliver.In a speech that can potentially set the tone for BJP’s campaign pitch, party chief Amit Shah said CM Arvind Kejriwal had failed to deliver on 80% of his promises. Speaking just hours before the announcement of poll dates, Shah also attacked the CM for not allowing prosecution of those who allegedly raised anti-India slogans at JNU in 2016 and for inciting violence against the Citizenship Amendment Act in the national capital.“Kejriwal had promised to install 15 lakh CCTV cameras for the safety of Delhi residents. People are looking all over but can’t find any camera. The AAP government had also promised free Wi-Fi. But the battery of mobile phones of young people will drain while searching for Wi-Fi signals as they are nowhere to be found,” Shah said in what marked an attempt to undercut AAP’s “achche beete paanch saal, lage raho Kejriwal (Incredible 5 years, carry on Kejriwal)” plank.Shah also alleged that while the Delhi government had reduced water bills, people were getting “poison-like” water and DJB’s loss under Kejriwal had jumped to Rs 800 crore as against Rs 150 crore that the public utility earned as profit five years ago.Accusing Kejriwal of supporting the “tukde tukde gang”, Shah said, “Students who raised anti-India slogans should be put behind bars or not? But Kejriwal is not giving sanction to police to prosecute them.” However, he did not make any reference to Sunday’s mayhem in JNU.While AAP, naturally so, was the principal focus of Shah’s speech, the BJP president did not spare Congress. In fact, he lumped Gandhi siblings Rahul and Priyanka with the Delhi chief minister for allegedly provoking violence over CAA by “misleading” minorities.

Title: Pune: Hypnotist abducted over financial dispute, released
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Chatushrungi police on Sunday booked four men, all from Baner-Balewadi areas, for kidnapping and issuing threats to a hypnotist from Pimple Saudagar on Friday afternoon over a financial dispute.

The hypnotist (age 37 years) lodged a FIR with the Chatushrungi police station stating that he had borrowed Rs30 lakhs from one of the men in 2017. Out of the total amount of Rs30 lakhs, the victim returned Rs10 lakhs. At the same time, he also returned about Rs16 lakhs by paying monthly instalments to the suspects.

In 2019, according to the complaint, the business of the hypnotist was in loss and he failed to pay the monthly instalment.

Police said that the man wanted his money back and called him to a hotel located at Baner from where he was kidnapped in a car. The four men took him to a farm house located at Sus and issued threats to him using a pistol.

Senior inspector Anil Shewale of Chatushrungi police station told TOI “The four men then released the hypnotist from the farm house unharmed. He went home and then came to the police station to lodge a complaint”.

Title: 200 home guards waiting for remunerations since August in Pilibhit
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pilibhit: Home guards in Pilibhit district, who play a pivotal role in assisting police in maintaining law and order, haven’t been paid since August last year. Their total arrears have gone up to over Rs 2.50 crore. The backlog is persisting despite the superintendent of police sending a number of reminders to state police administration without effect.

According to SP Abhishek Dixit, district police administration has engaged 200 home guards as supplementary force to carry out policing duty to ensure safety, security and peace at certain occasions like festivals, national holidays, elections for assembly and parliament, etc.

“Each home guard is paid Rs 702 a day. As their payment is pending since August 1, 2019, their total arrears have accumulated to Rs 2,56,95,500. The department had been allocated Rs 10.62 crore to meet the payment of home guards in March 2019, with which their arrears up to July 31 were cleared,” he said.

“The requisite funds for home guards have been regularly released every quarter by state police administration in the past, but despite three reminders between August 20, 2019 and January 2, 2020, it has been delayed this time,” he added.

The accounts section at district police headquarters informed that four other daily wagers deployed by the department have also not been paid wages since August 1. Their cumulative dues have now gone up to Rs 3 lakh.

The affected home guards, who preferred to remain anonymous, described how they were surviving without pay. They said those who were from rural areas and had agricultural lands were not starving as they had surplus produce, but around 40% of them who are from urban areas and were totally dependent on their salary for survival, were borrowing money from usurers at heavy interest rates to pay their children’s school fees and run their families.

Title: Pune: Man posing as Mathadi worker held for extortion
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A man posing as a Mathadi worker was arrested on Sunday for attempting to extort Rs40,000 from an employee of a private company at Senapati Bapat Road.

Vicky Dilip Dhotre (26) of Wadarwad was arrested after the 30-year-old employee lodged an FIR at the Chatushrungi police on Saturday.

The incident occurred on Saturday evening when the employee was shifting the furniture and computers of a software company from Hadapsar to Senapati Bapat Road. He said soon after his loaded truck reached the software company’s new office, Dhotre stopped him at the gate. “He demanded Rs40,000 from the employee to allow him to unload the material,” assistant inspector of Chatushrungi police Dattatray Shinde said.

Shinde said that Dhotre asked the employee to transfer the money to his cousin’s bank account as Mathadi fees. “The employee asked an aggravated Dhotre to unload the truck first, following which he would transfer the amount. The suspect, however, refused to render his services and kept threatening the private company employee,” the assistant inspector said. When Dhotre refused to back-off, the company employee noted down his cellphone number and reported the extortion bid to the police.

“After tracing the miscreant, we asked him for his identity card and licence to check if he was authorized to do the job of Mathadi, but he failed to furnish the details. Further probe revealed that he was only posing as Mathadi worker,” he said.

Title: Vidyavihar man gets 5 years for abetting girlfriend’s suicide
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: In a significant order, a sessions court has held a 36-year-old Vidyavihar man guilty of abetting his 26-year-old girlfriend ’s 2012 suicide after he went back on his promise to marry her and instead married another woman. The accused, Avinash Gaikwad, was in a relationship with the woman for over six years, had lived in with her intermittently and also forced her to have an abortion. Sentencing Gaikwad to five years’ rigorous imprisonment, the court said punishment should act as a deterrent.

“A tendency is growing in society of giving a promise to marry, having a sexual relation with a lady and thereafter refusing to marry. So, it destroys the character and career of the lady. In the present case, the deceased was an educated lady who kept faith in the accused. The accused used her but he refused to marry her and married another girl. She was shocked and committed suicide,” said the court.

The victim, a teacher with a master’s degree, attempted suicide on July 8, 2012, near a temple in Vidyavihar station by consuming pesticide. She called her cousin soon after. When her cousin arrived and found her in a semi-conscious state, she was rushed to a hospital. The victim told her she had consumed pesticide and had written a note which was in her bag. She died four days later.

The prosecution examined eight witnesses, including her brother, relatives, the manager of a hotel where the victim and the accused had stayed together, doctor who conducted the post- mortem and the police. The victim’s father, the complainant, died in the period the case was pending in court.

The prosecution submitted the victim and the accused lived in the same building and hence got to know each other. The victim used to live in the city with her aunt while her parents lived in the village. The prosecution also submitted the accused had always promised to marry the victim and hence she agreed to get sexually involved with him.

The victim’s brother told the court the accused had even met their father and promised to marry her. He said though the brother of the accused was against the marriage, he assured them of it. The prosecution also produced a suicide note and said it clearly showed the victim committed suicide as she was deeply in love with the accused who had cheated her by marrying another woman.

It said a handwriting expert had concluded the note was written by the victim.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: With new zeal, Congress eyes turnaround
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

NEW DELHI: In the capital’s triangular poll battle , it’s Congress that probably faces the toughest of the challenges . After being in office for three consecutive terms — from 1998 to 2013 — the party was pushed to the brink in the 2013 assembly polls, managing only eight seats in the 70-member assembly. The worst, however, came a year later when AAP, in just its second election, won a record 67 seats. Congress couldn’t even open its account.

Virtually unassailable at one point in time, Congress has faced a string of debacles, including the Lok Sabha elections of 2014 and 2019, and the 2017 municipal polls after that. However, not only did the party’s vote share improve considerably in the last Lok Sabha election, it also managed to secure the second position in five of the seven seats, pushing AAP to the third spot.

Buoyed by the recent successes in Haryana, Maharashtra and Jharkhand, the state unit of Congress feels it stands a good chance this time around in Delhi. “We have been in government for 15 years and we have the vision and the capacity toserve. Development has stagnated in the capital in the last six years and AAP could not even maintain the city that the Sheila Dikshit-led government left behind,” Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra said.

Former Gole Market (abolished after delimitation) MLA and campaign committee chairman Kirti Azad said: “We are prepared and will run an aggressive campaign, which will compare the work done by Congress under Dikshit and the current (Arvind) Kejriwal government,” Azad said.

Fragmented and divided into groups in the absence of a clear leadership after Dikshit’s death in July 2019, the Congress leadership in Delhi seems to be coming back together under Chopra. By giving him the reins of the party, appointing Azad as chairman of the campaign committee and giving charge of publicity to veteran functionary Jai Prakash Agarwal, Congress has also tried to bring Punjabi, Poorvanchali and Vaish communities together, as these dominate Delhi’s demography.

Together with Arvinder Singh Lovely as the election management committee head and Mukesh Sharma as the in charge of media, the party will be looking to bring back its old vote bank that had shifted to AAP.

Chopra said the Delhi unit was now united like never before and senior functionaries were willing to go in the field and work like ordinary party workers. But will it translate into votes? “It was Congress that privatised power distribution and ensured 24x7 supply in Delhi. Our government converted public transport to CNG and increased forest cover to over 21% to reduce pollution. We signed an agreement with Haryana government to get more water for Delhi, started metro, brought in new buses, constructed flyovers and hospitals and opened five universities and new schools. People have seen our work and trust us,” the Delhi Congress president said.

He added that party’s manifesto will have several new schemes for Delhi, including relief in electricity consumption up to 600 units, free power up to 200 units for small traders and monthly pension of Rs 5,000 for senior citizens and other deprived sections. “The monthly pension of Rs5,000 will give a lot of relief to families that have elderly parents. It will help them by medicines. The children will also be keen to keep their parents with them and look after them,” Chopra said.

Title: 31% rise in Rajasthan crimes last year; spike in murder, dacoity cases
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan ’s crime rate increased by 31% last year compared to 2018, police statistics revealed, adding that cases of dacoity, theft, loot, rape, abduction and murder saw a substantial hike.Officials said the increase was largely due to more registration of cases due to awareness among the masses. They also claimed that in most cases charge-sheets had been submitted.DGP Bhupendra Singh said, “Although there has been a spike in crime rate, disposal of cases also increased simultaneously. The law and order situation was better than 2018 and even during the Lok Sabha elections, no cases of violence were reported along with the fact that repolling was not required. There are certain issues which still need to be worked on and we are focusing on those.”He said from 2017 to 2019, there was an increase of 32.58% in cases lodged under various IPC sections.Although there was a hike in crime rate, there was a massive dip in incidents of communal violence with only seven such cases being reported as compared to 313 the previous year. In 2019, disposal was done in 2,07,319 cases, which is 28% higher than 2018.Singh added that the Special Operations Group constituted a Serious Frauds Investigation Unit and Cyber Crime Unit while CID was also planning to launch a Heinous Crime Monitoring Unit.“There have been few areas like Alwar , Bhiwadi and Bharatpur where special attention was required and more police personnel have been deployed in critical areas. Our aim is to also create awareness among youth about law as they are at times are both victims and perpetrators,” added Singh.Outlining the road map for the year ahead, the DGP said the plan was to focus on curbing road accidents, check organised crime and crimes against women and children.

Title: Priyanka Gandhi ‘funding’ violence in UP, alleges BJP’s UP chief Swatantra Dev Singh
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Swatantra Dev Singh. (Image taken from his official account/@swatantrabjp)

BAREILLY: BJP’s UP chief Swatantra Dev Singh has alleged that Congress leader Priyanka Gandhi was “funding” violence in Uttar Pradesh. He alleged that she was “bringing goons” from other states to foment trouble in the state.

“There was peace in UP for the last three years and I want to ask why Priyanka wants to cause riots here? Why doesn’t she do it in MP and Rajasthan? She is funding violence and bringing goons from other states and making them pelt stones to disrupt peace,” the BJP leader alleged while addressing a public meeting in Bareilly on Sunday night.

Referring to the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, he said, “Neither Nehru (Jawaharlal) nor Manmohan Singh could do this work while minorities in Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh suffered. They were forced to live a miserable life. For the first time, a political leader took this revolutionary decision and ensured CAA act came into existence. CAA is meant for giving Indian nationality to refugees belonging to the minority community so that they can live a respectable life. They can get house under PM housing scheme and benefits under other government schemes. I want to make it clear that CAA is not meant for withdrawing the nationality of any Indian Muslim. But opposition is misleading the people and disrupting the peace in the state.”

He further said, “Even Dr Ram Manohar Lohia had said in the past that minorities in Pakistan faced a lot of difficulties and they should be given Indian citizenship. But Samajwadi Party won’t remember the words of their founder because their leaders want to do politics for family benefits only.”

Title: Experts analyze 2019 healthcare budget quota
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pune: Primary healthcare continues to be weak in the country and instead of fixing it, the government is allocating more money towards tertiary healthcare (hospitals), said two healthcare experts at a presentation of the People’s Budget in the city on Friday.

Over the next few weeks, a series of presentations will be organized by a civil rights group to study the allocation in the Union Budget 2019 and the projected needs in key sectors, such as healthcare, education and employment, among others, which affect the lives of civilians.

The healthcare budget was analyzed by experts Anant Phadke and Abhijit More, who relied on successive budget allocations and global data to project the trend of allocations in the country.

“Under the Ayushman Bharat Yojana, the government will be spending on tertiary healthcare and money will be routed to private hospitals (through insurance). The allocations don’t even meet the Niti Aayog’s projection for the scheme,” More said.

He said the Ayushman Bharat Yojana would be applicable only in hospitals with over 50 beds, thereby leaving out over 90% of the healthcare facilities in the country, which have less than 30 beds each.

Phadke said the government continued to treat different citizens on different footings. He said the government’s healthcare spends Rs8,500 per year on a Union government employee, Rs6,000 on a defence personnel, Rs3,150 on a Railways employee and only Rs1,700 on civilians.

“The fact is a majority (over 60%) of the spends on healthcare are on out-patient department services and medicines. Only about 3% of the people require hospitalization. So, priorities need to be re-adjusted,” he added.

Title: Top forest official says give animals space, blames urbanisation for conflict
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pune: Man-animal conflict cannot be blamed on the animals as it is happening because humans are encroaching on their space, Sunil Limaye, additional principal chief conservator of forests, said.

“During cases of conflict, everyone holds the animals responsible. Animals need the space to thrive. We are encroaching due to urbanisation and the conflict will not end,” he said.

Limaye was speaking at a conference on Monday on Human and Wildlife Conflict: Concerns and Resolution organised by Biospheres in association with the department of botany at Modern College of Arts, Science and Commerce. The conference was a part of the Kirloskar Vasundhara International Film Festival.

Sachin Punekar, an ecologist and founder of city-based Biospheres, said urbanisation had caused distress among animals. “There has been a 35% growth in human land-use pattern. This is leading to urbanisation distress as it is pushing the animals out of their habitats and they’re moving towards cities,” he said.

Ajay Deshmukh, senior veterinary officer at Manekdoh Leopard Rescue and Rehabilitation Centre in Junnar, said leopards are a highly adaptive species.

“Considering that there is a lot of sugar cane plantation in the area, leopards have learnt to adapt to the new setting. They have made these sugar cane fields their home and are raising their cubs among these fields,” Deshmukh explained.

Co-existence is up to the people, he said. “People feel the leopard population is growing, when in reality they're spreading out. So, we have to decide whether we are ready to co-exist with these big cats,” Deshmukh said.

Subhash Badve, senior forest officer and an expert in grassland and pasture development, said food was one of the reasons that animals came to human dominated spaces for. “There's nothing left to eat in the jungle. There are human settlements and encroachments in forestland,” he said.

The conflict will end if food is made available to wildlife. “Grassland development is something nobody cares about. These grasslands have to be maintained and protected so the woody growth will increase and thorny spaces will increase. A working plan has to be made to protect these grasslands and the wildlife,” Badve said.

Toxicologist Sadanand Raut spoke about minimising deaths caused by snake bites. Calling it Mission Zero Snake Bite, Raut’s programme aims at survival since most deaths occur before reaching the hospital, he said.

Title: Kid murder: Youth held
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaipur: The city police on Monday arrested the neighbour of the 11-year-old boy who was found murdered on Saturday morning in Muhana police station area. The accused had lured the child with the promise to fly kites but instead tried to sodomise him. When the boy resisted, he was strangulated. The accused then slit the child’s throat and dumped the body under a haystack. Cops might arrest the accused’s mother as it appears that she knew about the murder.

Arpit Choudhary’s body was found hidden beneath haystack a day after he was reported missing. He had left his home around 7am on Friday to feed pigeons near his house. When he did not return, the family registered a missing person report.

The accused, identified as 27-year-old Rakesh Sharma, was arrested after cops questioned around 200 witnesses.

Yogesh Dadhich, DCP, Jaipur South told TOI, “There were three factors which led to Sharma’s arrest. We found that he and his mother had cleaned their entire house on Sunday morning which is a strange thing to do in winters. Then their beahviour was suspicious. FSL team also found victim’s hair at the accused’s house.”

The child had a fondness for flying kites and since the accused knew the victim, he used this as an excuse to lure Arpit to his house. Sharma then attempted to sodomise him but when the child started screaming, the accused first strangled him and then slit his throat. Cops found traces of cement on the victim’s clothes and a bag of cement was also found at Sharma’s house.

During the investigation, it was found that Sharma had previously also tried to molest other children. Initially cops had suspected a man who had killed his wife in 2015 and dumped her body at the same spot where Arpit’s body was found.

Title: No psychologist for mentally ill patients at Bareilly women’s shelter home since 2005
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BAREILLY: Allahabad high court has recently asked the UP government to submit a plan of action for improving security and other facilities at government shelter homes for women. But the reality is, most women’s shelter homes in the state have more inmates than their capacity.

The government shelter home in Bareilly has a capacity for 125 women, but currently houses 207 inmates. Of the 125 seats, 100 are reserved for mentally ill patients and 25 for others. However, the home has nearly 150 mentally ill women.

The shelter home has assigned posts of psychologists and craft teachers for mentally ill patients which are lying vacant for the past few years, with the post of psychologist lying vacant since 2005. Though doctors from mental and district hospitals visit the home, sources said psychologists are required regularly for counselling of inmates.

Chhaya Badhval, the assistant superintendent of the Bareilly home, said, “We have a crafts teacher for regular inmates, but the home doesn’t have one for mentally ill patients. There are mental illnesses patients who have recovered and need a teacher for vocational training. Also, around two women return to their families every month. Following treatment and counselling, mentally ill patients are able to recall their address and we contact their families. However, if we have a psychologist here, this number will go up.”

The high court also directed the government to install CCTV cameras in the shelter homes to enhance security. Officials said they have installed 12 CCTV cameras at the Bareilly home.

Shatrugan Kannaujia, district probation officer, Meerut, said, “We already have CCTV cameras installed at Nari Niketan in Meerut. Against the capacity of 75, we have 78 women living there. We also have vocational trainers, who train the women in the art of making handbags and other items, which can fetch them jobs later on. Psychologists, too, are available. Regarding instructions to install CCTV cameras, we’ll check the ones already installed to decide if more can be installed inside the premises.”

Nari Niketan in Mathura, with a capacity for 25 inmates, currently houses 35 inmates, including a child. Mathura DPO Anurag Srivastava claimed two psychologists, along with a woman physician, visit the home once a month. He said there are nine security personnel working three in each shift.

Title: Pune: 780 graduate as chartered accountants
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Over 780 candidates graduated as chartered accountants from The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI). The convocation ceremony was conducted on Friday at Bunts Sangha Pune, on the Mumbai-Bangalore highway .

Former MP Pradeep Rawat and ICAI president and CA Prafulla P Chhajed were present as chief guests.

Chhajed congratulated all the newly-qualified CAs. The ICAI council would begin to develop various audit tools, he said. The ICAI is also building a knowledge hub and developing a digital learning hub for its students and members.

Title: Why contempt proceedings shouldn’t be initiated against you, HC asks SSP Dehradun, Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nainital: Uttarakhand high court ( HC ) on Monday ordered the senior superintendent of police (SSP) of Dehradun and Haridwar districts to be personally present in court and show cause why contempt of court proceeding should not be initiated against them in an ongoing matter related to SC/ST scholarship scam.

The court’s action came after the two SSPs failed to file an ‘Action Taken Report’ as directed by the court in its last hearing on December 16. “SIT head IPS officer Manjunath, who is probing the scam, had told court in the last hearing that they have filed FIRs against colleges in both Haridwar and Dehradun districts and that now it was up to the police of the two districts to take action. However, despite the court order, the police officers did not submit a report,” said MC Pant, the lawyer appearing for the petitioner.

The court further said that the SSPs not only failed to file the report but also didn’t file an application to seek extension. “Order of court necessitates prompt compliance... the casual manner in which the orders of the court are treated is a concern. Since the order has been violated, both the SSPs shall appear by Thursday and show cause as to why contempt proceedings should not be initiated against them in what appears to be a wilful and deliberate violation of the court,” the judges said.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Alok Kumar Verma has been hearing a clutch of petitions that had flagged embezzlement of funds in awarding scholarship to students from underprivileged backgrounds of scheduled caste and scheduled tribes. There are also allegations that the benefits of scholarship which was meant for students whose family income is less than Rs 2.5 lakh has been availed by senior government officials.

Meanwhile, the court also directed the secretary of the state’s social welfare department to take a decision on granting sanction for prosecuting the government officials of the social welfare department by February 10 and file a compliance report as well.

This comes after Manjunath informed the court that he had sought permission of the government to prosecute the five officials working in the department who have fraudulently availed the benefits of the scholarship scheme.

“The police said that they have filed an FIR naming the five officials. However when the permission was sought, the government gave the go-ahead against only one of the officials arguing that they are hearing the person whose names have been mentioned in the FIR,” Pant said.

The court however held that the Prevention of Corruption Act under which the FIR has been filed does not say that the government should hear the accused when the permission for prosecution is sought by police officials. “The court therefore said that such a delay is curious and the secretary should take a decision by the next date of hearing,” Pant said.

Title: Rajasthan finalises borders of 6 civic bodies in 3 cities
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

File photo of Jaipur Municipal Corporation building

JAIPUR : The local self government department has finalised the boundaries of 250 wards falling under Jaipur Heritage Municipal Corporation and Greater Jaipur Municipal Corporation paving the way for elections to the local bodies this year.

A final notification in this regard was issued on Monday. The notification dated January 6 reads, “In exercise of powers conferred under Sections 6 and 10 of the Rajasthan Municipalities Act 2009 and Rule 3 of Rajasthan Municipalities (election) Rules 1994, the chief municipal officer (CMO) , municipal corporation Jaipur, Heritage, has sent the draft order of the ward formation and objections received on draft order with his comments regarding municipal corporation Jaipur heritage.”

It was informed that after considering objections on the draft order of the ward formation, the state government agreed with comments of the chief municipal officer (CMO) and approved the draft order of ward formation as proposed by the CMO.

Notification for two other cities Jodhpur and Kota, which will also have two municipal corporations and two mayors, was also issued by the department.

The exercise of delimitation was carried on in three cities after the state government on October 18, 2019 announced that Jaipur, Jodhpur and Kota will each have two municipal corporations and two mayors. The number of wards in three cities were also increased by the government.

In Jaipur, the number of wards increased from 150 to 250 and in Jodhupur from 100 to 160. In Kota , the number of wards were increased from 100 to 150.

The government reasoned that since three cities have a population of over 10 lakh each, these will be divided into two corporations.

After the notification, it is assumed that dates for the municipal elections in the six urban local bodies of three cities will be announced soon. An official informed, “Earlier, the municipal elections in these ULBs were scheduled in November 2019. However, it was postpond after the state government’s announcement. Now the elections are expected in May.”

Title: Pune: Customer’s bag stolen from plush mall on Nagar Road
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A travel bag containing valuables collectively worth Rs17,210 of an outstation customer was stolen from the baggage room of Phoenix Market City on Ahmednagar road between 6.30pm and 8pm on December 30.

The customer could not register a complaint because he was in a hurry to board a flight. The mall security officer, Ganesh Kamble (35), lodged an FIR on his behalf with the Airport police on January 4 after receiving the list of the stolen articles.

Police said the customer had visited the mall for shopping and kept his bag in the luggage room on the ground floor. The burglar broke the lock of the luggage room door with a sharp object, stole the bag and fled. The theft came to light after the room in-charge found the lock broken. The mall authorities then tallied the number of luggage pieces kept in the room and found that a bag was stolen, the police said.

Senior inspector Gajanan Pawar from the Airport police said on Monday, “The burglar was seen walking fearlessly in the CCTV footage of the mall. We suspect that he had conducted a recce earlier. We are in the process of establishing his identity. We shall also question the ex-employees of the mall.”

A spokesperson from the mall said, “The luggage room is in the service area of the ground floor. It is a secured place under the surveillance of CCTV cameras and opened only for keeping and removing luggage. The cameras have captured images of the man (in mid-20s) breaking the lock, stealing the first bag from the rack and walking out. The man was sporting a cap. He was seen loitering in the mall. The bag contained a speaker, blue tooth, hard disc, clothes and hotel bills, among other articles.”

The spokesperson said, “The man walked into the mall from the south-facing Ahmednagar road side. He walked out through the north side on the High Capacity Mass Transit Route. We have tracked his movements up to Vimannagar Chowk. He may have fled in the direction of Kharadi or Wagholi. We suspect that the man was aware of the place or was an ex-employee.”

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Over 2 lakh first-time voters to exercise franchise, Matiala has maximum at 7,000
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: When Delhi last voted in the assembly elections in 2015, the number of first time voters—those in the age group of 18 to 19—was 1.7 lakh. In the upcoming February elections, more than 2 lakh first-time voters will be eligible to exercise their franchise. Since the last assembly elections, the total number of voters has gone up by 16 lakh.In 2015, first-time voters comprised 1.3% of the total electorate. Their percentage this time has gone up slightly to 1.4% (2,08,883 voters).Matiala constituency, which has the largest electorate of 4.1 lakh voters, also has the highest number of first-time voters—7,184.Interestingly, out of the five constituencies with highest number of first- time voters, three, including Matiala are in outer Delhi, with the other two being Burari (5,616) and Bawana (4,615). The constituency with second highest number of young voters is Vikaspuri (6,153) and at fifth position is Badarpur (4,607) in Delhi’s southern fringe.Another welcome improvement in Delhi’s voter profile since the last assembly elections is the gender ratio of voters. While in January 2015, the number of women voters for every 1,000 male voters was 802, the figure has gone up to 824 now. Tilak Nagar constituency has taken the lead with a gender ratio of 951, while Shakur Basti is second at 943. Tughlaqabad had the lowest gender ratio of 638 in 2015 but this time it is Okhla that is at the bottom with a gender ratio of 677. Tughlaqabad is at the second lowest point with a gender ratio of 680, a big improvement from 2015 figures.The top four constituencies when it comes to gender ratio are in west and north Delhi—Tilak Nagar, Shakur Basti, Rohini (920) and Rajouri Garden (911). East Delhi’s Krishna Nagar (911) is at the fifth position. All the five constituencies with the lowest gender ratios are in south Delhi— Okhla, Tughlaqabad, Delhi Cantt (712), Sangam Vihar (726) and Badarpur (731).With Matiala topping the list of constituencies with largest electorate, the other top four are Vikaspuri (3.9 lakh), Burari (3.5 lakh), Okhla (3.3 lakh) and Badarpur (3.1 lakh). Chandni Chowk, with an electorate of 1.2 lakh, remains the constituency with the smallest electorate, with Matia Mahal and Delhi Cantt with just slightly higher number and Ballimaran and New Delhi with electorate of about 1.4 lakh each. While it is the third in the list of constituencies with smallest electorate, Delhi Cantt tops the chart when it comes to electors to population ratio with a whopping figure of 96.1%. The New Delhi constituency, located not very far from Delhi Cantt, has the lowest electors to population ratio of 46.7%.
