Title: Holy Faith, Alfa to crumble in a gap of 5 minutes
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kochi: Of the four illegal apartment complexes in Maradu, which are set to be razed using controlled explosion , Holy Faith H2O and Alfa Serene will be demolished within a gap of five minutes. H2O will be demolished at 11am and Alfa Serene at 11.05am on January 11.

The entire exclusion zone will be no-flying zone during the blasting. Any unauthorized drones flying in the area would be taken down. Entry to the water bodies around the four buildings will also be prohibited.

City police commissioner Vijay Sakhare said a detailed contingency plan is ready for exclusion zone of 200m radius of the four buildings. Traffic movement on major roads will be stopped for 10 minutes during the implosion . Small roads in the exclusion zone will also be blocked.

Besides police personnel, fire force and medical team will be deployed in the area. “Close to 500 police personnel will be deployed outside the boundary of 200m radius of the sites. Evacuation of the residents will be completed by 9am and the roads in the area will be blocked. Later, police will search all houses to ensure that nobody is left behind. There would be some traffic diversion and vehicular movement on the main road will be blocked for 10 minutes. Anyone can witness the event from outside the exclusion zone. We will manage traffic and crowd as well,” Sakhare said.

The commissioner said that electricity in the area will be disconnected during the process. “Once we ensure all these aspects, we can carry out the work safely. Possibility of any untoward incident during the blasting is very rare. For controlling traffic on backwaters, we will deploy marine enforcement as well. No electronic device will be allowed inside the exclusion zone,” he added.

On Saturday, eight fire tenders will be deployed outside the exclusion zone. On the second day, four fire tenders will be deployed for each building. After the fourth siren is sounded, they will move to the spot and pump water to the debris to control dust and heat.

Meanwhile, filling of holes with explosives at Holy Faith H2O was completed on Sunday morning and the experts moved to Jains Coral Cove for the work. Following the stuffing of explosives, police security around the building has been strengthened.

Maradu municipality has issued an advisory to people living near Alfa Serene asking them to take precautionary measures while leaving for safe places before the implosion.

There will be three pick-up points for residents living near Holy Faith H2O and Jains Coral Cove to board buses arranged by the district administration to move to Sacred Heart College in Thevara on Saturday. Residents in 200m radius of Jains Coral Cove and Golden Kayaloram will be shifted to Kerala University of Fisheries and Ocean Studies in Panangad on Sunday.

Officials of the fire force, police and medical team will be stationed in the control room at Maradu municipality office on the first day of implosion. On the second day, the control room will be set up at an unused building near the highway.

Four medical teams will be deployed near the area during implosion. The team comprises a doctor, nurse and attender. They will be positioned in an ambulance which will have first-aid and basic life support facilities.

Title: Samant report may not be tabled
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaipur: Even as the Samant committee report was submitted to the state government in August last year, no decision has yet been taken on it as it is still under examination. Moreover, looking at the financial crunch, the government may not present it in the state assembly during the budget session, scheduled to be held in February, according to sources.

The committee was set up by the previous BJP government to examine and implement the recommendations of the 7th Pay Commission and to iron out the pay anomalies in the salaries of the state government employees.

The state government employee unions (including ministerial, roadways, lab technicians and other employees) were hoping that the report will be in favour of them. The employee unions had demanded that the levels 5, 6, 7 (three levels created under 7th Pay Commission) must be merged under the grade pay 2,400 and levels 8 and 9 must be clubbed under the grade pay 2,800.

A finance department official had earlier said it was difficult to implement one of the main demands of the government employee unions, who wanted that under the grade pay 2,400 the pay levels 5, 6, 7 must be merged and the levels 8 and 9 to be clubbed under the grade pay 2,800.

"It is difficult to implement it (the merger of pay levels). The government took a conscious decision to create so many levels under the 7th pay commission, which was implemented in the recent past (in 2017). Why will it reconsider its decision in just less than two years? There is no reason to merge these levels," the official had said.

The committee had submitted the report with its recommendations for revising and fixing pay level, assessment of financial burden on the government and examine various allowances given to the employees.

The state government had set up a committee headed by a retired IAS officer D C Samant in 2017 to examine and implement the recommendations of the 7th Pay Commission for state government employees. Two retired officers of Rajasthan account service D K Mittal and M P Dixit were the members of the committee.

Title: Sea of devotees streams through Paramapatha Vaasal
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Trichy: The most auspicious event of the 21-day Vaikunda Ekadasi festival of Arulmigu Ranganathaswamy temple at Srirangam, the opening of Paramapatha Vaasal and the subsequent traversal of lord Namperumal, was celebrated with religious fervor in the early hours of Monday. Thousands of people were present inside and outside the temple complex to witness the auspicious happening as well as to pass through the Paramapatha Vaasal also known as Sorgavaasal (a gateway to heaven).

Arulmigu Ranganathaswamy temple, located between the Kollidam and the Cauvery, is revered as Boologa Vaikundam (heaven on earth) and is the foremost of all Divya Desam temples in Vaishnavite belief. Every year, during the Tamil month of Margazhi (December-January), Vaikunda Ekadasi is celebrated for about 21 days in the pattern of Pagal Pathu (daytime celebrations for 10 days) and Raa Pathu (night time celebrations for 10 days). On the final day of Pagal Paththu festivities, lord Namperumal appears in Mohini alangaaram for devotees followed by the beginning of Raa Paththu festivities that mark lord Namperumal being taken out in a procession from the sanctum sanctorum to exit through the Paramapatha Vaasal.

Meanwhile, as the first day of Raa Paththu that fell on Monday, Namperumal came out of his sanctum sanctorum by around 3.30 am. After passing through Rajamahendiran Thirusuttru, Naazhi Kettan gateway, Kulasekaran Suttru corridors all decked with thousands of devotees, lord Namperumal reached Vraja Nadhi Mandapam by around 4.30 am where special prayers were performed by senior priests.

As the clock struck 4.45 am, the Paramapatha Vaasal was opened after a period of one year. Subsequently, lord Namperumal wearing the gem-studded armour passed through the gateway amidst the Ranga Ranga and Govinda Govinda chants from a sea of devotees. “We believe that passing through the Paramapatha Vaasal would wash away the sins of our past. It was a divine experience to cherish,” C S Baskaran, a devotee from Salem said. After the holy exit through Sorgavaasal, Namperumal was worshipped by thousands of devotes near the Thousand pillar hall. Despite local holiday in Trichy district, the footfall compared to the past few years estimated between 1.5 lakh to 2 lakh on Monday was among the lowest in the recent years. Reopening of schools across Tamil Nadu after the half-yearly holiday and the auspicious event falling on a weekday were cited as the reasons for the dip in the footfall. Vaikunta Ekadasi festival that commenced with the conduct of Thirunedunthantakam ritual on December 26 is scheduled to conclude with the Nammalvar Motcham on January 16 at Srirangam.

Title: Flyers fume as GoAir flights continue to be delayed
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bengaluru: Two weeks on, GoAir passengers continue to have their travel plans disrupted, thanks to the low-cost carrier’s last-minute delays and cancellations. On Monday, 13 GoAir flights scheduled to depart from or arrive at Kempegowda International Airport were delayed.

While delays and cancellations have been reported across the airline ’s countrywide network, the most-affected ones have been in Bengaluru, Pune, Delhi, Hyderabad and Mumbai.

The flights delayed on Monday include Bengaluru-bound G8 273 from Patna, G8 807 from Jaipur, G8 404 from Varanasi, G8 378 from Patna, G8 286 from Goa, G8 383 from Mumbai, G8 112 and G8 124 from Delhi. Flights departing from Bangalore that were delayed include G8 119 to Delhi, G8 320 to Mumbai, G8 274 to Ranchi, G8 294 and G8 374 to Hyderabad.

Passengers claimed the airline sent an intimation about the delay less than an hour before scheduled departure. Departure time of several flights was changed multiple times by the airline and some passengers said they were issued multiple boarding passes by the airline.

GoAir did not comment on the delays. The emails sent by the airlines said: “We apologise for the inconvenience caused. These changes are due to issues beyond our control.”

BOX

Daily flight to Agra from March 5

Taj Mahal will soon be just one flight way for Bengalureans. Beginning March 5, the city will get its first direct flight to Agra. Indigo Airlines on Monday said it will launch a daily service between Bengaluru and Agra under the regional connectivity scheme (RCS). Flight 6E 5916 will leave Bengaluru at 11.35am and reach Agra at 2.10pm. The return flight, 6E 5917, will leave Agra at 2.40pm and arrive in Bengaluru at 5.05pm.

Title: Alwar hospital doing well without help
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

ALWAR: A government hospital is functioning in Alwar without recognition of the state government since 2003.

In government records, it is just a ward of government-run Rajiv Gandhi Hospital but it is operational as Geetanand Child Hospital. The matter has come to light following deaths of children in Kota’s JK Lon Hospital hit the headlines.

According to government records, it is a 23-bed paediatric ward with 18 healthcare staff. But, in reality it has 73 beds with Facility-Based Newborn Care (FBNC) unit. The hospital has an emergency and outdoor unit. It is a full-fledge hospital functional without state government’s recognition.

For the past 16 years, the residents of the area have been demanding to convert the ward into a hospital in government records, but all efforts went in vain.

Geetanand Child Hospital principal medical officer Dr Sunil Chouhan has taken up the issue and wrote to Congress minister Tikaram Julie for granting it hospital recognition.

Julie has assured him of taking measures in this direction. He said in the past, steps were taken for government recognition for the hospital, but now efforts will be intensified for improving facilities in the hospital.

Nurisng association’s district head Pushpraj Sharma said it was wrong as per norms, but they were providing treatment to patients just because of humanity as the hospital is functioning against norms.

Title: Day of thinking, accompanied by music
Content:
Ustad Amjad Ali Khan

AHMEDABAD: The recital of T M Krishna had swept many young Amdavadis into the rumble, boom, and clatter of conversations. Krishna — a Carnatic vocalist — was making only his first Saptak appearance. Perhaps young people were familiar with him as a persistent questioner, the Socrates from the South. TOI questioned Krishna about this section of his following.“It is wonderful that young people want to listen to questioning,” Krishna told TOI. “All I do is ask difficult questions of myself…I ask what we are. We are at a moment in political history when all of us have to learn a lot from young people.”In universities across the world, young people are questioning the Cannon, intellectual artefacts deemed to be classics. “The word ‘classical’ is deeply problematic,” Krishna said. “Classical is determined by people of the higher echelons of society. Usually, race, caste, and ethnicity are factors that seem to define what is classical.”Socrates is supposed to have said: “The unexamined life is not worth living.” On Sunday, Day 5 of Saptak, ‘culture’ too may have been examined.The final baithak of Day 5 featured the sarod legend Ustad Amjad Ali Khan. Khan-sahab draws throngs of devotees every year not only because of his stature in the Hindustani pantheon but also because of his guru-like generosity in annotating musical complexities.For instance, on Sunday, Khan-sahab dwelt on a Kafi nuance before his second presentation. The knowledgeable felt enlightened and the fledgling rasikas were thrilled just to hear him speak. Khan-sahab had advice for learners too. “It’s my suggestion to students to not blindly imitate legendary musicians,” he told TOI. “They must collect and learn compositions.”After the performance, scores of college-age people gathered around Khan-sahab. It was well past 1am. But he indulged the selfie seekers, who evidently had found something within their selves stirred because of his music.Pandit Shivkumar Sharma’s message to rasikas“I couldn’t come to Saptak this year,” Pandit Shivkumar Sharma, the santoor icon, told TOI. “I will definitely perform next year.” His programme had been scheduled on Monday. However, panditji’s principal tenet was emphasized in Ahmedabad by his disciple Takahiro Arai, who rendered Hamsadhvani on January 2. “Guruji always says that to be a good musician one must be a good human,” Arai told TOI.

Title: Delhi: Number of voters up by over 3 lakh since 2019 polls
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: More than 1.46 crore people will cast their votes to elect the seventh legislative assembly of the National Capital Territory of Delhi on February 8.

Chief electoral officer (CEO) of Delhi Ranbir Singh said the final electoral roll, as on January 1, 2020, was published on Monday. According to it, Delhi has 1,46,92,136 voters — 80,55,686 men, 66,35,635 women and 815 people belonging to the third gender.

The Delhi election office has disposed of all applications received till December 16 during the month-long summary revision. “But that does not mean that those filling up the forms now won’t be eligible to cast their votes in the upcoming assembly polls. All applications received till the last date of filing of nominations (January 18) will be included in the supplementary list to ensure that no eligible voter is left out of the election process,” Singh said.

He also said every voter should check the final electoral roll, which is available online and at the voter registration centre in each constituency, to ensure that his name exists on the roll.

According to the data, 3,64,678 more people are eligible to cast their votes this time compared with the 2019 Lok Sabha polls. Last May, Delhi had 1,43,27,458 registered voters.

In comparison with the last assembly polls in 2015, the voter count has increased by over 16 lakh. The gender ratio of voters has also improved. While in January 2015, the number of women for every 1,000 male voters was 802, the figure has gone up to 824. Tilak Nagar constituency has the highest gender ratio of 951, while Okhla has the lowest at 677.

During the summary revision exercise, which started with the publication of the draft roll, 2,47,950 voters were added and 60,848 deleted, registering a net increase of 1,87,102 electors, the CEO said. The names of over 12 lakh voters, which could not be verified during an elector verification programme carried out in last September-October, have been kept in a separate list. “These voters could not be verified during our door-to-door verification drive. We will keep special focus on them if they turn up to cast votes,” Singh said.

A detailed exercise of rationalising polling stations was also carried out to decongest the existing ones and merge those having inadequate number of voters. “As a result, the number of polling stations has decreased from 13,816 to 13,750 and that of polling locations from 2,700 to 2,689. This means the requirement of manpower will be less to conduct the polls,” said an election official.

The voter’s slip given to each electorate by the district electoral officers will have a QR code, which will be scanned by polling officials at a helpdesk as soon as the voter enters the polling station, said an official. “A voter’s entry and exit will be recorded in a database through an app. This way, we will know how many voters have exercised their franchise,” Singh said.

Before the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, AAP, the ruling party in Delhi, had alleged deletion of names belonging to various communities on the behest of BJP. Singh said no such complaint had been received from any political party this time.

Title: Police ensure smooth conduct of Vaikunda Ekadasi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Trichy: Though there was a dip in the footfall of devotees on the grand day of Vaikunda Ekadasi on Monday compared to the previous years, rigid crowd management system enforced by police helped the event pass smoothly. Meanwhile, identity cards issued to journalists and mediapersons by the public relationship office (PRO) of Trichy district collectorate was misused by a section of influential people who were not actually the representatives of media houses.

The procession of Lord Namperumal from sanctum sanctorum to Paramapatha Vaasal via Santhanu mandapam, Rajamahendiran Thirusuttru, Naazhi Kettan gateway and Kulasekaran Suttru involves risky manoeuvre owing to the crowd that trails the processional deity. Devotees, including the VVIPs and their families unwilling to wait for their turns, compete with each to get a close glimpse of the deity and often end up in minor skirmishes with police. However, this Vaikunda Ekadasi, 4,000 police personnel, majority of which were deployed inside the temple corridors, had managed to make the event pass without much trouble. The Naazhi Kettan gateway, Kulasekaran Suttru corridor and Paramapatha Vaasal gateway were manned with adequate policemen armed with ropes and public announcement system.

“Rigid crowd control mechanism is needed to streamline the crowd. As the city police accepted our demand to permit the local people to worship Namperumal via the Vellai gopuram after 5 am on Monday, the Srirangam residents feel contented,” B Hemanathan, a resident of Srirangam, said. Meanwhile, a section of devotees was upset over the preferential treatments given to some people to bypass the queue. People who were neither journalists nor any representative of media houses were also issued media passes and they moved along with the journalists to skip the queue and reach Rajamahendiran Thirusuttru. Owing to this, huge crowd occupied the corridors of the temple during the time of the procession.

Title: Rajasthan: Rs 30 crore Hadauti child health centre still in cold storage
Content:
Government’s ignorance towards Kota’s J K Lon Hospital was one of the reasons for the deaths of children

JAIPUR: The state government’s ignorance towards Kota’s J K Lon Hospital was one of the reasons for the deaths of children.Hadauti Institute of Child Health was planned there in 2017 at a cost of Rs 30 crore and a meeting was even held under then health minister Kali Charan Saraf. But all that remained on papers. The state government knew at the time that paediatric treatment facilities needed expansion, but nothing was done to make the centre a reality.A copy of the proposal prepared by department of paediatrics, J K Lon Hospital, sent to principal and controller of Government Medical College Kota, is in the possession of TOI. The subject of the proposal mentioned that it had been prepared in reference of the minutes of meeting of health minister as per the instruction of health minister plan for expansion of paediatric services in Kota.The proposal was prepared keeping in mind the paediatric population of Kota, Baran, Jhalawar and Bundi. “There were plans to set up the Hadauti Institute of Child Health with 300 bed capacity. The proposal was sent to the government, but budget was not allocated. There is no progress since then,” said Dr Vijay Sardana, principal and controller, Government Medical College, Kota.The proposal says there was a requirement of a new building and equipment. The proposal stated that the paediatric numbers accounted for 45% of the total population, which was around 20 lakh in 2017.According to the proposal, there was a requirement of 528 beds as per the norms of the centre to cater to 20 lakh kids of Hadauti region, which comprises Kota, Bundi, Baran and Jhalawar. Since, the region had 170 bed capacity, the proposal of adding 300 beds was sent to the government, but all efforts went in vain as no budget was allocated for the project.

Title: PWD hits back after min’s barb
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaipur: A day after health minister Raghu Sharma took a dig at PWD, headed by deputy CM Sachin Pilot, for delay in the renovation work at JK Lon Hospital, the department on Monday hit back and blamed the medical education department for not releasing the required budget for the construction on time.

Executive engineer, PWD, Virender Kumar Porwar through an official release on Monday, stated, “On the request of J K Lon hospital, Kota, we had given an estimate of Rs 10 lakh for repair, restoration and maintenance work of the hospital on July 23, 2019. This estimate was sent to medical education department for the final approval. On January 1, 2020 we got approval for the same and thus we have initiated the tender process in this regard.”

He claimed that till December 30, 2019 PWD did not get any budget for the repair and restoration work of the hospital. “However, on December, 31, 2019 the department(PWD) got a budget allocation of Rs 99,500 for repair work and it is under progress,” he added.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: BJP targets power at all 3 levels
Content:
Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: With the power of “triple engine” — governments at the Centre, state and municipal levels — BJP will take Delhi to new heights of development, Union minister Prakash Javadekar said on Monday.He added that with BJP forming the government, Delhi would get rid of Kejriwal-led dispensation that had been a big “obstruction” in the city’s development. Talking to reporters with Delhi BJP president Manoj Tiwari , Javadekar, who is Delhi BJP’s in charge for the assembly polls, attacked Kejriwal, saying his “lies” were exposed and people have seen his “real face”.“Kejriwal neither allowed expansion of Delhi Metro nor let the Centre pay Rs6,000 annually to the city’s farmers. The AAP government did not allow Aayushman Bharat and Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana to be implemented in Delhi and deprived people of their benefits,” Javadekar said, adding that, “The false claims and excuses of Kejriwal will not work now as the AAP government has completely failed.”BJP has launched an intensive campaign with senior party functionaries holding regular public meetings across the city to drum up support. Apart from highlighting various the central government’s schemes and initiatives, it will also try to corner the ruling AAP on local issues.Meanwhile, Tiwari claimed that the AAP government failed to deliver on most promises it made before the 2015 polls. “It cheated people in the name of free power, water and Wi-Fi. When people raised questions, he tried to mislead them by making new announcements. This government compelled people to drink poisonous water and breathe toxic air,” he alleged.BJP faces a tough task of holding up to its vote share of 57% it got in the Lok Sabha elections in May last year. With the party leadership making it clear that national issues such as Citizenship Amendment Act will be key in the upcoming polls, the party is also banking heavily on the Centre’s decision to give ownership rights to people in unauthorised colonies and pucaa houses to slum dwellers.While Delhi Development Authority has started a survey to ascertain the number of people living in the city’s slums, BJP has started registering people for pucca houses. About 20 lakh people are estimated to be residing in the city’s 675 slums, which comprise a huge vote bank for parties.

This story is from January 7, 2020

Prakash Javadekar

NEW DELHI: With the power of “triple engine” — governments at the Centre, state and municipal levels — BJP will take Delhi to new heights of development, Union minister Prakash Javadekar said on Monday.

He added that with BJP forming the government, Delhi would get rid of Kejriwal-led dispensation that had been a big “obstruction” in the city’s development. Talking to reporters with Delhi BJP president Manoj Tiwari , Javadekar, who is Delhi BJP’s in charge for the assembly polls, attacked Kejriwal, saying his “lies” were exposed and people have seen his “real face”.

“Kejriwal neither allowed expansion of Delhi Metro nor let the Centre pay Rs6,000 annually to the city’s farmers. The AAP government did not allow Aayushman Bharat and Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana to be implemented in Delhi and deprived people of their benefits,” Javadekar said, adding that, “The false claims and excuses of Kejriwal will not work now as the AAP government has completely failed.”

BJP has launched an intensive campaign with senior party functionaries holding regular public meetings across the city to drum up support. Apart from highlighting various the central government’s schemes and initiatives, it will also try to corner the ruling AAP on local issues.

Title: Citizens protest against JNU violence
Content:
The protesters on the footpath outside the IIM old campus

Ahmedabad: One day after masked goons went on a rampage inside the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus in New Delhi injuring 18 students and professors, scores of people in Ahmedabad gathered outside the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIM-A) old campus to condemn the violence and its perpetrators. On Monday, as the clock struck 5.15pm, people of all ages began gathering on the footpath outside the B-school, some holding placards others in silence.Protesters included students and professors from premier institutes in the city such as IIM-A, Ahmedabad University, Cept University, Gujarat Law Society (GLS), Gujarat University, Gujarat Vidyapith and MICA, among others.Workers of the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) gathered opposite the protesters, shouting slogans against leftist students.Police detained three ABVP workers when they became aggressive and got into a scuffle with police.Inspector H M Vyas of Gujarat University police said, “We detained the ABVP city general secretary Nirav Pandya, ABVP Gujarat University campus in-charge Divyapalsinh Solanki and a worker, Rishit Patel, from the IIM-A.”ABVP spokesperson Samarth Bhatt said, “The three were arrested when they were protesting against left-affiliated students’ wings. We have been portrayed as the accused by the left parties and their students wings.”Vadgam MLA Jignesh Mevani and activists Nirjhari Sinha, Mallika Sarabhai and Shamshad Pathan, among others were also part of the protest.Leaders, academicians and students said the violence at JNU was deplorable and raised concerns about the safety of students on campuses in Ahmedabad as well. “If my sister gets admission to JNU today, I will be scared, looking at the state of affairs. I strongly condemn what happened there. This can come down to Gujarat. CM Rupani should assure the student community of Gujarat that preventive measures will be taken to ensure such incidents do not take place,” said Mevani. “What happened in JNU was horrific. Such violence has to stop. In fact, in this case, students have given hope at a time when many of us are feeling dejected economically, socially and politically,” said Reetika Khera, a professor at IIM-A.Another IIM-A faculty member, on condition of anonymity, said, “Violence against students is problematic and it raises concerns and a sense of fear that if it happens in Delhi today, it may happen on my campus tomorrow. I fully support the students of JNU and condemn the attack.”Calling the situation in the universities of Gujarat undemocratic, sociologist Manishi Jani, said, “For the past four years, there have been no elections to the student senate of Gujarat University. The democratic process has crumbled and there are no political discussions whatsoever among students. Moreover, commercialization of education has further diluted the democratic process, because education has become unaffordable for people.”IIM-A director expresses solidarityIIM-Ahmedabad (IIM-A) director Professor Errol D’Souza took to Twitter on Monday morning to condemn attack on Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) on Sunday. Prof D’Souza, who obtained his PhD from JNU, termed the attack ‘a very low point in our post-independence history.’ The tweet received 23 comments, 521 retweets and 1,100 likes till Monday evening, many by former IIM-A students, JNU students, economists and professionals.

Title: Vision group members bat for online medical consultation
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bengaluru: The first meeting of Karnataka’s vision group for healthcare, research and innovation on Monday witnessed heated discussions on a range of medical issues, including the need for tele-medical consultations.

The 20-member committee set up by the government is headed by Dr Devi Shetty, chairman, Narayana Hrudayalaya.

“India has over 70 million diabetics and only 600 diabetologists. Why should a patient meet a doctor for every consultation when it can be done over the phone? When we are allowing a 10-year-old juvenile diabetic patient to take insulin on his/her own, why does the government think online consultation cannot be legal,” asked Dr Shetty. He said in the time of shortage of doctors, technology must be used to meet people’s medical needs.

Dr Sunita Maheshwari, paediatric cardiologist and a member of group, said the Centre has invited tenders for tele-medical consultation, but the Karnataka government says it is ‘not permitted’. “Online consultation is emerging as the norm all over the world. In the West, insurance companies mandate online consultation of patients after discharge to stress on follow up,” she said.

Responding to this, Dr H Veerabhadraiah, president, Karnataka Medical Council, said online medical consultations are not permitted in the state. “The error of margin is more in online consultation, without physical examination,” he pointed out. The doctor is a member of the vision group.

However after much debate, he asked the members to submit a proposal, stressing the need and benefits of online consultations. “The matter will be looked into once the proposal is received by KMC,” he said.

Medical education minister CN Ashwath Narayan said vision group meetings will be held frequently to improve public health service delivery in the state. Five members did not attend the session.

Title: BJP state president praises Sachin Pilot for playing opposition role
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Sachin Pilot

JAIPUR: Congress state chief and deputy CM Sachin Pilot has been playing the role of opposition within the ruling party. But his role as a critic of his own government got appreciation from an unlikely quarter. None other than BJP state president Satish Poonia has lauded Pilot for his role.

Pilot had a few days ago made a statement putting his government in the dock for the death of infants at J K Lon Hospital in Kota.

The state government has been taking cover for the deaths comparing the mortality figures of the previous regime. However, Pilot said such a comparison was uncalled for and the government should fix accountability.

Heaping praise on Pilot, Poonia said, “Pilot is a responsible people’s representative. Iit is a mature response from the ruling party chief.” the deputy CM had said that the state government could not wash its hands off by blaming the previous government after being in power for more than a year.

Poonia said, “I fully endorse the statement of Pilot that accountability in the government had to be fixed for the death of infants in such large numbers.”

The deputy chief minister who also holds the post of the party chief for the last six years in the state has been doing his task quite well. He had earlier put the chief minister and the government on the backfoot by taking to task the government for the poor law and order, incidentally being handled by the chief minister himself.

Pilot has not hesitated to attack his own government’s decision to elect a non-contested candidate to the post of chairperson of civic bodies which the government was forced to backtrack following the intervention of the party central leadership.

According to political experts, Sachin is trying to keep some distance from the government after the chief minister attempted to sideline him in the government. Though technically he is the second in command by virtue of being the deputy chief minister, the chief minister has been projecting PHED minister Dr BD Kalla as his de facto second. He has been made the chairman of almost all cabinet committees.

Title: Masked brutality unmasked by their scars
Content: NEW DELHI: Students with bandaged heads , limbs in plaster casts and blood-stained clothes were visible signs of the brutality of the violence unleashed by masked miscreants, unidentified as yet, in Jawaharlal Nehru University on Sunday. Meeting journalists on Monday, they recalled the assault they faced, with a visually impaired student sharing that even he wasn’t spared. Some students claimed to have jumped from the second floor of their hostel to escape the hostile mob.Read also: Goons ran riot as cops awaited JNU nodAishe Ghosh, president of JNU Students’ Union, appeared at the press meet with her head in bandages and her hand in a cast. She said that after the peace march organised by JNU Teachers’ Association, she and a friend were having tea when masked intruders began assaulting students and teachers. “I was trying to make my way to my hostel when around 30 men singled me out and surrounded me. Even as I was protesting, someone hit me on my head with an iron rod. I fell down and they thrashed me. I was bleeding profusely before some students came to my aid,” said Ghosh, adding that all her messages to police went unanswered.She said that the ambulance she was in wasn’t allowed to pass the gate. “I had to get out of the ambulance and ask the crowd to clear the way. You can see it was a deliberate attempt to murder me,” the JNUSU president said. Alongside her, Dripta showed her fractured leg and Meithry revealed she had suffered tissue tears on a leg.Visually impaired Surya Prakash, a resident of Sabarmati Hostel, claimed to be in his room, no. 51, when the miscreants barged in. “I told them to leave me alone because I could not see. But they did not listen. My back is badly bruised and there is a swelling on my hand,” said Prakash.Despite her serious injuries, Ghosh appeared defiant. “We will fight it out and every iron rod you hit us with, we will give back with our culture of democratic debate,” she declared on Monday. An MPhil scholar in the School of International Studies, the girl from Durgapur has been at the forefront of several protests in Delhi, including the anti-CAA stir. She is a member of the leftist Students’ Federation of India and was twice the convenor in SIS.In 2019, Ghosh had fought the students’ union poll in September last year as a candidate of the Left Unity, an alliance of leftist student organisations, and beat her rival by 2,313 votes. Popular on the campus for her speeches, Ghosh has been critical of the government on various issues, such as the dilution of the Right to Information Act. She has also fought for changes in the Bill on transgender rights, while accusing the central government of violating human rights in Kashmir.Among those hurt were members of ABVP, alleged by many to be behind Sunday’s violence. Present at a press meet on Monday was Manish Jangid, secretary of ABVP’s JNU unit, and the runner-up to Ghosh in the JNUSU presidential polls. He came with fractured hands. The other ABVP member who suffered injuries were Seshmani Sahu and Shivam Chaurasia. ABVP claimed 11 members were still missing.Jangid charged the leftist student activists with targeting individuals and attacked them around 4pm on Sunday. “They entered my hostel room and broke my laptop, which had my PhD thesis. Who will rewrite it for me?” Jangid claimed. “It is the Left that has been indulging in violence since semester registration began. Even at the hospitals, their national leaders arrived and met them while we were not provided treatment for almost three hours. We were so scared of the violence that some of us slept at the temple in Malviya Nagar.”Jangid also claimed that the Left had implicated them by creating the WhatsApp accounts in which they appeared to be planning the attack on the hostels.

Title: Rajasthan government should allot liquor licences to locals: Industry
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: As the excise department on Monday held a feedback for framing the liquor policy for 2020-21, the industry said there are many irritants that need to be removed if the government wants to attract better interest from investors.

Rajasthan Liquor Welfare Society, which represents the government retailers, said the department should ensure an assured margin of 20-22% to attract better participation. Early this financial year, the assured margins became a boiling issue between the government and the retailers as the latter said because of cess and other hidden charges, their margin was reduced to 10-12%.

Similarly, the association said the government should also remove the requirement of targets for selling liquor. Recently, many restaurants and hotel bars were issued penalty notices for not selling 10% more liquor.

President of the association Nilesh Mewara said that many a time, the shops allotted in a zone get concentrated in a single location and the department should make a rule of keeping them at a distance of 200 metres.

He said the policy should be for three years instead of the current practice of one year. “By the time we settle down for business, it almost consumes six months. The retailers fail to operate at full capacity throughout the year. That’s why three-year policy with renewal premium is a good proposition,” added Mewara.

The industry body wants the department not to impose any additional duty or cess or undertake any price-related decision in the middle of the year that would impact the margin of the retailers.

“The retailers make application based on the existing charges. Any deviation from this in the middle of the year would impact their margins. If the government wants to impose any duty or cess, they should do that well before the application process,” the industry body said.

Currently, the department is issuing licences to even people from other states. But the industry said that licences should be given to locals as there are many unemployed youth in the state.

Similarly, for relocation of shops, the retailers are required to pay 10% of the licence fees. The industry said that when the licence fees were between Rs 3-5 lakh, it used to be 10%. Since the licence fees have increased to Rs 30 lakh, the relocation charge should be 1-2%.

The long-pending demand of the industry has been to extend the closing time of the retail shops. They said that at least in big cities the timings should be relaxed to 10pm.

Title: Kerala: After demolition, it will be a battle against dust
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

In December 2018, the chairman of state-level monitoring committee had directed PCB to monitor the entire demo... Read More

KOCHI: Maradu is all set to witness a compelling spectator event on January 11 and 12 when coordinated implosions bring down the highrises in seconds, but the event has the potential to expose onlookers to hazardous levels of air pollution. Pollution control board (PCB) has made elaborate arrangements for monitoring the air quality and level of sound pollution in areas surrounding the apartment complexes after demolition.

PCB sources said they will treat Holy Faith H20 and two towers of Alfa Serene to be demolished on January 11 as one block and Jains Coral Cove and Golden Kayaloram as another while monitoring.

To contain the dust and threat of flying debris, PCB has directed agencies engaged in demolition to erect 10ft-high boundary walls around the buildings and use enough sprinklers.

“Events like these are nothing less than a calamity. We expect the dust to rise up to a height of 15ft after demolition,” said a senior PCB official. Sprinklers would be deployed around buildings to control dust through suppression.

“We have zeroed in on the south side of the buildings because the wind direction is from north to south. The exact location to install the equipment would be decided after Tuesday’s site visit,” said the official.

To collect data on dust generated after demolition, PCB would be using respirable dust samplers, which are meant for monitoring the total suspended particles (TSP) in ambient air conditions. “We would be monitoring both PM10 and PM2.5 and the data would be collected for a minimum of eight hours,” he said, adding that monitoring would begin at 11am.

PM10 is particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter, while PM2.5 is particulate matter 2.5 micrometers or less in diameter and are considered fine particles. Both PM10 and PM2.5 act as gas due to their small size and are harmful for human body because they can penetrate lungs.

PCB has chosen the south side of Jain Housing and Golden Kayaloram to fix their monitoring equipment considering the wind direction. “In Nettoor, the south side is backwaters and we may have to adjust the site accordingly,” the official said.

Both the chairman and the chief environmental engineer would be present at implosion sites to monitor the process and give directives. “We would also have our surveillance team at the spot. We would publish the data within two days after consultation with the chairman,” the source said.

In December, the chairman of state-level monitoring committee had directed PCB to monitor the entire process without giving room for any complaints on environmental pollution.

Title: 4 from Dahod arrested for house break-ins, remanded in four-day police custody
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nashik: A gang of three has been arrested from Gujarat ’s Dahod district by Nashik rural police for their involvement in number of house break-ins and thefts.

Police have also recovered cash and jewellery worth Rs 3.91 lakh from the suspects — identified as Kantibhai alias Kantgi Tersinghbhai Bhabhore (40), Nana alias Nanu Mandle (27) and Mando alias Tersingh Bhabhor.

Police inspector KK Patil said that large number of house break-ins was being reported under the jurisdiction of the Satana police station.

Patil, part of the rural police’s Local Crime Branch (LCB), said on instructions of superintendent of police Arti Singh they started investigating the case through CCTV footage gathered from spots where the crimes were committed.

“After going through the CCTV footage and other technical data collected by us, we came to the conclusion that the suspects must be from Gujarat which is on the border of Satana taluka,” he said.

“We then sent a team to Jaiswada village in Dahod district. After waiting for three days, the team finally managed to trace the suspects,” he added.

During interrogation the suspects confessed to have committed house break-ins in Satana, Wavi, Nandur Shingote and other parts of the rural district.

“The suspects used to move to different parts of Maharashtra on the pretext of being on pilgrimage and after identifying a closed shop or house, they used to commit the crime,” the officer said, adding that.

While four burglaries were committed in Satana, one each was committed in Wavi (Sinnar taluka) and Deola talukas of the rural district.

On Monday, the suspects were presented before a local court that remanded them in four-day police custody.

Title: Ahmedabad witnessed 45 per cent spike in dengue cases in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The year 2019 was deadly when it came to the bite of the Aedes Ageypti mosquito. The city registered 45% dengue cases in 2019, compared to 2018. Ahmedabad city reported 4,537 cases in 2019, up from 3,135 cases in 2018.

Official data revealed that the number of deaths due to dengue more than tripled to 13 in 2019 from four in 2018. The data released by the AMC’s health department shows that eight of the 13 deaths occurred in October. There were two deaths each in September and August and one in November. Officials said there was a spike in the number of dengue cases begining in August. In the first seven months of the year, just 206 cases were reported. This number was 246 cases in 2018.

Between August and December 2019, there was a 50% increase in the number of cases compared to the same period the previous year, with the city reporting 4,331 cases in 2019, against 2,889 cases in 2018.

“The most dengue cases were reported in October and 62% of the cases in 2019 were reported in just two months, September and October, 2,845 cases of the 4,537 annual total,” a health department official said.

He said the number of dengue cases in November doubled to 804 against 332 cases in November 2018. A recently released study by the Community Medicine Department of BJ Medical College, covering 6,434 dengue cases recorded from 2010 to 2016, revealed that the average incidence rate for dengue in Ahmedabad was 16.3 per lakh people. The study revealed that the incidence rate (26.2) was highest in the 0-14 years age group, followed by 17.3 per in the 15-44 years group.

Title: Why cops ‘supporting’ goons, Asaduddin Owaisi asks PM Modi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi addresses MIM workers at party headquarters

HYDERABAD: Hyderabad MP and AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Monday condemned the attack on JNU students and alleged that people who perpetrated violence had BJP’s tacit support. “Modi Sarkar must answer why cops are siding with goons,” he tweeted.

“I condemn the violent behaviour by the cowards who definitely had support of the ruling party. There is no doubt that they have been given the green signal by the powers that be,” the AIMIM chief said at party headquarters, Darussalam.

Continuing his tirade against NDA government, Owaisi said, “I hope the government rises above party affiliations and arrests the perpetrators, who covered their faces. They might have covered their faces, but their ideology has exposed them,” he said.

“For one and half hours, police did not know what was happening. This is the capital of India, on WhatsApp they mobilise people! What is the cyber cell doing? If some lumpen thugs can do this, what about the people who want to harm the integrity of country?” he asked.

“In solidarity with the brave students of JNU. This cruel attack is meant to ‘punish’ JNU students because they dared to stand up. It’s so bad that even Union ministers are tweeting helplessly. Modi Sarkar must answer why cops are siding with goons,” Owaisi tweeted.

Title: 2 more infants perish in Kota hospital, death count reaches 112 in 37 days
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

India accounts for a quarter of the global burden of neonatal deaths and the causes of such deaths are prevent... Read More

KOTA: Two more infants died in Kota’s JK Lon Hospital on Monday taking the toll to 12 in the first six days of January. In the last 37 days 112 children have died. Another 5-year-old boy suffering from cerebral palsy and undergoing medical treatment here for the last three days also died.

However, the hospital authorities claimed that he had not died in the hospital and termed it as a case of LMA (Left the hospital against medical advice).

Kota’s JK Lon Hospital had hit the headlines in December 2019 when 10 infants were reported dead within 48 hours on December 23 and 24, prompting central and state delegations to visit the hospital. The hospital recorded 100 infants’ deaths in December 2019, while 77 infants’ death in December 2018.

Two newborn babies died in JK Lon Hospital on Monday said Dr Suresh Dulara, superintendent of the hospital.

A three-day-old newborn, suffering from severe birth asphyxia was on ventilator and died during treatment at 1.15am on intervening nights of Sunday and Monday, deputy superintendent, Dr Gopikrishan Sharma said. It is yet to be verified from where the deceased newborn was referred to JK Lon, he added. Another three-day-old infant died between on Monday morning, he said and added that the infant was born in the same hospital and was put on ventilator after he suddenly fell ill. The infant was given mother’s milk in the morning following which he suffered from breathing complications. Dr Sharma added that sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is likely to be the cause of the death.

Clarifying about another five-year-old boy’s death in the hospital on Monday, the deputy superintendent told TOI that the boy was suffering from cerebral palsy since birth and was admitted here three days ago with severe breathing problem and pneumonia. His condition was deteriorating and on Monday he was put on ventilator. The parents, assuming him to be dead, insisted on taking him home. However, he was still breathing. Finally, the parents took him home around 11am and the hospital registered the case as (LMA), he added.

Meanwhile, the family of the five -year-old boy protested outside the hospital alleging negligence by the doctors.

On Monday Dr Jagdish Singh was appointed to one of the posts as professor in paediatric department here.

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: Youth slits throat of ex-lover, kills self
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A man, allegedly enraged over breakup with his lover, slit the woman’s throat and killed her at Karakkonam on Monday.

Anu, 23, barged into the residence of Ashika, 22, and slit her throat. Later, he wounded himself and succumbed to injuries in a hospital.

Vellarada police, which was probing the case, said that both Ashika and Anu were in a relationship and they split around six months ago and the rejection is believed to have provoked Anu to commit the murder.

While Ashika died instantly, Anu was rushed to Karakonam Medical College first and later to Trivandrum Medical College where he succumbed to cut wounds.

The body of Ashika is currently kept at Karakonam Medical College and Anu’s body is at Trivandrum Medical College, which will both be handed over to relatives after postmortem on Tuesday.

According to Vellarada station house officer inspector K Biju, the incident took place around 11:30am on Monday when only Ashika and her grandparents were at home. “Anu, who carried a kitchen knife with him, barged into the house and locked the door from inside, which prevented Ashika’s grandparents from intervening. He slit her throat first and then slit his own throat. When the neighbours broke into the house, they saw both lying in a pool of blood,” the inspector said.

Karakonam ward member R Sujeer said that both Ashika and Anu were in a relationship which turned sour around six months ago and even resulted in a complaint being filed by Ashika’s father at Vellarada police station.

“Parents of both Ashika and Anu had attended the meeting chaired by Vellarada CI, which concluded with Anu assuring that he will not disturb Ashika again. Anu used to work as a conductor in private vehicles while Ashika was doing a beautician course. Both families come from struggling backgrounds and such an unexpected tragedy has put both families in distress,” he said.

Ashika leaves behind father Ajith who works as a painter, mother Seema who is a homemaker and a younger brother.

Anu leaves behind father Mani who is working as a mason, mother Ramani, a tailor, and an elder brother Manu who works in Chennai.

Title: Panchavati police organise street play on traffic awareness, take oath
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nashik: The Panchavati police on Monday organised street plays for the residents of Ramkund and Panchavati areas to educated them about the seriousness of obeying traffic rules.

As part of Maharashtra Police Raising Day celebrations street plays were arranged on the theme of following traffic rules. Passers-by stopped by to watch the plays and appreciated the police and the students of NBT Law College, who enacted the play.

The police said that the aim was to emphasise on the results of neglecting traffic rules, which was portrayed through a street play . They stressed on how one can lose his / her life if the concerned person was not wearing a helmet while riding a two-wheeler. At the same time how speaking on cell-phone while driving could be dangerous. In the end, they also administered the oath of following traffic rules to the people who watched the street play.

A large number of people lose their lives on the city streets. The police said that human error was one of the main reasons for accidents. They said that if simple traffic rules are followed, those driving vehicles on the streets and highways would not only save themselves from accidents but also save other motorists and people on the road. “Many people do not know that if the seat-belt is not put on the protective air-bags do not open up in case of accidents and people could lose their life for such small negligence,” said the officer.

According to the police, this year 176 people lost their lives in road accidents. Apart from this many other people were injured grievously and got paralysed permanently.

Title: Amit Chawda flays govt for infants’ deaths, demands ouster of responsible doctors
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Amit Chawda stages a dharna in Rajkot on Monday

Rajkot: Gujarat Congress president Amit Chawda on Monday held the state government responsible for the deaths of 269 infants at Rajkot Civil Hospital in the past three months.

“The state government spends crores of rupees on building super speciality hospitals, but when it comes to providing basic health facilities to the poor, it has failed miserably,” alleged Chawda.

Chawda along with his supporters staged a dharna at Hospital Chowk and raised slogans against chief minister Vijay Rupani.

Chawda also demanded the resignation of those doctors responsible for the infants’ deaths.

Title: JNU News: Changing the character of JNU as we know it, bit by bit
Content:
A day after the violence, protests continued unabated on the campus

Protest against JNU campus violence live updates.

NEW DELHI: A day after being blindsided by a masked, lathi-wielding mob that spread violence and terror through the campus, Jawaharlal Nehru University is putting the pieces together. Teachers and students have linked hands in a human chain. Leaders of the students’ union, hurt and shaken, are rallying others at the spot where the attack started.Who, exactly, were the attackers shouting slogans of “goli maaro saalon ko” and “Bharat Mata”? How did they get in, and why weren’t they stopped in time? What was the larger motive for the attack, or was it just an expression of hatred? These questions remain unanswered, but the direction is clear.Read also: Goons ran riot as cops awaited JNU nod“They knew whom to target, whose car to vandalise. Specific teachers were attacked, and in the hostels, some students’ rooms were wrecked. Muslims, Kashmiris were singled out,” alleged a student. They tried to forcibly enter the home of a professor, Bikramaditya Kumar Chaudhuri, and threatened his wife while the police refused to come and help, said his colleague BS Butola, who pointed out that the records of who came into the campus on Sunday were now missing. “There was complete connivance between the police, JNU security and the mob,” alleged Nivedita Menon, professor of political science.“It adds to the sense of vulnerability,” said Professor Rajat Datta from School of Social Sciences, who has also studied in JNU. “I have been here for 28 years, and seen many ideological battles, but it has never been expressed in this violent way,” he added.Read also: HCU to AMU to JNU, campuses new battlefield for ideological warBorn in the tumultuous 1960s, JNU has always been a crucible of student idealism and politics. After the Emergency, the JNU students’ union, led by Sitaram Yechury, forced Indira Gandhi to resign as chancellor of the university. It has housed many ideologies and movements: communist, socialist, liberal and anti-caste, regional and, lately, also the Right. They have argued and fought and politicked. A whole set of legislators, including at least two ministers in the Modi government, have roots in JNU. So do civil servants, academics, journalists and executives, because apart from its political activity, its rhetoric and slogans and graffiti, JNU has been a unique academic model that welcomes a diverse set of students from across India. JNU was not about looking up to Oxford or Cambridge or any other “world class university”, as Rakesh Batabyal wrote in his history of JNU — it was about a home-grown democratic modernity, built to nurture Indian minds. Much of our best-known scholarship came from within its interdisciplinary schools, and its intellectuals both followed and broke out of the political and academic currents of their time.Read also: WhatsApp groups used to mobilise crowd under lensBut this is New India, one opposed to the JNU ethos. JNU vice-chancellor, M Jagadish Kumar, has been locked in confrontation with students and faculty since he joined. “Even during the Vajpayee government, JNU saw an an ideological campaign to change its character, but institutional norms were not touched,” Datta added.In 2016, JNU students peacefully marking the hanging of Afzal Guru were embroiled in a sedition case and tarred as “tukde tukde gang”, on the basis of clips later found to be doctored. A section of media has maligned JNU as a hub of anti-nationals, anarchists, moral deviants and freeloaders.The university has also been needled on many fronts, all of which have created uproar. The recent decision to hike fees threatens to change the character of JNU as a truly public university — if implemented, faculty estimates that 28% of the current student body would have to drop out immediately. The exam format has been changed — computerised, in English — and entirely taken out of the faculty’s influence, they worry that it will push out the most marginalised students, for whom JNU was once a ladder of opportunity, and who made JNU what it is.“JNU stands in the way of both Hindu Rashtra and of the possibility that critical thinking can be destroyed,” said Menon. But this time, she felt that the government and administration were betraying their nervousness, as young people around the country showed up in public in large numbers. “JNU won’t back down,” she said.In Video: Delhi: Changing the character of JNU, bit by bit

Title: Kshudiram-Nathuram duel plays out in fascism fight
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kolkata: A rally organised by Jadavpur University ( JU ) students to protest against Sunday’s violence at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) neared flashpoint after it came face to face with a BJP procession near Sulekha crossing on Monday evening.

Police had to resort to a mild lathi-charge to disperse students and BJP workers after both sides breached barricades and nearly came to blows. The JU students claimed that BJP workers hurled stones and bricks at them and claimed that the police action against them was uncalled for. DCP (South Suburban Division) Sudip Sarkar said, “While we were chasing some trouble makers, some students entered the mob. We could not differentiate the students from BJP workers who were burning tyres. We did not lathicharge students.”

BJP denied that its workers incited violence.While some JU students set BJP flags ablaze, the BJP workers set tyres on fire as passers-by scampered in fear. BJP leader and former MP Anupam Hazra said: “We had permission to march till Jadavpur police station. We had intimated the police well in advance. How could they stop us?”

Tension prevailed in the area for nearly an hour till the BJP workers dispersed. The students, however, resorted to a roadblock near the 8B bus stand from around 8.30pm, vowing to stand by those attacked at JNU. The situation may have worsened had a rally by CPM cadres got close to the spot. The CPM workers were also protesting against Sunday’s attack at JNU.

The students’ rally that came face to face with the BJP workers was the fourth march of the day from JU campus. The first one was brought out by SFI, which leads the Arts Faculty Students Union (AFSU). The procession went around the campus before spilling out on Raja S C Mullick Road. Commuters and locals, though inconvenienced, didn’t seem to mind though and waited for nearly 10 minutes till around 2.30 pm till the students re-entered the campus. Kolkata police commissioner Anuj Sharma said, “Police are making all efforts to coperate with students and law-abiding citizens to maintain peace. Senior officers are in the Jadavpur area to help people.”

Holding aloft banners and accusing the BJP of treading a fascist path, the students shouted slogans such as: ‘Tomar booke Nathuram, amar booke Kshudiram (You have Nathuram in your heart, while we think of Kshudiram)’ and ‘Tomar Mukhe Savarkar, Amar Mukhe Ambedkar (You talk of Savarkar while we talk of Ambedkar)’. Apart from students from the arts faculty, there were some from the science streams. “We stand in solidarity with them. Every attempt by the fascist government to destroy the mass students’ movements will now be dealt with equal resistance by us,” said Debraj Debnath, general secretary of the SFI unit at JU.

The second rally of the day was called by all departments of JU and this saw a large turnout. Many carried tambourines and sang songs of protest while going around the campus and then up to the Jadavpur police station. Even members of the Jadavpur University Teachers Association (JUTA) expressed their solidarity with the students. “We plan to form a joint team along with teachers of other institutes and send a delegation to meet JNU students,” said physics teacher Partha Pratim Roy who is the general secretary of JUTA.

The third rally was by the teachers that started from Gandhi Bhavan ended at the 8B bus stand. Students from other institutions stopped by to express solidarity. “Attacks on the student community is not acceptable,” said Raunak Saha, a student of Asutosh College.

Title: BJP, Congress spar over infant deaths
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

GANDHINAGAR: Gujarat Congress demanded the resignation of chief minister Vijay Rupani in the wake of the release of infant death figures in government hospitals across the state, including in the CM’s hometown Rajkot. State government spokesperson and deputy CM Nitin Patel countered Congress’s statements and said that state Congress leaders should also ask Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot to resign. “Instead of politicizing a serious and tragic issue, the Congress should rather ask its Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot to resign,” Patel said.

After visiting Rajkot government hospital, from where one of the highest figures of infant deaths have been reported, Amit Chavda, Gujarat Congress president said on Monday, “The large number of deaths of children in government hospitals has exposed the tall claims of good governance by the BJP . The recent all-India governance index shows Gujarat is among the worst states in health services. CM Vijay Rupani must accept moral responsibility and resign.’’

Paresh Dhanani, leader of opposition (LOP) in the state assembly added, “Gujarat’s health sector itself needs better treatment. Instead of accepting responsibility and taking corrective action, the government is coming up with excuses.”

Title: Pending trial doesn’t rob one of right to passport
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court granted permission to Gulamhussain Shaikh (37) to obtain a new passport with the observation that pending criminal proceedings against a person does not curtail his right to obtain a passport.

The court made the observations about the right of the accused after the state government vehemently opposed Shaikh’s application for permission to obtain a new passport. A metropolitan court had in November 2019 rejected Shaikh’s request for permission to apply for the passport.

Shaikh has been implicated in a copyright violation case, and is facing trial in the metropolitan court. After he was denied permission to get a new passport, which he claimed he needed, Shaikh approached the city sessions court and sought permission with the assertion that the denial of permission for issue of a new passport amounts to violation of his fundamental rights.

The state government continued to oppose Shaikh’s demand. Finally, the government put forth a condition for Shaikh, that he would have to surrender his passport if he was issued a new one. Shaikh agreed to this. The government told the court that it had no objection if Shaikh followed the condition.

The sessions court quashed the metropolitan court’s order and permitted Shaikh to apply for a passport.

Additional sessions judge Sachin Sethi said, “This court is of the considered opinion that though the applicant-accused could not have claimed his visit abroad as a matter of right but issuance of passport is certainly a matter which requires consideration. Apart from that, it is worthwhile to mention here that in any criminal case any person who is accused of any offence is presumed to be innocent until proved guilty, hence mere pendency of a criminal case can be no ground to deny issuance of passport, since presumption of innocence is a human right.”

Title: 2 chain snatchings reported on Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Nashik: Two elderly women were robbed of their gold chains by unidentified suspects in Panchavati and Mumbai Naka areas of the city on Sunday morning.

In the first incident, a 68-year-old woman was targeted at 9.30am by two bike-borne suspects near Tulsi Eye Hospital close under the jurisdiction of the Mumbai Naka police station.

The victim, a resident of General Vaidya Nagar, was near the hospital when the suspects came from behind and snatched her gold chain worth Rs 45,000 before fleeing.

The second incident took place in Chakradhar Nagar area of Panchavati at around 11.15 am. According to police, the 69-year-old woman was standing near the gate of her bungalow and speaking to the neighbours when two bike-borne suspects stopped near the woman on the pretext of asking an address.

“When the elderly woman told them that she was not aware of any such building, the suspect riding pillion snatched her gold chain and escaped on the bike,” a police officer said.

Until December 29, 2019, city police have registered as many as 87 cases of chain snatchings. In 2018, a total of 71 such cases were reported.

Of the total 87 chain snatchings last year, police have detected only 38 cases — detection rate of 54%.

Title: Meticulous planning did the trick for Million March success
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: How did Hyderabadis pull off the Million March on January 4 and managed a huge turnout? While the response was spontaneous with as many as 40 NGOs and three political parties taking an active part, it was meticulous planning that did the trick, claimed the organisers.

Hundreds of volunteers drew a complete map on who would be doing what. And this included asking a few hundred not to join the protest. Their job was to stay away from the rally and clean the premises soon after the conclusion of the rally at Dharna Chowk, Indira Park, at 5pm.

As many as 400 doctors were mobilised for anyone who needed medical help. At different places, 400 advocates were asked to stay put. Nearly 20 ambulances were parked near a hospital at Indira Park. The joint action committee members spoke to private hospitals in advance to immediately admit anyone needing medical care and not insist on advance being paid.

From Bholakpur alone, 3,000 protesters converged at Dharna Chowk. A local leader provided food packets and water bottles to protesters. A doctor, who is also an IT professional, got placards for protesters and also signboards to show where parking lots were. One leader from Mahbubnagar transported a few thousand protesters in 50 buses. This was in addition to buses which came from other districts.

The protesters were strictly given instructions not to come triple riding to the venue. At all the flyovers, volunteers were put on the job of ensuring that no one would stop to take selfies or take a look down at the procession of people below.

Another important precaution was taken to avoid any trouble with political group activists. Sources said the responsibility was given to Dalit organisations and individuals who could speak Telugu well and handle any situation that warranted their interference. “The main focus was on keeping the protest peaceful,” said MBT leader Amjed Ullah Khan. The focus of JAC is now on fighting cases that have reportedly been filed in 22 police stations against JAC convenor Mushtaq Malik.

“Police mentioned Mustaq Malik and others in the cases. That means they will book a huge number of persons to harass them. They also videographed people and their vehicles when they were heading for protest. We will meet the DGP and home minister to drop the cases,” Amjed Ullah Khan said.

Title: ‘Many kids who died in Kota not underweight’
Content:
Majority of the infants who died in December were not underweight (ANI File Photo)

JAIPUR: Contrary to the state government’s claim that infants who died at the Kota hospital were mostly underweight and premature, a report by the hospital shows that a majority of the infants who died in December were not underweight. TOI has a copy of the hospital report.A total of 100 infants died in Kota’s J K Lon Hospital in December last. In January, 12 infants died till Monday, taking the toll from December 1, 2019 till date to 112.After the deaths made national headlines, the state health minister Raghu Sharma had said: “Out of 18 lakh infants born in the state in 2019, one lakh were born in a critical condition. The infants referred to Kota hospital were underweight and pre-term (premature), along with a host of other complications, when they were brought in by their parents.”The hospital report, however, shows that out of 80 deaths in the hospital, between December 1 and December 26, 53 mortalities occurred in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), where neonates (below 28 days) are admitted for intensive care.

Title: JNU attack: CM Ashok Gehlot accuses BJP of ruining varsities
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

A protesting student outside RU being taken away by police on Monday

JAIPUR: Reacting to the attacks on JNU students, chief minister Ashok Gehlot in a tweet late on Monday accused the BJP of ruining universities.

“Condemn the attacks taking place in JNU strongly. Students, teachers have been beaten up, hostels vandalised and no police inside to stop this, which is most shocking. Why police is not doing anything to protect students? BJP’s divisive politics is ruining the universities.#SOSJNU”

Deputy CM Sachin Pilot also chose Twitter to express his anger. “I strongly condemn the violence and vandalism on the JNU campus causing injury to students and damaging property. Such acts are shameful and cowardly, strict action must be taken against the culprits. #SOSJNU.”

Civil society members in Jaipur also held a protest against the attack on JNU students and acts of vandalism by masked persons on Monday. A group under the banner of Aman Pasand (Peace Lovers) gathered at Gandhi Circle holding banners slamming RSS, ABVP and BJP accusing them of ruining the India’s premier university, JNU.

Former head of department, sociology, Rajasthan University, Rajeev Gupta said, “India is in complete grip of fascist forces and it is high time for the civil society to take a stand against them. Today, they are damaging premier universities which are cradle of wisdom. Tomorrow they will attack other institutes of democracy.”

The NSUI, a student wing of Congress party held a protest at Rajasthan University on Monday. During the protest over 12 students were detained when they attempted to jam the JLN Marg by the police and released after some hours.

Title: Come what may, we will support her, say JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh's kin
Content:
Shanti Sinha Aishe’s grandmother

DURGAPUR: Neighbours and friends of JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh rallied around her house in Durgapur on Monday morning and vowed to stand by the family in case there were provocations or attacks on the family.Aishe has emerged as the face of resistance against the brutal attack on students by masked men, who allegedly owed allegiance to ABVP, the students’ wing of BJP.While her parents left for Kolkata on Monday morning (her father Debashis had a pre-scheduled post-operative eye check-up at a city hospital), her grandmother Shanti Sinha spent an anxious day, worrying about Aishe’s condition. The image of her bloodied grand-daughter, which had spread like wildfire across social media within minutes of the attack, had left her shaken.“I cannot believe someone could do this to Aishe, that too in the nation’s capital. She did student politics to fight for the rights of economically weaker students. How can someoene attack her for doing so? I am very worried about her health. I have told my son to fly to Delhi as soon as he can,” she said.Family members, including Aishe’s mother and grandmother, iterated that they wouldn’t put pressue on her to leave JNU. Her mother has demanded the varsity vice-chancellor’s resignation and felt the attack to break the protest on the campus would only make the students more resolute to persist with the movement against fee hike at the university.Debashis’s friend Nepal Dey, who had dropped by to express concern over the incident and pledge support to the family, said he was shocked to learn about the attack and traumatised by the photographs.“Aishe is like daughter to me. I pray she recovers soon. Though the police were mute spectators when the attack was happening, I hope the men who attacked students with sticks and rods are punished,” Dey added.

Title: Video of drowning youth chased by excise team stirs row
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thrissur: As a video of the drowning of a youth chased by the excise department officials at Keezhpallikkara near Peringottukara on social media goes viral, it has stirred up a hornet’s nest.

Some residents in the area attacked the house of the person who captured the video, alleging apathy for not trying to rescue to the person. There are also allegations that the excise officials too did not bother to rescue him.

The youth Karalath Veettil Akshay, 20, of Triprayar had jumped into the river at Keezhpallikkara when excise officials raided the area on Saturday evening. The raids were a sequel to reports that several people were regularly assembling at a house there and indulging in drug abuse and drinking.

The group of people who had assembled there had run off when they saw the approaching excise team. Akshay jumped into the river and his body was recovered only on Sunday. Some in the area alleged that the excise and fire brigade officials were indifferent to the pleas for continued search, which led to the delay in the recovery of the body.

Meanwhile, nearby residents noticed that the custodian of the house, Santhosh, instead of rescuing Akshay, was busy shooting the video while he drowned. Later, Santosh’s house was attacked for which 13 persons have been arrested.

Deputy commissioner of excise P K Sanu said the department has ordered a probe into Akshay’s death. The joint excise commissioner and assistant excise commissioner will be visiting the area as part of the probe. Initially, a case of ‘man missing’ was registered, which has now been converted into a case of ‘unnatural death’, Anthikkad SI Haneesh said. tnn

Title: Rape cases in Rajasthan up 81% in 2019 compared to two years ago
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan witnessed an alarming rise in the number of rape cases registered across the state, reporting an increase of 81.45 per cent in 2019 when compared to 2017. The crime statistics were released by the state police on Monday. Crimes against women increased by nearly 50 per cent in 2019 compared to the previous year.While 3,305 rape cases were lodged in 2017, the number rose and touched 4,335 in 2018. In 2019, the registered rape cases reached 5,997. From 2018 to 2019, crimes against women increased by 49.14 per cent in the state. Apart from rape, complaints of harassment and eve-teasing too rose. There was an increase of 22 per cent in rape cases under the Pocso Act.In 2019, the highest increase was in cases of eve-teasing, which was 68 per cent more than the previous year.

Title: Don’t withhold domestic helps’ pay, they may seek revenge: Cops
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AHMEDABAD: To go with their regular projecting of ethnic and casteist profiles when they describe offences or crimes, city police have come up with “safety tips” for citizens which betray a certain class bias too. They advise citizens not to withhold the pay of their domestic workers not because it would be unfair, but because “they may take revenge”.

The city police’s website, in a segment containing safety tips, gives 25 pointed suggestions to citizen. Some of them are on how to deal with domestic help.

One safety tips reads, “Do not withhold pay, derogate (sic) or mistreat domestic workers. They may seek revenge.”

It also says, “Do not open cupboards, show valuables or discuss financial matters in front of domestic help. They may be tempted to carry out an unlawful act.”

A police official said these safety tips pertaining to domestic help were given as the city reported a gruesome murder of a 75-year-old woman, who was bludgeoned to death by her domestic help at her home in Naranpura in February 2017. After that, city police began an intensive drive to register domestic helps, apparently to thwart their involvement in crimes.

Apart from domestic help, the cops also provide tips on how to deal with vegetable vendors, washer men and milkmen. “Install safety features such as a peephole facility, safety latch or iron grill so that you can scan each visitor before allowing them entry. Be extra careful while allowing unknown persons like vegetable sellers, washermen and milkmen inside.”
