Cops have also provided some life advice in the safety tips, “Develop a network of friends and talk to your neighbor to ensure that you do not live a secluded life. Go for regular walks in groups and socialize.”

Title: Guj ATS, ICG seize 35kg of heroin off Jakhau coast
Content: Ahmedabad: The Gujarat anti-terrorist squad (ATS) and Indian Coast Guard (ICG) in a joint operation apprehended a fishing boat with five Pakistanis aboard off the Jakhau coast, in the early hours of Monday. Officials said 35 kg of heroin, worth Rs 175 crore in the international market, was seized from the boat.ATS sources said the consignment was to land at Jakhau. From there, it was to be delivered to an Afghan national in Delhi who is in the national capital on medical visa.Senior ATS sources said that the Pakistanis arrested told them that the consignment was to be dispatched to other countries through the Afghan national. Those arrested are being jointly interrogated by various agencies.This is the fourth major seizure of contraband from off the Gujarat coast since 2017. “For the past year and a half, Gujarat has emerged as a transit point for the Pakistan-based drug mafia to smuggle narcotics to other countries. Earlier, an Afghan national, Niyamat Khan, who also was in India on a medical visa, was arrested for smuggling 100kg of heroin out of India through South India,” a senior ATS source said.Deputy inspector general of police, ATS, Himanshu Shukla, said they received intelligence that a consignment of heroin was going to be smuggled into Gujarat at Jakhau.ACP ATS B P Rojiya had got this input and alerted senior cops. As the input specifically said that the drug consignment was being sent in a Pakistani fishing boat, ATS officers contacted the Indian Coast Guard and a joint operation was launched.ATS teams led by ACPs B H Chavda and B P Rojiya boarded Coast Guard fast interceptor boats (IBs) at Jakhau, and embarked on a search operation. Commandos of the marine task force and SOG Bhuj-Kutch were also stationed in Indian waters to help apprehend the smugglers.ATS officials said the search was concentrated north west of Jakhau, which the intelligence had specified. A suspicious Pakistani boat, ‘Jam Jam’ was found there in Indian waters at about 3am on Monday.The ICG IBs followed the boat and a team boarded it. A search revealed 35 packets of heroin.The contraband weighs 35kg and is valued at Rs 175 crore in the international market. The persons apprehended are presently being interrogated.

Title: JNU attack: When teachers came in line of fire
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

A vandalised car outside JNU campus tells a tale of destruction

NEW DELHI: Teachers were also not spared of the horror on Sunday with one of them being grievously injured . Teachers staying at Transit House had a harrowing time as the masked miscreants, armed with roads and sticks, chased members of their families and banged on the doors and windows.

Teachers recounted how it was difficult for them to hold the stones of half brick size which were thrown at them. A group of them later wrote to the President of India, regarding the violence in the campus and demanded sacking of the vice-chancellor.

Bikramaditya Kumar Choudhary, a teacher at the Centre for Regional Development, recounted how his wife had a narrow escape on Sunday. “She had gone for a walk and suddenly came back and started shouting, asking me to open the door. More than 100 men were chasing her. She entered the house and then we shut the door putting tables and cupboard. I then called up the security officer, police and the administration but no one responded,” said Choudhary who lives in Transit House. “The armed men wanted to terrorise us,” added Choudhary.

Teachers have also demanded an independent inquiry into the matter.

Sucharita Sen was the most injured and had to be taken to the hospital. Amit Thorat was the first one, who was attacked by the goons, when he was cycling. He somehow escaped and then informed the other teachers gathered at the peace march about the miscreants roaming around in the campus.

“They pushed me on the pavement and I fell. Then they started beating us. But after some point they said that I was not the one and then walked past. It looked like a planned attack with specific targets,” said Saugata Bhaduri from the School of language. Two other female teachers—Sonajharia Minz and Shukla Sawant were also injured due to the attack. “I tried to dodge the stones that were being pelted. Miscreants had rods and other equipment, which they were swinging indiscriminately,” said Minz.

Meanwhile, JNUTA has said that the VC is no longer capable of providing safety and demanded his resignation.

Another teacher group— the JNU teachers federation (JNUTF) condemned the violence and said the hostel wardens of the Sabarmati were chased and beaten up. In a statement, JNUTF said, “This culture of violence by masked gangs is extremely disturbing and needs to be thoroughly investigated by the administration.”

Title: Common mobility card still on paper; BMRC misses deadline
Content:
Representative image

TimesView Once again we have an example of the inability — intentional or otherwise — of the city’s infrastructure providers to coordinate in a way that would make things simpler for citizens. Whether it’s BBMP, BWSSB, Bescom or BMRCL and BMTC, this behaviour seems to have become a constant feature. The common mobility card, by itself, is a convenience and no more. But the failure to go through with it exemplifies a lackadaisical attitude. It would help if officials with these organisations saw themselves as public servants and not as whimsical benefactors.

Kochi shows the way

BENGALURU: The country’s tech capital has once again missed the deadline to get a common mobility card that can be used on Metro trains and buses.Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation Ltd ( BMRCL ) had promised to open four automatic fare collection (AFC) gates that would accept the cards at Nadaprabhu Kempegowda and Byappanahalli stations on a pilot basis from January 1. However, it hasn’t been done and the new deadline is yet to be announced.Rajkumar Dugar, convenor of NGO Citizens for Citizens said, “Bengaluru is an IT hub and it’s unfortunate that the common mobility card has remained on paper for more than five years. The card will help improve public transport ridership, reduce small-change problems and offer hassle-free commute. The delay is due to poor coordination between BMTC and BMRCL, mainly for revenue sharing.”BMRCL managing director Ajay Seth was unavailable for comment. However, sources said Bengaluru was yet to get a Unified Metropolitan Transport Authority (UMTA) to coordinate multiple modes of transport and to come up with initiatives like common mobility cards.Many smaller Indian cities are showing the way, though. In Kochi, for instance, a prepaid Kochi1 card was launched by Kochi Metro and Axis Bank to be used in Metro and private buses. In 2015, Kochi Metro Railway Limited (KMRL) signed a contract with Axis Bank in which the bank invested about Rs 100 crore for installation of the Automatic Fare Collection System. KMRL will get a royalty and about 20% of the revenue from the use of debit cards in transactions outside the Kochi Metro system. Axis Bank co-branded debit cards have been issued to Metro users. The bank will also maintain AFC system for 10 years.BMRCL spent its own funds for the expenditure required for AFC. With private buses dominating in Kochi, KMRL signed an agreement with seven private bus companies and all these buses now accept Kochi1 card. “At present, 100 private buses accept Kochi1 cards. Axis Bank has provided electronic ticketing machines for buses. We will soon extend this to about 1,000 buses,” said a senior KMRL official.Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation (BMTC) along with Axis Bank had launched an open-loop smart card in June 2016, but it was scrapped recently. The central government launched the National Common Mobility Card project, also known as One Nation One Card, in March 2019 for seamless travel through various transport modes. But it is yet to be implemented in Bengaluru.According to BMRCL officials, existing AFC gates at Phase 1 stations need to be upgraded to accept new open-loop cards. AFC gates at Phase 2 stations will be compatible.In 2011, BMTC along with BMRCL launched Metro-Bus Transit (MBT) passes: Saral (unlimited BMTC AC buses and Metro) and Saraag (unlimited BMTC non-AC buses and Metro), priced at Rs 110 and Rs 70 respectively. However, the daily passes were discontinued for lack of patronage.Globally, Hong Kong’s Octopus card, London’s Oyster card and Japan’s Suica card are not only used on buses and the Metro but also accepted for making payments in retail shops. Navigo Pass in Paris, Pasmo in Tokyo, SPTC in Shanghai, Nol Card in Dubai, SmartLink in New York and Singapore Tourist Pass Singapore are also popular.in Singapore are also popular.

Title: JNU violence: Students, teachers use phone torches to dispel darkness in Kolkata
Content:
A foreigner matches steps with protesters at a rally on College Street on Monday

KOLKATA: College Street , which is often identified as the educational hub, on Monday evening turned into focal point of protests against the attack on students of Jawaharlal Nehru University by masked goons on Sunday.The bustling street, flanked by colleges and universities on either side and lined with hundreds of bookshops, reverberated with slogans by protesters venting their anger, anxiety and hurt.As the evening progressed, thousands joined in and staged multiple protests, demanding action against the perpetrators of violence on JNU students and resignation of home minister Amit Shah for his failure to curb violence against students. On Sunday evening, videos of the violence and pictures of bleeding faces of the students along with images of the goons quickly spread on social media, evoking shock and outrage.Teachers and professors from various colleges and universities reached the spot not just to support the protesting students but to also guard them from any provocation. “India belongs to its women and children, Muslims and Dalits, tribals and members of the LGBTQI community. Indian belongs to its marginalized people too. Who made these fascists the custodians of Hindu religion? Who are they to decide that who will stay in this country and who will be ousted? They have now unleashed brutal violence on the student community and those who are questioning them,” said Pradip Basu, dean of humanities and social sciences at Presidency University.A group of students from the university started marching towards the state headquarters of BJP on Murlidhar Sen Lane behind the institute, but police stopped them. Professor Basu urged everyone resist. “I am in my sixties. But I could not stop myself from feeling angry after seeing the state of the country. It will be a blunder to dismiss these attacks on students as isolated incidents. Today they are targeting students, tomorrow they will upon all of us,” said Basu.Another protest march by members of Civil Society from College Street to Raj Bhavan saw a participation of more than 2,000 people. They raised slogans of ‘azaadi’ (freedom from oppression, fascism and majoritarianism) and sang Faiz Ahmed Faiz’s ‘hum dekhenge’.Srija Ray, a second-year student of Presidency University, participated in one of the marches, wore a black badge throughout the day as a mark of protest.“Time has come to take a stand. Fees are being increased manifold while funds for research are being curtailed. If students question such moves, police and goons are unleashed upon on them. Bigots want to turn colleges and universities into laboratories of Hindutva,” Ray said.Protesters said that every action of the central government, which is against the citizens, will be met with resistance. Campuses across the country erupted in violence last month after cops launched a crackdown on students of Jamia Millia Islamia University and Aligarh Muslim University after they protested against CAA and NRC. Alleged police brutalities led to tens of thousands of youths across the nation expressing solidarity with the victims.“We want to tell them that silencing people is not so easy. They will use violence and state machinery to quell our movement, but it is too late. People have hit the streets,” said Swagata Mukherjee, an engineering student.

Title: Former minister BZ Zameer threatens to protest outside G Somashekhara Reddy’s house if he’s not arrested
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Ballari City BJP legislator G Somashekhara Reddy. (ANI photo)

BENGALURU/BALLARI: Former minister BZ Zameer Ahmed Khan of the Congress set a one-week deadline for the BJP government on Monday to arrest Ballari City BJP legislator G Somashekhara Reddy for his recent speech warning Muslims of dire consequences if they continue to protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

Police have already booked Reddy, younger brother of tainted mining baron G Janardhan Reddy , under section 153-A (promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion) of the Indian Penal Code .

However, Khan took the fight to Reddy a step further. “If the government fails to arrest Reddy by January 13, I will stage a dharna outside his house in Ballari, come what may. Let them do whatever they want,” Khan told reporters in Bengaluru.

In his speech at a pro-CAA rally organized by BJP workers and ABVP activists in Ballari, the BJP legislator had said, “We [Hindus] are 83% and they [Muslims] are 17% and if we take law into hands, you know what will happen.”

Khan said on Monday, “I challenge Reddy, the coward, to unsheathe his sword and cut me down first. It is absolutely shameful for a legislator to speak such things against a particular community. Why is Prime Minister Narendra Modi , who often says Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas, silent?”

On his part, Reddy on Monday said he stood by what he said. “What I meant was you Muslims should not get swayed by CAA protests and damage public property. We [Hindus] are sons of the same mother and live peacefully. However, they [Muslims] should not test our [Hindu] patience. I stick by my words 100%,” he said.

A delegation of the Ballari district Congress unit also submitted an appeal to the deputy commissioner, inspector general of police and superintendent of police on Monday to arrest Reddy for his provocative speech.

Title: Rural distress hits silver demand; imports down 40%
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Ahmedabad: Agriculture and rural distress has hit demand for silver to a great extent in 2019. The import of silver declined by 40% year-on-year in 2019. The precious metal’s imports fell from 150.7 metric tonne (MT) in 2018 to 89.9MT in 2019, according to data by Ahmedabad Air Cargo Complex.

Silver price stood at Rs 49,600 per kg in the Ahmedabad market on Saturday. Analysts said that demand for both silver in terms of bullion as well as jewellery has declined. “With an acute water scarcity situation in the initial part of the year, and excess rainfall in the later half, rural incomes were affected to a great extent. This is clearly visible in the mounting burden of bad loans in the agriculture sector. Silver demand across the country is largely driven by people in the rural areas. With majority of rural population reeling under stress due to such an agrarian crisis, silver imports have declined,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).

Analysts also blame it on the prices of silver which remained significantly high throughout the year. “Due to slowing economic scenario, the cashflow situation is a major concern with several businesses and industrial sectors reeling under liquidity crisis amid stretched payment cycles. Moreover, price of silver also remained fairly high throughout the year, which deterred investments,” Acharya added.

Jewellers said that the amount of silver recycled is also very high. “Just like gold, silver purchases have also remained muted due to high prices and cashflow crisis. Moreover, there is a high degree of recycling in silver purchases as well. People come with previously purchased silver to buy new jewellery and thus, overall imports got affected,” said Ashish Zaveri, media convener, Jewellers’ Association of Ahmedabad (JAA).

Title: Gujarat worst in marine resource conservation
Content:
Gujarat has earned the dubious distinction of being the worst among coastal states of the country in conservin... Read More

In the recently released sustainable development goals (SDG) index 2019-20, Gujarat stands at the bottom of the nine coastal states of India

AHMEDABAD: Gujarat has earned the dubious distinction of being the worst among coastal states of the country in conserving marine and coastal resources. In the recently released sustainable development goals (SDG) index 2019-20, Gujarat stands at the bottom of the nine coastal states of India.While Karnataka, with a composite score of 65 in the SDG named ‘Life Under Water’ ranks best among the nine coastal states, Gujarat has a dismal composite score of 28 on this SDG. Coastal states have been ranked by Niti Aayog on parameters like water quality index, development of mangroves, use of nitrogen fertilisers in coastal areas, marine acidity levels and development of aquaculture.Despite the fact that Gujarat boasts of the longest coastline in the country of 1,600 kilometres, only 1.2 per cent of available potential area has been developed under aquaculture and there has been an increase of just 2.98 % in the mangrove cover in the past year. The water quality index of the state is also lowest among all the nine coastal states.However, the indicators and their values under this SDG have not been used in determining the overall score of the state, as only nine states have a coastline. Gujarat is ranked joint sixth with Maharashtra in the overall composite score of 17 SDGs for 2019-20.

Title: Consecutive Rajasthan governments have been stingy on health budget
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

File photo of health department office

JAIPUR: The deaths of 112 infants in 37 days in JK Lon Hospital in Kota due to shortage of medical equipment, poor infrastructure and vacant post of doctors/nursing staff prove that the state health budget had been falling short to meet the basic needs in the healthcare system.

Figures say in the current financial year, the health budget of Rs 13,039 crore constitute for about 5.90% of the total budget. The budgetary allocation for healthcare in the last two financial years 2017-18 and 2018-19 was 6.07% and 6.05%, respectively.

The preliminary reports say that cause of deaths was poor facilities like shortage of warmers, heaters, seats in intensive care units, oxygen cylinders and other medical equipment. These facilities are bought under capital funds within the health budget. Irony is that the capital budget had been least spend in the last few years. The average figure says that from 2014-15 to 2017-18, less than 50% of the capital funds had been utilised in the previous government.

Nisar Ahmed of Budget Analysis and Research Centre Trust (BARC), a research centre which monitors state budget, expenditure and spending said, “The deaths of infants shouldn’t be seen as a phenomena occurred overnight or in the last few months. It is a cumulative failure of the poor budgetary allocation added with unspent capital funds. Questions should also be raised to the previous government for not spending the amount for f building facilities,” said Ahmed.

Data procured from state budget pages says that budgetary allocation has increased by 9.61% from 2018-19 to 2019-20 while the health budget show insignificant rise of just 1.76% by the present Congress government.

“The previous government has not only neglected health budget, but spent on the privatisation of health services. The focus was on health insurance schemes at the cost of primary healthcare schemes by former CM Vasundhara Raje government,” said Chhaya Pancholi, a healthcare activist.

The rise of health budget (in %) in proportion to the state budget in the financial years—2016-17, 2017-18 were 2018-19 were 1.29/9.74, 2.24/10.34 and 18.3/31.41 respectively. According to self-confession by health minister Raghu Sharma, the JK Lone Hospital in Kota has an unspent amount of Rs 6 crore under the medical relief society of the hospital. TOI had repeatedly called up the health minister, but got no response.

Title: Mumbai: Man refuses to pay up for massage inquiry, becomes revenge porn victim
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Making an online inquiry for a massage service landed a 30-year-old jewellery designer in trouble. After he refused the Rs 50,000 service, he saw his wife’s photograph posted on a dating app and her fake profile described her as a sex worker. MIDC police said the fraudster did this to extort money from the man for the inquiry call he made on December 14.

The fraudster allegedly gathered his information from Facebook and used a morphed photograph of his wife to extort money.

The designer lives in Palghar and works in Andheri. “He received links to the dating app on WhatAspp while at work in Andheri on December 16. We are tracking the number on which the victim had made calls to inquire about the service. The fraudster seems to be part of a racket that targets people who go online for sex chats and sex workers. They then blackmail them into parting with money or threaten to malign them on social media,” said a police officer.

The victim first called the fraudster on December 14 after coming across the number online. In his complaint, he said, “The person took my number and sent photos of five women. He asked me to pick one for the service and asked me to drop by at his Churchgate service centre. I refused to do so and asked him to send the woman to Palghar, for which the person asked me to transfer Rs 50,000. I disconnected the line as I thought the amount was too high.”

Title: JNU violence: Some start leaving, but vow to be back
Content:
Students with belongings leaving JNU campus (ANI File Photo)

People protesting against JNU violence

NEW DELHI: The day after the mob attack , students and teachers of Jawaharlal Nehru University recounted the horrors of Sunday night. Fearful about their safety, many students left for home despite the university being fortified by police presence. Those still on campus formed a human chain from the lawns of Sabarmati Hostel till the main gate, demanding both the resignation of vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar and an independent inquiry into the first incident of its type in JNU ’s 50-year history.On Monday, the VC issued a statement in which he attributed the violence to students protesting over hiked hostel fees and the move to stop students from registering for the winter semester. However, many others on the campus alleged that the masked intruders were members of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), the RSS-affiliated student organisation. They also accused the administration of collusion with the attackers.ABVP retorted that the people who went on a rampage on the campus were mostly students from Jamia Millia Islamia and that left activists who wanted to disrupt the semester registration process.Sabarmati Hostel bore the marks of the mob attack, the 42 rooms there strewn with glass shards and debris. Periyar Hostel too bore signs of the violence. Congress functionary Sharmistha Mukherjee inspected this hostel on Monday.Radha Jattav, a first year master’s degree student and resident of Ganga Hostel, said she saw people being beaten when she left the library. “Thank god, the library closes early on Sundays, else the goons would have entered and created the same situation as in Jamia,” Jattav shuddered. “Since nobody wanted to be on the ground floor in case of an attack, six of us spent the night in one room. One of them, a person with disability, was so overcome that she left for home in the morning.”While Jattav plans to go home in Madhya Pradesh on Tuesday, Nitin Rakesh, a School of International Studies student and Jhelum Hostel resident, did not tarry. Before leaving for Lucknow on Monday, he said, “I am afraid as is my family. I will return when things normalise.”A PhD scholar recalled Sunday’s mayhem. “We have seen violence here since January 3, but yesterday terror was let loose,” he said. “A teacher was attacked while cycling on the campus. He ran and informed participants of a Jawaharlal Nehru University Teachers’ Association peace march that masked people were beating up everyone. In no time, the attackers were at the Sabarmati T-point, assaulting students and teachers.”

Title: Rajkot doctor, seven aides arrested for attacking trader
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

cap

Rajkot: A doctor was arrested on Monday for allegedly attacking a trader at Moti Tanki Chowk near Bheelvas Chowk locality in Rajkot on December 30 last year. Along with the doctor, seven of his associates were also arrested.

Police said the accused, identified as Dr Luckyraj Patel, had led his aides to attack Hiren Nathwani with a knife. The police are yet to find out that among the accused who had stabbed Nathwani.

Nathwani told the cops that he had a minor accident with Dr Patel’s car on December 28 near Prem Mandir on Kalawad Road.

Dr Patel had noted Nathwani’s car number, on the basis of which he obtained his address from the internet. Then Dr Patel visited Nathwani’s house in Vaishalinagar locality of Rajkot when the latter was absent. Dr Patel got Nathwani’s cellphone number from his wife and called him, saying that that he knew that he had an accident with his car and fled. Dr Patel asked Nathwani to come to strike a compromise at Moti Tanki Chowk and warned him of dire consequences, if he failed to turn up.

“When Nathwani reached Moti Tanki Chowk, there were seven people who attacked him allegedly at the instruction of Dr Patel. One of the accused allegedly stabbed him in his stomach and chest,” said an official from Pradyumannagar police station.

Those arrested along with Dr Patel were Dr Patel’s cousin Jaideep Patel, Yash Vyas, Arjun Rajput, Meet Vyas, Akash Mesvania, Raj Goswami and Dharmesh Yadav.

Title: Spurned lover stabs 17-yr-old girl in Kochi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kochi: A 17-year-old girl on Monday suffered serious stab injuries after she was attacked by a youth whom she had turned down at Kakkanad in Ernakulam .

The girl, a resident of Athani in Kakkanad, was stabbed multiple times by the youth while she was returning from her workplace. The girl, admitted to the Ernakulam Government Medical College Hospital, Kalamassery, has undergone emergency surgery and her condition remains critical. The accused, who fled from the crime scene after abandoning his bike, is on the run and the Infopark police have launched a probe to nab him.

According to the police, the incident took place around 5pm at Kuzhukuttimala on Infopark road when the girl was returning home from a day care where she worked as a part-time staff.

Police, quoting the witnesses, said that she was stopped by a bike-borne youth and both of them were seen talking for a few minutes. Suddenly, the youth took a knife and stabbed the girl multiple times on different parts of her body, including chest.

By the time the onlookers rushed to the crime scene, he managed to escape, leaving behind his bike.

“The girl was rushed to the hospital by the nearby residents. Preliminary inquiry suggests that it is a case of crime of passion. We have learned that a youth, a native of Padamugal, was making romantic advances towards the girl but the girl rejected him citing religious reasons. We suspect that this provoked the youth to plan and execute the crime,” said a police officer.

Meanwhile, officials of Government Medical College, Ernakulam, said that she is in a critical condition. “She suffered multiple injuries. She was stabbed on her neck, chest, abdomen and other parts of the body,” an official with the hospital said.

The girl has been pursuing a medical lab-assistant course in the city along with her part-time work. Her parents were separated and she was staying with her mother.

Police have seized the youth’s bike. They will take the girl’s statement after her condition becomes stable. Only after that more details can be confirmed, said police.

Title: Ran for life from one room to another, Kolkata students recall JNU hostel horror
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Broken doors and shattered glass panes after the violence on the JNU campus on Sunday

KOLKATA: A young PhD scholar from Ballygunge recalled Sunday evening as the scariest time of her life, running away from armed goons, running from room to room, hiding behind closed doors. She remained crammed with 30 others in a room for 10 minutes before taking shelter in another room for three hours till help arrived.

“I never thought I would feel so unsafe on my own university’s campus. I still shiver at the sight of my friends — injured and bleeding. Thirty of us hid in a small room in the hostel with lights turned off as armed goons went on the rampage outside, banging on closed doors and thrashing anyone who came their way,” said the scared scholar, Mehta, who agreed to be identified only by her last name to escape the wrath of the attackers. “My parents are tensed. My mother has fallen sick and my father is calling me up every 30 minutes to check if I am fine,” she added.

Mehta was among the scores of students from Bengal who study at JNU . Like most students — Sabarmati Hostel, the seat of Sunday’s violence — is their preferred place to stay.

Another student of literature — a resident of Dum Dum , who was also on the campus — said she ran for her life with others when they saw armed men and women pelting stones from the rooftops of Periyar boy’s hostel. “The attackers then proceeded to smash window panes and assault the students in the hostel,” she said. “We recognized some of the attackers. They actively support ABVP on the campus. But most of them had their faces covered. We have never faced such brutality here,” she said.

Mousumi Mandal, another PhD scholar from Patuli, said she was not on the campus at the time of the incident, but rushed to the aid of her friends the moment she heard about the attack. “By the time, I reached the campus, cops stood on guard manning all the entry points of the university. We marched from hostel to hostel calling out the students to get out of the rooms as we were there to escort them safely out of the campus,” said Mandal.

Mehta said, after being chased for the second time by armed goons, who had slashed at one of her friends and poured some acid-like liquid on them, she was forced to lock herself at a hostel room for three hours till 10.30pm.

Gourab Ghosh, a JNU student and SFI activist, played a crucial role in sending updates to other students in other hostels and even led them towards the north gate in a show of solidarity. “Police helped ABVP in the attack on students. We needed help. Lots of ABVP goons, with their faces covered, had entered campus with rods. When police asked students to chant ‘Bharat Mata Ki Jai’ at JNU north gate, we decided to identify all those leading the carnage. We managed to gather almost 120 students and march towards the main gate as the first sign of resistance,” Ghosh wrote on his Facebook wall.

Sougata Bhaduri, an English professor at the university and a resident Bagmari in north Kolkata, sustained injuries in the attack. “We were standing near the north gate when armed masked men began assaulting us all of a sudden. I was hit on my back and legs,” Bhaduri said.

Title: Clarify stand on NPR, NRC: Women to KCR
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: A group of women organisations on Monday urged the state government to clarify its stand on NRC and NPR implementation in Telangana. Women representatives from various organisations and NGOs from across the state urged CM KCR to ‘boycott NPR and NCR, like Kerala did’.

Condemning the attack on JNU students in Delhi, the women representatives said, “The unprecedented barbarism on students has made the nation restless. We share the grief and pain of these students and their parents”.

All India Muslim Personal Law Board member Asma Zohra said, “The government came to power with our votes, and if it fails to protect our sons and daughters, it must be dissolved. The fight and protests are against the unconstitutional moves of the government and to protect the Constitution.”

Title: NPR ‘pretest’ done in 6 districts of Telangana, Andhra Pradesh
Content:
Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi and Muslim organisations have asked CM KCR to stop all NPR activity in the state... Read More

HYDERABAD: Even as the National Population Register (NPR) is generating heat across the country, an NPR ‘pretest’ (trial form) was done in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh a few months ago. Senior officials said they did not receive any adverse feedback from the respondents.Three districts each in both states were selected along with 68 districts across India where the exercise was completed along with pretest for Census 2021. According to highly-placed sources, NPR prestesting was done in Nizamabad urban, Warangal urban and Mahbubnagar districts of Telangana and Vizianagaram, Anantapur and Guntur districts in AP.Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi and Muslim organisations have asked CM KCR to stop all NPR activity in the state. Women members of All India Muslim Personal Law Board on Monday appealed to KCR to pass a bill in assembly rejecting NPR and NRC.Sources said nearly 30 lakh people responded to the pretest form that was used to collect data in 74 districts in select states. Details on 21 parameters, especially place of birth of father and mother, last place of residence, along with Aadhaar (optional), PAN, voter ID card, passport, mobile phone number and driving licence numbers, were sought.An official from Nizamabad said the process passed off smoothly. “None of the respondents gave an adverse feedback. When this exercise was taken up in September and October 2019, there was no resistance from citizens. All of them submitted details voluntarily,” he said.Four wards in Nizamabad, seven villages of Veleru mandal in Warangal urban and four villages in Nawabpet mandal of Mahbubnagar were covered. A total of 144 enumerator blocs were identified with each having 120-150 houses. An official said families would be informed much in advance about the visit of an enumerator so that the documents were readily available for verification.In AP, eight villages in Anantapur’s Atmakur mandal, eight villages in Vizianagaram’s Bhogapruam mandal and six municipal wards in Guntur’s Narsaraopet were covered. “It is a myth that lot of documents need to be shown. Disclosing the details is also voluntary,” the official explained.Interestingly, this is not the first time that NPR has been undertaken in Telangana. In 2015, updation of NPR exercise of 2010 was taken up in all districts. “NPR exercise conducted first in 2010 and subsequently updated in 2015 collected details on 15 parameters only,” officials said.

Title: Bhadra court employees protest stringent rules
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The court employees at the city civil and sessions court at Bhadra protested on Monday against the stringent rules they are forced to follow after a court staff, Palak Soni, committed suicide during duty hours by jumping from the 7th floor of court building on Saturday.

While the court staff are planning a protest march to the Gujarat high court chief justice’s bungalow on Tuesday, the All India Subordinate Court Staff Association has written a letter to Chief Justice Vikram Nath demanding a “proper judicial and neutral inquiry into the matter by constituting a separate committee”.

The association has pointed out that the employees at the city civil court believe that the workload and mental harassment forced Soni to take the drastic step. It has pointed out 18 rules framed by the principal judge for court employees like prohibition on use of mobile phone, not talking to colleagues, restriction on their movement during office hours etc. Any slip in observing these results in issuance of notices, stoppage of salary, and departmental inquiries against employees etc. The association claimed that these rules add to the agony of court employees at the Bhadra court complex.

The association said that such rules are against provisions contained in service manual or court manual.’The association has also urged the chief justice to act promptly to arrest the spread of discontent among employees of other courts across the state.

Title: Delhi assembly election: ‘Office of profit’ case against AAP MLAs now infructuous
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: With the announcement of assembly polls in Delhi , the pending petition being re-heard by the Election Commission seeking disqualification of 20 AAP MLAs for having held office of profit as parliamentary secretaries has virtually become infructuous.

The EC had in January 2018 recommended disqualification of all AAP MLA, holding that they had held office of profit as parliamentary secretaries between their appointment on March 13, 2015, and the Delhi High Court quashing the appointments on September 8, 2016.

On March 23, 2018, the HC set aside the disqualification notification issued by the Centre, based on EC’s opinion, on the ground that no oral hearing was given to the AAP MLAs in violation of principles of natural justice. EC subsequently started hearing the plea afresh, as directed by the HC.

During the re-hearing, AAP MLAs sought to cross-examine petitioner Prashant Patel, who had moved the ‘office of profit’ plea before the President, and others. The EC on September 25, 2018, dismissed the AAP MLAs’ application seeking summoning and examination of witnesses and ruled that all documents available on record pertaining to the appointment and tenure of 20 respondent AAP MLAs as parliamentary secretaries “were self-explanatory”.

The AAP MLAs then challenged the order by EC in the Delhi HC. The matter is sub-judice. An EC functionary said the next date of hearing by the HC was January 10.

However, with the polls already announced and the appointment of the AAP MLAs as parliamentary secretaries already set aside by Delhi HC on September 8, 2016, the disqualification proceedings have no meaning and the MLAs will be free to re-contest the upcoming elections.

Other proceedings that will be affected due to Monday’s polling schedule announcement are of former AAP MLAs Anil Bajpai and Devender Sehrawat, who have challenged their disqualification in the HC. The ex-AAP MLAs have challenged their disqualification under the anti-defection law.

As per Section 15(1)(a) of Government of NCT of Delhi Act, 1991, a person is disqualified from being chosen as or being an MLA if he holds an office of profit under the central government or state government other than an office declared by law not to disqualify its holder. “The disqualification ends the moment he gives up the office of profit and he can re-contest the election immediately thereafter,” said an EC functionary.

During the term of the AAP government, four office of petitions were moved against different sets of AAP MLAs. Based on EC’s opinion, three petitions were dismissed — against 27 MLAs for holding posts of chairpersons of Rogi Kalyan Samitis (EC opinion tendered on July 10, 2018), against 11 AAP MLAs for heading district disaster management committees (on August 26, 2019) and against AAP MLA Surender Singh (on September 16, 2019).

Title: Bengaluru: 90 buses to ply on nine new feeder routes from four Metro stations
Content:
Mobility study

BENGALURU: You may soon get a BMTC feeder bus every 5-10 minutes from Mysuru Road, Byappanahalli, Banashankari and Indiranagar Metro stations.BMTC officials said they have decided to come up with nine new Metro feeder routes with 10 dedicated buses running on each. The average route is 9km long.According to BMTC records, the headway — the time between two buses — in 46% of the current routes is more than 15 minutes, which makes it four buses plying on the route every hour. Also, 32% of the current route network has a headway of more than 30 minutes, which is less than two buses per hour.“The aim is to provide public transport users reliable services and help reduce their travel time. It will also provide a single-journey experience and boost public transport ridership,” said a senior BMTC official.“Most Metro stations do not have bus bays. So it is difficult to park and then pick up and drop passengers. BMRCL has promised bus bays in all upcoming stations wherever feasible,” said another official.Metro’s daily ridership is around 4.5 lakh and is expected to touch 5 lakh this year. According to BMRCL, Byappanahalli, Kempegowda Majestic Interchange, Indiranagar, Yelachenahalli, MG Road, Mysuru Road, Mantri Square Sampige Road, Vijayanagar, Trinity and Rajajinagar are the busiest stations.However, BMTC officials said most of its feeder services are suffering loss. Currently, the transport utility operates 155 feeder buses on 30 routes from different Metro stations. However, there are complaints of poor frequency. According to officials, better feeder services have the potential to increase Metro’s ridership by 10%, remove 28,000 cars from roads, reduce parking space and emission levels.Stations like Chikpet, Peenya, Dasarahalli, Ulsoor , Trinity, Cubbon Park, Vidhana Soudha, Sir M Visvesvaraya, Magadi Road, Hosahalli and KR Market don’t have dedicated feeder buses. Some of these stations have regular buses plying from near them.At present, the frequency of feeder buses along the Green Line is more than 10 minutes. The route length of feeder buses along Green Line varies between 6Km and 19Km. On the Purple Line, the frequency is 15-30 minutes. The average route length varies between 10Km and 30Km. The longer the route length, the more time the buses will take to complete the trips, extending passengers wait time.BMTC officials said they are also envisaging a plan to increase its ridership to around 40 lakh now to 73 lakh by 2030. “We need 10,000 more buses and 65 new depots to increase public transport mode share to 41% by 2030,” he adds.Bangalore Metro Rail Corporation Ltd is conducting a mobility improvement study to improve the use of public transport in the city. Sources said New Delhi-based Urban Mass Transit Company has been roped in for the purpose. UMTC representatives are holding a survey at four terminal stations, including Byappanahalli and Mysuru Road on the Purple Line and Yelachenahalli and Nagasandra on the Green Line. They are asking passengers on their journey details like cost, distance and first- and last-mile connectivity mode.

Title: 19-year-old girl attacked by her stalker, three aides
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A 19-year-old girl was assaulted by her stalker and his three aides near Viralbaug at Valmikivas in Jamnagar on Sunday evening.

Police said the accused, Gajan Vaghela, hit Puja Parmar with a bat. He was accompanied by the co-accused — Deepak Parmar, Vinod Sodha and Kavo Vaghela.

According to the police, Gajan had been stalking Puja for the past few days, demanding that she get into a relationship with him. However, Puja told him she was not interested and did not entertain his advances. On the fateful day, when Puja was returning in an autorickshaw from her friend’s house, the accused followed her on their bikes.

“The accused waylaid the autorickshaw and made Puja alight. Then Gajan asked her as to why she was not talking to him. When Puja said that she was not interested in him and that he should not call her again, Gajan hit her with a bat. When passers-by gathered at the spot, the accused fled,” said an official from Jamnagar B division police station.

Meanwhile, the police have launched a manhunt for the accused.

Title: Astronomers join hands to observe dimming Betelgeuse
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Ahmedabad: Betelgeuse, the second brightest star in Orion constellation, has been visibly losing its brightness from October 2019 onwards and this has city-based amateur astronomers excited. The star, located about 700 lightyears away from the Solar system, is one of the closest Red supergiants, which could meet its ultimate fate in a supernova at any time. The world over, the dimming has enthusiasts glued to telescopes due to the event’s implications.

Dhananjay Rawal, a city-based science communicator, said Orion is one of the most recognizable constellations in the night sky. “Betelgeuse is a variable star – meaning its brightness varies greatly over time – but this time it is decreasing steadily. It could mean two things, it could be a temporary phase, or it could lead to a supernova,” he said, adding that Indians know the star as ‘Aardra’.

In human history, only three to four supernovae have been observed with the naked eye, the last in early 17th century. “If the star turns into supernova even in this century, it will be after a very long time and the star has thus gained attention. The red star is visible even today and it’s a great time to observe it – whatever its fate,” said Kuldip Vora, an amateur astronomer who has been watching the star for the past two months. “If it indeed turns into supernova, it will become brighter than the full moon and will be visible even in the day.”

Manoj Pai, president of the Astronomy Club Ahmedabad, said they recently held a viewing of the star for members. “We went to outskirts of the city to get a good view. In terms of our Solar system, if the star is at where the Sun is, it’s circumference would be greater even than Mars’ orbit. It’s an opportunity for us to introduce the enthusiasts to the exciting world of stars,” he said.

Most importantly, such phenomena takes earthlings back to skygazing.

Title: Anganwadis ineffective in ensuring mom, child health
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Jaipur: At a time when infants from underprivileged families are dying, the anganwadi centres (AWC), whose job is to monitor the health of pregnant women, lactating mothers and children (up to 5 years), are also turning out to be ineffective.

The state has close to 66,000 AWCs with most of them are running from makeshift or rented places with bare minimum support like transport facilities, medical staff, nutrition supplements, teaching materials and regular meals for children.

The AWCs are the first point of contact for pregnant woman to get registered in order to avail the facilities. “Once the registration is done, it will enable the beneficiary to get the benefits like regular health checkups, examination of blood and urine at each visit or on a monthly basis, along with incentives like Indira Gandhi Matritva Sahyog Yojana and Janani Suraksha Yojana. Those who miss out registration fail to get such incentives making themselves and their child vulnerable to several diseases,” said Chhaya Pancholi of Jan Swasthy Abhiyan, a advocacy group working for right to health.

Padma Rawal, a mother who lost her five-month-old son at JK Lon Hospital in Kota on December 23, has complained to have not received any supplements from AWC. She is a resident of Chattarpura in Kota and was registered by the AWC which runs in a rented 10x8-sq-feet room. “They have never called for the monthly check-up and food items which I was told was never received,” said Rawal.

Her son was born healthy in a dispensary and fell ill to pneumonia in his fifth month. The anganwadis are also supposed to deliver nutrition supplements (take away ration) to pregnant women and hot cooked meals to children.

Other provisions of the AWCs are once in a month on a fixed day, Maternal Child Health and Nutrition Day has to be observed at the centre. It is to be organised jointly by the health and the ICDS department. “On the given day, immunisation of children is carried out and ANC (ante-natal care) checkups are done of pregnant women. Every pregnant woman should ideally receive 4 ANCs during the course of her pregnancy. Each ANC consists of abdomen examination, blood test, weight and BP test, together with receiving iron folic acid tablets and two TT shots,” said Pancholi.

Consecutive governments have failed to address the problem of streamlining the AWCs. The NFHS-4 report said in Rajasthan only 38.5% pregnant women get 4 ANC checkups and only about 17.3% pregnant women receive 100 or more iron folic acid tablets. Along with 46.6% of the pregnant women are anaemic in the state, 27% of the women within reproductive age have BMIs below normal.

Title: Gold rush: Price hits record high of Rs 42,300
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Continuing its upward rally, the price of gold touched another record high on Monday, breaching the Rs 42,000-mark, on account of global factors. The price of the yellow metal stood at Rs 42,300 per 10 gram on Monday in the Ahmedabad market, increasing by Rs 1,000 against the closing price on Friday. Analysts said that escalating tensions between Iran and the US was a major trigger for rise in gold prices.

“As tensions between Iran and the US escalated, global rates of gold rallied. In the international market, gold rose from $1,448 per ounce to $1,525. Moreover, the Indian currency depreciated too against the US dollar. As a result, gold prices saw a sharp rise in the Indian market on Monday,” said Haresh Acharya, director, India Bullion and Jewellers’ Association (IBJA).

Gold prices already showed a steep rise on Friday, when prices rose by Rs 900 in a day. Overall, gold prices showed an increase of Rs 1,800 in two days. Jewellers indicate that rising gold prices will only dent demand for gold.

“The wedding season is ongoing and the demand for gold will remain. However, nobody can afford to buy gold at this price and thus the proportion of purchases made through exchange of old gold will significantly go up. As a result, overall demand for the yellow metal will remain low-key,” said a city-based jeweller.

Title: Cops return valuables worth over Rs 1.20 cr
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: Cash and other valuables worth Rs 1.20 crore were returned to the complainants at a police function on Monday.

The programme was part of a series of events organised as part of the Maharashtra Police Raising Day celebration from January 2 to January 8. Jewellery worth Rs 37 lakh, vehicles worth Rs 25 lakh, cellphones worth Rs 2.32 lakh and other articles worth Rs 54.69 lakh were returned to the complainants.

Speaking at the function, police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil said the department was making all efforts to see that people coming to the police stations with their problems or complaints are dealt with empathy. To serve this purpose, a call is made from the police control room to every complainant asking about their experience of visiting the police station.

“People are in immense pain when they come to the police station to lodge their complaints. The aim of the police is to deal with such people with empathy and if swift action is needed, the police take it immediately,” he said.

He said that the police control room number now has eight lines, instead of two earlier lines. The police were taking all efforts to ensure that their response time was minimum and no time is wasted in nabbing the culprit. He also lauded the work of police officials in cracking some very challenging cases.

Underlining the need for citizens and private establishments to take their own security measures, Nangare-Patil said residents should appoint security guards and financial institutes must have proper security guards and CCTVs at the ATMs.

“If the financial institutes fail to take up the suggested security measures, the police would be forced to lodge complaints against them,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan leopard death count comes down by 17% in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Leopard mortality has gone down significantly in the state with 17% dip in the number of deaths reported in 2019 compared to the previous year. Leopard is listed on a par with tigers under Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Act (WPA), 1972.

According to the data provided by the Wildlife Protection Society of India (WPSI), 45 leopards died in 2019, nine less than the 2018 figure.

Rajasthan ranked fourth in leopard deaths in the country in 2019. Maharashtra topped the list with 94 followed by Uttarakhand (79) and Madhya Pradesh (54).

Although, the number of deaths has reduced, a big concern remains that half of these are said to be unnatural—caused by road accidents, electrocution or due to man-animal conflicts.

Tito Joseph, programme manager of WPSI told TOI, “Ten leopards were killed in road accidents and two in rail accidents. The state government should propose mitigation measures to address these issues.”

Conservationists also feel that depletion of natural prey base in most of the forest areas and reserves has led to shifting of the wild animals towards killing of livestock.

As leopards are highly adaptable, they venture close to human settlements whenever there is shortage of food. This is a risk for the big cats as well, since they often become victims of man-animal conflict.

Shatrunjay Singh, who is working for leopard conservation at Jawai Bandh Leopard Conservation Reserve (JBLCR) said, “Fortunately, leopard population has also increased in the state, though the issue remains that they frequently kill livestock. To avoid man-animal conflict, the government should expedite disbursing compensation for livestock killed by wild animals.”

Rajasthan became the first in the world when the state announced leopard reserves under Project Leopard. The initiative started in 2018 with the inauguration of the ‘Leopard Reserve’ at Jhalana forest. The project is being implemented in a phase-wise manner. Proposal of seven more leopard projects in the state including Kumbhalgarh, Jaisamnad, Shergarh, Mount Abu, Khetri, Jawai Baandh Conservation Reserve and Bassi are under consideration.

Title: Gujarat: PIL seeks prohibitive pressure
Content:
Representative image

A new PIL was filed on Monday seeking court directions to the government for strict implementation of the prohibition law in dry Gujarat

AHMEDABAD: While the Gujarat high court is hearing half a dozen petitions demanding relaxation in liquor laws, a new PIL was filed on Monday seeking court directions to the government for strict implementation of the prohibition law in dry Gujarat.Petitioner Prakash Kapadia has in particular taken objection to the recent instructions issued by the state director general of police (DGP) for removing intra-state and inter-state checkposts, which were seen hurdles for bootleggers. The petitioner has questioned the motive behind shutting down these checkposts with immediate effect.The petitioner has claimed that the reason behind diversion of force from these checkposts to cities to maintain law and order is not satisfactory at all. He further argues that such a decision of abolishing checkposts raises concerns whether it would lead to giving bootleggers free entry to the state.The petitioner has questioned closure of all checkposts on state and district borders and sought quashing of this decision. In support of his demand, Kapadia has argued that Gujarat is a dry state, but more than 1,000 persons were caught drunk in Valsad district on the New Year’s Eve.The petitioner further argued that such a closure of checkposts on state borders will result in free flow of liquor in the state, which is in violation of the Gujrat Prohibition Act.The data revealed that liquor worth over Rs 100 crore was caught from the Ratanpur checkpost on Gujarat-Rajasthan border, and nearly 200 breweries were caught in two zones of Ahmedabad police commissionerate.The PIL cited figures placed by the state government before the assembly during the winter session and argued that 13 IMFL bottles are caught every minute in Gujarat, and one bottle of IMFL is caught every minute in Ahmedabad.This PIL is likely to come up for hearing later this week.The high court on Monday adjourned hearing till January 27 on petitions seeking relaxation in prohibition laws so that people can drink at private places. There is one PIL and four special civil applications for relaxing strict liquor ban. Objecting to these petitions, the state government claimed that the practice of drinking will deteriorate the condition of the poor and of women.

Title: Dilapidated BHEL quarters, a den of criminal activities
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Bhopal: The gangrape of a minor in broad daylight on Saturday at an abandoned quarter in Berkhera has once again brought to focus safety and security issues at the dilapidated quarters in BHEL township. These abandoned houses have become safe hideouts from miscreants and criminals.

These houses are frequented by criminals who use them as safe hideouts after committing crimes in the city.

Constructed almost 50-55 years ago, the BHEL quarters were full of hustle bustle and were occupied by workers. Gradually, these houses were abandoned after workers and executives retired and moved out of the township. The staff strength in BHEL going down to 6500 from 17,000 added to the problem. Presently, only about 3,500 of the 6,300 quarters are occupied.

Soon after the incident, a blame game has started with the district police saying that they have sent many letters to BHEL management in the past asking them to either demolish the abandoned quarters or take up responsibility of security arrangements in the township. BHEL has said they have contracted private security agency for security in the township and will take necessary action.

Once the quarters were abandoned, many slums have come up close to them. These slums are mostly occupied by contract labourers who are employed in BHEL. Miscreants often use the abandoned houses for gambling, consuming liquor and other criminal activities.

In many burglary and theft gangs busted by police, it was revealed that the accused used these quarters to hide their robbed booty.

Township residents said streetlights are also not functional in the locality which makes life miserable for those still residing here. “Come at night. Then you would realise the condition we are living in. Just imagine, what a single family staying among 50 dilapidated houses undergoes daily,” said a worker pleading anonymity.

Residents alleged that in the absence of proper maintenance and security, several crimes took place in the area. In 2013, businessman Manish Takhtani was murdered and his body was dumped in the abandoned quarters in Govindpura area and set on fire. Several incidents of loot and other crimes have also taken place there. The township is covered by two police stations -- Piplani and Govindpura.

Speaking to TOI, DIG Irshad Wali said the abandoned BHEL quarters have been a problem for police for long. In many cases in the past it was found that criminals use these quarters to hide from police and store their robbed goods. Police have written several letters to BHEL management in the past and asked them either to demolish these structures or own up the responsibility of security in the area.

He said that police conduct regular patrolling in the BHEL township and it will be further intensified.

When contacted PRO BHEL Raghavendra Shukla expressed ignorance about the gangrape case. He said that BHEL management will take cognizance in the matter and take required action. Shukla said that BHEL already have contracted private security agency which keeps a vigil and provides security in the township area. The management will inquire into the matter, he said.

Title: 43 test positive for swine flu in last fortnight
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The number of swine flu cases in the state has risen. In the last fortnight, 43 cases have been reported, with many of these being from Hyderabad. Experts say that the number of cases may surge further in January, and an alert has been sent to hospitals to be prepared for the same.

“While all district and area hospitals have been alerted on the possibility of swine flu cases increasing, currently cases are mostly being reported from private hospitals in and around the city. We have been expecting a surge in cases mostly in the month of January. As of now, out of 100 samples, less than 7% have turned out to be positive for the H1N1 virus,” said a senior official from the state health department.

Since the beginning of November, when swine flu cases usually begin to rise, hospitals have already been alerted thrice to prepare isolation wards. However, this year, the rise in cases has begun late, with most cases being reported over the last fortnight. Usually the H1N1 virus become more active with a decrease in temperature, with the common symptoms being cough, cold, fever, body pain and breathlessness. Patients having cough or sore throat with high grade fever are in the high-risk category, which includes pregnant women, children, elderly and those with comorbid conditions.

“Such patients should be immediately shifted to Gandhi Hospital and paediatric cases should be shifted to Niloufer Hospital, where adequately trained teams, other requisite equipment and treatment facilities are ready,” stated a recent advisory.

Title: IMFL, beer worth Rs 20L seized in Surendranagar
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Rajkot: A total of 6 ,586 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) and 5,064 cans of beer worth Rs 20 lakh were seized in Olak village of Lakhtar taluka in Surendranagar district on Sunday night.

Police said the seizure was effected when the bootleggers were busy dividing their share of liquor bottles and beer cans.

“We had received a prior information about the bootleggers being scheduled to gather in Olak, following which we raided the spot. However, seeing us, the bootleggers abandoned their two SUVs and fled from the spot,” said Deepak Dhol, inspector with Surendranagar local crime branch.

Dhol said that the police investigation revealed that the liquor cache had been ordered by Vasant Vania and his nephew Deepak Vania.

“We have booked the Vania duo for the crime and launched a manhunt for them as well as the other bootleggers whose identities are yet to be ascertained,” added Dhol.

Title: Gujarat: Labour and rural labour commissionerates merged
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

GANDHINAGAR: The state labour and employment department has merged the rural labour commissionerate with the labour commissionerate.

The rural labour commissionerate was established in 1980 following recommendations of the Satem Commission in an attempt to ensure that unorganized agricultural workers get minimum wages as prescribed by the government under the Unorganised Workers' Social Security Act 2008. Offices of the labour officer and assistant labour officer are functioning in 33 districts and in 116 talukas respectively under the Gujarat rural labour commissionerate, Gandhinagar .

“The rural labour commissionerate was established for the benefit of agricultural workers. However, the government of India implemented the Unorganised Workers' Social Security Act 2008, which also covers agricultural workers. In view of the changed scenario, we feel there is no need to have a separate set up of rural labour commissionerate,” said Vipul Mittra, additional chief secretary, labour and employment department.

An official added that since employees of both the rural labour commissionerate and the labour commissionerate belong to a common cadre, there are unlikely to be any cadre-related service issues because of the merger. “This step will also address the issue of recruitment for the Gujarat state social welfare board,” he said.

Title: Kerala: 70-year-old arrested for molesting kid
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

Title: CBSE schedule derails plan for revision classes
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: City schools are struggling to conduct revision classes for class 10-12 students due to shortage of working days this academic year.

The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) advanced the board exams by nearly two weeks this year. As per the schedule released by the board, the exams will be held from February 15 this year as against March first-week conducted for the last few years. Not just that, the CBSE had also advanced the practical exams, which started on January 1 and will be held till February 7, cutting down another 15 days of revision period for students.

“For students struggling to cope up, we are calling them at 7:30am, an hour before the classes begin. Apart from this, we have rearranged our classes wherein we conduct only four periods of 90 minutes and focus on the core subjects,” said Simi Nagi, principal of Pallavi Model School, Alwal.

There are many schools which are calling students even on Sundays to conduct revision classes. Especially those who started academic session in June. Whereas, there are few others such as Delhi Public School (DPS), Nacharam, which are using technology to prepare students for the ensuing board exams.

“We are conducting live web-classes from our in-house studios wherein students can learn even by sitting at home. Teachers are available on call for an hour every evening to resolve students’ doubts apart from addressing queries on our internal student-teacher WhatsApp groups,” said Sunitha Rao, principal of DPS, Nacharam.

Adding to the misery were the number of working days that school managements in Telangana lost due to the RTC strike owing to which the state government had extended the Dasara holidays by a week. School managements rue that despite extending the number of holidays, the state government has not extended the SSC exam dates, thereby leaving them with insufficient time to conduct revision classes. As per schedule, the SSC board exams are scheduled to commence from March 19.

“Inconsistency in classes due to extended holidays has jeopardized students learning. Schools are forced to rush syllabus due to shortage of working days and are unable to conduct enough revision classes before commencement of exams,” said S Madhusudan, state general secretary of Telangana Recognised School Managements Association, adding that the government should have considered postponement of exams to March last week for this year.

Managements fear that revision classes and conducting back-to-back pre-board exams in within a tight time schedule may impact confidence and results of students.

Title: Life mission’s family meet and adalats begin in state
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Life housing mission has kicked off block-level family meetings and adalats.

The state-level inauguration of them was held at Varkala by minister for local self government A C Moideen.

The minister said life mission not only aims at giving homes to the homeless but also at bringing them to the mainstream by giving social and employment aid. He said CM Pinarayi Vijayan will declare completion of 2 lakh homes under life mission by January last week.

The minister also distributed keys of completed houses to the beneficiaries. The panchayats that showed good performance in implementing life mission were also honoured. K P Sabukuttan Nair, deputy CEO, life mission, presented the progress report of the mission.

The family meetings are convened to facilitate service of around 20 departments under the same umbrella. Services of local self government, agriculture, social justice, Kudumbasree, MGNREGS, SC/ST and health departments were made available during the adalats. The renewal of voter ID card and Aadhaar card-related services were also held.

Title: Poll code to delay several projects in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Election Commision of India

NEW DELHI: With the Election Commission announcing the dates for the Delhi assembly elections and the model code of conduct coming into effect, several civic and infrastructure projects are likely to be affected. Many projects in the city are nearing completion, but they cannot be inaugurated until the polls are over.

Some of the big PWD projects that will have to wait are Pragati Maidan redevelopment plan and Chandni Chowk redevelopment plan. Development of stack parking lots and guest housing policy will also be hit. “A lot of our projects will now be put on hold,” said a Public works department (PWD) official.

After construction ban, the poll code is likely to delay the Pragati Maidan redevelopment plan further. Work on it was scheduled to be completed by April 2020.

Some of the other projects that may face delay include Chandni Chowk pedestrianisation, redesigning of the nine arterial roads and decongesting city’s 77 problematic intersections and corridors.

The new Wi-Fi and CCTV spots will also not be inaugurated now that the MCC has been imposed, said a Delhi govt official.

Inauguration of five foot overbridges on the outer ring road was to be done in a few days, claim officials. But now, these FOBs cannot be thrown open to the public by Delhi government till February 11 midnight.

At three municipal corporations, work on several parking projects and improvement of roads will also get affected.

North Delhi Municipal Corporation, which had floated tenders for hiring the contractor to construct multilevel car parking lot at Shastri Park and Old Rajendra Nagar, can now issue work order only after February 11. “The parking projects are aimed at decongesting busy areas. But even if the responses to tenders are received by mid of January, we cannot issue work order now,” said a senior north corporation official. Work on improvement of internal roads may also be delayed.

In east Delhi, all five multilevel parking lots at Apsara Border, Preet Vihar (Aditya Arcade), Babarpur Road, Pushta Road and Nand Nagri will see further development only after February. These parking lots aimed to create additional space for 1,100 cars in east Delhi areas. “Work on the parking lots was pursued seriously to streamline traffic movement and management in prominent market places near them. But now, we have to wait for the completion of election process before taking any further decision,” said an EDMC official.

In south corporation, though various projects were given nod in last standing committee or house meeting, approval on important policies such as licensing policy for guesthouses, hotels and project for maintenance of road sweepers and suction machines will be given after elections. “We had finalised the licensing policy but there were certain bylaws which still needed to be verified,” said a senior SDMC official.

The poll code is also likely to affect work on stack parking near Waste to wonder park and progress on 15-20 automated multilevel stack parking facilities at Malviya Nagar, Janakpuri, Okhla and Nizamuddin.

Title: Debris will be sold quickly: Contractor
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

The dumping yard at Chandiroor in Aroor

KOCHI: When the questions about the removal of concrete waste from the four apartment complexes in Maradu becomes a concern as the dates for demolition approaches fast, the debris-removal contractor said that it will not be a problem for residents as there is high-demand for the debris for land-filling and construction of roads. Around 200 loads of pre-demolition debris which were dumped at the yard at Chandiroor in Aroor over the last one month has been used for land-filling at construction sites and roads at various parts of Ernakulam and Alappuzha districts. Sources at Prompt Enterprises, the debris-removal contractor, said that contractors have been approaching them to make advance bookings to buy the debris once the four buildings are demolished.

“The Pollution Control Board has given permission to use the yard for debris dumping and we are already taking measures like sprinkling water and covering the boundary with nets to prevent dust pollution. Now we have only 20 loads of debris here at the yard and the rest have been used for landfill at our construction sites. Also, more than 40 loads have been sold to private contractors. At a time when the scarcity of sand and soil becoming a big challenge for contractors who are engaged in landfilling the construction sites, the debris from the demolished flats will be helpful. So we don’t think the thousands of tonnes of debris post demolition will remain dumped here for long time causing pollution concerns,” said an official of Prompt Enterprises.

At present the debris is dumped at a 2.6acre yard situated at 200 metres from the National Highway in Chandiroor in Aroor panchayat. As the yard will not be sufficient to accommodate the debris post demolition, the contractor has leased out an 8-acre land near Kumbalam toll plaza. They said that concrete waste amounting to around 4000 loads (in large multi-axle trucks) is expected to be removed from the four demolition sites in Maradu. The contractor will also bring in a concrete recycling machine after the demolition to turn the waste into concrete powders which can be used for road laying and construction.

Meanwhile, the Aroor Panchayat officials said that they have not received any intimation about using the land within the panchayat for the debris dumping. “Some of the residents in the locality have raised concern about the pollution aspects. We were not intimated about the decision to dump the waste from Maradu here. We did not give any permission to the contractor too,” said Panchayat president Ratnamma.

Title: Joint family membership no basis to claim tenancy right: Bombay high court
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Bombay high court has ruled that a person cannot claim an independent right or inheritance of tenancy in a property merely by virtue of being a member of a joint family.

In a civil suit stretching over 38 years in relation to an old wada in Shukrawar Peth, the HC has upheld the Pune district court’s November 1, 1997, ruling, which directed five petitioner/occupants of two ground-floor and four first-floor rooms in the wada to evict the premises in favour of original landlords Yashwant Shankar Barve, his brother, Sadanand, and the latter’s wife, Sulabha — all three since deceased and represented by their legal heirs. The Barves initiated an eviction suit in Pune court on August 12, 1982.

On January 3, the HC bench of Justice G S Kulkarni dismissed the petition, holding that the same was ‘without any merit’ and gave the petitioners — Vasant Sadashiv Joshi and four others — six months to hand over the possession of the suit premises to the legal heirs of the original landlords.

“The petitioner/occupants now have the option of either vacating the premises on their own or move an appeal in the Supreme Court in which case, our clients will take a call on exercising their legal options,” lawyer Drupad Patil, who represented the landlords, told TOI on Monday.

The question dealt by the HC was whether the member of a joint family can claim an independent right or inheritance of tenancy in the suit premises when the tenant holding the rent receipt had himself shifted out of the premises.

The suit premises was taken on tenancy in 1937 by a joint Hindu family headed by Raghunath Joshi, who passed away in 1971. After Raghunath’s death, the rent receipt was transferred in the name of his son, Achyut, who shifted out to a property of his own in 1979. However, Raghunath’s brother, Sadashiv, continued to occupy the premises and after Sadashiv’s death in 1981, his eldest son, Vasant, and four siblings continued the occupation till date.

In their petition against the 1997 Pune court ruling, Vasant and his four siblings claimed, among other things, that the provisions under Section 5 (11) (c) (i) of the Bombay Rent Act recognised that every member of the joint family or the joint family itself becomes a tenant. The HC dismissed such interpretation by observing that the same had no legal foundation as the provisions would attract only when a tenant dies and, in the instant case, tenant Achyut was surviving and has moved out of the suit premises.

The bench also referred to the definition of a ‘tenant’ under the Act and held that recognising the petitioners’ claim would lead to an absurdity. “Firstly, it would amount to reading something into the definition of tenant, which has not been provided for and/or excluded by the legislature. Secondly, it would be contrary to the conduct of the parties who wholeheartedly accepted, chose and elected that the tenant for the suit premises after the death of Raghunath would be Achyut,” the bench said.

After Raghunath’s death and, again, after shifting out of Achyut from the suit premises, neither Sadashiv nor Vasant Joshi made any claim to the tenancy right, the bench said and further observed that recognising the claim would create insurmountable uncertainty for the landlords in pursuing eviction proceedings as every successive member of the family would claiming legal rights and protection under the Bombay Rent Act.

The bench finally held that there was no perversity in the findings as recorded by the (Pune) district judge and, that, the latter had correctly decreed the suit and had dismissed the petitioners’ appeal.

Title: Drunk Bhavnagar PSI abuses, assaults cops in Ahmedabad police station
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

AHMEDABAD: “How dare you touch me. I am a police official and will send you all in jail.” These were words of police sub-inspector M H Yadav (35), posted in Bhavnagar, when he was found sloshed outside a restaurant in Bhadaj area of Ahmedabad during wee hours of Monday.

Yadav, who is currently in-charge PI of Bharatnagar police station in Bhavnagar, was seen abusing people outside the restaurant. He is resident of Swagat Flamingo flat in Sargasan, Gandhinagar.

According to police, as Yadav continued bragging about his identity, constables of Sola High Court police station, who had reached there first, called up the second PI D H Gadhvi.

When Gadhvi tried to talk to Yadav, he told him that he was in-charge PI of Bharatagar in Bhavnagar and can’t be arrested.

Gadhvi first confirmed Yadav’s identity with other cops and then gathered panch witness who confirmed that Yadav was drunk. Yadav was taken to Sola high court police station, where he abused the cops.

When a PSI J J Rana tried to pacify him, Yadav abused and threatened him with dire consequences. At the same time, when one of the constables began writing the complaint, Yadav threatened to kill him and even physically assaulted him.

Other cops at the station, including first PI J P Jadeja and Gadhvi tried to stop Yadav who kept on abusing them and threatened to kill them, states the FIR.

Title: Chhindwara tops ‘multiparameter’ ranking of urban cities in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

BHOPAL: Focusing on comprehensive assessment of urban development, the MP government has released its own ranking.
