In contrast to the Union government rankings, MP urban administration and housing development (UAHD) rankings of municipal corporations has MP CM Kamal Nath’s assembly constituency Chhindwara on top, followed by Burhanpur and Dewas . Bhopal is rank of eighth and Indore is eleventh. The rankings, which assess cities on six broad parameters, were released on Sunday.

“The rankings are to basically get a balanced view on urban development. Currently, the focus has been only on Swachh rankings. Our methodology is also to include other programmes of urban development,” said MP UAHD principal secretary, Sanjay Dubey.

Interestingly, Gwalior and Jabalpur divisions are at the bottom of the rankings, similar to overall rankings of the Union government. MP urban development minister Jaivarshan Singh’s assembly constituency is in Gwalior division.

Drawing focus and evaluating performance of municipal commissioners, the MP UAHD has tagged multiple parameters besides weightage to Swachh Bharat only. Compared to the MP UAHD ranking, the Union government's Swachh ranking has Indore as the cleanest city in India and Bhopal as cleanest capital city. The two cities are also among the most liveable, going by the Union government’s ease of living index.

The MP UAHD ranking is based on assessment of wider criteria, including cleanliness, implementation of project under AMRUT, housing development and urban livelihoods mission and smart city development. Chhindwara scored 77.52 out of 100 points. Burhanpur from a non-ODF city, in November got an ODF++ certification, scored 70.44, ahead of Dewas which got 69.40 points.

“Burhanpur has improved on various accounts of project development. A comprehensive sewage networking project is underway along projects funded under AMRUT,” said Burhanpur municipal commissioner, Bhagwandas Bhumarkar. Similarly, focused development of Chhindwara has meant that tax collection efficiency of the corporation has improved, along with implementation of various urban development projects.

Interestingly, none of the top three cities are part of the Union government’s smart cities' mission. MP, as a state, has the most number of smart cities in India. The top performing city with smart cities' tag, was Ujjain with a score of 66.89 and is ranked fourth. Bhopal, at rank 8, got 62.35 points. It scored the least number of points on implementation of housing schemes, including Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana and CM housing mission. Overall, Bhopal performed well on smart city implementation, with Indore still taking the top slot in Swachh Bharat Mission. However, Indore’s tax collection efficiency was rated as the worst.

Title: Kutch West police install feedback machines
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: To evaluate the behaviour of police personnel while dealing with common people, Kutch West Police have installed machines called Public Response Tracking Information by Help of Assessment by Visitors (Pratibhav). The machines have been installed at the Bhuj city police station and B division police station in the pilot project.

SP West Kutch, Saurabh Tolambiya, said this is the first-of-its-kind project in the state. An official said that the machine has four buttons. “The first is the start button. The other buttons are Good (Uttam), Average, and Poor,” the official said. “People’s feedback will directly reach the SP’s office and the control room.”

Tolambiya said that over the past three days, police have received 75 submissions. Of these, 59 have been Uttam, 15 average, and 1 poor.

“We have taken care that cops themselves do not press the Uttam button,” Tolambiya said. “We have installed CCTV cameras on the machines in such a way that the back of a person is seen but not the response.”

Tolambiya said that the responses will be used to take corrective measures and to ensure that common people who visit police stations are treated well. Tolambiya said it is important that trust is developed between police and people.

Title: JNU violence: Indian Medical Association condemns violence against doctors
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: The Indian Medical Association (IMA) has issued a statement condemning the “mindless violence on doctors and nurses who rushed to treat injured in JNU”. This is the third such statement coming from IMA headquarters in the capital blaming the state and law enforcers.

Last month, the IMA had issued a statement that all violence is unacceptable, especially those perpetrated by the state on people who require medical attention.

“The situation in the country smacks of total anarchy and breakdown of law and order is complete. If doctors and nurses are not safe in the capital of the country, it speaks volumes about the governance or lack of it,” the statement issued on Monday by IMA national president Dr Rajan Sharma and secretary general Dr RV Asokan read.

“How does it reflect on the nation if it cannot protect its doctors and nurses reaching out to the injured? Is this a civil war? What is the message that goes out to the world?” asked the medical body.

IMA reiterated its stand that doctors and nurses have the right of way to treat the injured and that everyone had the right to life and access to care. The IMA headquarters directed its Delhi state branch to react strongly and take appropriate action.

In an earlier statement issued on December 22 last year, IMA referred to police storming into a hospital in Karnataka’s Mangaluru. “This is a new low in the civic life of the nation but not entirely unexpected given the impunity with which violence is heaped on doctors and hospitals. However, the difference this time is that it is the establishment which has lost its restraint,” said the IMA, adding that no violence was acceptable in a hospital as “hospitals are sacrosanct and are exempted even in a war zone”.

The government and its establishment have no right to deny anyone their right to access, said the statement adding that it stood for retaining hospitals as safe zones. It went on to state that Indian doctors would never let down anyone who required care and that no politics could dilute this resolve of the IMA.

Dr Asokan has also written a piece titled New Truth on the IMA national general secretary’s page, in which he states: “Whatever may be the New Truth, medical profession and the values by which it survives stand still in Time. The patient is just another human being. S/he does not have another identity ….The colour, creed and ideology of the patient is immaterial. Hospital is an institution which reflects and radiates this core value. Any temporal authority is constrained by this Lakshman Rekha.”

Title: Telangana auto unions to go ahead with strike on January 8
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representational Image

HYDERABAD: A day after central trade unions held a meeting with the labour minister, the auto unions in Telangana , on Sunday, said they will go ahead with the strike on January 8 to protest anti-labour policies of the government.

All the 10 central trade unions conveyed their firm resolve on ‘Bharat Bandh’ after meeting the labour minister. “We stand with central trade unions as the minister did not address any issues being faced by the workers. The unions were just told that steps are being taken for welfare of workers,” said Satti Reddy, convenor of JAC.

The auto unions JAC also released a poster that will be pasted on the autos, announcing their participation in the strike. “Apart from demanding increase in meter charges and setting up of welfare associations for auto drivers, we are going on a one-day strike to fight for the rightful implementation of labour laws that favour the workers,” said Reddy.

Title: Disabled protest against AMC for failing to pay honorarium
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Aurangabad: Members of the Prahar Apang Kranti Andolan launched an agitation in front of the civic administration on Monday and and warned of continuing their protest till chief minister Uddhav Thackeray’s visit to the city on Thursday until the AMC fulfilled the demands of the people with disabilities (PwDs).

The district unit of Prahar Apang Kranti Andolan submitted a memorandum to the municipal commissioner stating that most PwDs registered in the city had not been paid their honorarium from the funds reserved for disabled people. The activists of the outfit have held several agitations in the past, after which the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) started releasing the honorarium to the PwDs.

District chief of Prahar Apang Kranti Andolan, Shivaji Gade, said that the agitation would not be withdrawn until and unless the money was deposited in the accounts of PwDs. The state government mandates local bodies to reserve 5% of their total budget for the welfare and rehabilitation of PwDs.

According to mayor Nandkumar Ghodele, there are 2,107 PwDs in the city registered with the AMC. The honorarium for 468 PwDs has been released and the process of releasing the payment for another 650 of them was underway. “The civic body is cash-strapped and is unable to release the payment for all PwDs. Many of the disabled people registered with the AMC are from the talukas, they are not our responsibility. ,” said Ghodele.

Title: Cold to take a break in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, say IMD officials
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Temperature to rise from Tuesday

AHMEDABAD: After a short spell of cold, the city and state will experience warmer days with both minimum and maximum temperatures above average on Monday.

According to India meteorological department (IMD) website, Ahmedabad on Monday recorded the maximum temperature of 28.4°C and minimum temperature of 13.6°C.

The figures were 0.7 degrees and 0.8 degrees higher than the average, according to the website. On Tuesday, the minimum temperature is likely to reach 15°C.

“The rise in temperature is due to change in wind directions. After northerly winds, the state is again experiencing northeasterly winds. On Monday, the past 24 hours’ data indicated that except Naliya, which recorded 8.5°C minimum temperature, all the weather stations recorded above 10°C of minimum temperature,” said an IMD official, adding that they don’t expect any major change in minimum temperature for Tuesday and Wednesday.

Officials added that this winter, they have observed cyclic trend in temperature rise in the region.

“For Ahmedabad, the trend has shown fall in average day temperature and rise in night temperature.

The coastal areas have also recorded largely 10 degrees-plus minimum temperature,” said an official.

In northern and central Gujarat, Deesa was the coldest with 10.8°C, followed by Ahmedabad (13.6°C), VV Nagar (13°C) and Gandhinagar (14°C).

Title: AMC to push for Thackeray memorial during CM’s visit
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Aurangabad: The civic administration will push for the establishment of the Babasaheb Thackeray memorial and the implemention of the water supply project among other key issues during CM Uddhav Thackeray’s visit to the city scheduled for later this week.

Mayor and Sena corporator Nandkumar Ghodele said on Monday that Thackeray would lend an ear to the issues plaguing the city in his capacity as the state CM for the first time. “Presentations on various projects funded by the government like the Rs 100 crore road project, underground drainage project, conservation of nine historic gates, Smart City and Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojana will be given to the CM,” said Ghodele.

The CM, along with cabinet ministers Eknath Shinde and Subhash Desai, will attend a meeting at the Government guest house at 3.45pm on Thursday.

“We have five key demands that we will present before the CM—establishment of the Balasaheb Thackeray memorial, implementation of the Rs 1,680 crore-water supply scheme on priority basis, approval for the Rs 267 crore-road project, installation of the raised statue of Shivaji Maharaj at Kranti Chowk and renovation of Sant Eknath Rangmandir,” said Ghodele. The civic body will be needing funds from the state government for all these projects.

On Friday, Thackeray will visit Priyadarshini Garden in Cidco N-6 to see the location where AMC has decided to raise Balasaheb Thackeray’s memorial. Ghodele said that the civic body would inform the CM about a mural of Balasaheb Thackeray, which it would install at Swami Dayanand Saraswati Chowk on January 22.

The CM’s visit is significant for the AMC as the elections for the civic body are due in March-April this year. The public representatives, especially those in majority, want faster completion of ongoing projects and approval for new ones.

Title: Hyderabad to get woman mayor; quota for civic bodies finalised
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The first citizen of Greater Hyderabad will be a woman when elections are conducted to the biggest urban local body, which manages the state capital. Reservation matrix (for SCs, STs, BCs and women) for municipalities and municipal corporations, including Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), in the state were announced on Sunday. The reservation matrix will be in place for two terms.

Elections for 120 municipalities and 10 municipal corporations will be held on January 22.

This is the first time GHMC mayor post has been reserved for women after the formation of Telangana. Earlier, two women had served as mayors in the city. Sarojini Pulla Reddy of Congress was the first woman mayor of Municipal Corporation of Hyderabad in 1965, while Banda Karthika Reddy, also of Congress, was the first woman mayor of GHMC (2009) in the undivided AP.

GHMC mayor’s seat, which is presently reserved for BCs and held by B Rammohan of TRS, has been reserved for a woman from open category (OC) in the draw of lots held on Sunday to fix the quota for women in 123 municipalities and 13 municipal corporations.

Municipal administration director TK Sridevi announced names of wards, divisions, chairpersons and mayor posts reserved for SCs, STs, BCs and women and said the quota would be in place for two terms. While SC and ST quota was finalised in proportion to their population, BC reservations were fixed on the basis of voter numbers. Women seats were reserved through draw of lots.

Sridevi said BCs got between 30-33% reservations in municipalities and municipal corporations after SC and ST quota was fixed. “We ensured the SC-fixed cap of not exceeding over all reservation beyond 50% was complied with,” Sridevi said.

The government finalised reservations for all mayor posts despite polls not being conducted in GHMC, Greater Warangal Municipal Corporation and Khammam Municipal Corporation. For municipal chairpersons’ posts in 123 municipalities, the officials reserved four seats for STs, 17 for SCs, 40 for BCs and 62 for general. About 50% posts have been reserved for women in the exercise done on the basis of the 2011 Census data.

Title: Pune: Duo held for snatching cellphone
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A robbery victim’s sharp memory helped the Chikhali police solve a cellphone-snatching case and arrest the suspects within 24 hours of the crime.

A police team led by sub-inspector Dnyaneshwar Dhangar on Sunday arrested Deepak Rajguru (24) and Harshad Mane (24) from Nigdi Ota Scheme on the charge of snatching the cellphone of Raju Behera (19) of Rupinagar in Talawade on Saturday.

Dhangar said Behera was walking towards Rupinagar when two bike-borne men stopped him near Triveninagar Chowk. “They then snatched his cellphone worth Rs 10,000 and fled,” he said.

He said Behera promptly approached the police and gave the detailed description of the duo with the registration number of their motorcycle. “These crucial details helped us trace the suspects, leading to their arrest,” Dhangar said.

Title: Flyers fume over 14-hour delay of GoAir flight to Kolkata
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Passengers stranded on the tarmac in Bhubaneswar airport.

PUNE: As many as 162 passengers of a GoAir flight to Kolkata, slated to take off from the Lohegaon airport at 10.25pm on Sunday, went through over a 16-hour-long ordeal because of rescheduling after the boarding was completed and diversion to Bhubaneswar due to poor visibility in Bengal capital.

Worse, the flyers were made to sit in the aircraft for an hour in Bhubaneswar. They spent two more hours on the tarmac before being taken to the terminal building there.

The flight (G8 394) was slated to take off from Pune at 10.25pm on Sunday and land in Kolkata at 12.50am on Monday. It finally reached the destination around 2.50pm on Monday — a delay of 14 hours.

A GoAir spokesperson said, “GoAir flight G8 394 from Pune to Kolkata was diverted to Bhubaneswar because of bad weather in Kolkata. The flight landed safely with 162 passengers on-board in Bhubaneswar. All passengers were deplaned, transferred to the terminal building and offered refreshments during the delay. However, this was aggravated with Flight Duty Time Limitation (FDTL) of the crew, which led to a further delay in departure from Bhubaneswar. GoAir sincerely regrets any inconvenience caused to its passengers.”

Debjani Chatterjee, one of the flyers, told TOI, “We boarded the plane on time in Pune and remained seated in the aircraft for around half-an-hour. At 11pm, we were told to de-board. We went back to the terminal building. After a while, we were told that the flight had been delayed and would depart at 1.30am.”

The flight did finally take off at 1.30am for Kolkata, but more hassles were in store for the flyers.

“When we were about to reach the destination, there was an announcement from the deck that the flight could not land at Kolkata because of poor visibility. The flight then landed in Bhubaneswar at 4.40am. It seemed the cabin crew and other officials of the airline had no clue as to what was going on and we remained seated in the aircraft for an hour after landing in Bhubaneswar.”

Chatterjee said a woman flyer’s relative was in a serious condition in Kolkata. “While we were waiting, she got information over the phone that her relative had passed away. She pleaded with the airline staffers to do something as she had to reach Kolkata, but they could not help her,” Chatterjee said.

After an hour, the aircraft’s doors were opened and the passengers de-boarded.

Chatterjee said the passengers were then left stranded on the tarmac for around two hours. “At one point, I heard someone saying there was a snag in the aircraft. Then someone said the diversion had happened because of low fuel. No refreshments were served to the passengers. At 7.30am, the airline’s staffers told passengers to go to the terminal building. We were told that the plane will take off around 11.30am on Monday after a fresh set of crew arrived,” she said.

The plane got delayed further. “It finally took off at 1.30pm on Monday and landed in Kolkata around 2.50pm.

Chandan Mondal, another passenger, tweeted, “My grandma expired. Flight delayed more than 12 hours. Many travelling for exam, someone for medical emergency. Why Indian government doesn’t have solutions to handle any emergency?”

Title: CM Pinarayi Vijayan terms violence on JNU campus Nazi-style attack
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CM Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan compared Sunday’s riot on JNU campus to a ‘Nazi-style attack’ intended to create an atmosphere of fear in India. “Sangh Parivar should end this diabolical plan to silence universities with bloodshed,” he said. Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said the JNU attack exposed the extent of fascism threat in the country.

AISF, CPI’s student union, has called for a statewide strike by boycotting classes on Tuesday, in solidarity with students of JNU.

Vijayan while condemning the JNU attacks said the attack on the students and faculty of JNU is an appalling display of intolerance running amok. The attackers intend to create an atmosphere of unrest and terror in the country.

“The scale of the attack reveals the extent of planning that went into it. Sangh Parivar must end this diabolical plan to silence universities with bloodshed. Remember, those students are speaking for all,” he said.

Chennithala said the Sangh Parivar should not be under the impression that those who are opposing them could be suppressed using brutal attacks. “The people of this country would come out in open in large numbers to protest against their high-handedness,” he added.

“Both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union home minister Amit Shah are providing silent support to the perpetrators of crime. Two girls had protested against the house-to-house campaign carried out by Shah in New Delhi. This should be seen as the provocation behind the attack against the JNU students,” said Chennithala.

While condemning the attack on the teachers and students of the most prestigious university of the country, Chennithala said it shows the intolerance of BJP and Sangh Parivar against the protests coming out from an institution which has churned out many eminent personalities including Nobel laureates.

Former KPCC president V M Sudheeran said the police remained mute spectators when the attack was carried out against the students, which shows the silent support of the administration for the attack. “The police in New Delhi is directly under the control of Shah and hence he cannot run away from the responsibility of the attack,” said Sudheeran.

Title: Maharashtra govt directs PMC to enforce parking policy without delay
Content:
PMC said a paid parking system will be in place on some major roads.

TimesView Why does the civic body need a push from the government to implement its own policy? As the authorities continue to drag their feet on the issue, the wide ‘smart’ footpaths and the cycle tracks on them have become parking havens in the city. A major part of the Balgandharva bridge is blocked by parked cars. Even the Z bridge has not been spared. Private bus operators are seen finding new spots to park their vehicles illegally. It is time to implement the parking rules in letter and spirit.

PUNE: The state government has directed the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) to implement the parking policy, which was passed by its general body in March last year.The direction follows non-governmental organisation (NGO) Parisar writing to the then Devendra Fadnavis-led government in the state in August last year, insisting on the policy implementation in the city.Through a letter, the urban development department of the state government directed PMC to implement the parking policy in September last year. The letter stated, “The policy must be implemented at the level of the PMC immediately.”The NGO received a copy of the letter on December 31 last year. Parisar representatives said the Union government made the parking policy implementation one of the pre-conditions for the approval of the Pune Metro .Parisar founder Sujit Patwardhan said the issue was raised with the previous mayor and municipal commissioner on several occasions, but to no avail. Parisar’s Ranjit Gadgil said, “The power to decide about the parking charges on city roads rests completely with the municipal commissioner as per the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act. As per section 243A of the Act, the general body has the power to approve the parking fees.”When contacted, mayor Murlidhar Mohol said the policy would come into force soon. “It has been decided by PMC to identify some major roads in the city where pay and park will be implemented first. Subsequently, it will be enforced in other parts of the city,” he said.Traffic expert Pranjali Deshpande, who worked on the policy, said fees were an effective way of not only reducing private vehicle use but also ensuring that available parking spaces were efficiently used.

Title: Villagers budget to keep girls from dropping out of college
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: Worried about their girls giving up studies because the daily 10km walk to college had become unbearable, these villagers from Nashik district decided to step in.

Nearly 211 girls from Vadner Bhairav, a village located off the Nashik–Mumbai highway in Chandwad taluka, attend colleges located at least four kilometres away. Villagers and college authorities noticed that almost 50% of these girls don’t attend college regularly as they cannot afford the Rs 2,000 annual fees for the college bus service.

They decided to give the girls’ education a push. In a general body meeting of the village in December 2019, it was decided that the women and child welfare committee would bear the transport cost of these 211 girls, effective from this month. Moreover, the panel will fund the college travel — be it the larger town of Pimpalgaon or even Nashik, about 45km away — of all girls in the village for the next five years.

“None of the girls studying in colleges — even as far as Nashik city — will have to worry about the transportation cost. The women and child welfare committee of the village has decided to foot the bill. The decision will be applicable for the next five years,” Raosaheb Gaikwad, deputy sarpanch of the village, said.

The 28,000 residents of the village decided to come together so that their girls do not drop out. The village local governing body has revenue collection of Rs 60 lakh. The 17-member of body of the village has nine women members, and it adopted the resolution for financing the transportation.

“There are many girls, who have left their colleges, and limited themselves to farming and other activities largely because they cannot afford the travel expenses for studies. We, therefore, decided to make the things easier for them,” Gaikwad said.

The college, run by Maratha Vidya Prasarak Samaj, has started a bus on no-profit, no-loss basis exclusively for the girls. The vehicle is equipped with the global positioning system and closed circuit television cameras. The annual fee of the bus is Rs 2,000 for every student.

Vaishali Patil, who attends college now, couldn’t suppress her excitement. “This initiative will encourage girls to study more and be capable of steering their own career in various fields. We hope this initiative will continue and not face any opposition.”

Roshan Suryawanshi, the village development officer, said they had noticed that 103 girls would skip classes for the sole reason that they are unable to walk 10 km daily to and from the college. “Many other girls quit college because of the same reason. The women and child welfare body then decided to take up the responsibility of bearing the cost of their college travel,” he said.

He added that they have already presented the cheque for the travel cost of all the 211 girls from their village to the college authorities. “We chose the bus service because it has safety features and the college will take the other responsibilities as well,” Suryawanshi said.

The village has also adopted the resolution of providing the monthly pass for all the girls taking lessons in Pimpalgaon or Nashik city. The cost of the pass of the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) bus will be borne by the village. In order to ensure the funding does not stop, the budgetary allocation has been made.

Title: ‘Termination illegal’, Muthoot employees strike work again
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Citing the dismissal of 166 employees, including the secretary of Muthoot Finance Employees Union, employees of Muthoot Finance have launched another indefinite strike .

According to MP Elamaram Kareem, CITU state secretary, the management had terminated 166 employees and closed 43 branches as a retaliatory action against the 52-day strike organized by the union members in August and September, last year. “The management identified union members, including the secretary, and the branches in which they worked. They have decided to close only those branches. This is a clear violation of the prior agreement and amounts to contempt of court,” said Kareem in a news conference on Saturday.

MFEU is a part of Non Banking and Private Finance Association , which is organising the strike in front of the head office of Muthoot Finance in Kochi. Employees from all the 564 branches of Muthoot are participating in the indefinite strike in support of the dismissed employees.

Kareem said Muthoot management does not have an employee-friendly attitude and they have constantly tried to dismantle the union. “In August, the employees began a strike demanding minimum wages for the employees of non-banking sector. The management did not pay any heed to the needs of the employees. They sent officers who did not have any power to make any decision in the dispute settlement and compromise meetings. They are blinded by the arrogance of their wealth,” said Kareem.

He also said the termination of 166 employees was a direct violation of the tripartite agreement reached upon on October 10, last year.

“The management had assured that they will not take any action against the employees who took part in the strike. The memorandum, which recorded the conditions of compromise, clearly states all these conditions. These employees have been dismissed without any reason,” he added.

Around 3,000 Muthoot employees were on strike from August 20, last year, he said, adding: “It is actually a shame that a company, which boasts about their large gold reserves and a profit of Rs 2,106 crore, is not paying minimum wages to their own employees who made these achievements possible.”

Former MLA V Sivankutty alleged that a few former IPS officers were trying to interfere in this strike.

“Some former IPS officers are now working as security counsellors for Muthoot. They are free to do any job they desire. But I don’t understand why they are trying to interfere in these matters,” said Sivankutty.

Title: Charges framed in actor rape case
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kochi: Ernakulam additional special session court on Monday framed charges against actor Dileep and nine other accused in the actor rape case.

Dileep and the other accused including first accused Pulsar Suni appeared in court. Suni reached late since he was brought from central prison at Viyyur in Thrissur.

Later, relevant portions from the chargesheet, submitted by the special investigation team, was read to the accused behind closed doors. The accused pleaded innocence in the case. The procedure was completed within an hour.

When the court asked them when the trial into the case could start, the counsels of the accused informed three dates. Counsels of Dileep and Pulsar Suni requested the court to start trial on January 29 and 27 respectively. However, the prosecution requested for the trial to begin by January 27. The court will decide the date to start trail on Tuesday.

Dileep is the eighth accused in the case. Martin Antony, Vijesh, Salim, Pradeep, Charly Thomas, Sanal Kumar and Vishnu are the other accused.

The prosecution will file the list of witnesses in the case on Tuesday. There are 359 witnesses in the case. The court will examine 616 documents and 250 material objects during trail in the case.

Dileep had filed a petition in the court requesting to discharge him from the case. The court had dismissed his plea.

The case is related to a Malayalam actress being raped in a moving vehicle on February 17, 2017 by goons and a video was recorded of the attack.

The court had allowed the accused to watch the video at a joint session in the court following directions from the Supreme Court. The accused had approached the Supreme court requesting them to be allowed to watch the video. Dileep had even requested the court to allow him to watch the video alone, which the court refused to hear.

The accused, their counsels, prosecution and the judge watched the video. An IT expert representing Dileep too watched the visuals in eight clips.

Title: Gujarat: Neighbours fight over TikTok video
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In a bid to shoot an action video on TikTok cellphone application, a 22-year-old man took a wooden stick to make the video which did not go well with their neighbours who began abusing the man. Soon, the man’s family and his neighbour’s family indulged in a brawl in Madhavpura area.

In her FIR with Madhavpura police, Shobhna Koshti, 47, a resident of Narsinh Temple Chawl in Madhavpura, said that she on Sunday evening heard noise outside her house. When she went out, she saw her neighbours Rekha Koshti and other family members beating Shobhna’s son Karan, 22.

As she tried to rescue her son, Rekha pulled her hair and thrashed Shobhna also. At that time, Rekha’s other family members also attacked Shobhna and her son Karan. After that, she called up police and filed a complaint with the Madhavpura police.

Karan told cops that he was shooting a video on TikTok with other friends. During which, Rekha had come there and began taking away a wooden stick which he had kept as a prop to make an impressive video. Karan told Rekha not to take away the stick but she allegedly began abusing him alleging that he only shoots videos and does not focus on work. The heated arguments took an ugly turn when Rekha’s family members started beating Karan.

Title: Plastic use: SCB to penalise erring shops
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: The Secunderabad Cantonment Board is getting ready to penalise erring shopkeepers over single-use plastic despite a ban on its usage.While the penalties will be in three categories, one such penalty would invite a jail term for three months, officials warned.A fine of Rs 5,000 will be imposed if a shopkeeper is caught red-handed during raids by the Cantonment board officials. A fine of Rs 10,000 will be collected if a shopkeeper is found committing an offence for a second time. For a third-time offence, the culprit will have to pay Rs 25,000 fine and undergo three-month imprisonment.Soon after orders on single-use plastic ban came into force in July last year, SCB gave five months’ time to the shopkeepers to start implementing the ban orders strictly. “Raids will be conducted from next week on all commercial properties in the Cantonment and penalties will be imposed. In all, 5,200 commercial properties, including shopping malls, hotels and restaurants, chain-link shops and eateries, butcher shops and wine shops are running businesses in SCB limits,” SCB solid waste management (SWM) superintendent M Devender told TOI.While implementing the ban orders, raids will also be conducted on 17 commercial godowns where plastic and thermocol are used for packaging home and electronic appliances, officials said. “We conducted raids on 20 commercial properties recently and seized plastic material,” Devender said. Sources said the raids would be intensifed till all the shopkeepers fall in line and completely stop using plastic.SCB is also making efforts to educate shopkeepers by taking up a vigorous campaign against single-use plastic. “We will also tell them about the various categories of penalties being collected by the board,” an official explained.Meanwhile, self-help group women members have begun making paper bags and selling them to shopkeepers. “Though we did not conduct any survey on usage of plastic, we received feedback from the residents that over 60% of the shopkeepers have begun using jute and paper bags. This is a good sign,” an official added.

Title: Haryana: 15 farmers booked
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

HISAR: Hisar police have registered a case against 15 farmers from Shishwala village for allegedly stealing water for irrigation and attacking canal department guard in. Police have started the investigation but so far no arrest has been made. Sadar police station has registered a case on the complaint of Mandeep Kumar, a resident of Arya Nagar of Hisar and a beldar at irrigation department against Raman, Rajesh, Dholu, Dalbir and 10 to 12 unidentified farmers, all from Shishwala village of Hisar district .

Title: Sargotsavam- Second day
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Kozhikode: Sargotsavam , the three-day state arts festival of students of model residential schools and pre-matric hostels, run by the scheduled tribes development department, turned out to be a platform for tribal children to showcase their talent and culture.

Though the festival underway at East Hill was devoid of the hype and extravagance characteristic of the competitions in the state school arts festivals, Sargotsavam stood out for the enthusiasm of the participants and the talent displayed by the students.

Spirited performances by students in drama, mimicry and traditional folk song competitions were the highlights on the second day of the fest. At the end of day two, Dr Ambedkar Memorial Government Model Residential School was leading with 78 points followed by Dr Ambedkar Vidyanikethan CBSE school at Njaraneeli in Thiruvananthapuram with 77 points.

The fest was formally inaugurated on Sunday by state labour minister T P Ramakrishnan. He said Sargotsavam will ensure that the traditional arts forms which are unique to the state do not go extinct. He added that the students are playing a big role in keeping alive various art forms.

The minister said that the state government had rolled out several welfare schemes for the welfare of students belonging to the SC/ST categories.

“Under the Gotra Bandu educational scheme drawn up to address the language barrier among Scheduled Tribe students, 241 people have been appointed as teachers in Wayanad and 25 in Attappadi. Also ‘Padanamuris’ equipped with library, computer, furniture, TV, internet connection and white board are being set up near tribal hamlets,” the minister added.

He said efforts are underway to construct new buildings for 16 educational institutions including MRS hostels and ITIs.

Title: Chennai students protest, stand by JNU peers
Content: Protestors demanded arrest of the perpetrators and resignation of JNU vice-chancellor for the attack that l... Read More CHENNAI: Students from IIT Madras, University of Madras and Presidency College have joined their fellow students across the country in condemning the attack on students and teachers at the Jawarharlal Nehru University (JNU) by unidentified people.Besides expressing solidarity with JNU students, they demanded arrest of the perpetrators and resignation of JNU vice-chancellor for the attack that left 34 students and faculty members injured.As soon as news of the protest in IIT Madras emerged, the administration swung into action. A lecture by neurobiologist Colin Blakemore as part of Shaastra ended without the question-and-answer session for “external reasons”.Students gathered at the Central Lecture Theatre (CLT) and took out a rally from Gajendra Circle to the Himalaya lawns.“We raised slogans condemning the attack on students by Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) goons on JNU students and expressed our solidarity. JNU vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar and the central government are responsible for the attack,” a student from ChintaBar, a student body at IIT-Madras said.A student from the Ambedkar Periyar Study Circle (APSC) said, “We are demanding arrest of the goons who attacked JNU students.”A section of students from University of Madras protested condemning the attacks. “We demand the action against ABVP for this attack. Our protest will continue on Tuesday till the attackers get arrested,” a student said.DMK MP Kanimozhi met the students the university and extended her support. A group of students from Presidency College also protested. Some students protested near Chennai collectorate against the attack.Academicians and alumni of JNU expressed shock over the incident. Ramu Manivannan, a professor from the department of political science at University of Madras, said, “It’s a very organised political violence meant to curb the freedom of expression and to create fear among students and crush their voices.”C Lakshmanan, an associate professor from Madras Institute of Development Studies and a JNU alumnus, said the violence was unprecedented in the history of JNU.“The masked goons were brought from outside to the campus and the orchestrated violence that went on for more than an hour is shocking. As a JNU alumnus, it was painful. I felt shaken,” he said.Lakshmanan said the “ruling dispensation” is unleashing violence against students and faculty members of JNU. “It is an attempt to quell the peaceful student protests,” he said.Another alumni of JNU and a retired professor said the attack was “objectionable” and the campus had always been a “place for healthy debate”. “Violence in any form cannot be tolerated,” he said.

Title: Whip on power theft adds Rs 1 cr to MSEDCL kitty
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Nashik: The year-long action against power thefts in Nashik circle had borne fruit, added over Rs one crore to the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited ( MSEDCL ) revenue collection.

Pravin Daroli, superintendent engineer of Nashik, had launched a special drive against power theft on January 6, 2019. Till December 31, 2019, the office had detected 246 thefts with the assessment of Rs 86.95 lakh. Taking into account the compounding amount of Rs 14.19 lakh, the total collection through the action was Rs 1.07 core. These cases of thefts do not include the ones carried out by the flying squads of the MSEDCL.

MSEDCL official said the assessment is the amount charged by electricity company for the power thefts, while the compounding amount is the one that is paid to the government (by the accused). The compounding cost is paid only for the first case of power theft by a person, considering that it may be an error. In case of repeat offence, an First Information Report (FIR) is filed.

“I had planned to carry out the drive against power thefts at my level. Hence, I took the support of the officials ans used IT to zero in on the power thefts,” Daroli said.

The team swung into action from the first month of 2019 and set target for themselves. The teams analysed the data of the bills of consumers from all subdivisions to identify those with irregular power consumption.

“Our first factor was irregular consumption – it could be due to failure of the meter or because of tampering and there was no third reason. Once those were listed, a soft enquiry was carried out to figure out if the consumer was staying here regularly or not,” the officer said.

The officer pointed out that most of the cases were related to slow meters, which were running from 30% to 80% of the capacity. The other instances of thefts had some other reasons.

About 11 cases were such that the consumers used a remote slow down the units of the meter, while there were at least 15 consumers who bypassed the meters to ensure power consumption was not recorded. There were also the consumers whose power connections were permanently disconnected, but they were still drawing power – either directly from overhead lines or clandestinely from the nearest distribution point.

Title: 12 from SPPU selected for R-Day parade
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Pune: Twelve students from several colleges affiliated to Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) have been selected for the Republic Day parade to be held in Mumbai.

The students are National Service Scheme volunteers. The candidates must report at the Kalina Sports Complex in Mumbai on January 17.

The selected candidates are Akash Malode (SP College), Akash Renuse, Deepak Naikawde (H V Desai), Nikhilesh Shivtare (Kaveri College), Gitesh Dinger (Modern College), Mahesh Daale (NC and SC, Shevgaon), Pratiksha Jadhav (Shardabai Pawar Women's College), Suprita Thorat (SSC College, Junnar), Archana Gadhadhe (B A College, Pathardi), Shraddha Gaikwad (Ness Wadia), Anu Kongare (SITS College, Narhe) and Vishakha Kachare (MMCC).

Title: Pune: Two detained in footwear shop owner murder case
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Two persons were detained on Monday night for questioning in connection with the murder of a footwear shop owner after the city police studied CCTV footage and technical data to obtain vital clues about the assailants.

Police refused to disclose information about the duo and their link, if any, to the crime.

The victim, Chandan Krupadas Shewani (48) of Sadhu Vaswani Chowk, was found shot dead at Padegaon village near Lonand in Satara district on Sunday morning. His shop was on Laxmi road. The post-mortem report revealed he suffered two bullet injuries.

The police said the people who kidnapped Shewani late on Saturday night killed him for some reason without waiting for ransom. “We have arrived at the conclusion that the note stating ‘Rs2 crore nahi diya iske liye gaya, bhai ke order pe thokna pada’ (He did not give us Rs2 crore, hence, we had to eliminate him on boss’ order) was kept near Shewani’s body to mislead the police probe,” a senior officer said.

DCP (Zone II) Shirish Sardeshpande said the probe was heading to the right direction and the police had obtained many clues in the case.

The crime branch and the Bund Garden police teams collected CCTV footage from various locations of Laxmi Road, Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Road and Maldhakka Chowk. “Our teams are still studying the footage and we shall definitely find clues from them,” the senior officer said.

Shewani was a bachelor. He stayed with his parents and sister at Sadhu Vaswani Chowk.

He had left his shop “Shiv Kailas Shoes” around 10pm on Saturday for home in his black sedan but did not reach home. His sister, Sangeeta Krupadas Shewani, lodged a missing person’s report with the Bund Garden police in the wee hours of Sunday.

Title: Hyderabad: Restrict use of loudspeakers near schools, demand child rights activists
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

HYDERABAD: Child-rights activists asked the state to restrict use of loudspeakers near schools during campaigning for civic elections , as students will be preparing for exams. They said although loudspeakers are prohibited up to 100 meters near educational institutions and hospitals, rules are not being followed.

“To ensure that students don’t face any inconvenience, loudspeakers should be restricted near schools,” said Achyuta Rao of Balala Hakkula Sangham, adding that display boards reading silent zone should be erected near schools.

The activists said that stern action should be taken against individuals causing noise pollution, especially near educational institutions and hospitals. Parents, too, said that restricting loudspeakers will help students prepare better without any disturbance.

Title: 1L from city to join trade unions strike
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

Aurangabad: Around 1 lakh private and public sector employees in Aurangabad district will participate in the strike called by the trade unions and employees’ federations on January 8.

The protest is against privatisation by government and ‘anti-labour’ policies of the central government.

A rally from Kranti Chowk to divisional commissioner’s office will be taken out at 11am on Wednesday. The rally is expected to witness participation from 40,000 workers, the organisers said.

Udhhav Bhawalkar, organiser of Centre of Indian Trade Unions (Citu) joint action committee said that a decision to hold nationwide bandh on January 8 was also taken in the Citu’s meeting in Delhi on September 30. Later, the country’s 208 farmer bodies decided to support the bandh which would cover rural India. “Last year too, we held a bandh on January 8,” he said.

The union representatives said that the reduction of inflation, increase in employment and implementation of labour-friendly policies will be the key demands

Title: Karnataka’s revenue collection second highest in the country: BS Yediyurappa
Content:
This story is from January 7, 2020

A delegation of Valmiki community leaders met CM BS Yediyurappa on Monday, to press for an increase in reserva... Read More

BENGALURU: Amid fears that the state might miss revenue targets for this fiscal due to the economic slowdown, chief minister BS Yediyurappa on Monday said Karnataka stood second in the country in collection of goods & services tax.

“Till December end, the state collected Rs 61,245 crore through GST (which includes states GST) which is 14.2% more than previous year and the second highest among states,” Yediyurappa said.

He was speaking after chairing a meeting of officials of revenue generating departments — excise, commercial tax, transport, stamps and registration and mines — on Monday as part of preparations for the state budget.

Figures released by the government show that barring transport, the other departments have clocked an average 72% revenue collection of targets. But with just three months remaining for the current fiscal to end, officials fear a sizeable shortfall.

The transport department has mopped up Rs 4,864 crore as against a target of Rs 7,100 crore. “This is mainly because of the fall in vehicle sales,” the CM said. Yediyurappa acknowledged fears of a revenue shortfall, but instructed officials to work harder than ever.

“The focus for the next three months should be on collecting more tax by way of identifying tax evaders and plugging leaks,” he said.
